58492_11_ITEM14_P15_S0	A Summary of Significant Accounting Policies PRINCIPLES OF CONSOLIDATION:
58492_11_ITEM14_P16_S0	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of Leggett Platt, Incorporated and its majority-owned subsidiaries ( we or our ).
58492_11_ITEM14_P17_S0	Prior to 2010, many subsidiaries outside of the United States were consolidated as of and for a fiscal year ended November 30.
58492_11_ITEM14_P17_S1	As of December 31, 2010, these subsidiaries converted to a calendar reporting year.
58492_11_ITEM14_P17_S2	The net impact of the change in fiscal years of these subsidiaries was immaterial, and is presented as an adjustment to January 1, 2010 retained earnings.
58492_11_ITEM14_P17_S3	Management does not expect foreign exchange restrictions to significantly impact the ultimate realization of amounts consolidated in the accompanying financial statements for subsidiaries located outside the United States.
58492_11_ITEM14_P18_S0	All intercompany transactions and accounts have been eliminated in consolidation.
58492_11_ITEM14_P19_S0	ESTIMATES: The preparation of financial statements in conformity with generally accepted accounting principles requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses and the disclosure of contingencies.
58492_11_ITEM14_P19_S1	Actual results could differ from those estimates.
58492_11_ITEM14_P20_S0	CASH EQUIVALENTS: Cash equivalents include cash in excess of daily requirements which is invested in various financial instruments with original maturities of three months or less.
58492_11_ITEM14_P20_S1	ACCOUNTS AND OTHER RECEIVABLES AND ALLOWANCE FOR DOUBTFUL ACCOUNTS: Trade accounts receivable are recorded at the invoiced amount and generally do not bear interest.
58492_11_ITEM14_P20_S2	Credit is also occasionally extended in the form of a trade note receivable to facilitate our customers operating cycles.
58492_11_ITEM14_P20_S3	Nontrade notes receivable are established in special circumstances, such as in partial payment for the sale of a business.
58492_11_ITEM14_P20_S4	Notes receivable generally bear interest at market rates commensurate with the corresponding credit risk on the date of origination.
58492_11_ITEM14_P21_S0	The allowance for doubtful accounts is an estimate of the amount of probable credit losses.
58492_11_ITEM14_P21_S1	Interest income is not recognized for accounts that are placed on nonaccrual status.
58492_11_ITEM14_P22_S0	Allowances and nonaccrual status designations are determined by individual account reviews by management, and are based on several factors such as the length of time that receivables are past due, the financial health of the companies involved, industry and macroeconomic considerations, and historical loss experience.
58492_11_ITEM14_P23_S0	Interest income is recorded on the date of cash receipt for nonaccrual status accounts.
58492_11_ITEM14_P23_S1	Account balances are charged off against the allowance when it is probable the receivable will not be recovered.
58492_11_ITEM14_P24_S0	All inventories are stated at the lower of cost or market.
58492_11_ITEM14_P24_S1	We generally use standard costs which include materials, labor and production overhead at normal production capacity.
58492_11_ITEM14_P24_S2	The cost for approximately 60% of our inventories is determined by the last-in, first-out (LIFO) method and is primarily used to value domestic inventories with raw material content consisting of steel, wire, chemicals and foam scrap.
58492_11_ITEM14_P24_S3	For the remainder of the inventories, we principally use the first-in, first-out (FIFO) method, which is representative of our standard costs.
58492_11_ITEM14_P24_S4	For these inventories, the FIFO cost at December 31, 2010 and 2009 approximated expected replacement cost.
58492_11_ITEM14_P25_S0	Inventories are reviewed at least quarterly for slow-moving and potentially obsolete items using actual inventory turnover, and if necessary, are written down to estimated net realizable value.
58492_11_ITEM14_P25_S1	Reserves for slow-moving and obsolete inventory on a FIFO basis were as follows: DIVESTITURES:
58492_11_ITEM14_P25_S2	A business is classified as a discontinued operation when (i) the operations and cash flows of the business can be clearly distinguished and have been or will be eliminated from our ongoing operations; (ii) the business has either been disposed of or is classified as held for sale; and (iii) we will not have any significant continuing involvement in the operations of the business after the disposal transactions.
58492_11_ITEM14_P25_S3	Significant judgments are involved in determining whether a business meets the criteria for discontinued operations reporting and the period in which these criteria are met.
58492_11_ITEM14_P25_S4	If a business is reported as a discontinued operation, the results of operations through the date of sale, including any gain or loss recognized on the disposition, are presented on a separate line of the income statement.
58492_11_ITEM14_P25_S5	Interest on debt directly attributable to the discontinued operation is allocated to discontinued operations.
58492_11_ITEM14_P25_S6	Gains and losses related to the sale of businesses that do not meet the discontinued operation criteria are reported in continuing operations and separately disclosed if significant.
58492_11_ITEM14_P26_S0	Assets Held for Sale An asset or business is classified as held for sale when (i) management commits to a plan to sell and it is actively marketed; (ii) it is available for immediate sale and the sale is expected to be completed within one year; and (iii) it is unlikely significant changes to the plan will be made or that the plan will be withdrawn.
58492_11_ITEM14_P26_S1	In isolated instances, assets held for sale may exceed one year due to events or circumstances beyond our control.
58492_11_ITEM14_P27_S0	Upon being classified as held for sale, the recoverability of the carrying value must be assessed.
58492_11_ITEM14_P27_S1	Evaluating the recoverability of the assets of a business classified as held for sale follows a defined order in which property and intangible assets subject to amortization are considered only after the recoverability of goodwill and other assets are assessed.
58492_11_ITEM14_P27_S2	After the valuation process is completed, the assets held for sale are reported at the lower of the carrying value or fair value less cost to sell, and the assets are no longer depreciated or amortized.
58492_11_ITEM14_P27_S3	An impairment charge is recognized if the carrying value exceeds the fair value.
58492_11_ITEM14_P28_S0	The assets and related liabilities are aggregated and reported on separate lines of the balance sheet.
58492_11_ITEM14_P29_S0	If a decision to dispose of an asset or a business is made and the held for sale criteria are not met, it is considered held for use.
58492_11_ITEM14_P30_S0	Assets of the business are evaluated for recoverability in the following order: (i) assets other than goodwill, property and intangibles; (ii) property and intangibles subject to amortization; and (iii) goodwill.
58492_11_ITEM14_P31_S0	In evaluating the recoverability of property and intangible assets subject to amortization, in a held for use business, the carrying value is first compared to the sum of the undiscounted cash flows expected to result from the use and eventual disposition.
58492_11_ITEM14_P31_S1	If the carrying value exceeds the undiscounted expected cash flows, then a fair value analysis is performed.
58492_11_ITEM14_P31_S2	An impairment charge is recognized if the carrying value exceeds the fair value.
58492_11_ITEM14_P32_S0	PROPERTY, PLANT AND EQUIPMENT: Property, plant and equipment is stated at cost, less accumulated depreciation.
58492_11_ITEM14_P32_S1	Assets are depreciated by the straight-line method and salvage value, if any, is assumed to be minimal.
58492_11_ITEM14_P33_S0	The table below presents the depreciation periods of the estimated useful lives of our property, plant and equipment.
58492_11_ITEM14_P34_S0	Accelerated methods are used for tax purposes.
58492_11_ITEM14_P35_S0	Property is tested for recoverability at year end and whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that its carrying value may not be recoverable as discussed above.
58492_11_ITEM14_P35_S1	Goodwill results from the acquisition of existing businesses and is not amortized; it is assessed for impairment annually and as triggering events may occur.
58492_11_ITEM14_P35_S2	We perform our annual review in the second quarter of each year.
58492_11_ITEM14_P36_S0	Recoverability of goodwill is evaluated using a two-step process.
58492_11_ITEM14_P37_S0	The first step involves a comparison of the fair value of a reporting unit with its carrying value.
58492_11_ITEM14_P38_S0	Reporting units are business groups one level below the operating segment level for which discrete financial information is available and reviewed by segment management.
58492_11_ITEM14_P39_S0	If the carrying value of the group exceeds its fair value, the second step of the process is necessary and involves a comparison of the implied fair value and the carrying value of the goodwill of that group.
58492_11_ITEM14_P39_S1	If the carrying value of the goodwill of a group exceeds the implied fair value of that goodwill, an impairment loss is recognized in an amount equal to the excess.
58492_11_ITEM14_P40_S0	In evaluating the recoverability of goodwill, it is necessary to estimate the fair values of the business groups.
58492_11_ITEM14_P40_S1	In making this assessment, we estimate the fair market values of our reporting units using a discounted cash flow model and comparable market values for similar entities using price to earnings ratios.
58492_11_ITEM14_P40_S2	Key assumptions and estimates used in the cash flow model include discount rate, internal sales growth, margins, capital expenditure requirements, and working capital requirements.
58492_11_ITEM14_P40_S3	Recent performance of the group is an important factor, but not the only factor, in our assessment.
58492_11_ITEM14_P41_S0	There are inherent assumptions and judgments required in the analysis of goodwill impairment.
58492_11_ITEM14_P41_S1	It is possible that assumptions underlying the impairment analysis will change in such a manner that impairment in value may occur in the future.
58492_11_ITEM14_P41_S2	Substantially all other intangible assets are amortized using the straight-line method over their estimated useful lives ranging from 1 to 40 years with a weighted average of 15 years and are evaluated for impairment using a process similar to that used in evaluating the recoverability of property, plant and equipment.
58492_11_ITEM14_P42_S0	The cost of employee services received in exchange for all equity awards granted is based on the fair market value of the award as of the grant date.
58492_11_ITEM14_P42_S1	Expense is recognized net of an estimated forfeiture rate using the straight line method over the vesting period of the award.
58492_11_ITEM14_P43_S0	We recognize sales when title and risk of loss pass to the customer.
58492_11_ITEM14_P43_S1	The terms of our sales are split approximately evenly between FOB shipping point and FOB destination.
58492_11_ITEM14_P43_S2	The timing of our recognition of FOB destination sales is determined based on shipping date and distance to the destination.
58492_11_ITEM14_P43_S3	We have no significant or unusual price protection, right of return or acceptance provisions with our customers nor is it our practice to replace goods damaged or lost in transit.
58492_11_ITEM14_P44_S0	Sales allowances, discounts and rebates can be reasonably estimated throughout the period and are deducted from sales in arriving at net sales.
58492_11_ITEM14_P45_S0	SHIPPING AND HANDLING FEES AND COSTS: Shipping and handling costs are included as a component of Cost of goods sold.
58492_11_ITEM14_P46_S0	RESTRUCTURING COSTS: Restructuring costs are items such as employee termination, contract termination, plant closure and asset relocation costs related to exit activities.
58492_11_ITEM14_P46_S1	Restructuring-related items are inventory writedowns and gains or losses from sales of assets recorded as the result of exit activities.
58492_11_ITEM14_P47_S0	We recognize a liability for costs associated with an exit or disposal activity when the liability is incurred.
58492_11_ITEM14_P48_S0	Certain termination benefits for which employees are required to render service are recognized ratably over the respective future service periods.
58492_11_ITEM14_P49_S0	The provision for income taxes is determined using the asset and liability approach of accounting for income taxes.
58492_11_ITEM14_P49_S1	Under this approach, deferred taxes represent the future tax consequences expected to occur when the reported amounts of assets and liabilities are recovered or paid.
58492_11_ITEM14_P50_S0	The provision for income taxes represents income taxes paid or payable for the current year plus the change in deferred taxes during the year.
58492_11_ITEM14_P50_S1	Deferred taxes result from differences between the financial and tax basis of our assets and liabilities and are adjusted for changes in tax rates and laws, as appropriate.
58492_11_ITEM14_P50_S2	A valuation allowance is provided to reduce deferred tax assets when management cannot conclude that it is more likely than not that a tax benefit will be realized.
58492_11_ITEM14_P51_S0	A provision is also made for incremental taxes on undistributed earnings of foreign subsidiaries and related companies to the extent that such earnings are not deemed to be indefinitely invested.
58492_11_ITEM14_P52_S0	The calculation of our U.S., state, and foreign tax liabilities involves dealing with uncertainties in the application of complex global tax laws.
58492_11_ITEM14_P52_S1	We recognize potential liabilities for anticipated tax issues which might arise in the U.S. and other tax jurisdictions based on management s estimate of whether, and the extent to which, additional taxes will be due.
58492_11_ITEM14_P52_S2	If payment of these amounts ultimately proves to be unnecessary, the reversal of the liabilities would result in tax benefits being recognized in the period when we determine the liabilities are no longer necessary.
58492_11_ITEM14_P52_S3	Conversely, if the estimate of tax liabilities proves to be less than the ultimate tax assessment, a further charge to tax expense would result.
58492_11_ITEM14_P53_S0	CONCENTRATION OF CREDIT RISKS, EXPOSURES AND FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS: We manufacture, market, and distribute engineered products for the various end markets described in Note F. Operations are principally located in the United States, although we also have operations in Asia, Europe, Canada and Latin America.
58492_11_ITEM14_P53_S1	We maintain allowances for potential credit losses.
58492_11_ITEM14_P53_S2	We perform ongoing credit evaluations of our customers financial conditions and generally require no collateral from our customers, some of which are highly leveraged.
58492_11_ITEM14_P53_S3	Management also monitors the financial condition and status of noncustomer receivables.
58492_11_ITEM14_P54_S0	Noncustomer receivables primarily consist of notes accepted as partial payment for the divestiture of a business.
58492_11_ITEM14_P54_S1	Some of these companies are highly leveraged and the notes are not fully collateralized.
58492_11_ITEM14_P55_S0	We have no material guarantees or liabilities for product warranties which require disclosure.
58492_11_ITEM14_P55_S1	From time to time, we will enter into contracts to hedge foreign currency denominated transactions, natural gas purchases, and interest rates related to our debt.
58492_11_ITEM14_P56_S0	To minimize the risk of counterparty default, only highly-rated financial institutions that meet certain requirements are used.
58492_11_ITEM14_P56_S1	We do not anticipate that any of the financial institution counterparties will default on their obligations.
58492_11_ITEM14_P57_S0	The carrying value of cash and short-term financial instruments approximates fair value due to the short maturity of those instruments.
58492_11_ITEM14_P58_S0	Although we obtain insurance for workers compensation, automobile, product and general liability, property loss and medical claims, we have elected to retain a significant portion of expected losses through the use of deductibles.
58492_11_ITEM14_P58_S1	Accrued liabilities include estimates for unpaid reported claims and for claims incurred but not yet reported.
58492_11_ITEM14_P58_S2	Provisions for losses are recorded based upon estimates of the aggregate liability for claims incurred utilizing our prior experience and information provided by our third-party administrators and insurance carriers.
58492_11_ITEM14_P59_S0	DERIVATIVE FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS: We utilize derivative financial instruments to manage market and financial risks related to interest rates, foreign currency and commodities.
58492_11_ITEM14_P59_S1	We seek to use derivative contracts that qualify for hedge accounting treatment; however some instruments that economically manage currency risk may not qualify for hedge accounting treatment.
58492_11_ITEM14_P59_S2	It is our policy not to speculate using derivative instruments.
58492_11_ITEM14_P59_S3	Under hedge accounting, we formally document our hedge relationships, including identification of the hedging instruments and the hedged items, as well as our risk management objectives and strategies for entering into the hedge transaction.
58492_11_ITEM14_P59_S4	The process includes designating derivative instruments as hedges of specific assets, liabilities, firm commitments or forecasted transactions.
58492_11_ITEM14_P59_S5	We also formally assess both at inception and on a quarterly basis thereafter, whether the derivatives used in hedging transactions are highly effective in offsetting changes in either the fair value or cash flows of the hedged item.
58492_11_ITEM14_P59_S6	If it is determined that a derivative ceases to be highly effective, deferred gains or losses are recorded in the Consolidated Statements of Operations.
58492_11_ITEM14_P59_S7	Derivatives are recorded in the Consolidated Balance Sheets at fair value in Other current or Sundry assets or Other current or Other long-term liabilities.
58492_11_ITEM14_P60_S0	The hedge of a forecasted transaction or of the variability of cash flows to be received or paid related to a recognized asset or liability or anticipated transaction is designated as a cash flow hedge.
58492_11_ITEM14_P60_S1	The effective portion of the change in fair value of a cash flow hedge is recorded in accumulated other comprehensive income.
58492_11_ITEM14_P60_S2	When the hedged item impacts the income statement, the gain or loss included in other comprehensive income is reported on the same line of the Consolidated Statements of Operations as the hedged item to match the gain or loss on the derivative to the gain or loss on the hedged item.
58492_11_ITEM14_P60_S3	Any ineffective portion of the changes in the fair value of the cash flow hedge is immediately reported in the Consolidated Statements of Operations on the same line as the hedged item.
58492_11_ITEM14_P61_S0	Cash flow hedges are presented as operating cash flows when the contracts are settled.
58492_11_ITEM14_P62_S0	The hedge of a recognized asset or liability or an unrecognized firm commitment is designated as a fair value hedge.
58492_11_ITEM14_P62_S1	For fair value hedges, both the effective and ineffective portions of the changes in fair value of the derivative, along with the gain or loss on the hedged item that is attributable to the hedged risk, are recorded in earnings and reported in the Consolidated Statements of Operations on the same line as the hedged item.
58492_11_ITEM14_P63_S0	Fair value hedges are presented as operating cash flows when the contracts are settled.
58492_11_ITEM14_P64_S0	The hedge of a net investment in a foreign operation is designated as a net investment hedge.
58492_11_ITEM14_P64_S1	The effective portion of the change in the fair value of derivatives, based upon spot rates, used as a net investment hedge of a foreign operation is recorded in other comprehensive income on the Consolidated Statements of Changes in Equity.
58492_11_ITEM14_P64_S2	Any ineffective portion of the change in the fair value of an instrument designated as a net investment hedge is recorded as Other (income) expense, net in the Consolidated Statements of Operations.
58492_11_ITEM14_P65_S0	Net investment hedges are presented as investing cash flows when the contracts are settled.
58492_11_ITEM14_P66_S0	The functional currency for most foreign operations is the local currency.
58492_11_ITEM14_P66_S1	The translation of foreign currencies into U.S. dollars is performed for balance sheet accounts using current exchange rates in effect at the balance sheet date and for income and expense accounts using monthly average exchange rates.
58492_11_ITEM14_P66_S2	The cumulative effects of translating the functional currencies into the U.S. dollar are included in comprehensive income.

58492_11_ITEM14_P86_S0	C Impairment Charges Goodwill Goodwill is required to be tested for impairment at least once a year or as triggering events may occur.
58492_11_ITEM14_P87_S0	We perform our annual goodwill impairment review in June of each year as discussed in Note A. Fair value of reporting units is determined using a combination of two valuation methods: a market approach and an income approach with each method given equal weight in determining the fair value assigned to each reporting unit.
58492_11_ITEM14_P87_S1	Absent an indication of fair value from a potential buyer or similar specific transaction, we believe that the use of these two methods provides a reasonable estimate of a reporting unit s fair value.
58492_11_ITEM14_P87_S2	Assumptions common to both methods are operating plans and economic projections, which are used to project future revenues, earnings, and after tax cash flows for each reporting unit.
58492_11_ITEM14_P87_S3	These assumptions are applied consistently for both methods.
58492_11_ITEM14_P88_S0	The market approach estimates fair value by first determining price to earnings ratios for comparable publicly-traded companies with similar characteristics of the reporting unit.
58492_11_ITEM14_P89_S0	comparable companies is based upon current enterprise value compared to projected earnings for the next two years.
58492_11_ITEM14_P89_S1	The enterprise value is based upon current market capitalization and includes a 25% control premium.
58492_11_ITEM14_P89_S2	Projected earnings are based upon market analysts projections.
58492_11_ITEM14_P89_S3	The earnings ratios are applied to the projected earnings of the comparable reporting unit to estimate fair value.
58492_11_ITEM14_P89_S4	Management believes this approach is appropriate because it provides a fair value estimate using multiples from entities with operations and economic characteristics comparable to our reporting units.
58492_11_ITEM14_P90_S0	The income approach is based on projected future (debt-free) cash flow that is discounted to present value using factors that consider the timing and risk of future cash flows.
58492_11_ITEM14_P90_S1	Management believes that this approach is appropriate because it provides a fair value estimate based upon the reporting unit s expected long-term operating cash flow performance.
58492_11_ITEM14_P91_S0	Discounted cash flow projections are based on 10-year financial forecasts developed from operating plans and economic projections noted above, growth rates, estimates of future expected changes in operating margins, terminal value growth rates, future capital expenditures and changes in working capital requirements.
58492_11_ITEM14_P91_S1	The goodwill impairment reviews performed in June 2010 and 2009 indicated no goodwill impairments, and there were no triggering events in either year that required additional goodwill reviews.
58492_11_ITEM14_P91_S2	Reporting units fair values in relation to their respective carrying values and significant assumptions used in these reviews are presented in the tables below.
58492_11_ITEM14_P91_S3	If actual results differ from estimates used in these calculations, we could incur future impairment charges.

58492_11_ITEM14_P111_S3	Separately, we also utilize a role-based approach (Grow, Core, Fix or Divest) as a supplemental management tool to ensure capital (which is a subset of the overall resources referred to above) is efficiently allocated within the reportable segment structure.

58492_11_ITEM14_P141_S0	The following table recaps the impact of stock-based compensation on the results of operations (including discontinued operations) for each of the years ended December 31: When the tax deduction for an exercised stock option or converted stock unit exceeds the compensation cost that has been recognized in income, a windfall tax benefit is created.
58492_11_ITEM14_P141_S1	The windfall benefit is not recognized in income, but rather on the balance sheet as additional contributed capital.
58492_11_ITEM14_P142_S0	When the current tax deduction for an exercised stock option or converted stock unit is less than the deferred tax asset recorded in regard to the compensation cost that has been recognized in income, a tax shortfall is created.
58492_11_ITEM14_P142_S1	To the extent we have accumulated tax windfalls the shortfall is recognized on the balance sheet as a reduction of additional contributed capital.
58492_11_ITEM14_P143_S0	Net windfall is presented below: (1) Stock Option Grants We have granted stock options in several areas as follows:
58492_11_ITEM14_P144_S0	As compensation of outside directors Options granted to a broad group of employees on a discretionary basis We grant stock options annually on a discretionary basis to a broad group of employees.
58492_11_ITEM14_P144_S1	Options generally become exercisable in one-third increments at 18 months, 30 months and 42 months after the date of grant.
58492_11_ITEM14_P144_S2	Options have a maximum term of ten years and the exercise prices are equal to Leggett s closing stock price on the grant date.
58492_11_ITEM14_P145_S0	A retirement termination occurs if the employee is age 65, or age 55 with 20 years of Company service at termination.
58492_11_ITEM14_P145_S1	For retirement terminations, options continue to vest and remain exercisable for 3 years and 6 months after termination of employment.
58492_11_ITEM14_P145_S2	Therefore, the expense for these options is accelerated when the employee is retirement eligible.
58492_11_ITEM14_P146_S0	Officers and directors receive stock option awards.
58492_11_ITEM14_P146_S1	Other employees participate in option choice programs.
58492_11_ITEM14_P146_S2	In connection with the January 2010 grant, we gave most participants the choice to receive stock options or to receive a cash payment in lieu of options.
58492_11_ITEM14_P146_S3	The value of the cash alternative (paid in the first quarter) was equal to approximately one-half of the Black Scholes value of the option grant the employee would have otherwise received.
58492_11_ITEM14_P147_S0	In January 2011, we offered two different option choice programs.
58492_11_ITEM14_P147_S1	One group of employees was offered the same option/cash choice as in 2010, with the cash alternative being equal to approximately one-half of the Black-Scholes value of the option grant foregone.
58492_11_ITEM14_P147_S2	Another group of employees, generally higher level employees, were offered a choice between stock options or restricted stock units (RSUs), on a ratio of four options foregone for every one offered.
58492_11_ITEM14_P147_S3	The stock units vest in one-third increments at 12 months, 24 months and 36 months after the date of grant.
58492_11_ITEM14_P148_S0	Deferred Compensation Program We offer a Deferred Compensation Program under which key managers and outside directors may elect to receive stock options, stock units or interest-bearing cash deferrals in lieu of cash compensation:
58492_11_ITEM14_P149_S0	Stock options under this program are granted on the last business day of the year prior to the year the compensation is earned.
58492_11_ITEM14_P149_S1	The number of options granted equals the deferred compensation times five, divided by the stock s market price on the date of grant.
58492_11_ITEM14_P149_S2	The option has a 10-year term.
58492_11_ITEM14_P149_S3	It vests as the associated compensation is earned and becomes exercisable beginning 15 months after the grant date.
58492_11_ITEM14_P150_S0	Stock is issued when the option is exercised.
58492_11_ITEM14_P151_S0	Deferred stock units (DSU) under this program are acquired every two weeks (when the compensation would have otherwise been paid) at a 20% discount to the market price of our common stock on the acquisition date and they vest immediately.
58492_11_ITEM14_P152_S0	Expense is recorded as the compensation is earned.
58492_11_ITEM14_P152_S1	Stock units earn dividends at the same rate as cash dividends paid on our common stock.
58492_11_ITEM14_P152_S2	These dividends are used to acquire stock units at a 20% discount.
58492_11_ITEM14_P152_S3	Stock units are converted to common stock and distributed in accordance with the participant s pre-set election.
58492_11_ITEM14_P152_S4	Beginning in 2010, stock units may be settled in cash at the discretion of the Company.
58492_11_ITEM14_P152_S5	Participants must begin receiving distributions no later than ten years after the effective date of the deferral and installment distributions cannot exceed ten years.
58492_11_ITEM14_P153_S0	Interest-bearing cash deferrals under this program are reported in Other long-term liabilities on the balance sheet and are disclosed in Note I.

58492_11_ITEM14_P160_S0	(2) Stock-Based Retirement Plans We have two stock-based retirement plans: the tax-qualified Stock Bonus Plan (SBP) for non-highly compensated employees, and the non-qualified Executive Stock Unit Program (ESUP) for highly compensated employees.
58492_11_ITEM14_P160_S1	We make matching contributions to both plans.
58492_11_ITEM14_P160_S2	In addition to the automatic 50% match, we will make another matching contribution of up to 50% of the employee s contributions for the year if certain profitability levels as defined in the SBP and the ESUP are obtained.
58492_11_ITEM14_P161_S0	Participants in the SBP may contribute up to 6% of their compensation above a certain threshold to purchase Leggett stock or other investment alternatives at market prices.
58492_11_ITEM14_P161_S1	We immediately match 50% of the employee contributions.
58492_11_ITEM14_P161_S2	Employees are allowed to fully diversify their employee deferral accounts immediately and their employer accounts after three years of service.
58492_11_ITEM14_P162_S0	Dividends earned on Company stock held in the SBP are reinvested or paid in cash at the participant s election.
58492_11_ITEM14_P163_S0	Participants in the ESUP may contribute up to 10% (depending upon salary level) of their compensation above the same threshold applicable to the SBP.
58492_11_ITEM14_P163_S1	We immediately match 50% of the employee contributions.
58492_11_ITEM14_P164_S0	Contributions to the ESUP, including dividend equivalents, are used to acquire stock units at 85% of the common stock market price on the acquisition date.
58492_11_ITEM14_P164_S1	Stock units are converted to common stock at a 1-to-1 ratio upon distribution from the program.
58492_11_ITEM14_P164_S2	Beginning in 2010, units from the ESUP may be settled in cash at the discretion of the Company.
58492_11_ITEM14_P164_S3	The ESUP offered no diversification opportunity for contributions through December 31, 2010.
58492_11_ITEM14_P164_S4	Beginning April 1, 2011, participant contributions will be credited to a diversified investment account established for the participant and we will make premium contributions to the diversified investment accounts equal to 17.65% of the participant s contribution.
58492_11_ITEM14_P164_S5	A participant s diversified investment account balance will be adjusted to mirror the investment experience, whether positive or negative, of the diversified investments selected by the participant.
58492_11_ITEM14_P164_S6	Participants may change investment elections in the diversified investment accounts, but cannot purchase Company common stock or stock units in these accounts.
58492_11_ITEM14_P164_S7	The diversified investment accounts will consist of various mutual funds and retirement target funds and will be settled in cash.
58492_11_ITEM14_P164_S8	Company matching contributions will be in the form of stock units.
58492_11_ITEM14_P164_S9	Company matches in the SBP and ESUP fully vest upon three and five years, respectively, of cumulative service, subject to certain participation requirements.
58492_11_ITEM14_P164_S10	Distributions under both plans are triggered by an employee s retirement, death, disability or separation from Leggett.

58492_11_ITEM14_P184_S0	Level 1: Quoted prices for identical assets or liabilities in active markets.
58492_11_ITEM14_P185_S0	Level 2: Other significant inputs observable either directly or indirectly (including quoted prices for similar securities, interest rates, yield curves, credit risk, etc.).
58492_11_ITEM14_P186_S0	Level 3: Unobservable inputs that are not corroborated by market data.

58492_11_ITEM14_P217_S0	Q Fair Value We utilize fair value measures for both financial and non-financial assets and liabilities.
58492_11_ITEM14_P217_S1	The primary areas in which we utilize fair value measures of non-financial assets and liabilities are allocating purchase price to the assets and liabilities of acquired companies as discussed in Note R and evaluating long-term assets for potential impairment as discussed in Notes B and C. The areas in which we utilize fair value measures of financial assets and liabilities are cash equivalents, short-term investments and derivatives hedging financial risks primarily related to interest rates, foreign currency, and commodities.
58492_11_ITEM14_P218_S0	Fair value measurements are established using a three level valuation hierarchy that prioritizes the inputs to valuation techniques used to measure fair value into the following categories:
58492_11_ITEM14_P219_S0	Level 1: Quoted prices for identical assets or liabilities in active markets.
58492_11_ITEM14_P220_S0	Level 2: Inputs other than quoted prices included in Level 1 that are observable for the asset or liability either directly or indirectly.
58492_11_ITEM14_P221_S0	flow techniques with all significant inputs derived from or corroborated by observable market data.
58492_11_ITEM14_P222_S0	Derivative assets and liabilities in this category are valued using models that consider various assumptions and information from market-corroborated sources.
58492_11_ITEM14_P222_S1	The models used are primarily industry-standard models that consider items such as quoted prices, market interest rate curves applicable to the instruments being valued as of the end of each period, discounted cash flows, volatility factors, current market and contractual prices for the underlying instruments, as well as other relevant economic measures.
58492_11_ITEM14_P222_S2	Substantially all of these assumptions are observable in the marketplace, can be derived from observable data or are supported by observable levels at which transactions are executed in the marketplace.
58492_11_ITEM14_P223_S0	Level 3: Unobservable inputs that are not corroborated by market data.
58492_11_ITEM14_P224_S0	The following tables present assets and liabilities that were accounted for at fair value on a recurring basis.
58492_11_ITEM14_P225_S0	The following table summarizes the estimated fair values of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed at the date of acquisition during the periods presented, and any additional consideration paid for prior years acquisitions: During 2010 we also increased our ownership portion to 100% in an automotive business that was previously not wholly owned for $8.6, of which $7.6 represented net cash consideration.

58492_11_ITEM14_P229_S0	S Derivative Financial Instruments Risk Management Strategy Objectives We are subject to market and financial risks related to interest rates, foreign currency, and commodities.
58492_11_ITEM14_P229_S1	In the normal course of business, we utilize derivative instruments (individually or in combinations) to manage these risks.
58492_11_ITEM14_P229_S2	We seek to use derivative contracts that qualify for hedge accounting treatment; however, some instruments may not qualify for hedge accounting treatment.
58492_11_ITEM14_P229_S3	It is our policy not to speculate using derivative instruments.
58492_11_ITEM14_P229_S4	As of December 31, 2010 and 2009, we have recorded the following assets and liabilities representing the fair value for our most significant derivative financial instruments.
58492_11_ITEM14_P229_S5	The fair values of the derivatives reflect the change in the market value of the derivative from the date of the trade execution, and do not consider the offsetting underlying hedged item.
58492_11_ITEM14_P230_S0	Cash Flow Hedges At December 31, 2010 and 2009, we had outstanding derivative financial instruments that hedge forecasted transactions and anticipated cash flows.
58492_11_ITEM14_P231_S0	The effective changes in fair value of unexpired contracts are recorded in accumulated other comprehensive income and reclassified to income or expense in the period in which earnings are impacted and are presented as operating cash flows when the contracts are settled.
58492_11_ITEM14_P232_S0	The commodity cash flow hedges manage natural gas commodity price risk.
58492_11_ITEM14_P232_S1	All commodity hedges at December 31, 2010 had maturities of less than three years.
58492_11_ITEM14_P232_S2	We routinely hedge commodity price risk up to 36 months.
58492_11_ITEM14_P233_S0	The foreign currency hedges manage risk associated with exchange rate volatility of various currencies.
58492_11_ITEM14_P233_S1	The foreign currency cash flow hedges outstanding at December 31, 2010 had maturity dates within one year.
58492_11_ITEM14_P233_S2	In general, foreign currency cash flow hedges have maturities within two years.
58492_11_ITEM14_P234_S0	In anticipation of long-term debt maturing in April 2013, we entered into forward starting interest swaps in 2010.
58492_11_ITEM14_P234_S1	The swap contracts manage benchmark interest rate risk associated with $200 of planned debt issuance in August 2012.
58492_11_ITEM14_P234_S2	The swaps have a weighted average interest rate of 4.0% and hedge the benchmark rate of an expected issuance of $200 of debt.
58492_11_ITEM14_P234_S3	The credit spread over the benchmark bonds will continue to fluctuate until the time of issuance.
58492_11_ITEM14_P235_S0	Our fair value hedges manage foreign currency risk associated with subsidiaries inter-company assets and liabilities.
58492_11_ITEM14_P235_S1	Hedges designated as fair value hedges recognize gain or loss currently in earnings and are presented as operating cash flows when the contracts are settled.
58492_11_ITEM14_P235_S2	These fair value hedges generally have a maturity date within one year.
58492_11_ITEM14_P236_S0	We had no net investment hedge activity in 2010 or 2009.
58492_11_ITEM14_P236_S1	In September 2008, we liquidated a $30.0 net investment hedge of a Swiss subsidiary.
58492_11_ITEM14_P236_S2	The liquidation had a cash cost of $4.4, which is presented as an investing cash flow in our Statement of Cash Flows.
58492_11_ITEM14_P236_S3	We have deemed all ineffectiveness to be immaterial, and as a result, have not recorded any amounts for ineffectiveness.
58492_11_ITEM14_P236_S4	If a hedge was not highly effective, the portion of the change in fair value considered to be ineffective would be recognized immediately in the consolidated condensed statements of operations.
58492_11_ITEM14_P237_S0	Derivatives Not Qualifying for Hedge Accounting Treatment At December 31, 2010 and 2009, we had one derivative transaction that did not qualify for hedge accounting treatment.
58492_11_ITEM14_P237_S1	Gains or losses on this transaction are recorded directly to income and expense in the period impacted, and offset the majority of gains and losses on the underlying Euro inter-company debt.

58492_11_ITEM14_P240_S0	NPI Lawsuit On January 18, 2008, National Products, Inc. ( NPI ) sued Gamber-Johnson, LLC ( Gamber ), a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Company, in Case C08-0049C-JLR, in the United States District Court, Western District of Washington, alleging that portions of a Gamber marketing video contained false and misleading statements.
58492_11_ITEM14_P240_S1	NPI and Gamber compete in the market for vehicle computer mounting systems.
58492_11_ITEM14_P240_S2	NPI sought: (a) injunctive relief requiring Gamber to stop using the video and to notify customers; (b) damages for its alleged lost profits; and (c) disgorgement of Gamber s profits in an unspecified amount.
58492_11_ITEM14_P240_S3	Although part of the claims were dismissed by the Court before and during trial, a jury, on April 12, 2010, found four statements in the video were false and deliberate and awarded $10 in disgorgement damages against Gamber.
58492_11_ITEM14_P240_S4	On August 16, the Court: (a) reduced the jury verdict to approximately $0.5; (b) granted NPI attorney fees and costs in an amount to be determined; and (c) granted an injunction requiring Gamber to notify its distributors and resellers of the verdict.
58492_11_ITEM14_P240_S5	The Court subsequently awarded NPI $2.0 in attorney s fees and costs.
58492_11_ITEM14_P241_S0	We believe that Gamber has valid bases upon which the appellate court could overturn the verdict and the award of attorney fees and costs.
58492_11_ITEM14_P241_S1	We intend to vigorously pursue an appeal.
58492_11_ITEM14_P241_S2	NPI has also filed an appeal.
58492_11_ITEM14_P242_S0	We established an accrual for this suit in an amount we believe is probable.
58492_11_ITEM14_P242_S1	Also, we believe that it is probable that at least part of the verdict, attorney s fees and costs will be covered by insurance, but that coverage is subject to the insurance company s reservation of rights.

58492_11_ITEM14_P248_S0	In the suits to which the Company is a party, the plaintiffs, on behalf of the class of purchasers, seek three times the amount of unspecified damages allegedly suffered as a result of alleged overcharges in the price of polyurethane foam products during the period 1979 to the present in one case, and from at least 2001 to the present in the other five cases.

58492_11_ITEM14_P268_S1	2.13 L P Cash Deferral .
58492_11_ITEM14_P268_S2	The deferral of Compensation into an obligation of the Company to pay on a future date or dates the Compensation plus interest thereon determined pursuant to Section 5.4.
58492_11_ITEM14_P268_S3	An option to purchase shares of Common Stock issued pursuant to Section 4. 2.15 Participant .
58492_11_ITEM14_P269_S0	A director of the Company, a Section 16 Officer of the Company, or a management or highly compensated employee of the Employer selected by the Committee, who has delivered a signed Election form to the Company.
58492_11_ITEM14_P269_S1	The Committee may revoke an individual s right to participate in the Program if he no longer meets the Program s eligibility requirements or for any other reason.
58492_11_ITEM14_P269_S2	Such termination will not affect Benefits previously vested under the Program.

58492_11_ITEM14_P271_S1	No Participant or Beneficiary will have any of the rights of a shareholder with respect to Stock Units.
58492_11_ITEM14_P272_S0	A severe financial hardship to the Participant resulting from an illness or accident of the Participant, the Participant s spouse, or a dependent of the Participant, loss of the Participant s property due to casualty, or other similar extraordinary and unforeseeable circumstances arising as a result of events beyond the control of the Participant.
58492_11_ITEM14_P273_S0	3. ELECTION TO DEFER 3.1 Type and Amount of Deferral .
58492_11_ITEM14_P274_S0	Each Participant may elect to defer all or a portion of his Compensation into an Option, Stock Units, an L P Cash Deferral, or any combination of the three.
58492_11_ITEM14_P274_S1	A Participant s Election must be made on or before the last business day of December for Compensation relating to the following calendar year, except that newly eligible Participants may make an Election during the calendar year within 30 days of first becoming eligible for participation for Compensation earned subsequent to the date of Election.
58492_11_ITEM14_P274_S2	Elections may be modified or withdrawn until such time as an original Election could no longer be made.
58492_11_ITEM14_P274_S3	The Committee may provide for Elections at any other times with respect to all or any part of Compensation or Contributions to the extent that such Elections are consistent with the requirements of Section 409A. 3.3 Benefit Plan Contributions and Payroll Deductions .
58492_11_ITEM14_P275_S0	If Compensation payable after giving effect to a deferral Election will be insufficient to make all Company benefit contributions and required tax withholdings, the Participant must, at the time of the Election, make arrangements suitable to the Company for the payment of such amounts.
58492_11_ITEM14_P275_S1	Benefits under the Program vest when the Participant would have been vested in the Compensation but for the election to defer.
58492_11_ITEM14_P275_S2	Benefits not vested will terminate immediately upon a Participant s termination of employment or, with respect to non-employee directors, termination of service.
58492_11_ITEM14_P276_S0	4.1 Number of Options and Exercise Price .
58492_11_ITEM14_P276_S1	Unless the Committee determines otherwise, the number of Option shares granted to a Participant is equal to the nearest number of whole shares determined under the following formula:
58492_11_ITEM14_P277_S0	Compensation Foregone means the Compensation the Participant elected to defer into Options.
58492_11_ITEM14_P278_S0	The Exercise Price for each share covered by an Option is the fair market value of Company stock on the Grant Date.
58492_11_ITEM14_P278_S1	Options will be granted as of the last business day in December of each year or such other date as the Committee determines (the Grant Date ).
58492_11_ITEM14_P278_S2	The term of an Option will expire 10 years after the Grant Date (the Expiration Date ).
58492_11_ITEM14_P279_S0	Options will be exercisable on March 15 th of the year following the year the compensation is earned and vested.
58492_11_ITEM14_P279_S1	However, despite any later specified date for exercise, any vested portion of an Option will become exercisable in full upon the death or Disability of the Participant.
58492_11_ITEM14_P280_S0	An Option may be exercised by delivering notice to the Company s captive broker accompanied by payment of the Exercise Price for the shares purchased.
58492_11_ITEM14_P280_S1	Such payment may be made in cash, by delivering or attesting to ownership of shares of L P Common Stock or a combination of cash and Common Stock.
58492_11_ITEM14_P280_S2	No shares will be delivered in connection with an Option exercise unless all amounts required to satisfy tax and any other required withholdings have been paid.
58492_11_ITEM14_P281_S0	An Option may be exercised only by a Participant during his life or, in the case of Disability, by his guardian or legal representative.
58492_11_ITEM14_P281_S1	Upon the death of a Participant, the Option may be exercised by his Beneficiary or, if the Participant fails to designate a Beneficiary, by his legal representative.
58492_11_ITEM14_P281_S2	If any Option has not been fully exercised on the Expiration Date, the unexercised portion of the Option shall be deemed exercised on such Expiration Date, provided the then market price of a share of L P Common Stock exceeds the per share Exercise Price.
58492_11_ITEM14_P281_S3	In such event, shares of Common Stock will not be issued until the Exercise Price and any other required amounts have been paid.
58492_11_ITEM14_P281_S4	If the Company has not received payment of the Exercise Price and any other required amounts within 30 days after the Expiration Date, the exercise will be void and the Company will have no further obligation to the Participant with respect to the expired Option.
58492_11_ITEM14_P281_S5	Although the Company intends to settle the Option exercise in stock, notwithstanding any other provision of the Program, the Company reserves the right to settle the Option exercise in cash in lieu of shares of Common Stock.
58492_11_ITEM14_P281_S6	If settled in cash, the amount of the payment will be equal to the Fair Market Value (as defined in the Company s Flexible Stock Plan) of the number of shares of Common Stock that would otherwise be issued upon Option exercise.
58492_11_ITEM14_P281_S7	Fair Market Value shall be determined at the date of exercise, in the same manner as if the exercise would have been settled in shares of Common Stock.
58492_11_ITEM14_P282_S0	All Options will be non-qualified options that are not entitled to special tax treatment under 422 of the Internal Revenue Code.
58492_11_ITEM14_P283_S0	A Participant will have no rights as a shareholder with respect to the shares covered by his Option until stock has been issued for the shares.
58492_11_ITEM14_P283_S1	No adjustment will be made for dividends or other rights for which the record date is before the issuance date.
58492_11_ITEM14_P284_S0	STOCK UNIT AND L P CASH DEFERRALS 5.1 Stock Units .
58492_11_ITEM14_P284_S1	An account will be established to track Stock Units for each Participant who elects a Stock Unit deferral.
58492_11_ITEM14_P284_S2	Compensation will be deferred on a bi-weekly basis or as Compensation otherwise would have been paid, unless the Committee determines otherwise.
58492_11_ITEM14_P285_S0	All deferrals and Dividend Contributions to a Participant s account will be used to acquire Stock Units at a price equal to 80% of the fair market value of a share of Common Stock on the date such deferrals and Dividend Contributions are made.
58492_11_ITEM14_P285_S1	On the date a cash dividend is paid on Common Stock, the Company will make a Dividend Contribution equal to the per share cash dividend on the number of Stock Units credited to the Participant s account on the dividend record date.
58492_11_ITEM14_P285_S2	Prior to distribution, Stock Units will be converted to the appropriate number of whole shares of Common Stock.
58492_11_ITEM14_P285_S3	The Company will make the distributions by January 31 st of the elected distribution year.
58492_11_ITEM14_P286_S0	For installment elections, each annual distribution will be equal to the balance of Stock Units in the Participant s account divided by the number of payments remaining.
58492_11_ITEM14_P286_S1	The Company will withhold from the shares distributed any amount required to pay applicable taxes (at the Company s required withholding rate).
58492_11_ITEM14_P286_S2	Alternatively, the Participant may pay such taxes in cash if he elects to do so before the distribution date.
58492_11_ITEM14_P286_S3	The Company may, at any time, require a Participant to settle the tax liability in cash.
58492_11_ITEM14_P286_S4	Although the Company intends to settle Participants accounts in stock, notwithstanding any other provision of the Program, the Company reserves the right to pay Stock Units in cash in lieu of shares of Common Stock.
58492_11_ITEM14_P286_S5	If settled in cash, the amount of the distribution will be equal to the Fair Market Value (as defined in the Company s Flexible Stock Plan) of the number of shares of Common Stock that would otherwise be issued.
58492_11_ITEM14_P286_S6	Fair Market Value shall be determined at the date the shares would otherwise have been issued.
58492_11_ITEM14_P286_S7	5.4 Interest on L P Cash Deferral .
58492_11_ITEM14_P286_S8	L P Cash Deferrals will bear interest at a rate established by the Committee.
58492_11_ITEM14_P286_S9	The interest will begin accruing on the date the Deferred Compensation would have been paid but for the deferral.
58492_11_ITEM14_P286_S10	Until the Committee determines otherwise, the Chief Financial Officer will determine the interest rates.
58492_11_ITEM14_P287_S0	5.5 Timing and Form of Distribution .
58492_11_ITEM14_P287_S1	The Participant will select the timing and form of distribution for Stock Unit and L P Cash Deferrals on his Election form.
58492_11_ITEM14_P287_S2	The first payment date may not be earlier than two years after the Election is made or such other date as the Committee determines.
58492_11_ITEM14_P287_S3	The Committee may establish maximum deferral periods and maximum payout periods.
58492_11_ITEM14_P287_S4	Until otherwise determined, distribution payouts must begin within 10 years of the effective date of the deferral, and all amounts subject to the deferral must be distributed within 10 years of the first distribution payout.
58492_11_ITEM14_P287_S5	The Participant may make an election to extend the payout period or change the form of distribution for Stock Unit and L P Cash Deferrals, not to exceed any maximum payout period established by the Committee.
58492_11_ITEM14_P287_S6	For purposes of the foregoing, each payout date in an installment distribution election will be treated as a separate election.
58492_11_ITEM14_P287_S7	Unless otherwise permitted under rules applicable to Section 409A, the election change must be made not less than 12 months before the scheduled payment date and must extend the distribution payment by at least five years.
58492_11_ITEM14_P288_S0	5.6 Convert L P Cash Deferral to Stock Units .
58492_11_ITEM14_P288_S1	If a Participant elects an L P Cash Deferral, the Participant may later ask the Committee to convert the L P Cash Deferral to a Stock Unit Deferral.
58492_11_ITEM14_P288_S2	Such a conversion may only be made during the year in which the Compensation subject to the deferral election is earned.
58492_11_ITEM14_P288_S3	The Committee may, in its sole discretion and as permitted under applicable law, grant such conversion to the Participant on such date and upon such terms as the Committee determines.
58492_11_ITEM14_P288_S4	The Participant will forfeit all accrued interest of the L P Cash Deferral if the Committee grants his request.
58492_11_ITEM14_P288_S5	In the event of an Unforeseeable Emergency, the Committee may, in its sole discretion and as permitted under applicable law, authorize an early distribution of a Participant s vested L P Cash Deferral or Stock Unit account and cancellation of the Participant s election.
58492_11_ITEM14_P288_S6	Amounts distributed due to an Unforeseeable Emergency must be limited to the amount reasonably necessary to satisfy the emergency need.
58492_11_ITEM14_P289_S0	The Company s obligation to a Participant for Stock Unit and L P Cash Deferrals is a mere promise to pay shares or money in the future and the Participant will have the status of a general unsecured creditor of the Company.
58492_11_ITEM14_P289_S1	The Committee and the Company s Secretary will make all determinations regarding benefits under the Program in accordance with ERISA.
58492_11_ITEM14_P289_S2	If a Participant believes he is entitled to receive a distribution under the Program and he does not receive such distribution, he must make a claim in writing to the Committee.
58492_11_ITEM14_P289_S3	The Committee will review the claim.
58492_11_ITEM14_P289_S4	If the claim is denied, the Committee will provide a written notice of denial within 90 days setting out: the reasons for the denial; provisions of the Program upon which the denial is based; any additional information to perfect the claim and why such information is necessary; the steps to be taken if a review is sought, including, as applicable, the right to file an action under Section 502(a) of ERISA following an adverse determination; and the time limits for requesting a review and for review.
58492_11_ITEM14_P289_S5	If a claim is denied and the Participant desires a review, he will notify the Secretary in writing within 60 days of the receipt of notice of denial.
58492_11_ITEM14_P290_S0	In requesting a review, the Participant may review the Program or any related document and submit any written statement he deems appropriate.
58492_11_ITEM14_P290_S1	The Secretary will then review the claim and, if the decision is adverse to the Participant, provide a written decision within 60 days setting out: the reasons for the denial; provisions of the Program upon which the denial is based; a statement that the Participant is entitled to receive, upon request and free of charge, copies of documents relied upon in making the decision; and, as applicable, the Participant s right to bring an action under Section 502(a) of ERISA.
58492_11_ITEM14_P291_S0	COMPANY BENEFIT PLANS 6.1 Impact on Benefit Plans .
58492_11_ITEM14_P291_S1	The deferral of Compensation under the Program is not intended to affect other Employer benefit plans in which the Participant is participating or may be eligible to participate.
58492_11_ITEM14_P291_S2	The impact of the Program on other benefits is described below.
58492_11_ITEM14_P292_S0	401(k) Plans Participation in the Program will reduce compensation eligible for contributions under an Employer 401(k) plan in the year the compensation is earned.
58492_11_ITEM14_P292_S1	For Participants in the Company s Retirement 401(k) ( Retirement K ), this could result in a corresponding reduction of the Company s matching contributions in the Retirement K. The Company s Retirement K Excess Program is intended to address this limitation and other limitations affecting matching contributions in the Retirement K.
58492_11_ITEM14_P292_S2	In certain circumstances, the Retirement K Excess Program will make a cash payment equal to the lost matching contribution to the Retirement K. When previously deferred compensation comes out of the Program, the compensation will be considered eligible compensation for a contribution under the L P 401(k) Plan.
58492_11_ITEM14_P293_S0	For stock distributions (e.g. a Stock Unit distribution or an Option exercise), the Company must, to the extent possible, take the 401(k) contribution from a Participant s other cash compensation in the calendar year.
58492_11_ITEM14_P294_S0	Executive Stock Unit Program The amount of payroll deduction for Stock Units under the Company s Executive Stock Unit Program ( ESU Program ) will be calculated as if no deferral had occurred.
58492_11_ITEM14_P294_S1	In the case of an ESU Program Participant who defers 100% of Compensation under the Deferred Compensation Program, the Company will make the Matching Contribution and Additional Matching Contribution under the ESU Program as though the full Participant s Contribution had been made.
58492_11_ITEM14_P295_S0	Discount Stock Plan Contributions under the Discount Stock Plan will be calculated as if no deferral had occurred.
58492_11_ITEM14_P296_S0	Life Insurance and Disability Benefits To the extent the level of benefits is based upon a Participant s compensation, Deferred Compensation will be included when it would have otherwise become payable but for the deferral.
58492_11_ITEM14_P296_S1	Except as provided in Section 6.1, the Participant must make contributions and payments under all Employer benefit plans in which he is participating in the amounts required as if no deferral had occurred.
58492_11_ITEM14_P296_S2	If there is not sufficient Compensation after deferral from which to withhold required contributions and payments, the Participant must make arrangements suitable to the Company for payment of the required amounts.
58492_11_ITEM14_P297_S0	Except to the extent the Committee otherwise designates pursuant to Section 7.2(e), the Committee will control and manage the operation and administration of the Program.
58492_11_ITEM14_P297_S1	The Committee will have such authority as may be necessary to discharge its responsibilities under the Program, including the authority to: (a) interpret the provisions of the Program; (b) adopt rules of procedure consistent with the Program; (c) determine questions relating to Benefits and rights under the Program; (d) maintain records concerning the Program; (e) designate any Company employee or committee to carry out any of the Committee s duties, including authority to manage the operation and administration of the Program; and (f) determine the content and form of the Participant s Election and all other documents required to carry out the Program.
58492_11_ITEM14_P298_S0	7.3 Section 16 Officers and Non-Employee Directors .
58492_11_ITEM14_P298_S1	Notwithstanding the foregoing, (i) the Committee may not delegate its authority with respect to Section 16 Officers, and (ii) the Board of Directors must approve any action related to Benefits for non-employee directors or advisory directors.

58492_11_ITEM14_P299_S1	Notwithstanding anything contained in the Program or in any document issued under the Program, it is intended that the Program will at all times meet the requirements of Section 409A and any regulations or other guidance issued thereunder, and that the provisions of the Program will be interpreted to meet such requirements.
58492_11_ITEM14_P300_S0	MISCELLANEOUS 8.1 Change in Capitalization .
58492_11_ITEM14_P301_S0	In the event of a stock dividend, stock split, merger, consolidation or other recapitalization of the Company affecting the number of outstanding shares of Common Stock, the number of Option shares and Exercise Price and the number of Stock Units credited to a Participant s account will be appropriately adjusted.
58492_11_ITEM14_P301_S1	Nothing contained in the Program or in any document issued under the Program will constitute evidence of any agreement or understanding that the Employer will employ or retain the Participant for any period of time or at any particular rate of compensation.
58492_11_ITEM14_P301_S2	A Participant may designate one or more Beneficiaries to receive all of his Benefits resulting from any deferrals under this Program if he dies.
58492_11_ITEM14_P301_S3	A Participant may change or revoke a designation of a Beneficiary at any time upon written notice to the Company.
58492_11_ITEM14_P301_S4	If a notice of beneficiary is not on file or if the Beneficiary is not living when the Participant dies, the Participant s estate will be his Beneficiary.
58492_11_ITEM14_P301_S5	No Benefits or interests therein may be transferred, assigned or pledged during a Participant s lifetime.
58492_11_ITEM14_P302_S0	Participant or Beneficiary or transferred by operation of law in the event of bankruptcy or insolvency.
58492_11_ITEM14_P302_S1	Any attempted assignment or transfer will be void.
58492_11_ITEM14_P302_S2	However, the Committee may, in its sole discretion, allow a Participant to transfer Options by way of a bona fide gift.
58492_11_ITEM14_P302_S3	The donee will hold such Options subject to the Program.
58492_11_ITEM14_P302_S4	The Program will be binding upon and inure to the benefit of the Company, its successors and assigns, and each Participant, his heirs, personal representatives, and Beneficiaries.
58492_11_ITEM14_P302_S5	The Company will have the right to amend or terminate the Program at any time.
58492_11_ITEM14_P302_S6	However, no such amendment or termination will deprive any Participant of the right to receive Benefits previously vested under the Program.
58492_11_ITEM14_P302_S7	To the extent not preempted by ERISA, Missouri law will govern this Program.
58492_11_ITEM14_P302_S8	To the extent permitted by Section 409A, the Committee retains the right to delay a Participant distribution if the payment of such distribution would violate securities laws, eliminate or reduce the Company s tax deduction by application of Section 162(m) of the Internal Revenue Code, violate loan covenants or other contractual terms to which the Company is a party, or otherwise result in material harm to the Company.

58492_11_ITEM15_P5_S0	Summary Leggett Platt, Incorporated was founded as a partnership in Carthage, Missouri in 1883 and was incorporated in 1901.
58492_11_ITEM15_P5_S1	The Company, a pioneer of the steel coil bedspring, has become an international diversified manufacturer that conceives, designs and produces a wide range of engineered components and products found in many homes, offices, retail stores and automobiles.
58492_11_ITEM15_P5_S2	As discussed below, our operations are organized into 19 business units, which are divided into 10 groups under our four segments: Residential Furnishings; Commercial Fixturing Components; Industrial Materials; and Specialized Products.
58492_11_ITEM15_P5_S3	In addition, certain of our former businesses are classified as discontinued operations.
58492_11_ITEM15_P6_S0	Our Residential Furnishings segment began with an 1885 patent of the steel coil bedspring.
58492_11_ITEM15_P6_S1	Today, we supply a variety of components used by bedding and upholstered furniture manufacturers in the assembly of their finished products.
58492_11_ITEM15_P6_S2	Our range of products offers our customers a single source for many of their component needs.
58492_11_ITEM15_P6_S3	Long production runs, internal production of key raw materials, and numerous manufacturing and assembly locations allow us to supply many customers with components at a lower cost than they can produce themselves.
58492_11_ITEM15_P6_S4	In addition to cost savings, sourcing components from us allows our customers to focus on designing, merchandising and marketing their products.
58492_11_ITEM15_P7_S0	Customers Most of our Residential Furnishings customers are manufacturers of finished bedding products (mattresses and foundations) or upholstered furniture for residential use.
58492_11_ITEM15_P7_S1	We also sell many products, including ornamental beds, bed frames, power foundations, carpet underlay, and top-of-bed accessories, directly to retailers and distributors.
58492_11_ITEM15_P7_S2	We sell geo components products primarily to dealers, contractors, landscapers, road construction companies and government agencies.
58492_11_ITEM15_P8_S0	Our Fixture Display group designs, produces, installs and manages our customers store fixtures and point-of-purchase projects.
58492_11_ITEM15_P8_S1	Our Office Furniture Components group designs, manufactures, and distributes a wide range of engineered components targeted for the office seating market.
58492_11_ITEM15_P9_S0	Bases, columns, back rests, casters and frames for office chairs, and control devices that allow office chairs to tilt, swivel and elevate Customers Customers of the Commercial Fixturing Components segment include:
58492_11_ITEM15_P10_S0	We believe that the quality of the Industrial Materials segment s products and services, together with low cost, have made us the leading U.S. supplier of drawn steel wire and a major producer of welded steel tubing.
58492_11_ITEM15_P10_S1	Our Wire group operates a steel rod mill with an annual output of approximately 500,000 tons, of which a substantial majority is used by our own wire mills.
58492_11_ITEM15_P10_S2	We have six wire mills that supply virtually all the wire consumed by our other domestic businesses.
58492_11_ITEM15_P10_S3	Our Tubing group operates two major plants that also supply nearly all of our internal needs for welded steel tubing.
58492_11_ITEM15_P10_S4	In addition to supporting our internal requirements, the Industrial Materials segment supplies many external customers with wire and tubing products.
58492_11_ITEM15_P11_S0	We use about half of our wire output and about one-quarter of our welded steel tubing output to manufacture our own products.
58492_11_ITEM15_P11_S1	For example, we use our wire and steel tubing to make:
58492_11_ITEM15_P12_S0	Automotive seat components and frames The Industrial Materials segment also has a diverse group of external customers, including:
58492_11_ITEM15_P13_S0	Our Specialized Products segment designs, produces and sells components for automotive seating, specialized machinery and equipment, and service van interiors.
58492_11_ITEM15_P13_S1	Our established design capability and focus on product development have made us a leader in innovation.
58492_11_ITEM15_P13_S2	We also benefit from our broad geographic presence and our internal production of key raw materials and components.
58492_11_ITEM15_P14_S0	Specialty trailers used by telephone, cable and utility companies Customers Our primary customers for the Specialized Products segment include:
58492_11_ITEM15_P15_S0	In November 2007 we outlined significant changes to the Company s strategy.
58492_11_ITEM15_P15_S1	Beginning Stock Price) , changed the priorities for use of cash, adopted role-based portfolio management and implemented more rigorous strategic planning.
58492_11_ITEM15_P15_S2	Our goals were to: i) divest or fix low performing businesses, ii) return more cash to investors, iii) improve margins and returns on the businesses we keep, and iv) then begin to carefully and conservatively grow the Company (at 4-5% of annual revenue).
58492_11_ITEM15_P16_S0	I We have made significant progress over the past three years.
58492_11_ITEM15_P16_S1	The divestitures were largely complete by the end of 2008; margins and returns have improved; and we have returned much of our excess cash to our shareholders through higher dividends and share repurchases.
58492_11_ITEM15_P16_S2	Our focus now is two-part: i) continue improving margins, and ii) begin laying the groundwork for long-term 4-5% growth.
58492_11_ITEM15_P16_S3	Some of the activities associated with the change in strategy led to asset impairment and restructuring costs during the past three years.
58492_11_ITEM15_P16_S4	For information related to those costs, see Note C on page 86 and Note D on page 90 in the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
58492_11_ITEM15_P17_S0	Key Financial Metric TSR is the primary financial metric we use to monitor performance.
58492_11_ITEM15_P17_S1	Our goal is to achieve TSR in the top 1/3 of the S P 500, over the long term.
58492_11_ITEM15_P17_S2	For the three-year period ended December 31, 2010 we generated TSR of 16% per year, on average, which places us in the top 8% of the S P 500.
58492_11_ITEM15_P17_S3	We employ four key levers to achieve TSR: i) revenue growth, ii) margin expansion, iii) dividends, and iv) share repurchases.
58492_11_ITEM15_P17_S4	In 2008, dividends and stock buyback largely drove our TSR; during 2009, we benefited significantly from margin improvement; and in 2010, revenue growth (from improved market demand) boosted TSR.
58492_11_ITEM15_P17_S5	We expect that this balanced approach will generate consistently higher TSR.
58492_11_ITEM15_P18_S0	Consistent with the change in our strategy, we modified some of our incentive plans to emphasize the importance of TSR.
58492_11_ITEM15_P18_S1	Beginning in January 2008, we introduced a new performance incentive for senior executives based solely on 3-year TSR relative to a group of 320 peers.
58492_11_ITEM15_P18_S2	We also modified business unit bonuses to give more importance to achieving higher returns on the assets under their direct control.
58492_11_ITEM15_P18_S3	The strategic changes have increased available cash.
58492_11_ITEM15_P18_S4	We expect to continue returning much of this cash to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases.
58492_11_ITEM15_P18_S5	During the past three years, we generated approximately $1.8 billion of cash flow from operations and divestitures.
58492_11_ITEM15_P18_S6	Furthermore, as anticipated, since 2007 we ve reduced combined annual spending for acquisitions and capital expenditures by over 70% (to $73 million in 2010).
58492_11_ITEM15_P18_S7	Since late 2007, we have raised quarterly dividends by 50%, from $.18 per share to $.27 per share currently.
58492_11_ITEM15_P18_S8	During the past three years, we have also spent over $600 million to repurchase 33 million shares of our stock, which reduced outstanding shares by approximately 13%.
58492_11_ITEM15_P18_S9	In 2010, we repurchased over 6 million shares at an average per share price of $21.64 (and issued 4 million shares through employee benefit plans) (most of these shares are purchased by employees in lieu of cash compensation).
58492_11_ITEM15_P19_S0	We manage our business units as a portfolio, with different roles (Grow, Core, Fix, Divest) for each business unit based upon competitive advantages, strategic position, and financial health.
58492_11_ITEM15_P19_S1	We undergo a rigorous strategic planning process, in part to assess each business unit s portfolio role.
58492_11_ITEM15_P20_S0	Business units in the Grow category should provide avenues for profitable growth in competitively advantaged positions.
58492_11_ITEM15_P21_S0	Core business units are expected to enhance productivity, maintain market share, and generate cash flow from operations while using minimal capital.
58492_11_ITEM15_P21_S1	Business units in the Fix category will be given a limited time in which to significantly improve performance.
58492_11_ITEM15_P21_S2	Finally, a few small business units (or portions of business units) are considered non-strategic, and may be divested as the M A market recovers and allows for reasonable sales prices.
58492_11_ITEM15_P21_S3	To remain in the portfolio, business units are expected to consistently generate after-tax returns in excess of the Company s cost of capital.
58492_11_ITEM15_P21_S4	Each business unit has opportunity to improve, and may employ a variety of means to achieve higher returns including trimming expenses, introducing new products, improving productivity, adopting more disciplined pricing, reducing working capital, and consolidating assets.
58492_11_ITEM15_P21_S5	Business units that fail to consistently generate after-tax returns in excess of our cost of capital will move to the Fix or Divest categories.
58492_11_ITEM15_P22_S0	During 2009 and 2010 significant effort went into improving margins.
58492_11_ITEM15_P22_S1	EBIT margin for 2009 was 7.5% on $3.06 billion of sales while EBIT margin for 2010 was 8.6% on sales of $3.36 billion.
58492_11_ITEM15_P22_S2	Gross margin for 2009 and 2010 was 20.6% and 19.5%, respectively.
58492_11_ITEM15_P23_S0	Disciplined Growth Consistent with the plan we unveiled in 2007, we are now beginning to devote resources to the next phase of our strategy.
58492_11_ITEM15_P23_S1	We aim to eventually achieve consistent, long-term, profitable growth of 4-5% annually.
58492_11_ITEM15_P23_S2	To achieve this goal, we will need to supplement the approximate 2%-3% growth that our markets typically produce (in normal economic times) with two additional areas of opportunity.
58492_11_ITEM15_P24_S0	First, we must enhance our success rate at developing and commercializing innovative new products within markets in which we already enjoy strong competitive positions.
58492_11_ITEM15_P24_S1	Second, we need to uncover new growth platforms; opportunities in markets new to us, and in which Leggett would possess a competitive advantage.
58492_11_ITEM15_P24_S2	Both efforts are receiving significant management attention and priority, and we are making progress in both areas.
58492_11_ITEM15_P24_S3	We have had success this past year with new products introduced in our office components, automotive, and home furniture components businesses.
58492_11_ITEM15_P24_S4	Though individually those were modest successes, collectively they added to sales and earnings growth in 2010.
58492_11_ITEM15_P24_S5	In addition, we have instituted some of the processes that need to be in place to identify new market opportunities.
58492_11_ITEM15_P24_S6	Successful development of new growth platforms will take time; we do not anticipate significant contributions from these activities in the near term.
58492_11_ITEM15_P25_S0	PART I Acquisitions and Divestitures Historically, our typical acquisition targets have been small, private, profitable, entrepreneurial companies that manufacture goods either within our existing product lines or one step away from those product lines and complementary to our existing businesses.
58492_11_ITEM15_P25_S1	As part of our change in strategic direction, we expect fewer and more strategic acquisitions to be completed.
58492_11_ITEM15_P25_S2	All acquisitions should create value by enhancing TSR; they should have clear strategic rationale and sustainable competitive advantage in attractive markets.
58492_11_ITEM15_P25_S3	We have had no significant acquisitions in the last three years.
58492_11_ITEM15_P25_S4	For further information about acquisitions, see Note R on page 118 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.

58492_11_ITEM15_P40_S0	passed through to customers with selling price adjustments.
58492_11_ITEM15_P41_S0	Significant steel cost increases in 2008 were followed by significant cost decreases in 2009 as global economies weakened.
58492_11_ITEM15_P41_S1	In both cases, we generally adjusted pricing to our customers to reflect the changes in commodity costs.
58492_11_ITEM15_P41_S2	In late 2009 and early 2010, steel costs increased, and again we implemented price increases to recover the majority of the higher costs.
58492_11_ITEM15_P41_S3	By the end of 2010, we were facing further inflation in steel costs, and announced and began implementing additional price increases in early 2011.
58492_11_ITEM15_P41_S4	The degree to which we are able to mitigate or recover higher costs, should they occur, could influence our future earnings.
58492_11_ITEM15_P41_S5	Also, if raw material costs decrease there may be downward pressure on selling prices, temporarily resulting in lower segment margins, as we consume higher cost inventories.
58492_11_ITEM15_P41_S6	Higher raw material costs in recent years have led some of our customers to modify their product designs, changing the quantity and mix of our components in their finished goods.
58492_11_ITEM15_P41_S7	In some cases, higher cost components have been replaced with lower cost components, causing us to shift production accordingly.
58492_11_ITEM15_P41_S8	This has primarily impacted profit margins in our Residential Furnishings and Industrial Materials segments.
58492_11_ITEM15_P41_S9	We are responding by developing new products (including new types of innersprings, box springs and reclining chair mechanisms) that enable our customers to reduce their total costs, and in certain instances, provide higher margin and profit contribution for our operations.
