58492_11_ITEM15_P49_S0	Competition Many companies offer products that compete with those we manufacture and sell.
58492_11_ITEM15_P49_S1	The number of competing companies varies by product line, but many of the markets for our products are highly competitive.
58492_11_ITEM15_P49_S2	We tend to attract and retain customers through product quality, innovation, competitive pricing and customer service.
58492_11_ITEM15_P49_S3	Many of our competitors try to win business primarily on price but, depending upon the particular product, we experience competition based on quality, performance and availability as well.
58492_11_ITEM15_P49_S4	We believe we are the largest U.S. manufacturer, in terms of revenue, of the following:
58492_11_ITEM15_P50_S0	I We continue to face pressure from foreign competitors as some of our customers source a portion of their components and finished products offshore.
58492_11_ITEM15_P51_S0	In addition to lower labor rates, foreign competitors benefit (at times) from lower raw material costs.
58492_11_ITEM15_P51_S1	They may also benefit from currency factors and more lenient regulatory climates related to safety and environmental matters.
58492_11_ITEM15_P52_S0	We typically remain price competitive, even versus many foreign manufacturers, as a result of our highly efficient operations, low labor content, vertical integration in steel and wire, and large scale purchasing of raw materials and commodities.
58492_11_ITEM15_P52_S1	However, we have also reacted to foreign competition in certain cases, by selectively adjusting prices, and by developing new proprietary products that help our customers reduce total costs.
58492_11_ITEM15_P52_S2	In instances where our customers move production of their finished products overseas, our operations must be located nearby to supply them efficiently.
58492_11_ITEM15_P52_S3	We currently operate 10 facilities in China.
58492_11_ITEM15_P53_S0	In late 2007, we filed an antidumping suit related to innerspring imports from China, South Africa and Vietnam.
58492_11_ITEM15_P53_S1	We saw a distinct decline in unfair imports during 2008 after the antidumping investigations began.
58492_11_ITEM15_P53_S2	As a result, we regained market share and performance in our Bedding group improved.
58492_11_ITEM15_P53_S3	The investigations were brought to a favorable conclusion in early 2009.
58492_11_ITEM15_P53_S4	The current antidumping duty rates on innersprings from these countries are significant, ranging from 116% to 234%, and should remain in effect at least until early 2014.
58492_11_ITEM15_P53_S5	Imported innersprings from these countries are now supposed to be sold at fair prices, however the duties on certain innersprings are being evaded by various means including shipping the goods through a third country and falsely identifying the country of origin.
58492_11_ITEM15_P53_S6	Leggett, along with several U.S. manufacturers of products with active antidumping or antidumping/countervailing duty orders, formed a coalition and are working with Members of Congress, the U.S. Department of Commerce, and U.S. Customs and Border Protection to seek stronger enforcement of existing antidumping and/or countervailing duty orders.
58492_11_ITEM15_P54_S0	We experienced a temporary loss of market share during the last half of 2010 as certain of our customers purchased a portion of their innerspring requirements from European suppliers.
58492_11_ITEM15_P54_S1	The opportunity to buy these components at a lower price resulted from a combination of factors that benefited European suppliers in the early summer: i) the weaker Euro, ii) temporarily lower raw material costs in Europe, and iii) greater excess capacity as a result of last summer s economic turmoil in Europe.
58492_11_ITEM15_P54_S2	Because of the slowing of consumer demand for mattresses in the last half of 2010, it took longer for these imported products to be consumed, but by year-end, we had regained the majority of the volume.
58492_11_ITEM15_P55_S0	Seasonality As a diversified manufacturer, we generally have not experienced significant seasonality.
58492_11_ITEM15_P55_S1	The timing of acquisitions, dispositions, and economic factors in any year can distort the underlying seasonality in certain of our businesses.
58492_11_ITEM15_P56_S0	Historically, for the Company as a whole, the second and third quarters typically have proportionately greater sales, while the first and fourth quarters are generally lower.
58492_11_ITEM15_P56_S1	However, in 2010, sales in the first and second quarters were higher on strength in our Residential Furnishings and Commercial Fixturing Components segments.
58492_11_ITEM15_P56_S2	Consumer demand for bedding and furniture was stronger during the first half of the year, we believe in part due to larger income tax refunds and home purchasing incentives.
58492_11_ITEM15_P57_S0	stronger in the first half of the year, as retailers increased store remodeling activity (a larger portion of which occurred in the earlier part of the year) and decreased new store construction.
58492_11_ITEM15_P57_S1	Notwithstanding 2010, our four segments tend to experience seasonality as follows:
58492_11_ITEM15_P58_S0	Residential Furnishings: typically has the strongest sales in the second and third quarters due to increased consumer demand for bedding and furniture during those periods.
58492_11_ITEM15_P59_S0	Commercial Fixturing Components: generally has heavy third quarter sales of its store fixture products, with the first and fourth quarters normally lower.
58492_11_ITEM15_P59_S1	This aligns with the retail industry s normal construction cycle the opening of new stores and completion of remodeling projects in advance of the holiday season.
58492_11_ITEM15_P60_S0	Industrial Materials: minimal variation in sales throughout the year.
58492_11_ITEM15_P61_S0	Specialized Products: relatively little quarter-to-quarter variation in sales, although the automotive business is typically somewhat heavier in the second and fourth quarters of the year and lower in the third quarter due to model changeovers and plant shutdowns in the automobile industry during the summer.
58492_11_ITEM15_P61_S1	Backlog Our customer relationships and our manufacturing and inventory practices do not create a material amount of backlog orders for any of our segments.
58492_11_ITEM15_P62_S0	Production and inventory levels are geared primarily to the level of incoming orders and projected demand based on customer relationships.

58492_12_ITEM1_P0_S0	Leggett Platt, Incorporated was founded as a partnership in Carthage, Missouri in 1883 and was incorporated in 1901.
58492_12_ITEM1_P0_S1	The Company, a pioneer of the steel coil bedspring, has become an international diversified manufacturer that conceives, designs and produces a wide range of engineered components and products found in many homes, offices, retail stores and automobiles.
58492_12_ITEM1_P0_S2	As discussed below, our operations are organized into 20 business units, which are divided into 10 groups under our four segments: Residential Furnishings; Commercial Fixturing Components; Industrial Materials; and Specialized Products.
58492_12_ITEM1_P1_S0	Our Residential Furnishings segment began with an 1885 patent of the steel coil bedspring.
58492_12_ITEM1_P1_S1	Today, we supply a variety of components used by bedding and upholstered furniture manufacturers in the assembly of their finished products.
58492_12_ITEM1_P1_S2	Our range of products offers our customers a single source for many of their component needs.
58492_12_ITEM1_P1_S3	Efficient manufacturing methods, internal production of key raw materials, and numerous manufacturing and assembly locations allow us to supply many customers with components at a lower cost than they can produce themselves.
58492_12_ITEM1_P1_S4	In addition to cost savings, sourcing components from us allows our customers to focus on designing, merchandising and marketing their products.
58492_12_ITEM1_P2_S0	Customers Most of our Residential Furnishings customers are manufacturers of finished bedding products (mattresses and foundations) or upholstered furniture for residential use.
58492_12_ITEM1_P2_S1	We also sell many products, including ornamental beds, bed frames, adjustable beds, carpet underlay, and top-of-bed accessories, directly to retailers and distributors.
58492_12_ITEM1_P2_S2	We sell Geo Components products primarily to dealers, contractors, landscapers, road construction companies and government agencies.
58492_12_ITEM1_P3_S0	Our Fixture Display group designs, produces, installs and manages our customers store fixtures projects.
58492_12_ITEM1_P4_S0	Our Office Furniture Components group designs, manufactures, and distributes a wide range of engineered components targeted for the office seating market.
58492_12_ITEM1_P5_S0	Bases, columns, back rests, casters and frames for office chairs, and control devices that allow office chairs to tilt, swivel and elevate Customers Customers of the Commercial Fixturing Components segment include:
58492_12_ITEM1_P6_S0	We believe that the quality of our products and services, together with low cost, have made us the leading U.S. supplier of drawn steel wire and a major producer of welded steel tubing.
58492_12_ITEM1_P6_S1	Our Wire group operates a steel rod mill with an annual output of approximately 500,000 tons, of which a substantial majority is used by our own wire mills.
58492_12_ITEM1_P6_S2	We have five wire mills that supply virtually all the wire consumed by our other domestic businesses.
58492_12_ITEM1_P6_S3	Our Steel Tubing business unit operates two major plants that also supply nearly all of our internal needs for welded steel tubing.
58492_12_ITEM1_P6_S4	In addition to supporting our internal requirements, we also supply many external customers with wire and steel tubing products.
58492_12_ITEM1_P6_S5	On January 12, 2012, we completed the acquisition of Western Pneumatic Tube Holding, LLC (Western).
58492_12_ITEM1_P6_S6	Western is a leading provider of integral components for critical aircraft systems, and forms the new Aerospace Products business unit within the Tubing Group.
58492_12_ITEM1_P6_S7	Western specializes in fabricating thin-walled, large diameter, welded tubing and specialty formed products from titanium, nickel and other specialty materials for leading aerospace suppliers and OEMs.
58492_12_ITEM1_P7_S0	Titanium and nickel tubing for the aerospace industry Customers We use about half of our wire output and about one-quarter of our steel tubing output to manufacture our own products.

58492_12_ITEM1_P8_S0	Automotive seat components and frames The Industrial Materials segment also has a diverse group of external customers, including:
58492_12_ITEM1_P9_S0	Our Specialized Products segment designs, produces and sells components for automotive seating, specialized machinery and equipment, and service van interiors.
58492_12_ITEM1_P9_S1	Our established design capability and focus on product development have made us a leader in innovation.
58492_12_ITEM1_P9_S2	We also benefit from our broad geographic presence and our internal production of key raw materials and components.

58492_12_ITEM1_P11_S0	Telecom, cable, home service and delivery companies Strategic Direction Key Financial Metric Total Shareholder Return (TSR), relative to peer companies, is the key financial measure that we use to assess long-term performance.
58492_12_ITEM1_P11_S1	TSR = (Change in Stock Price + Dividends Received)/Beginning Stock Price.
58492_12_ITEM1_P11_S2	Our goal is to achieve TSR in the top 1/3 of the S P 500 over the long term through a balanced approach that employs all four TSR sources: revenue growth, margin expansion, dividends, and share repurchases.
58492_12_ITEM1_P12_S0	We monitor our TSR performance (relative to the S P 500) on a rolling three-year basis.
58492_12_ITEM1_P12_S1	For the three-year measurement period that ended December 31, 2011 we generated TSR of 21% per year, on average, which places us in the top 38% of the S P 500.
58492_12_ITEM1_P12_S2	In addition, our TSR has exceeded that of the S P 500 index for four consecutive years.
58492_12_ITEM1_P13_S0	I Our incentive programs reward return generation.
58492_12_ITEM1_P14_S0	Senior executives participate in a TSR-based incentive program (based on our performance compared to the performance of a group of approximately 320 peers).
58492_12_ITEM1_P15_S0	Business unit bonuses emphasize the achievement of higher returns on the assets under the unit s direct control.
58492_12_ITEM1_P15_S1	More Cash to Shareholders During the past three years, we generated approximately $1.26 billion of cash flow from operations.
58492_12_ITEM1_P15_S2	Capital expenditures were $75 million in 2011, compared to $68 million in 2010, and $83 million in 2009.
58492_12_ITEM1_P15_S3	Since late 2007, we have raised quarterly dividends by 56%, from $.18 per share to $.28 per share currently.
58492_12_ITEM1_P15_S4	During the past three years, we have also repurchased roughly 27 million shares of our stock (and issued approximately 11 million shares through employee benefit plans), which reduced the net outstanding shares by approximately 11%.
58492_12_ITEM1_P15_S5	In 2011, we repurchased approximately 10 million shares at an average per share price of $22.86 (and issued approximately 3 million shares through employee benefit plans).
58492_12_ITEM1_P15_S6	As discussed in more detail below under Acquisitions, we completed the acquisition of Western Pneumatic Tube for a cash purchase price of $188 million in January 2012.
58492_12_ITEM1_P15_S7	As such, we do not anticipate repurchasing a significant number of shares in 2012.
58492_12_ITEM1_P15_S8	We utilize a rigorous strategic planning process to help guide future decisions regarding business unit roles, capital allocation priorities, and new areas in which to grow.
58492_12_ITEM1_P15_S9	We review the portfolio classification of each unit on an annual basis to determine its appropriate role (Grow, Core, Fix, or Divest).
58492_12_ITEM1_P15_S10	This review includes criteria such as competitive position, market attractiveness, business unit size, and fit within our overall objectives, as well as financial indicators such as EBIT and EBITDA growth, operating cash flows, and return on assets.
58492_12_ITEM1_P16_S0	Business units in the Grow category should provide avenues for profitable growth from competitively advantaged positions in attractive markets.
58492_12_ITEM1_P17_S0	Core business units are expected to enhance productivity, maintain market share, and generate cash flow from operations while using minimal capital.
58492_12_ITEM1_P17_S1	To remain in the portfolio, business units are expected to consistently generate after-tax returns in excess of our cost of capital.
58492_12_ITEM1_P17_S2	Business units that fail to consistently attain minimum return goals will be moved to the Fix or Divest categories.
58492_12_ITEM1_P18_S0	Disciplined Growth Long-term, we aim to eventually achieve consistent, profitable growth of 4-5% annually.
58492_12_ITEM1_P18_S1	To attain this goal, we will need to supplement the approximate 2-3% growth that our markets typically produce (in normal economic times) with two additional areas of opportunity.
58492_12_ITEM1_P19_S0	First, we must enhance our success rate at developing and commercializing innovative new products within markets in which we already enjoy strong competitive positions.
58492_12_ITEM1_P19_S1	Second, we need to uncover new growth platforms; opportunities in markets new to us, and in which we would possess a competitive advantage.
58492_12_ITEM1_P20_S0	Our long-term, 4-5% annual growth objective envisions periodic acquisitions.
58492_12_ITEM1_P20_S1	We seek acquisitions within our growth businesses, and look for opportunities to enter new, higher growth markets (carefully screened for sustainable competitive advantage).
58492_12_ITEM1_P20_S2	We expect all acquisitions to (a) have a clear strategic rationale, a sustainable competitive advantage, and a strong fit with the Company; (b) create value by enhancing Total Shareholder Return, have an internal rate of return in excess of 10% and have positive discounted cash flow; (c) for stand-alone companies: generally, revenue in excess of $50 million, strong management and future growth opportunity with a strong market position in a market growing faster than GDP; and (d) for add-on companies: generally, revenue in excess of $15 million, significant synergies, and a strategic fit with an existing business unit.
58492_12_ITEM1_P20_S3	We had no significant acquisitions in 2009, 2010 or 2011.
58492_12_ITEM1_P20_S4	In January 2012, we acquired Western Pneumatic Tube, which produces thin-walled, larger diameter, welded tubing and specialty formed products for aerospace applications.
58492_12_ITEM1_P21_S0	Western specializes in fabricating products from specialty materials, such as titanium and other refractory alloys, nickel-based alloys, stainless steel and other high strength metals.
58492_12_ITEM1_P21_S1	Western supplies its products primarily to the commercial aerospace market, but also to the defense and industrial markets.
58492_12_ITEM1_P21_S2	Western s products are utilized in aircraft systems and aircraft engine systems, including fuel, hydraulic, pneumatic, environmental, life support, stability and cooling systems.
58492_12_ITEM1_P22_S0	Western operates two facilities: one in Kirkland, Washington, and another near San Diego, California.

58492_12_ITEM1_P43_S0	PART I Competition Many companies offer products that compete with those we manufacture and sell.
58492_12_ITEM1_P43_S1	The number of competing companies varies by product line, but many of the markets for our products are highly competitive.
58492_12_ITEM1_P43_S2	We tend to attract and retain customers through product quality, innovation, competitive pricing and customer service.
58492_12_ITEM1_P43_S3	Many of our competitors try to win business primarily on price but, depending upon the particular product, we experience competition based on quality, performance and availability as well.
58492_12_ITEM1_P43_S4	We believe we are the largest U.S. manufacturer, in terms of revenue, of the following:
58492_12_ITEM1_P44_S0	We continue to face pressure from foreign competitors as some of our customers source a portion of their components and finished products offshore.
58492_12_ITEM1_P44_S1	In addition to lower labor rates, foreign competitors benefit (at times) from lower raw material costs.
58492_12_ITEM1_P44_S2	They may also benefit from currency factors and more lenient regulatory climates.
58492_12_ITEM1_P45_S0	We typically remain price competitive, even versus many foreign manufacturers, as a result of our highly efficient operations, low labor content, vertical integration in steel and wire, and large scale purchasing of raw materials and commodities.
58492_12_ITEM1_P45_S1	However, we have also reacted to foreign competition in certain cases, by selectively adjusting prices, and by developing new proprietary products that help our customers reduce total costs.
58492_12_ITEM1_P46_S0	Premium non-innerspring mattresses (those that have either a foam or air core) have experienced rapid growth in the U.S. bedding market in recent years.
58492_12_ITEM1_P46_S1	While still a relatively small portion of the total market in units (approximately 10%), these products represent a much larger portion of the total market in dollars (approximately 25%-30%) due to their higher average selling prices.
58492_12_ITEM1_P46_S2	We expect these products to continue to grow.
58492_12_ITEM1_P46_S3	Some of our traditional bedding customers are beginning to offer mattresses that combine an innerspring core with top layers comprised of specialty foam and gel.
58492_12_ITEM1_P46_S4	These hybrid products allow our bedding customers to address a consumer preference for the feel of a specialty mattress and the characteristics of an innerspring.
58492_12_ITEM1_P47_S0	In late 2007, we filed an antidumping suit related to innerspring imports from China, South Africa and Vietnam.
58492_12_ITEM1_P47_S1	We saw a distinct decline in unfair imports during 2008 after the antidumping investigations began.
58492_12_ITEM1_P47_S2	As a result, we regained market share and performance in our Bedding Group improved.
58492_12_ITEM1_P47_S3	The investigations were brought to a favorable conclusion in early 2009.
58492_12_ITEM1_P47_S4	The current antidumping duty rates on innersprings from these countries are significant, ranging from 116% to 234%, and should remain in effect at least until early 2014.
58492_12_ITEM1_P47_S5	Imported innersprings from these countries are now supposed to be sold at fair prices, however the duties on certain innersprings are being evaded by various means including shipping the goods through a third country and falsely identifying the country of origin.
58492_12_ITEM1_P48_S0	coalition and are working with Members of Congress, the U.S. Department of Commerce, and U.S. Customs and Border Protection to seek stronger enforcement of existing antidumping and/or countervailing duty orders.
58492_12_ITEM1_P49_S0	Seasonality As a diversified manufacturer, we generally have not experienced significant seasonality.
58492_12_ITEM1_P49_S1	The timing of acquisitions, dispositions, and economic factors in any year can distort the underlying seasonality in certain of our businesses.
58492_12_ITEM1_P50_S0	Historically, for the Company as a whole, the second and third quarters typically have proportionately greater sales, while the first and fourth quarters are generally lower.
58492_12_ITEM1_P51_S0	Residential Furnishings: typically does not exhibit any significant seasonality, except for a reduction in fourth quarter sales.
58492_12_ITEM1_P52_S0	Commercial Fixturing Components: generally has modestly stronger third quarter sales of its store fixture products, with the fourth quarter significantly lower.
58492_12_ITEM1_P52_S1	This aligns with the retail industry s normal construction cycle the opening of new stores and completion of remodeling projects in advance of the holiday season.
58492_12_ITEM1_P53_S0	Industrial Materials: minimal variation in sales throughout the year.
58492_12_ITEM1_P54_S0	Specialized Products: relatively little quarter-to-quarter variation in sales, although the automotive business is typically somewhat heavier in the second and fourth quarters of the year and lower in the third quarter due to model changeovers and plant shutdowns in the automobile industry during the summer.
58492_12_ITEM1_P54_S1	Backlog Our customer relationships and our manufacturing and inventory practices do not create a material amount of backlog orders for any of our segments.
58492_12_ITEM1_P55_S0	Production and inventory levels are geared primarily to the level of incoming orders and projected demand based on customer relationships.

58492_12_ITEM1A_P0_S0	and elsewhere in this report are risk factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from the results contemplated by the forward-looking statements contained in this report.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P0_S1	We may amend or supplement these risk factors from time to time by other reports we file with the SEC.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P1_S0	We have exposure to economic and other factors that affect market demand for our products.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P1_S1	As a supplier of products to a variety of industries, we are adversely affected by general economic downturns.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P1_S2	Our operating performance is heavily influenced by market demand for our components and products.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P1_S3	Market demand for the majority of our products is most heavily influenced by consumer confidence.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P1_S4	To a lesser extent, market demand is impacted by other broad economic factors, including disposable income levels, employment levels, housing turnover, energy costs and interest rates.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P1_S5	All of these factors influence consumer spending on durable goods, and drive demand for our products.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P1_S6	Some of these factors also influence business spending on facilities and equipment, which impacts approximately one-quarter of our sales.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P2_S0	Demand weakness in our markets can lead to lower unit orders, sales and earnings in our businesses.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P3_S0	Several factors, including a weak global economy, a depressed housing market, or low consumer confidence could contribute to conservative spending habits by consumers around the world.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P4_S0	Short lead times in most of our markets allow for limited visibility into demand trends.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P4_S1	In 2011, stagnant demand negatively impacted our major residential markets.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P4_S2	Many consumers continued to postpone spending on larger ticket items such as bedding and furniture in the face of ongoing economic weakness.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P5_S0	If economic and market conditions deteriorate, we may experience material negative impacts on our business, financial condition, operating cash flows and results of operations.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P5_S1	Deteriorating financial condition of our customers could negatively affect our financial position, results of operations, cash flows and liquidity.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P6_S0	We serve customers in a variety of industries, some of which have and are continuing to experience low levels of demand due to a weak global economy.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P6_S1	A sustained economic downturn increases the possibility that one or more of our significant customers, or a group of less significant customers, could become insolvent, which could adversely impact our sales, net earnings, financial condition, cash flow and liquidity.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P6_S2	Costs of raw materials could negatively affect our operating results.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P6_S3	Raw material cost increases (and our ability to respond to cost increases through selling price increases) can significantly impact our earnings.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P6_S4	We typically have short-term commitments from our suppliers; therefore, our raw material costs move with the market.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P6_S5	When we experience significant increases in raw material costs, we typically implement price increases to recover the higher costs.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P6_S6	Inability to recover cost increases (or a delay in the recovery time) can negatively impact our earnings.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P6_S7	Conversely, if raw material costs decrease, we generally pass through reduced selling prices to our customers.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P6_S8	Reduced selling prices tied to higher cost inventory reduces our segment margins and earnings.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P7_S0	PART I Steel is our most significant raw material.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P8_S0	The global steel markets are cyclical in nature and have been volatile in recent years.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P8_S1	This volatility can result in large swings in pricing and margins from year to year.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P8_S2	Our operations can also be impacted by changes in the cost of fabrics and foam scrap.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P8_S3	We experienced significant fluctuations in the cost of these commodities in recent years.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P8_S4	Higher raw material costs in recent years led some of our customers to modify their product designs, changing the quantity and mix of our components in their finished goods.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P8_S5	In some cases, higher cost components were replaced with lower cost components.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P8_S6	This primarily impacted our Residential Furnishings and Industrial Materials product mix and decreased profit margins.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P8_S7	This trend could further negatively impact our results of operations.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P8_S8	We may not be able to realize deferred tax assets on our balance sheet depending upon the amount and source of future taxable income.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P8_S9	Our ability to realize deferred tax assets on our balance sheet is dependent upon the amount and source of future taxable income.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P8_S10	Economic uncertainty or tax law changes could change our underlying assumptions on which valuation reserves are established and negatively affect future period earnings and balance sheets.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P8_S11	Competition could adversely affect our operating results.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P8_S12	We operate in markets that are highly competitive.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P8_S13	We believe that most companies in our lines of business compete primarily on price, but, depending upon the particular product, we experience competition based on quality, performance and availability as well.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P8_S14	We face ongoing pressure from foreign competitors as some of our customers source a portion of their components and finished products from Asia and Europe.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P8_S15	In addition to lower labor rates, foreign competitors benefit (at times) from lower raw material costs.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P8_S16	They may also benefit from currency factors and more lenient regulatory climates.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P9_S0	If we are unable to purchase key raw materials, such as steel, at prices competitive with those of foreign suppliers, our ability to maintain market share and profit margins could be harmed by foreign competitors.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P10_S0	Premium non-innerspring mattresses (those that have either a foam or air core) have experienced rapid growth in the U.S. bedding market in recent years.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P10_S1	While still a relatively small portion of the total market in units (approximately 10%), these products represent a much larger portion of the total market in dollars (approximately 25%-30%) due to their higher average selling prices.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P10_S2	If sales of foam or air core mattresses continue to grow appreciably, it could reduce our market share in the U.S. bedding market, and negatively impact our sales and earnings.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P10_S3	Our goodwill and other long-lived assets are subject to potential impairment.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P10_S4	A significant portion of our assets consists of goodwill and other long-lived assets, the carrying value of which may be reduced if we determine that those assets are impaired.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P10_S5	At December 31, 2011, goodwill and other intangible assets represented approximately $1.04 billion, or approximately 36% of our total assets.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P10_S6	In addition, net property, plant and equipment and sundry assets totaled approximately $648 million, or approximately 22% of total assets.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P11_S0	We review our ten reporting units for potential goodwill impairment in June as part of our annual goodwill impairment testing, and more often if an event or circumstance occurs making it likely that impairment exists.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P11_S1	In addition, we test for the recoverability of long-lived assets at year end, and more often if an event or circumstance indicates the carrying value may not be recoverable.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P11_S2	We conduct impairment testing based on our current business strategy in light of present industry and economic conditions, as well as future expectations.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P11_S3	The annual goodwill impairment review performed in June 2011 indicated no goodwill impairments, but fair market value for one of our ten reporting units (Fixture Display) only exceeded book value by approximately 15%.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P11_S4	The fair market values of all other reporting units exceeded book value by more than 30%.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P11_S5	The goodwill associated with the Fixture Display reporting unit was $112 million at December 31, 2011.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P12_S0	The unit is dependent upon capital spending by retailers on both new stores and remodeling of existing stores.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P12_S1	Retailer activity was moderately lower in 2011, and the unit did not meet expectations.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P12_S2	If actual performance does not improve and remains at current levels, future goodwill impairments could be possible.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P13_S0	In December 2011, management approved a restructuring plan which primarily related to the closure of four underperforming plants.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P13_S1	This resulted in long-lived asset impairment of $31 million.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P13_S2	Prior to that event, our last material asset impairment occurred in 2007.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P13_S3	If actual results differ from the assumptions and estimates used in the goodwill and long-lived asset calculations, we could incur impairment charges, which could negatively impact our results of operations.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P14_S0	We are exposed to foreign currency risk.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P14_S1	We expect that international sales will continue to represent a significant percentage of our total sales, which exposes us to currency exchange rate fluctuations.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P14_S2	In 2011, 29% of our sales were generated by international operations.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P14_S3	The revenues and expenses of our foreign operations are generally denominated in local currencies; however, certain of our operations experience currency-related gains and losses where sales or purchases are denominated in currencies other than their local currency.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P14_S4	Further, our competitive position may be affected by the relative strength of the currencies in countries where our products are sold.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P14_S5	Foreign currency exchange risks inherent in doing business in foreign countries may have a material adverse effect on our future operations and financial results.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P14_S6	Technology failures or cyber security breaches could have a material adverse effect on our operations.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P15_S0	We rely on information systems to obtain, process, analyze and manage data, as well as to facilitate the manufacture and distribution of inventory to and from our facilities.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P15_S1	We receive, process and ship orders, manage the billing of, and collections from, our customers, and manage the accounting for, and payment to, our vendors.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P15_S2	Security breaches of this infrastructure can create system disruptions or unauthorized disclosure of confidential information.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P15_S3	If this occurs, our operations could be disrupted, or we may suffer financial loss because of lost or misappropriated information.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P15_S4	We cannot be certain that advances in criminal capabilities or new discoveries in the field of cryptography will not compromise our technology protecting information systems.
58492_12_ITEM1A_P15_S5	If these systems are interrupted or damaged by these events or fail for any extended period of time, then our results of operations could be adversely affected.

58492_12_ITEM7_P4_S0	We assess our overall performance by comparing our Total Shareholder Return (TSR), on a rolling three-year basis, to that of peer companies.
58492_12_ITEM7_P4_S1	We target TSR in the top one-third of the S P 500 over the long-term.
58492_12_ITEM7_P4_S2	For the three years ended December 31, 2011, we generated TSR of 21% per year on average.
58492_12_ITEM7_P4_S3	That places us in the top 38% of the S P 500, just shy of our top one-third goal.
58492_12_ITEM7_P4_S4	These topics are discussed in more detail in the sections that follow.
58492_12_ITEM7_P5_S0	INTRODUCTION Total Shareholder Return Total Shareholder Return (TSR), relative to peer companies, is the key financial measure that we use to assess long-term performance.
58492_12_ITEM7_P5_S1	TSR is driven by the change in our share price and the dividends we pay [TSR = (Change in Stock Price + Dividends) / Beginning Stock Price].
58492_12_ITEM7_P5_S2	We seek to achieve TSR in the top one-third of the S P 500 over the long-term through a balanced approach that employs all four TSR sources: revenue growth, margin expansion, dividends, and share repurchases.
58492_12_ITEM7_P6_S0	We monitor our TSR performance (relative to the S P 500) on a rolling three-year basis.
58492_12_ITEM7_P6_S1	For the three-year measurement period that ended December 31, 2011, we generated TSR of 21% per year on average, while the S P 500 index generated average TSR of 14% per year.
58492_12_ITEM7_P6_S2	That places us in the top 38% of the S P 500, just shy of our top one-third goal.
58492_12_ITEM7_P6_S3	Our incentive programs reward return generation.
58492_12_ITEM7_P7_S0	Senior executives participate in a TSR-based incentive program (based on our performance compared to the performance of a group of approximately 320 peers).
58492_12_ITEM7_P8_S0	Business unit bonuses emphasize the achievement of higher returns on the assets under the unit s direct control.
58492_12_ITEM7_P9_S0	Customers We serve a broad suite of customers, with our largest customer representing less than 6% of our sales.
58492_12_ITEM7_P9_S1	Many are companies whose names are widely recognized; they include most manufacturers of furniture and bedding, a variety of other manufacturers, and many major retailers.
58492_12_ITEM7_P9_S2	Major Factors That Impact Our Business Many factors impact our business, but those that generally have the greatest impact are market demand, raw material cost trends, and competition.
58492_12_ITEM7_P10_S0	Market Demand Market demand (including product mix) is impacted by several economic factors, with consumer confidence being most significant.
58492_12_ITEM7_P10_S1	Other important factors include disposable income levels, employment levels, housing turnover, and interest rates.
58492_12_ITEM7_P10_S2	All these factors influence consumer spending on durable goods, and therefore affect demand for our components and products.
58492_12_ITEM7_P10_S3	Some of these factors also influence business spending on facilities and equipment, which impacts approximately one-quarter of our sales.
58492_12_ITEM7_P11_S0	Demand improved in certain of our markets during 2011, with automotive and office furniture leading the way.
58492_12_ITEM7_P11_S1	In contrast, stagnant demand negatively impacted our major residential markets.
58492_12_ITEM7_P11_S2	Many consumers continued to postpone spending on larger-ticket items such as bedding and furniture in the face of ongoing economic weakness.
58492_12_ITEM7_P12_S0	PART II It is our belief that the U.S. economy will face headwinds for longer than we previously expected.
58492_12_ITEM7_P12_S1	We are no longer willing to wait for an economic recovery to bolster earnings, and as a result, we have taken further steps to improve ongoing profitability.
58492_12_ITEM7_P12_S2	We have closed some production facilities and reduced overhead costs.
58492_12_ITEM7_P12_S3	While these activities improve our cost structure, capacity utilization levels in the majority of our operations remain low.
58492_12_ITEM7_P12_S4	Our current productive capacity should readily accommodate sales of over $4 billion (assuming current sales mix).
58492_12_ITEM7_P12_S5	Until our spare capacity is fully utilized, each additional $100 million of sales from incremental unit volume is expected to generate approximately $25 million to $35 million of additional pre-tax earnings.
58492_12_ITEM7_P13_S0	Raw Material Costs In many of our businesses, we enjoy a cost advantage from buying large quantities of raw materials.
58492_12_ITEM7_P13_S1	This purchasing leverage is a benefit that many of our competitors generally do not have.
58492_12_ITEM7_P13_S2	Still, our costs can vary significantly as market prices for raw materials (many of which are commodities) fluctuate.
58492_12_ITEM7_P13_S3	We typically have short-term commitments from our suppliers; accordingly, our raw material costs generally move with the market.
58492_12_ITEM7_P13_S4	Our ability to recover higher costs (through selling price increases) is crucial.
58492_12_ITEM7_P13_S5	When we experience significant increases in raw material costs, we typically implement price increases to recover the higher costs.
58492_12_ITEM7_P13_S6	Conversely, when costs decrease significantly, we generally pass those lower costs through to our customers.
58492_12_ITEM7_P13_S7	The timing of our price increases or decreases is important; we typically experience a lag in recovering higher costs, so we also expect to realize a lag as costs decline.
58492_12_ITEM7_P13_S8	Steel is our principal raw material and at various times in past years we have experienced extreme cost fluctuations in this commodity.
58492_12_ITEM7_P13_S9	In most cases, the major changes (both increases and decreases) were passed through to customers with selling price adjustments.
58492_12_ITEM7_P14_S0	In late 2009 and early 2010, steel costs increased, and we raised our selling prices to recover the majority of the higher costs.
58492_12_ITEM7_P14_S1	By the end of 2010, we were facing further inflation in steel costs, and we implemented additional price increases in early 2011.
58492_12_ITEM7_P14_S2	By mid-year, market prices for certain types of steel had begun to decrease.
58492_12_ITEM7_P14_S3	The margin pressure we experienced in the last half of 2011 resulted in part from lowering our selling prices (selectively) in advance of our average cost of steel declining, in order to maintain market share and minimize deterioration in product mix.
58492_12_ITEM7_P14_S4	As a producer of steel rod, we are also impacted by volatility in metal margins (the difference in the cost of steel scrap and the market price for steel rod).
58492_12_ITEM7_P14_S5	Scrap costs increased in 2010, and while market prices for steel rod also increased, those increases did not keep pace with escalating scrap costs.
58492_12_ITEM7_P14_S6	As a result, metal margins within the steel industry (and in our rod producing operation) were lower during 2010.
58492_12_ITEM7_P14_S7	Scrap costs increased further in early 2011 but market prices for steel rod also increased.
58492_12_ITEM7_P14_S8	Metal margins for the full year 2011 were slightly improved.
58492_12_ITEM7_P14_S9	Our other raw materials include woven and non-woven fabrics, foam scrap, and chemicals.
58492_12_ITEM7_P14_S10	We have experienced changes in the cost of these materials in recent years, and in most years, have been able to pass them through to our customers.
58492_12_ITEM7_P14_S11	In late 2010 these costs began increasing, and in early 2011, we implemented price increases to recover the majority of the higher costs.
58492_12_ITEM7_P15_S0	When we raise our prices to recover higher raw material costs, this sometimes causes customers to modify their product designs and replace higher cost components with lower cost components.
58492_12_ITEM7_P15_S1	We experienced this de-contenting effect in our Residential Furnishings segment in the last half of 2011 (however selective selling price reductions helped contain this activity).
58492_12_ITEM7_P15_S2	As our customers changed the quantity and mix of components in their finished goods to address commodity inflation, our profit margins were negatively impacted.
58492_12_ITEM7_P15_S3	We must continue to find ways to assist our customers in improving the functionality and reducing the cost of their products, while providing higher margin and profit contribution for our operations.
58492_12_ITEM7_P16_S0	Competition Many of our markets are highly competitive with the number of competitors varying by product line.
58492_12_ITEM7_P16_S1	In general, our competitors tend to be smaller, private companies.
58492_12_ITEM7_P16_S2	Many of our competitors, both domestic and foreign, compete primarily on the basis of price.
58492_12_ITEM7_P16_S3	Our success has stemmed from the ability to remain price competitive, while delivering better product quality, innovation, and customer service.
58492_12_ITEM7_P16_S4	We continue to face pressure from foreign competitors as some of our customers source a portion of their components and finished products offshore.
58492_12_ITEM7_P16_S5	In addition to lower labor rates, foreign competitors benefit (at times) from lower raw material costs.
58492_12_ITEM7_P16_S6	They may also benefit from currency factors and more lenient regulatory climates.
58492_12_ITEM7_P17_S0	We typically remain price competitive, even versus many foreign manufacturers, as a result of our highly efficient operations, low labor content, vertical integration in steel and wire, and large scale purchasing of raw materials and commodities.
58492_12_ITEM7_P17_S1	However, we have also reacted to foreign competition in certain cases by selectively adjusting prices, and by developing new proprietary products that help our customers reduce total costs.
58492_12_ITEM7_P17_S2	We experienced a temporary loss of market share during the last half of 2010 as certain of our bedding customers purchased a portion of their innerspring requirements from European suppliers.
58492_12_ITEM7_P17_S3	The opportunity to buy these components at a lower price resulted from a combination of factors: i) the weaker Euro; ii) temporarily lower wire costs; and iii) greater excess capacity as a result of economic turmoil in Europe.
58492_12_ITEM7_P17_S4	By the end of 2010, we had regained the majority of the lost volume.
58492_12_ITEM7_P17_S5	The margin pressure we experienced in the last half of 2011 resulted in part from price competition in other of our businesses as we reduced prices (selectively) to maintain market share in light of depressed industry volume.
58492_12_ITEM7_P18_S0	Premium non-innerspring mattresses (those that have either a foam or air core) have experienced rapid growth in the U.S. bedding market in recent years.
58492_12_ITEM7_P18_S1	While still a relatively small portion of the total market in units (approximately 10%), these products represent a much larger portion of the total market in dollars (approximately 25%-30%) due to their higher average selling prices.
58492_12_ITEM7_P18_S2	We expect these products to continue to grow.
58492_12_ITEM7_P18_S3	Some of our traditional bedding customers are beginning to offer mattresses that combine an innerspring core with top layers comprised of specialty foam and gel.
58492_12_ITEM7_P18_S4	These hybrid products allow our bedding customers to address a consumer preference for the feel of a specialty mattress and the characteristics of an innerspring.
58492_12_ITEM7_P19_S0	In late 2007, we filed an antidumping suit related to innerspring imports from China, South Africa and Vietnam.
58492_12_ITEM7_P20_S0	As a result, we regained market share and performance in our Bedding group improved.
58492_12_ITEM7_P20_S1	The investigations were brought to a favorable conclusion in early 2009.
58492_12_ITEM7_P20_S2	The current antidumping duty rates on innersprings from these countries are significant, ranging from 116% to 234%, and should remain in effect at least until early 2014.
58492_12_ITEM7_P20_S3	Imported innersprings from these countries are now supposed to be sold at fair prices, however the duties on certain innersprings are being evaded by various means including shipping the goods through a third country and falsely identifying the country of origin.
58492_12_ITEM7_P20_S4	Leggett, along with several U.S. manufacturers of products with active antidumping or antidumping/countervailing duty orders, formed a coalition and are working with Members of Congress, the U.S. Department of Commerce, and U.S. Customs and Border Protection to seek stronger enforcement of existing antidumping and/or countervailing duty orders.
58492_12_ITEM7_P21_S0	2011 Restructuring Plan In December 2011, we approved a restructuring plan to reduce our overhead costs and improve ongoing profitability.
58492_12_ITEM7_P22_S0	The activities primarily entailed the closure of four underperforming facilities.
58492_12_ITEM7_P22_S1	We incurred a $37 million pre-tax (largely non-cash) charge in the 4 th quarter of 2011 primarily related to this plan, which included $31 million of long-lived asset impairments and $6 million of other restructuring-related costs.
58492_12_ITEM7_P22_S2	We expect an additional $2 million of restructuring costs in 2012, with these plant closures complete by mid-year.
58492_12_ITEM7_P22_S3	Earnings should benefit in 2012 from the cost savings associated with the 2011 Restructuring Plan and other restructuring activity initiated in the latter part of 2011.
58492_12_ITEM7_P22_S4	Our 2012 forecast anticipates an approximate $15-$20 million pre-tax earnings benefit ($.07-$.10 per share) from these activities.
58492_12_ITEM7_P23_S0	We divested seven businesses as a part of the strategic realignment we announced in late 2007.
58492_12_ITEM7_P23_S1	The bulk of this activity (five of the seven divestitures) was complete by the end of 2008.
58492_12_ITEM7_P23_S2	In 2009, we sold the Coated Fabrics business unit, and in 2010 we divested the Storage Products business unit.
58492_12_ITEM7_P23_S3	Results of operations for these businesses are classified as discontinued operations in our financial statements.
58492_12_ITEM7_P23_S4	For more information about discontinued operations and the divestitures, see Note B to the Consolidated Financial Statements on page 84.

58492_12_ITEM7_P24_S1	The main revenue catalyst was raw material-related price inflation, but currency and a change in sales at our steel mill (from intra-segment to trade) also contributed to the year-over-year increase.
58492_12_ITEM7_P24_S2	Across the remainder of the company as a whole, unit volume was up slightly.
58492_12_ITEM7_P24_S3	Full-year earnings decreased, from $177 million in 2010 to $153 million in 2011 primarily from higher restructuring-related costs.

58492_12_ITEM7_P26_S2	Across the bulk of our businesses, in aggregate, market demand increased slightly.

58492_12_ITEM7_P27_S1	Other factors, including slightly higher unit volume, a lower effective tax rate, and higher selling, administrative, and other costs essentially offset during the year.

58492_12_ITEM7_P28_S1	In our consolidated financials, an adjustment is made at the corporate level (i.e. outside the segments) to convert about 60% of our inventories to the last-in, first-out (LIFO) method.

58492_12_ITEM7_P30_S1	The 2011 consolidated worldwide effective income tax rate of 24.2% was lower than the 28.1% incurred in 2010.
58492_12_ITEM7_P30_S2	Several factors contributed to the reduction, including changes in our mix of earnings among taxing jurisdictions, one-time benefits from tax planning strategies, and tentative agreement reached with the IRS regarding the examination of our 2004 through 2008 tax years.
58492_12_ITEM7_P30_S3	As a result of the tax planning strategies and audit, we recognized tax benefits of $5 million in 2011.
58492_12_ITEM7_P30_S4	This is comparable to a tax benefit realized in 2010 related to the IRS examination in that year of certain tax credit claims, which was substantially offset by incremental taxes from the repatriation of certain foreign earnings in that year.
58492_12_ITEM7_P30_S5	We also experienced other less significant, discrete tax items (both favorable and unfavorable) that substantially offset for the year.
58492_12_ITEM7_P31_S0	Segment Results In the following section we discuss 2011 sales and earnings before interest and taxes (EBIT) for each of our segments.

58492_12_ITEM7_P32_S0	(1) This is the change in sales not attributable to acquisitions or divestitures.
58492_12_ITEM7_P32_S1	These are sales that come from the same plants and facilities that we owned one year earlier.
58492_12_ITEM7_P33_S0	(2) Segment margins are calculated on total sales.
58492_12_ITEM7_P33_S1	Overall company margin is calculated on external sales.
58492_12_ITEM7_P34_S0	Residential Furnishings Residential Furnishings sales increased in 2011, primarily from inflation and currency, which generated little profit.
58492_12_ITEM7_P34_S1	Unit volume in the segment was flat.
58492_12_ITEM7_P34_S2	Demand in most of our residential markets continued to be soft as consumers postponed spending on larger-ticket items such as bedding and furniture in the face of an ongoing weak economy.
58492_12_ITEM7_P34_S3	Full-year unit volumes were essentially flat in our U.S. Spring business but declined in International Spring and Furniture Hardware (from pronounced market weakness mid-year).
58492_12_ITEM7_P34_S4	The only business in the segment that posted meaningful unit growth was our Adjustable Bed business, where unit volumes grew 44% for the full year.
58492_12_ITEM7_P35_S0	PART II EBIT and EBIT margins decreased versus 2010, primarily due to higher restructuring-related costs (of $9 million), less favorable sales mix, inflation, and other operating cost increases.

58492_12_ITEM7_P36_S1	We consolidated four operations in the segment, including two carpet underlay plants, a Canadian spring facility, and a fabric coating business.
58492_12_ITEM7_P36_S2	We expect segment margins to benefit in 2012 from the cost savings associated with these activities.
58492_12_ITEM7_P37_S0	Commercial Fixturing Components Sales decreased in 2011, largely from lower demand in our Store Fixtures business, as some of the large, value-oriented retailers significantly curtailed both new store construction and remodeling activity during the year.
58492_12_ITEM7_P37_S1	In contrast, market demand continued to improve in Office Furniture Components as that business posted strong growth for the full year.
58492_12_ITEM7_P37_S2	EBIT and EBIT margins also decreased versus the prior year, primarily due to lower sales.
58492_12_ITEM7_P37_S3	Our efforts to improve ongoing profitability resulted in the decision late in 2011 to consolidate one of our six remaining store fixture locations.
58492_12_ITEM7_P37_S4	The majority of the sales from this operation will be supplied through two of our remaining facilities.
58492_12_ITEM7_P37_S5	In addition, consistent with our stated plan to continually assess our portfolio and exit non-core businesses, we divested our small, U.K.-based point-of-purchase display operation in January 2012.
58492_12_ITEM7_P37_S6	Industrial Materials 2011 sales increased, reflecting steel-related price inflation and higher trade sales from our steel mill, both of which generated little incremental profit.
58492_12_ITEM7_P37_S7	Full-year unit volumes declined in both Wire Drawing and Steel Tubing, reflecting weak bedding, furniture, and store fixtures end markets.
58492_12_ITEM7_P37_S8	EBIT and EBIT margins decreased versus 2010, mainly from higher restructuring-related costs (of $23 million).
58492_12_ITEM7_P37_S9	EBIT margins also decreased during the year as a result of a change in sales from intra-segment to trade at our steel rod mill.
58492_12_ITEM7_P37_S10	These trade sales have positive earnings contribution in addition to covering overhead costs, and have kept the mill running at full capacity while internal demand for steel rod has been down.
58492_12_ITEM7_P37_S11	However, this sales shift is dilutive to margins since it increases our reported sales while preserving comparable EBIT levels.
58492_12_ITEM7_P38_S0	Restructuring activities in late 2011 involved the closure of two facilities in the segment.
58492_12_ITEM7_P38_S1	We closed one of our six domestic wire drawing operations and consolidated that volume into two of the remaining plants.
58492_12_ITEM7_P38_S2	We also announced the closing of a wire forming operation that was a supplier of coated wire dishwasher racks into the domestic appliance industry.
58492_12_ITEM7_P38_S3	These activities should improve capacity utilization within the segment in 2012 and benefit future earnings and margins.
58492_12_ITEM7_P39_S0	Specialized Products In Specialized Products, sales increased in 2011, primarily reflecting improved demand across the major businesses in the segment.
58492_12_ITEM7_P39_S1	Changes in currency exchange rates also added to year-over-year sales growth.
58492_12_ITEM7_P40_S0	Automotive growth continues to be driven by the recovery in global industry production levels.

58492_12_ITEM7_P57_S0	In this section, we provide details, reflecting both continuing and discontinued operations, about our:
58492_12_ITEM7_P58_S0	Debt position and total capitalization We use cash for the following:
58492_12_ITEM7_P59_S0	Repurchase our stock Our operations provide most of the cash we require, but debt may also be used to fund a portion of our needs.
58492_12_ITEM7_P59_S1	For more than 20 years, our operations have provided more than sufficient cash to fund both capital expenditures and dividend payments.
58492_12_ITEM7_P59_S2	In 2009, we generated the second highest level of cash from operations in our history, at $565 million, which included a significant reduction in working capital as sales contracted.
58492_12_ITEM7_P59_S3	With a slight increase in working capital in 2010 (due to sales growth), operating cash was $363 million.
58492_12_ITEM7_P59_S4	In 2011, cash flow from operations decreased to $329 million, but still readily exceeded our annual requirement for capital expenditures and dividends.
58492_12_ITEM7_P59_S5	We expect 2012 cash flow from operations to again exceed $300 million.
58492_12_ITEM7_P59_S6	We ended 2011 with net debt to net capital of 29%, below the conservative end of our long-term targeted range of 30%-40%.
58492_12_ITEM7_P60_S0	Page 49 presents a table of the calculation of net debt as a percent of net capital at the end of the past two years.
58492_12_ITEM7_P60_S1	Uses of Cash Finance Capital Requirements Improving returns of the existing asset base will continue to be a key focus.
58492_12_ITEM7_P60_S2	However, cash is available to fund selective growth, both internally (through capital expenditures) and externally (through acquisitions).
58492_12_ITEM7_P61_S0	Capital expenditures include investments we make to maintain, modernize, and expand manufacturing capacity.
58492_12_ITEM7_P61_S1	The chart above shows that capital expenditures have been relatively stable in recent years, although well below levels of the previous decade.
58492_12_ITEM7_P61_S2	We expect capital expenditures to approximate $100 million in 2012.
58492_12_ITEM7_P61_S3	In all of our businesses, we continue to invest in the maintenance of facilities and equipment.
58492_12_ITEM7_P61_S4	However, with excess productive capacity across our operations (from continued low demand levels), we have reduced spending on expansion projects.
58492_12_ITEM7_P61_S5	The anticipated increase in 2012 relates primarily to specific new automotive programs that we have been awarded, and that should contribute to earnings and cash flow beginning in 2013.
58492_12_ITEM7_P62_S0	In 2008, we began assigning each Business Unit a specific role (e.g. Grow, Core, Fix, Divest) within our portfolio of businesses.
58492_12_ITEM7_P62_S1	This changed our long-term priorities for allocating capital and reduced capital spending levels.
58492_12_ITEM7_P62_S2	We actively pursue disciplined growth within our Grow business units and earmark expansion capital for these opportunities.
58492_12_ITEM7_P63_S0	Operations designated as Core business units receive capital primarily for productivity enhancements.
58492_12_ITEM7_P64_S0	Our strategic, long-term, 4-5% annual growth objective envisions periodic acquisitions.
58492_12_ITEM7_P64_S1	We are seeking acquisitions within our growth businesses, and are looking for opportunities to enter new, higher growth markets (carefully screened for sustainable competitive advantage).
58492_12_ITEM7_P64_S2	During the past few years, acquisitions were a lower priority as we primarily focused on completing the divestitures and improving margins and returns of our existing businesses.
58492_12_ITEM7_P64_S3	As a result, no significant acquisitions were completed in 2009, 2010, and 2011.
58492_12_ITEM7_P64_S4	We recently turned our focus onto acquisitions and have begun actively soliciting opportunities while maintaining our screening discipline.
58492_12_ITEM7_P64_S5	On December 20, 2011, we announced our plan to purchase, for $188 million, Western Pneumatic Tube, a leading provider to the aerospace industry of integral components for critical aircraft systems.
58492_12_ITEM7_P64_S6	With 2011 sales of $57 million, these operations will constitute a new, stand-alone business unit within our Industrial Materials segment.
58492_12_ITEM7_P64_S7	This acquisition aligns extremely well with our strategy to seek businesses with secure, leading positions in growing, profitable, attractive markets and that make sense to be a part of Leggett Platt.
58492_12_ITEM7_P64_S8	We completed the acquisition on January 12, 2012.
58492_12_ITEM7_P64_S9	Additional details about acquisitions can be found in Note R to the Consolidated Financial Statements on page 115.
58492_12_ITEM7_P65_S0	We expect to continue returning cash to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases.
58492_12_ITEM7_P65_S1	In 2011 we modestly increased the quarterly dividend, to $.28 per share, and extended to 40 years our record of consecutive annual dividend increases, at an average compound growth rate of 14%.
58492_12_ITEM7_P65_S2	Our targeted dividend payout is approximately 50-60% of net earnings, but actual payout has been higher recently and will likely remain above targeted levels in the near term.
58492_12_ITEM7_P65_S3	Maintaining and increasing the dividend remains a high priority.
58492_12_ITEM7_P65_S4	We anticipate spending approximately $160 million on dividends in 2012.
58492_12_ITEM7_P65_S5	Cash from operations has been, and is expected to continue to be, more than sufficient to readily fund both capital expenditures and dividends.
58492_12_ITEM7_P66_S0	During the past three years, we repurchased a total of 27 million shares of our stock (and issued 11 million shares through employee benefit and stock purchase plans), reducing outstanding shares by 11%.
58492_12_ITEM7_P66_S1	In 2011, we repurchased 10 million shares at an average per-share price of $22.86.
58492_12_ITEM7_P66_S2	During the year, we issued 3 million shares through employee benefit plans (including shares that were purchased by employees in lieu of cash compensation).
58492_12_ITEM7_P66_S3	For the past few years, we have made few acquisitions; instead, we used excess cash (including divestiture proceeds) largely to repurchase shares.

58492_12_ITEM7_P66_S5	Although no specific repurchase schedule has been established, we have been authorized by the Board to repurchase up to 10 million shares in 2012.
58492_12_ITEM7_P67_S0	PART II Cash from Operations Cash from operations is our primary source of funds.
58492_12_ITEM7_P67_S1	Earnings and changes in working capital levels are the two broad factors that generally have the greatest impact on our cash from operations.
58492_12_ITEM7_P67_S2	As shown in the chart below (and discussed in the paragraph that follows), most of the variability in cash from operations in recent years has come from changes in working capital.
58492_12_ITEM7_P68_S0	In 2011, cash from operations decreased primarily due to lower earnings.
58492_12_ITEM7_P68_S1	The decrease in 2010 operating cash (versus 2009) was due to the change in working capital levels (as shown in the chart above).
58492_12_ITEM7_P68_S2	Cash from operations in 2009 benefitted from a $186 million reduction in working capital that occurred as a result of the economy-induced sales contraction.
58492_12_ITEM7_P68_S3	The following table presents key working capital measures at the end of the past two years.
58492_12_ITEM7_P69_S0	(1) The accounts receivable ratio represents the days of sales outstanding calculated as: ending net accounts receivable (net sales number of days in the year).
58492_12_ITEM7_P70_S0	(2) The inventory ratio represents days of inventory on hand calculated as: ending net inventory (cost of goods sold number of days in the year).
58492_12_ITEM7_P71_S0	(3) The accounts payable ratio represents the days of payables outstanding calculated as: ending accounts payable (cost of goods sold number of days in the year).
58492_12_ITEM7_P72_S0	Accounts Receivable and Days Sales Outstanding (DSO): The dollar amount of accounts receivable increased from year-end 2010 levels, primarily due to inflation-driven sales increases.
58492_12_ITEM7_P72_S1	We continue to focus on collection efforts to ensure customer accounts are paid on time.
58492_12_ITEM7_P72_S2	As part of our accounts receivable review process, we evaluate individual customers payment histories, financial health, industry prospects, and current macroeconomic events in determining if outstanding amounts are collectible.
58492_12_ITEM7_P72_S3	In 2011, we incurred $9 million of bad debt expense as compared to $7 million in 2010.
58492_12_ITEM7_P72_S4	Changes in the DSO reflected in the table above are consistent with our historical range, and are not indicative of changes in payment trends or credit worthiness of customers.
58492_12_ITEM7_P72_S5	Instead, DSO fluctuates from year to year with normal differences in the timing of sales and cash receipts.
58492_12_ITEM7_P73_S0	Inventory and Days Inventory on Hand (DIO):
58492_12_ITEM7_P74_S0	Although the unit volume of our inventories was down from year-end 2010 levels, the dollar value of inventories increased slightly due to inflation in raw material costs.
58492_12_ITEM7_P74_S1	During 2011, we recognized expense of $10 million associated with obsolete and slow moving inventories; in 2010 this expense totaled $13 million.
58492_12_ITEM7_P74_S2	We do not expect significant changes in customer or industry trends that would materially increase the exposure to inventory obsolescence.
58492_12_ITEM7_P74_S3	Our DIO typically fluctuates within a reasonably narrow range as a result of differences in the timing of sales, production levels, and inventory purchases.
58492_12_ITEM7_P74_S4	Our DIO decreased compared to the prior year due to lower unit volumes of inventory.
58492_12_ITEM7_P74_S5	This improvement reflects a continued focus on optimizing returns and a reduction of inventory in response to persistent demand weakness in certain markets.
58492_12_ITEM7_P75_S0	Accounts Payable and Days Payable Outstanding (DPO): The dollar value of accounts payable increased in 2011 primarily due to inflation in raw material costs.
58492_12_ITEM7_P75_S1	We actively strive to optimize payment terms with our vendors, and over the last few years, have increased our DPO by approximately ten days.
58492_12_ITEM7_P76_S0	Changes in the DPO reflected in the table above are the result of normal fluctuation in our operating activity.
58492_12_ITEM7_P77_S0	Working capital levels vary by segment.
58492_12_ITEM7_P77_S1	The Commercial Fixturing Components segment typically has relatively higher accounts receivable balances due to the longer credit terms required to service certain customers of the Fixture Display group.
58492_12_ITEM7_P77_S2	This business group also generally requires higher inventory investments due to the custom nature of its products, longer manufacturing lead times (in certain cases), and the needs of many customers to receive large volumes of product within short periods of time.
