58492_12_ITEM7_P93_S0	PART II CRITICAL ACCOUNTING POLICIES AND ESTIMATES We prepare our consolidated financial statements in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
58492_12_ITEM7_P93_S1	To do so, we must make estimates and judgments that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues, expenses, and disclosures.
58492_12_ITEM7_P93_S2	If we used different estimates or judgments our financial statements would change, and some of those changes could be significant.
58492_12_ITEM7_P93_S3	Our estimates are frequently based upon historical experience and are considered by management, at the time they are made, to be reasonable and appropriate.
58492_12_ITEM7_P94_S0	Estimates are adjusted for actual events, as they occur.
58492_12_ITEM7_P94_S1	Critical accounting estimates are those that are: a) subject to uncertainty and change, and b) of material impact to our financial statements.
58492_12_ITEM7_P94_S2	Listed below are the estimates and judgments which we believe could have the most significant effect on our financial statements.
58492_12_ITEM7_P94_S3	We provide additional details regarding our significant accounting policies in Note A to the Consolidated Financial Statements on page 79.
58492_12_ITEM7_P95_S0	Goodwill is assessed for impairment annually as of June 30 and as triggering events occur.
58492_12_ITEM7_P95_S1	In the past three years, no impairments have been recorded as a result of the annual impairment reviews.
58492_12_ITEM7_P96_S0	In order to assess goodwill for potential impairment, judgment is required to estimate the fair market value of each reporting unit (which is one level below reportable segments) using the combination of a discounted cash flow model and market approach using price to earnings ratios for comparable publicly traded companies with characteristics similar to the reporting unit.
58492_12_ITEM7_P96_S1	The cash flow model contains uncertainties related to the forecast of future results as many outside economic and competitive factors can influence future performance.
58492_12_ITEM7_P96_S2	Margins, sales levels, and discount rates are the most critical estimates in determining enterprise values using the cash flow model.
58492_12_ITEM7_P97_S0	Fair market values for one of the 10 reporting units (Fixture Display) exceeded book value by approximately 15%.
58492_12_ITEM7_P97_S1	The goodwill associated with this reporting unit is $112 million, and is dependent on capital spending by retailers on both new stores and remodeling of existing stores.
58492_12_ITEM7_P98_S0	Retailer activity was moderately lower in 2011.
58492_12_ITEM7_P98_S1	The Fixture Display reporting unit did not meet expectations for 2011, but is expected to recover to forecasted earnings levels over the next two years.
58492_12_ITEM7_P98_S2	If actual performance does not improve and remains at current levels, future goodwill impairments could be possible.
58492_12_ITEM7_P98_S3	The remaining reporting units have fair market values that exceed carrying value by more than 30%, and have goodwill of $815 million.
58492_12_ITEM7_P99_S0	The market approach requires judgment to determine the appropriate price to earnings ratio.
58492_12_ITEM7_P100_S0	Ratios are derived from comparable publicly-traded companies that operate in the same or similar industry as the reporting unit.
58492_12_ITEM7_P101_S0	Information regarding material assumptions used to determine if a goodwill impairment exists can be found in Note C on page 86.
58492_12_ITEM7_P102_S0	Other long-lived assets are tested for recoverability at year-end and whenever events or circumstances indicate the carrying value may not be recoverable.
58492_12_ITEM7_P102_S1	For other long-lived assets we estimate fair value at the lowest level where cash flows can be measured (usually at a branch level).
58492_12_ITEM7_P103_S0	Impairments of other long-lived assets usually occur when major restructuring activities take place, or we decide to discontinue product lines completely.
58492_12_ITEM7_P103_S1	Our impairment assessments have uncertainties because they require estimates of future cash flows to determine if undiscounted cash flows are sufficient to recover carrying values of these assets.
58492_12_ITEM7_P103_S2	For assets where future cash flows are not expected to recover carrying value, fair value is estimated which requires an estimate of market value based upon asset appraisals for like assets.
58492_12_ITEM7_P104_S0	Impairments were $35 million in 2011, $2 million in 2010, and $3 million in 2009.
58492_12_ITEM7_P104_S1	The 2011 impairments were largely the result of lowered future business expectations at several underperforming locations that resulted in the decision to exit some unprofitable lines of business.
58492_12_ITEM7_P104_S2	Prior forecasts assumed a recovery in business levels (primarily housing related industries) that did not materialize.
58492_12_ITEM7_P105_S0	We have several operations that are dependent on the housing and retail industries that could also experience future impairments if these operations cash flows do not improve from current levels.
58492_12_ITEM7_P106_S0	We reduce the carrying value of inventories to reflect an estimate of net realizable value for obsolete and slow-moving inventory.
58492_12_ITEM7_P107_S0	Our inventory reserve contains uncertainties because the calculation requires management to make assumptions about the value of products that are obsolete or slow-moving (i.e. not selling very quickly).
58492_12_ITEM7_P108_S0	At December 31, 2011, the reserve for obsolete and slow-moving inventory was $39 million (approximately 7% of FIFO inventories).
58492_12_ITEM7_P109_S0	If we have had no sales of a given product for 12 months, those items are generally deemed to have no value and are written down completely.
58492_12_ITEM7_P110_S0	If we have more than a one-year s supply of a product, we value that inventory at net realizable value (what we think we will recover).
58492_12_ITEM7_P111_S0	Changes in customer behavior and requirements can cause inventory to quickly become obsolete or slow moving.
58492_12_ITEM7_P111_S1	The calculation also uses an estimate of the ultimate recoverability of items identified as slow moving based upon historical experience (65% on average).
58492_12_ITEM7_P112_S0	Additions to inventory reserves in 2011 were $10 million, which was comparable to the previous year.
58492_12_ITEM7_P112_S1	These additions in 2011 were incurred generally among all segments and considered to be a normal level of obsolescence.
58492_12_ITEM7_P112_S2	We incurred write-downs of $2 million related to the 2011 restructuring plan.
58492_12_ITEM7_P113_S0	We are substantially self-insured for costs related to workers compensation, and this requires us to estimate the liability associated with this obligation.
58492_12_ITEM7_P114_S0	Our estimates of self-insured reserves contain uncertainties regarding the potential amounts we might have to pay (since we are self-insured).
58492_12_ITEM7_P114_S1	We consider a number of factors, including historical claim experience, demographic factors, and potential recoveries from third party insurance carriers.
58492_12_ITEM7_P115_S0	Over the past five years, we have incurred, on average, $11 million annually for costs associated with workers compensation.
58492_12_ITEM7_P115_S1	Average year-to-year variation over the past five years has been approximately $2 million.
58492_12_ITEM7_P115_S2	At December 31, 2011, we had accrued $37 million to cover future self-insurance liabilities.
58492_12_ITEM7_P116_S0	Internal safety statistics and cost trends have improved in the last several years.
58492_12_ITEM7_P116_S1	We expect worker compensation costs to remain at current lower levels for the foreseeable future.
58492_12_ITEM7_P117_S0	For accounts and notes receivable, we estimate a bad debt reserve for the amount that will ultimately be uncollectible.
58492_12_ITEM7_P117_S1	When we become aware of a specific customer s potential inability to pay, we record a bad debt reserve for the amount we believe may not be collectible.
58492_12_ITEM7_P118_S0	Our bad debt reserve contains uncertainties because it requires management to estimate the amount uncollectible based upon an evaluation of several factors such as the length of time that receivables are past due, the financial health of the customer, industry and macroeconomic considerations, and historical loss experience.
58492_12_ITEM7_P119_S0	A significant change in the financial status of a large customer could impact our estimates.
58492_12_ITEM7_P119_S1	The average annual amount of customer-related credit losses was $11 million (less than 1% of annual net sales) over the last three years.
58492_12_ITEM7_P119_S2	At December 31, 2011, our reserves for doubtful accounts totaled $23 million (about 5% of our accounts and customer-related notes receivable of $467 million).
58492_12_ITEM7_P120_S0	Our customers are diverse and many are small-to-medium sized companies, with some being highly leveraged.
58492_12_ITEM7_P120_S1	Bankruptcy can occur with some of these customers relatively quickly and with little warning.
58492_12_ITEM7_P121_S0	In 2011 and 2010, bad debt expense averaged $8 million, which is a return to more normal levels compared to 2009.
58492_12_ITEM7_P121_S1	We did not experience any significant individual customer bankruptcies during the past two years.
58492_12_ITEM7_P121_S2	We believe the financial health of our major customers is stable, but some are highly leveraged, and this could cause circumstances to change in the future.
58492_12_ITEM7_P121_S3	We recognized an $11 million loss in 2009 related to the Aluminum divestiture note.
58492_12_ITEM7_P121_S4	At December 31, 2011, we had $20 million of non-customer notes outstanding, primarily related to divested businesses, and have recorded reserves of $3 million for these notes.
58492_12_ITEM7_P121_S5	Most of these notes are held by highly leveraged entities, which could result in the need for additional reserves in the future.
58492_12_ITEM7_P122_S0	For our pension plans, we must estimate the cost of benefits to be provided (well into the future) and the current value of those benefit obligations.
58492_12_ITEM7_P123_S0	The pension liability calculation contains uncertainties because it requires management to estimate an appropriate discount rate to calculate the present value of future benefits paid, which also impacts current year pension expense.
58492_12_ITEM7_P124_S0	Determination of pension expense requires an estimate of expected return on pension assets based upon the mix of investments held (bonds and equities).
58492_12_ITEM7_P125_S0	The discount rates used to calculate the pension liability and pension expense for our most significant plans decreased approximately 85 basis points in 2011 due to lower corporate bond yields.
58492_12_ITEM7_P125_S1	Each 25 basis point decrease in the discount rate increases pension expense by $.4 million and increases the plans benefit obligation by $8.3 million.
58492_12_ITEM7_P126_S0	Other assumptions include rates of compensation increases, withdrawal and mortality rates, and retirement ages.
58492_12_ITEM7_P126_S1	These estimates impact the pension expense or income we recognize and our reported benefit obligations.
58492_12_ITEM7_P127_S0	The expected return on assets in 2011 decreased to 6.7%, compared to 6.8% in 2010 and 6.9% in 2009.
58492_12_ITEM7_P127_S1	A 25 basis point reduction in the expected return on assets would increase pension expense by $.5 million, but have no effect on the plans funded status.
58492_12_ITEM7_P128_S0	Assuming a long-term investment horizon, we do not expect a material change to the return on asset assumption.
58492_12_ITEM7_P129_S0	In the ordinary course of business, we must make estimates of the tax treatment of many transactions, even though the ultimate tax outcome may remain uncertain for some time.
58492_12_ITEM7_P129_S1	These estimates become part of the annual income tax expense reported in our financial statements.
58492_12_ITEM7_P129_S2	Subsequent to year end, we finalize our tax analysis and file income tax returns.
58492_12_ITEM7_P129_S3	Tax authorities periodically audit these income tax returns and examine our tax filing positions, including (among other things) the timing and amounts of deductions, and the allocation of income among tax jurisdictions.
58492_12_ITEM7_P130_S0	We adjust income tax expense in our financial statements in the periods in which the actual outcome becomes more certain.
58492_12_ITEM7_P131_S0	Our tax liability for unrecognized tax benefits contains uncertainties because management is required to make assumptions and to apply judgment to estimate the exposures related to our various filing positions.
58492_12_ITEM7_P131_S1	Our effective tax rate is also impacted by changes in tax laws, the current mix of earnings by taxing jurisdiction, and the results of current tax audits and assessments.
58492_12_ITEM7_P132_S0	Potential changes in tax laws could impact assumptions related to the non-repatriation of certain foreign earnings.
58492_12_ITEM7_P132_S1	If all non-repatriated earnings were taxed, we would incur additional taxes of approximately $53 million.
58492_12_ITEM7_P132_S2	Tax audits by various taxing authorities are expected to increase as governments continue to look for ways to raise additional revenue.
58492_12_ITEM7_P132_S3	Based upon past experience, we do not expect any major changes to our tax liability as a result of this increased audit activity; however, we could incur additional tax expense if we have audit adjustments higher than recent historical experience.
58492_12_ITEM7_P133_S0	At December 31, 2011 and 2010, we had $14 million and $13 million, respectively, of net deferred tax assets on our balance sheet related to operating loss and tax credit carryforwards.
58492_12_ITEM7_P133_S1	The ultimate realization of these deferred tax assets is dependent upon the amount, source, and timing of future taxable income.
58492_12_ITEM7_P133_S2	Valuation allowances are established against future potential tax benefits to reflect the amounts we believe have no more than a 50% probability of being realized.
58492_12_ITEM7_P134_S0	In addition, assumptions have been made regarding the non-repatriation of earnings from certain subsidiaries.
58492_12_ITEM7_P134_S1	Those assumptions may change in the future, thereby affecting future period results for the tax impact of possible repatriation.
58492_12_ITEM7_P135_S0	The recovery of net operating losses (NOL s) has been closely evaluated for the likelihood of recovery based upon factors such as the age of losses, viable tax planning strategies, and future taxable earnings expectations.
58492_12_ITEM7_P135_S1	We believe that appropriate valuation allowances have been recorded as necessary.
58492_12_ITEM7_P135_S2	However, if earnings expectations or other assumptions change such that additional valuation allowances are required, we could incur additional tax expense.
58492_12_ITEM7_P136_S0	We evaluate various legal, environmental, and other potential claims against us to determine if an accrual or disclosure of the contingency is appropriate.
58492_12_ITEM7_P136_S1	If it is probable that an ultimate loss will be incurred, we accrue a liability for the reasonable estimate of the ultimate loss.
58492_12_ITEM7_P137_S0	Our disclosure and accrual of loss contingencies (i.e., losses that may or may not occur) contain uncertainties because they are based on our assessment of the likelihood that the expenses will actually occur, and our estimate of the likely cost.
58492_12_ITEM7_P137_S1	Our estimates and judgments are subjective and can involve matters in litigation, the results of which are generally very unpredictable.
58492_12_ITEM7_P138_S0	We have several environmental clean-up activities related to current and closed facilities that mostly involve soil and groundwater contamination.
58492_12_ITEM7_P138_S1	Based upon facts available at this time, we believe reserves are adequate, however cost estimates could change as we determine more about the severity and cost of remediation.
58492_12_ITEM7_P139_S0	Legal contingencies are related to numerous lawsuits and claims described in Note T on page 119.
58492_12_ITEM7_P139_S1	Over the past five years, the largest annual cost for litigation claims was $8 million (excluding legal fees).
58492_12_ITEM7_P140_S0	Historically, actual settlements have been reasonably close to original loss estimates.
58492_12_ITEM7_P141_S0	PART II CONTINGENCIES Our disclosure and accrual of loss contingencies (i.e., losses that may or may not occur) are based on our assessment of the likelihood that the expenses will actually occur, and our estimate of the likely cost.
58492_12_ITEM7_P141_S1	Our estimates and judgments are subjective and can involve matters in litigation, the results of which are generally very unpredictable.
58492_12_ITEM7_P142_S0	NPI Lawsuit On January 18, 2008, National Products, Inc. ( NPI ) sued Gamber-Johnson, LLC ( Gamber ), our wholly-owned subsidiary, in Case C08-0049C-JLR, in the United States District Court, Western District of Washington, alleging that portions of a Gamber marketing video contained false and misleading statements.
58492_12_ITEM7_P142_S1	NPI and Gamber compete in the market for vehicle computer mounting systems.
58492_12_ITEM7_P142_S2	NPI sought: (a) injunctive relief requiring Gamber to stop using the video and to notify customers; (b) damages for its alleged lost profits; and (c) disgorgement of Gamber s profits in an unspecified amount.
58492_12_ITEM7_P142_S3	Although part of the claims were dismissed by the Court before and during trial, a jury, on April 12, 2010, found four statements in the video were false and deliberate and awarded $10 million in disgorgement damages against Gamber.
58492_12_ITEM7_P142_S4	On August 16, 2010, the Court: (a) reduced the jury verdict to approximately $0.5 million; (b) granted NPI attorney fees and costs in an amount to be determined; and (c) granted an injunction requiring Gamber to notify its distributors and resellers of the verdict.
58492_12_ITEM7_P142_S5	The Court subsequently awarded NPI $2.0 million in attorney fees and costs.
58492_12_ITEM7_P143_S0	On September 17, 2010, NPI filed an appeal to the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals.
58492_12_ITEM7_P143_S1	On September 7, 2011, a three judge panel of the Court of Appeals affirmed the trial court s decision.
58492_12_ITEM7_P143_S2	Each party filed a request for rehearing en banc (a rehearing by the full court), which was denied on October 24, 2011.
58492_12_ITEM7_P143_S3	On November 22, 2011, our insurance carrier paid the judgment and attorney fee awards in full (roughly $2.5 million).
58492_12_ITEM7_P144_S0	Shareholder Derivative Lawsuit On August 10, 2010, a shareholder derivative suit was filed by the New England Carpenters Pension Fund in the Circuit Court of Jasper County, Missouri as Case No. 10AO-CC00284 ( 2010 Suit ).
58492_12_ITEM7_P144_S1	The 2010 Suit was substantially similar to a prior suit filed by the same plaintiff, in the same court, on February 5, 2009 ( 2009 Suit ).
58492_12_ITEM7_P144_S2	The 2009 Suit was dismissed without prejudice based on the plaintiff s failure to make demand on our Board and shareholders.
58492_12_ITEM7_P144_S3	As before, the plaintiff did not make such demand.
58492_12_ITEM7_P144_S4	On April 6, 2011, the 2010 Suit was dismissed without prejudice.
58492_12_ITEM7_P145_S0	On May 12, 2011, the plaintiff filed an appeal to the Missouri Court of Appeals.
58492_12_ITEM7_P145_S1	The briefing process began January 2012.
58492_12_ITEM7_P145_S2	We do not expect a ruling from the Court of Appeals for several months.
58492_12_ITEM7_P145_S3	The 2010 Suit was purportedly brought on our behalf, naming us as a nominal defendant, and certain current and former officers and directors as individual defendants including David S. Haffner, Karl G. Glassman, Matthew C. Flanigan, Ernest C. Jett, Harry M. Cornell, Jr., Felix E. Wright, Robert Ted Enloe, III, Richard T. Fisher, Judy C. Odom, Maurice E. Purnell, Jr., Ralph W. Clark and Michael A. Glauber.
58492_12_ITEM7_P146_S0	The plaintiff alleged, among other things, that the individual defendants: breached their fiduciary duties; backdated and received backdated stock options violating our stock plans; caused or allowed us to issue false and misleading financial statements and proxy statements; sold our stock while possessing material non-public information; committed gross mismanagement; wasted corporate assets; committed fraud; violated the Missouri Securities Act; and were unjustly enriched.
58492_12_ITEM7_P146_S1	The plaintiff was seeking, among other things: unspecified monetary damages against the individual defendants; certain equitable and other relief relating to the profits from the alleged improper conduct; the adoption of certain corporate governance proposals; the imposition of a constructive trust over the defendants stock options and proceeds; punitive damages; the rescission of certain unexercised options; and the reimbursement of litigation costs.
58492_12_ITEM7_P146_S2	The plaintiff was not seeking monetary relief from us.
58492_12_ITEM7_P147_S0	We have director and officer liability insurance in force subject to customary limits and exclusions.
58492_12_ITEM7_P147_S1	We and the individual defendants filed motions to dismiss the 2010 Suit in late October 2010, asserting: the plaintiff failed to make demand on our Board and shareholders as required by Missouri law, and, consistent with the Court s ruling in the 2009 Suit, this failure to make demand should not be excused; the plaintiff is not a representative shareholder; the 2010 Suit was based on a statistical analysis of stock option grants and our stock prices that we believe was flawed; the plaintiff failed to state a substantive claim; the common law fraud claim was not pled with sufficient particularity; and the statute of limitations has expired on the fraud claim and all the alleged challenged grants except the December 30, 2005 grant.
58492_12_ITEM7_P147_S2	As to this grant, the motions to dismiss advised the Court that it was made under our Deferred Compensation Program, which (i) provided that options would be dated on the last business day of December, and (ii) was filed with the SEC on December 2, 2005 setting out the pricing mechanism well before the grant date.
58492_12_ITEM7_P147_S3	We do not expect that the outcome of this matter will have a material adverse effect on our financial condition, operating cash flows or results of operations.

58492_12_ITEM7_P148_S1	A number of these lawsuits have been voluntarily dismissed without prejudice.

58492_12_ITEM7_P150_S1	In the U.S. actions, the plaintiffs, on behalf of themselves and/or a class of purchasers, seek three times the amount of unspecified damages allegedly suffered as a result of alleged overcharges in the price of polyurethane foam products from at least 1999 to the present.
58492_12_ITEM7_P150_S2	Each plaintiff also seeks attorney fees, pre-judgment and post-judgment interest, court costs, and injunctive relief against future violations.
58492_12_ITEM7_P151_S0	On April 15 and May 6, 2011, we filed motions to dismiss the U.S. direct purchaser and indirect purchaser class actions in the consolidated case in Ohio, for failure to state a legally valid claim.

58492_12_ITEM7_P152_S0	Discovery is underway in the U.S. actions.
58492_12_ITEM7_P152_S1	Limited and Hickory Springs Manufacturing Company, et.al.

58492_12_ITEM7_P153_S0	In each of the Canadian cases, the plaintiffs, on behalf of themselves and/or a class of purchasers, seek from over 15 defendants restitution of the amount allegedly overcharged, general and special damages in the amount of $100 million, punitive damages of $10 million, pre-judgment and post-judgment interest, and the costs of the action.

58492_12_ITEM7_P155_S0	Brazilian Value-Added Tax Matters On December 22, 2011, the Brazilian Finance Ministry, Federal Revenue Office issued a notice of violation against our wholly-owned subsidiary, Leggett Platt do Brasil Ltda.
58492_12_ITEM7_P155_S1	( L P Brazil ) in the amount of approximately $4 million, under Case No. 10855.724660/2011-43.
58492_12_ITEM7_P156_S0	The Brazilian Revenue Office claimed that for the period beginning November 2006 and continuing through December 2007, L P Brazil used an incorrect tax rate for the collection and payment of value-added tax primarily on the sale of mattress innersprings in Brazil.
58492_12_ITEM7_P156_S1	The Brazilian Revenue Office has communicated that it will likely expand the audit to the tax years 2008 through January 2011.
58492_12_ITEM7_P156_S2	As a result, it is possible that we may receive an additional notice of violation on the same subject matter.
58492_12_ITEM7_P156_S3	L P Brazil responded to the notice of violation on January 25, 2012 denying the violation.
58492_12_ITEM7_P157_S0	L P Brazil is also party to a proceeding involving the State of Sao Paulo, Brazil where the State of Sao Paulo, on April 16, 2009, issued a Notice of Tax Assessment and Imposition of Fine to L P Brazil seeking approximately $3.3 million for the tax years 2006 and 2007.
58492_12_ITEM7_P157_S1	The State of Sao Paulo argued that L P Brazil was using an incorrect tax rate for the collection and payment of value-added tax on mattress innerspring sales in the State of Sao Paulo.
58492_12_ITEM7_P157_S2	On September 29, 2010, the Court of Tax and Fees of the State of Sao Paulo ruled in favor of L P Brazil nullifying the tax assessment.
58492_12_ITEM7_P157_S3	The State filed an appeal, which is currently pending.
58492_12_ITEM7_P158_S0	We deny all of the allegations in these actions.
58492_12_ITEM7_P158_S1	We believe that we have valid bases upon which to contest such actions and will vigorously defend ourselves.
58492_12_ITEM7_P158_S2	However, these contingencies are subject to many uncertainties.
58492_12_ITEM7_P158_S3	At this time, we do not believe it is probable that this matter will have a material adverse effect on our financial condition, operating cash flows or results of operations.
58492_12_ITEM7_P159_S0	Patent Infringement Claim On January 24, 2012, in a case in the United States District Court for the Central District of California, the jury entered a verdict against us in the amount of $5 million based upon an allegation by plaintiff that we infringed three patents on an automatic stapling machine and on methods used to assemble box springs.
58492_12_ITEM7_P159_S1	This action was originally filed on October 4, 2010, as case number CV10-07416 RGK (SSx) under the caption Imaginal Systematic, LLC v. Leggett Platt, Incorporated; Simmons Bedding Company; and Does 1 through 10, inclusive.
58492_12_ITEM7_P159_S2	Leggett is contractually obligated to defend and indemnify Simmons Bedding Company against a claim for infringement.
58492_12_ITEM7_P159_S3	At trial, the plaintiff alleged damages of $16.2 million.
58492_12_ITEM7_P159_S4	We disputed each patent s validity; the methodology used to calculate damages; and denied that we infringed any patent.
58492_12_ITEM7_P159_S5	The plaintiff has also requested pre-judgment interest and royalties for future use of the machines and attorneys fees and costs.
58492_12_ITEM7_P159_S6	We intend to object to all of these claims.
58492_12_ITEM7_P159_S7	We intend to appeal the case to the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals and believe we have valid bases upon which to appeal.
58492_12_ITEM7_P159_S8	We do not believe that it is probable that the judgment will be upheld on appeal in its current form.
58492_12_ITEM7_P159_S9	We also filed reexamination proceedings in the Patent Office (Case Nos. 95/001,543 filed February 11, 2011; 95/001,546 and 95/001,547 filed February 16, 2011) challenging the validity of each patent at issue.
58492_12_ITEM7_P159_S10	The Patent Office ruled in our favor on the pertinent claims of two of the three patents.
58492_12_ITEM7_P159_S11	With respect to the third patent, we intend to appeal the Patent Office s decision upholding validity; however, due to a change made to all of the machines we do not believe that the machines are currently using the feature alleged to have infringed the third patent.
58492_12_ITEM7_P159_S12	At this time, we do not believe it is probable that this matter will have a material adverse effect on our financial condition, operating cash flows or results of operations.

58492_12_ITEM9B_P0_S0	Directors, Executive Officers and Corporate Governance.
58492_12_ITEM9B_P0_S1	The subsections entitled Proposal 1 Election of Directors, Corporate Governance, Board and Committee Composition and Meetings, Consideration of Director Nominees and Diversity, Section 16(a) Beneficial Ownership Reporting Compliance and Director Independence in the Company s definitive Proxy Statement for the Company s Annual Meeting of Shareholders to be held on May 10, 2012, are incorporated by reference.
58492_12_ITEM9B_P1_S0	Directors of the Company Directors are elected annually at the Annual Meeting of Shareholders and hold office until the next annual meeting of shareholders or until their successors are elected and qualified.
58492_12_ITEM9B_P1_S1	All current directors have been nominated for re-election at the Company s Annual Meeting of Shareholders to be held May 10, 2012.
58492_12_ITEM9B_P1_S2	If a nominee fails to receive a majority of the votes cast in the director election, the Nominating Corporate Governance Committee (N CG Committee) will make a recommendation to the Board of Directors whether to accept or reject the director s resignation and whether any other action should be taken.
58492_12_ITEM9B_P1_S3	If a director s resignation is not accepted, that director will continue to serve until the Company s next annual meeting and his or her successor is duly elected and qualified.
58492_12_ITEM9B_P1_S4	If the Board accepts the director s resignation, it may, in its sole discretion, either fill the resulting vacancy or decrease the size of the Board to eliminate the vacancy.
58492_12_ITEM9B_P1_S5	The Company s Bylaws and Corporate Governance Guidelines set the director retirement age at 72; however, the Board Chair, CEO or President may request a waiver for any director.
58492_12_ITEM9B_P1_S6	so they may stand for re-election at the 2012 annual meeting.

58492_12_ITEM15_P3_S0	Management s Annual Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting Management of Leggett Platt, Incorporated is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting as defined in Exchange Act Rule 13a-15(f).
58492_12_ITEM15_P3_S1	Leggett Platt s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
58492_12_ITEM15_P3_S2	The Company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that:
58492_12_ITEM15_P4_S0	Provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use or disposition of Leggett Platt assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
58492_12_ITEM15_P4_S1	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
58492_12_ITEM15_P4_S2	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
58492_12_ITEM15_P5_S0	Under the supervision and with the participation of management (including ourselves), we conducted an evaluation of the effectiveness of Leggett Platt s internal control over financial reporting, as of December 31, 2011, based on the criteria in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.
58492_12_ITEM15_P5_S1	Based on the evaluation under this framework, we concluded that Leggett Platt s internal control over financial reporting was effective as of December 31, 2011.

58492_12_ITEM15_P16_S0	December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009 A Summary of Significant Accounting Policies PRINCIPLES OF CONSOLIDATION:
58492_12_ITEM15_P17_S0	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of Leggett Platt, Incorporated and its majority-owned subsidiaries ( we or our ).
58492_12_ITEM15_P18_S0	Prior to 2010, many subsidiaries outside of the United States were consolidated as of and for a fiscal year ended November 30.
58492_12_ITEM15_P18_S1	As of December 31, 2010, these subsidiaries converted to a calendar reporting year.
58492_12_ITEM15_P18_S2	The net impact of the change in fiscal years of these subsidiaries was immaterial, and is presented as an adjustment to January 1, 2010 retained earnings.
58492_12_ITEM15_P18_S3	Management does not expect foreign exchange restrictions to significantly impact the ultimate realization of amounts consolidated in the accompanying financial statements for subsidiaries located outside the United States.
58492_12_ITEM15_P19_S0	All intercompany transactions and accounts have been eliminated in consolidation.
58492_12_ITEM15_P20_S0	ESTIMATES: The preparation of financial statements in conformity with generally accepted accounting principles requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses and the disclosure of contingencies.
58492_12_ITEM15_P21_S0	Legal costs are accrued when a loss is probable and reasonably estimable.
58492_12_ITEM15_P21_S1	If a range of outcomes are possible, the most likely outcome is used to accrue these costs.
58492_12_ITEM15_P22_S0	Any insurance recovery is recorded separately if it is determined that a recovery is probable.
58492_12_ITEM15_P22_S1	Legal fees are accrued when incurred.
58492_12_ITEM15_P22_S2	Actual results could differ from those estimates.
58492_12_ITEM15_P23_S0	CASH EQUIVALENTS: Cash equivalents include cash in excess of daily requirements which is invested in various financial instruments with original maturities of three months or less.
58492_12_ITEM15_P23_S1	ACCOUNTS AND OTHER RECEIVABLES AND ALLOWANCE FOR DOUBTFUL ACCOUNTS: Trade accounts receivable are recorded at the invoiced amount and generally do not bear interest.
58492_12_ITEM15_P23_S2	Credit is also occasionally extended in the form of a trade note receivable to facilitate our customers operating cycles.
58492_12_ITEM15_P23_S3	Nontrade notes receivable are established in special circumstances, such as in partial payment for the sale of a business.
58492_12_ITEM15_P23_S4	Notes receivable generally bear interest at market rates commensurate with the corresponding credit risk on the date of origination.
58492_12_ITEM15_P24_S0	The allowance for doubtful accounts is an estimate of the amount of probable credit losses.
58492_12_ITEM15_P24_S1	Interest income is not recognized for accounts that are placed on nonaccrual status.
58492_12_ITEM15_P25_S0	Allowances and nonaccrual status designations are determined by individual account reviews by management, and are based on several factors such as the length of time that receivables are past due, the financial health of the companies involved, industry and macroeconomic considerations, and historical loss experience.
58492_12_ITEM15_P26_S0	Interest income is recorded on the date of cash receipt for nonaccrual status accounts.
58492_12_ITEM15_P26_S1	Account balances are charged off against the allowance when it is probable the receivable will not be recovered.
58492_12_ITEM15_P27_S0	All inventories are stated at the lower of cost or market.
58492_12_ITEM15_P27_S1	We generally use standard costs which include materials, labor and production overhead at normal production capacity.
58492_12_ITEM15_P27_S2	The cost for approximately 60% of our inventories is determined by the last-in, first-out (LIFO) method and is primarily used to value domestic inventories with raw material content consisting of steel, wire, chemicals and foam scrap.
58492_12_ITEM15_P27_S3	For the remainder of the inventories, we principally use the first-in, first-out (FIFO) method, which is representative of our standard costs.
58492_12_ITEM15_P27_S4	For these inventories, the FIFO cost for the periods presented approximated expected replacement cost.
58492_12_ITEM15_P28_S0	Inventories are reviewed at least quarterly for slow-moving and potentially obsolete items using actual inventory turnover, and if necessary, are written down to estimated net realizable value.
58492_12_ITEM15_P28_S1	Reserves for slow-moving and obsolete inventory on a FIFO basis were as follows:
58492_12_ITEM15_P29_S0	A business is classified as a discontinued operation when (i) the operations and cash flows of the business can be clearly distinguished and have been or will be eliminated from our ongoing operations; (ii) the business has either been disposed of or is classified as held for sale; and (iii) we will not have any significant continuing involvement in the operations of the business after the disposal transactions.
58492_12_ITEM15_P29_S1	Significant judgments are involved in determining whether a business meets the criteria for discontinued operations reporting and the period in which these criteria are met.
58492_12_ITEM15_P29_S2	If a business is reported as a discontinued operation, the results of operations through the date of sale, including any gain or loss recognized on the disposition, are presented on a separate line of the income statement.
58492_12_ITEM15_P29_S3	Interest on debt directly attributable to the discontinued operation is allocated to discontinued operations.
58492_12_ITEM15_P29_S4	Gains and losses related to the sale of businesses that do not meet the discontinued operation criteria are reported in continuing operations and separately disclosed if significant.
58492_12_ITEM15_P30_S0	Assets Held for Sale An asset or business is classified as held for sale when (i) management commits to a plan to sell and it is actively marketed; (ii) it is available for immediate sale and the sale is expected to be completed within one year; and (iii) it is unlikely significant changes to the plan will be made or that the plan will be withdrawn.
58492_12_ITEM15_P30_S1	In isolated instances, assets held for sale may exceed one year due to events or circumstances beyond our control.
58492_12_ITEM15_P31_S0	Upon being classified as held for sale, the recoverability of the carrying value must be assessed.
58492_12_ITEM15_P31_S1	Evaluating the recoverability of the assets of a business classified as held for sale follows a defined order in which property and intangible assets subject to amortization are considered only after the recoverability of goodwill and other assets are assessed.
58492_12_ITEM15_P31_S2	After the valuation process is completed, the assets held for sale are reported at the lower of the carrying value or fair value less cost to sell, and the assets are no longer depreciated or amortized.
58492_12_ITEM15_P31_S3	An impairment charge is recognized if the carrying value exceeds the fair value.
58492_12_ITEM15_P32_S0	The assets and related liabilities are aggregated and reported on separate lines of the balance sheet.
58492_12_ITEM15_P33_S0	If a decision to dispose of an asset or a business is made and the held for sale criteria are not met, it is considered held for use.
58492_12_ITEM15_P34_S0	Assets of the business are evaluated for recoverability in the following order: (i) assets other than goodwill, property and intangibles; (ii) property and intangibles subject to amortization; and (iii) goodwill.
58492_12_ITEM15_P35_S0	In evaluating the recoverability of property and intangible assets subject to amortization, in a held for use business, the carrying value is first compared to the sum of the undiscounted cash flows expected to result from the use and eventual disposition.
58492_12_ITEM15_P35_S1	If the carrying value exceeds the undiscounted expected cash flows, then a fair value analysis is performed.
58492_12_ITEM15_P35_S2	An impairment charge is recognized if the carrying value exceeds the fair value.
58492_12_ITEM15_P36_S0	PROPERTY, PLANT AND EQUIPMENT: Property, plant and equipment is stated at cost, less accumulated depreciation.
58492_12_ITEM15_P36_S1	Assets are depreciated by the straight-line method and salvage value, if any, is assumed to be minimal.
58492_12_ITEM15_P37_S0	The table below presents the depreciation periods of the estimated useful lives of our property, plant and equipment.
58492_12_ITEM15_P38_S0	Accelerated methods are used for tax purposes.
58492_12_ITEM15_P39_S0	Property is tested for recoverability at year end and whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that its carrying value may not be recoverable as discussed above.
58492_12_ITEM15_P39_S1	Goodwill results from the acquisition of existing businesses and is not amortized; it is assessed for impairment annually and as triggering events may occur.
58492_12_ITEM15_P39_S2	We perform our annual review in the second quarter of each year.
58492_12_ITEM15_P40_S0	Recoverability of goodwill is evaluated using a two-step process.
58492_12_ITEM15_P41_S0	The first step involves a comparison of the fair value of a reporting unit with its carrying value.
58492_12_ITEM15_P42_S0	Reporting units are business groups one level below the operating segment level for which discrete financial information is available and reviewed by segment management.
58492_12_ITEM15_P43_S0	If the carrying value of the group exceeds its fair value, the second step of the process is necessary and involves a comparison of the implied fair value and the carrying value of the goodwill of that group.
58492_12_ITEM15_P43_S1	If the carrying value of the goodwill of a group exceeds the implied fair value of that goodwill, an impairment loss is recognized in an amount equal to the excess.
58492_12_ITEM15_P44_S0	In evaluating the recoverability of goodwill, it is necessary to estimate the fair values of the business groups.
58492_12_ITEM15_P44_S1	In making this assessment, we estimate the fair market values of our reporting units using a discounted cash flow model and comparable market values for similar entities using price-to-earnings ratios.
58492_12_ITEM15_P44_S2	Key assumptions and estimates used in the cash flow model include discount rate, internal sales growth, margins, capital expenditure requirements, and working capital requirements.
58492_12_ITEM15_P44_S3	Recent performance of the group is an important factor, but not the only factor, in our assessment.
58492_12_ITEM15_P45_S0	There are inherent assumptions and judgments required in the analysis of goodwill impairment.
58492_12_ITEM15_P45_S1	It is possible that assumptions underlying the impairment analysis will change in such a manner that impairment in value may occur in the future.
58492_12_ITEM15_P45_S2	Substantially all other intangible assets are amortized using the straight-line method over their estimated useful lives and are evaluated for impairment using a process similar to that used in evaluating the recoverability of property, plant and equipment.
58492_12_ITEM15_P46_S0	The cost of employee services received in exchange for all equity awards granted is based on the fair market value of the award as of the grant date.
58492_12_ITEM15_P46_S1	Expense is recognized net of an estimated forfeiture rate using the straight line method over the vesting period of the award.
58492_12_ITEM15_P47_S0	We recognize sales when title and risk of loss pass to the customer.
58492_12_ITEM15_P47_S1	The terms of our sales are split approximately evenly between FOB shipping point and FOB destination.
58492_12_ITEM15_P47_S2	The timing of our recognition of FOB destination sales is determined based on shipping date and distance to the destination.
58492_12_ITEM15_P47_S3	We have no significant or unusual price protection, right of return or acceptance provisions with our customers nor is it our practice to replace goods damaged or lost in transit.
58492_12_ITEM15_P48_S0	Sales allowances, discounts and rebates can be reasonably estimated throughout the period and are deducted from sales in arriving at net sales.
58492_12_ITEM15_P49_S0	SHIPPING AND HANDLING FEES AND COSTS: Shipping and handling costs are included as a component of Cost of goods sold.
58492_12_ITEM15_P49_S1	RESTRUCTURING COSTS: Restructuring costs are items such as employee termination, contract termination, plant closure and asset relocation costs related to exit activities.
58492_12_ITEM15_P49_S2	Restructuring-related items are inventory writedowns and gains or losses from sales of assets recorded as the result of exit activities.
58492_12_ITEM15_P50_S0	We recognize a liability for costs associated with an exit or disposal activity when the liability is incurred.
58492_12_ITEM15_P51_S0	Certain termination benefits for which employees are required to render service are recognized ratably over the respective future service periods.
58492_12_ITEM15_P52_S0	The provision for income taxes is determined using the asset and liability approach of accounting for income taxes.
58492_12_ITEM15_P52_S1	Under this approach, deferred taxes represent the future tax consequences expected to occur when the reported amounts of assets and liabilities are recovered or paid.
58492_12_ITEM15_P53_S0	The provision for income taxes represents income taxes paid or payable for the current year plus the change in deferred taxes during the year.
58492_12_ITEM15_P53_S1	Deferred taxes result from differences between the financial and tax basis of our assets and liabilities and are adjusted for changes in tax rates and laws, as appropriate.
58492_12_ITEM15_P53_S2	A valuation allowance is provided to reduce deferred tax assets when management cannot conclude that it is more likely than not that a tax benefit will be realized.
58492_12_ITEM15_P54_S0	A provision is also made for incremental taxes on undistributed earnings of foreign subsidiaries and related companies to the extent that such earnings are not deemed to be indefinitely invested.
58492_12_ITEM15_P55_S0	The calculation of our U.S., state, and foreign tax liabilities involves dealing with uncertainties in the application of complex global tax laws.
58492_12_ITEM15_P55_S1	We recognize potential liabilities for anticipated tax issues which might arise in the U.S. and other tax jurisdictions based on management s estimate of whether, and the extent to which, additional taxes will be due.
58492_12_ITEM15_P55_S2	If payment of these amounts ultimately proves to be unnecessary, the reversal of the liabilities would result in tax benefits being recognized in the period when we determine the liabilities are no longer necessary.
58492_12_ITEM15_P55_S3	Conversely, if the estimate of tax liabilities proves to be less than the ultimate tax assessment, a further charge to tax expense would result.
58492_12_ITEM15_P56_S0	CONCENTRATION OF CREDIT RISKS, EXPOSURES AND FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS: We manufacture, market, and distribute engineered products for the various end markets described in Note F.
58492_12_ITEM15_P56_S1	Our operations are principally located in the United States, although we also have operations in Europe, China, Canada, Mexico and other various countries.
58492_12_ITEM15_P56_S2	We maintain allowances for potential credit losses.
58492_12_ITEM15_P56_S3	We perform ongoing credit evaluations of our customers financial conditions and generally require no collateral from our customers, some of which are highly leveraged.
58492_12_ITEM15_P56_S4	Management also monitors the financial condition and status of noncustomer receivables.
58492_12_ITEM15_P57_S0	Noncustomer receivables primarily consist of notes accepted as partial payment for the divestiture of a business.
58492_12_ITEM15_P57_S1	Some of these companies are highly leveraged and the notes are not fully collateralized.
58492_12_ITEM15_P58_S0	We have no material guarantees or liabilities for product warranties which require disclosure.
58492_12_ITEM15_P58_S1	From time to time, we will enter into contracts to hedge foreign currency denominated transactions, natural gas purchases, and interest rates related to our debt.
58492_12_ITEM15_P59_S0	To minimize the risk of counterparty default, only highly-rated financial institutions that meet certain requirements are used.
58492_12_ITEM15_P59_S1	We do not anticipate that any of the financial institution counterparties will default on their obligations.
58492_12_ITEM15_P60_S0	The carrying value of cash and short-term financial instruments approximates fair value due to the short maturity of those instruments.
58492_12_ITEM15_P61_S0	Although we obtain insurance for workers compensation, automobile, product and general liability, property loss and medical claims, we have elected to retain a significant portion of expected losses through the use of deductibles.
58492_12_ITEM15_P62_S0	Provisions for losses are recorded based upon estimates of the aggregate liability for claims incurred utilizing our prior experience and information provided by our third-party administrators and insurance carriers.
58492_12_ITEM15_P63_S0	DERIVATIVE FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS: We utilize derivative financial instruments to manage market and financial risks related to interest rates, foreign currency and commodities.
58492_12_ITEM15_P63_S1	We seek to use derivative contracts that qualify for hedge accounting treatment; however some instruments that economically manage currency risk may not qualify for hedge accounting treatment.
58492_12_ITEM15_P63_S2	It is our policy not to speculate using derivative instruments.
58492_12_ITEM15_P63_S3	Under hedge accounting, we formally document our hedge relationships, including identification of the hedging instruments and the hedged items, as well as our risk management objectives and strategies for entering into the hedge transaction.
58492_12_ITEM15_P63_S4	The process includes designating derivative instruments as hedges of specific assets, liabilities, firm commitments or forecasted transactions.
58492_12_ITEM15_P63_S5	We also formally assess both at inception and on a quarterly basis thereafter, whether the derivatives used in hedging transactions are highly effective in offsetting changes in either the fair value or cash flows of the hedged item.
58492_12_ITEM15_P63_S6	If it is determined that a derivative ceases to be highly effective, deferred gains or losses are recorded in the Consolidated Statements of Operations.
58492_12_ITEM15_P63_S7	Derivatives are recorded in the Consolidated Balance Sheets at fair value in Other current or Sundry assets or Other current or Other long-term liabilities.
58492_12_ITEM15_P64_S0	The hedge of a forecasted transaction or of the variability of cash flows to be received or paid related to a recognized asset or liability or anticipated transaction is designated as a cash flow hedge.
58492_12_ITEM15_P65_S0	The effective portion of the change in fair value is recorded in accumulated other comprehensive income.
58492_12_ITEM15_P65_S1	When the hedged item impacts the income statement, the gain or loss included in other comprehensive income is reported on the same line of the Consolidated Statements of Operations as the hedged item to match the gain or loss on the derivative to the gain or loss on the hedged item.
58492_12_ITEM15_P65_S2	Any ineffective portion of the changes in the fair value is immediately reported in the Consolidated Statements of Operations on the same line as the hedged item.
58492_12_ITEM15_P66_S0	Cash flow hedges are presented as operating cash flows when the contracts are settled.
58492_12_ITEM15_P67_S0	The hedge of a recognized asset or liability or an unrecognized firm commitment is designated as a fair value hedge.
58492_12_ITEM15_P67_S1	For fair value hedges, both the effective and ineffective portions of the changes in fair value of the derivative, along with the gain or loss on the hedged item that is attributable to the hedged risk, are recorded in earnings and reported in the Consolidated Statements of Operations on the same line as the hedged item.
58492_12_ITEM15_P68_S0	Fair value hedges are presented as operating cash flows when the contracts are settled.
58492_12_ITEM15_P69_S0	The hedge of a net investment in a foreign operation is designated as a net investment hedge.
58492_12_ITEM15_P69_S1	The effective portion of the change in the fair value of derivatives, based upon spot rates, used as a net investment hedge of a foreign operation is recorded in other comprehensive income on the Consolidated Statements of Changes in Equity.
58492_12_ITEM15_P69_S2	Any ineffective portion of the change in the fair value of an instrument designated as a net investment hedge is recorded as Other expense (income), net in the Consolidated Statements of Operations.
58492_12_ITEM15_P70_S0	Net investment hedges are presented as investing cash flows when the contracts are settled.
58492_12_ITEM15_P71_S0	The functional currency for most foreign operations is the local currency.
58492_12_ITEM15_P71_S1	The translation of foreign currencies into U.S. dollars is performed for balance sheet accounts using current exchange rates in effect at the balance sheet date and for income and expense accounts using monthly average exchange rates.
58492_12_ITEM15_P71_S2	The cumulative effects of translating the functional currencies into the U.S. dollar are included in comprehensive income.

58492_12_ITEM15_P73_S0	In the Consolidated Balance Sheets and Footnote I Non-current assets held for sale have been consolidated into Sundry assets, as all material divestiture activity is complete.

58492_12_ITEM15_P74_S1	Activities related to the acquisition of noncontrolling interest and excess tax benefits from stock-based compensation previously included in the Other line item within Financing Activities are now presented separately.

58492_12_ITEM15_P85_S5	Goodwill Goodwill is required to be tested for impairment at least once a year or as triggering events may occur.
58492_12_ITEM15_P85_S6	We perform our annual goodwill impairment review in the second quarter of each year as discussed in Note A. Fair value of reporting units is determined using a combination of two valuation methods: a market approach and an income approach with each method given equal weight in determining the fair value assigned to each reporting unit.
58492_12_ITEM15_P85_S7	Absent an indication of fair value from a potential buyer or similar specific transaction, we believe that the use of these two methods provides a reasonable estimate of a reporting unit s fair value.
58492_12_ITEM15_P85_S8	Assumptions common to both methods are operating plans and economic projections, which are used to project future revenues, earnings, and after-tax cash flows for each reporting unit.
58492_12_ITEM15_P85_S9	These assumptions are applied consistently for both methods.
58492_12_ITEM15_P86_S0	The market approach estimates fair value by first determining price to-earnings ratios for comparable publicly-traded companies with similar characteristics of the reporting unit.
58492_12_ITEM15_P86_S1	The price-to-earnings ratio for comparable companies is based upon current enterprise value compared to projected earnings for the next two years.
58492_12_ITEM15_P86_S2	The enterprise value is based upon current market capitalization and includes a 25% control premium.
58492_12_ITEM15_P86_S3	Projected earnings are based upon market analysts projections.
58492_12_ITEM15_P86_S4	The earnings ratios are applied to the projected earnings of the comparable reporting unit to estimate fair value.
58492_12_ITEM15_P86_S5	Management believes this approach is appropriate because it provides a fair value estimate using multiples from entities with operations and economic characteristics comparable to our reporting units.
58492_12_ITEM15_P87_S0	The income approach is based on projected future (debt-free) cash flow that is discounted to present value using factors that consider the timing and risk of future cash flows.
58492_12_ITEM15_P87_S1	Management believes that this approach is appropriate because it provides a fair value estimate based upon the reporting unit s expected long-term operating cash flow performance.
58492_12_ITEM15_P88_S0	Discounted cash flow projections are based on 10-year financial forecasts developed from operating plans and economic projections noted above, growth rates, estimates of future expected changes in operating margins, terminal value growth rates, future capital expenditures and changes in working capital requirements.
58492_12_ITEM15_P89_S0	The goodwill impairment reviews performed in each year presented indicated no goodwill impairments.
58492_12_ITEM15_P90_S0	we concluded that a formal goodwill impairment review at December 31, 2011 was not necessary.

58492_12_ITEM15_P90_S2	If actual results differ from estimates used in these calculations, we could incur future impairment charges.

58492_12_ITEM15_P120_S0	The Company may elect the type of borrowing under the 2011 Agreement, which determines the rate of interest to be paid on the outstanding principal balance, as follows:
58492_12_ITEM15_P121_S0	Under an ABR loan, the Company will pay interest at the Alternate Base Rate, which is the greater of (a) the prime rate publicly announced by JPMorgan; (b) the weighted average rate on overnight Federal funds transactions, plus 1 / 2 of 1%; or (c) the rate appearing on Reuters Screen LIBOR01 for dollar deposits with one month maturity multiplied by a fraction (the numerator being 1, and the denominator being 1 minus the aggregate of the maximum reserve percentage to which JPMorgan is subject for eurocurrency funding) plus 1%.
58492_12_ITEM15_P122_S0	Under a Fixed Rate loan, the Company will pay interest at (a) the rate published on a designated reference page of the Reuters Group service (for the available currency and interest period chosen for the loan by the Company) equal to the rate published for deposits denominated in such currency with a maturity comparable to such interest period, plus (b) a fixed spread percentage (based upon the S P and Moody s ratings of the Company s senior unsecured debt).
58492_12_ITEM15_P123_S0	Under a Dollar Swingline loan (which is initially made by JPMorgan for short-term administrative convenience on same day notice) the Company will pay interest at a rate equal to the weighted average rate on overnight Federal funds transactions, plus 1.5%.
58492_12_ITEM15_P124_S0	Under a Competitive loan, the Company will pay interest at a rate equal to a competitive variable or fixed rate accepted by the Company.
58492_12_ITEM15_P124_S1	The Company is required to periodically pay accrued interest on any outstanding principal balance under the 2011 Agreement at different time intervals based upon the elected interest rate and the elected interest period.
58492_12_ITEM15_P124_S2	Any outstanding principal under the 2011 Agreement will be due upon the maturity date.
58492_12_ITEM15_P124_S3	The Company may also terminate or reduce the lending commitments under the 2011 Agreement, in whole or in part, upon three business days notice.

58492_12_ITEM15_P130_S1	The windfall benefit is not recognized in income, but rather on the balance sheet as additional contributed capital.

58492_12_ITEM15_P131_S1	To the extent we have accumulated tax windfalls the shortfall is recognized on the balance sheet as a reduction of additional contributed capital.
58492_12_ITEM15_P132_S0	(1) Stock Option Grants We grant stock options in the following areas:
58492_12_ITEM15_P133_S0	In conjunction with our Deferred Compensation Program Options granted to a broad group of employees on a discretionary basis We grant stock options annually on a discretionary basis to a broad group of employees.
58492_12_ITEM15_P133_S1	Options generally become exercisable in one-third increments at 18 months, 30 months and 42 months after the date of grant.
58492_12_ITEM15_P133_S2	Options have a maximum term of ten years and the exercise prices are equal to Leggett s closing stock price on the grant date.
58492_12_ITEM15_P133_S3	Grant date fair values are calculated using the Black-Scholes option pricing model and will be amortized by the straight-line method over the options total vesting period, except for employees who terminate due to retirement.
58492_12_ITEM15_P134_S0	A retirement termination occurs if the employee is age 65, or age 55 with 20 years of Company service at termination.
58492_12_ITEM15_P134_S1	For retirement terminations, options continue to vest and remain exercisable for 3 years and 6 months after termination of employment.
58492_12_ITEM15_P134_S2	Therefore, the expense for these options is accelerated when the employee is retirement eligible.
58492_12_ITEM15_P135_S0	Other employees participate in option choice programs.
58492_12_ITEM15_P135_S1	In connection with the January 2010 grant, we gave most participants the choice to receive stock options or to receive a cash payment in lieu of options.
58492_12_ITEM15_P135_S2	The value of the cash alternative (paid in the first quarter) was equal to approximately one-half of the Black Scholes value of the option grant the employee would have otherwise received.
58492_12_ITEM15_P136_S0	In connection with the January 2011 grant, we offered two different option choice programs.
58492_12_ITEM15_P136_S1	One group of employees was offered the same option/cash choice as in 2010, with the cash alternative being equal to approximately one-half of the Black-Scholes value of the option grant foregone.
58492_12_ITEM15_P136_S2	Another group of employees, generally higher level employees, were offered a choice between stock options or restricted stock units (RSUs), on a ratio of four options foregone for every one RSU offered.
58492_12_ITEM15_P136_S3	The stock units vest in one-third increments at 12 months, 24 months and 36 months after the date of grant.
58492_12_ITEM15_P137_S0	Deferred Compensation Program We offer a Deferred Compensation Program under which key managers and outside directors may elect to receive stock options, stock units or interest-bearing cash deferrals in lieu of cash compensation:
58492_12_ITEM15_P138_S0	Stock options under this program are granted on the last business day of the year prior to the year the compensation is earned.
58492_12_ITEM15_P138_S1	The number of options granted equals the deferred compensation times five, divided by the stock s market price on the date of grant.
58492_12_ITEM15_P138_S2	The option has a 10-year term.
58492_12_ITEM15_P138_S3	It vests as the associated compensation is earned and becomes exercisable beginning 15 months after the grant date.
58492_12_ITEM15_P139_S0	Stock is issued when the option is exercised.
58492_12_ITEM15_P140_S0	Deferred stock units (DSU) under this program are acquired every two weeks (when the compensation would have otherwise been paid) at a 20% discount to the market price of our common stock on the acquisition date and they vest immediately.
58492_12_ITEM15_P141_S0	Expense is recorded as the compensation is earned.
58492_12_ITEM15_P141_S1	Stock units earn dividends at the same rate as cash dividends paid on our common stock.
58492_12_ITEM15_P141_S2	These dividends are used to acquire stock units at a 20% discount.
58492_12_ITEM15_P141_S3	Stock units are converted to common stock and distributed in accordance with the participant s pre-set election.
58492_12_ITEM15_P141_S4	Beginning in 2010, stock units may be settled in cash at the discretion of the Company.
58492_12_ITEM15_P141_S5	Participants must begin receiving distributions no later than ten years after the effective date of the deferral and installment distributions cannot exceed ten years.
58492_12_ITEM15_P142_S0	Interest-bearing cash deferrals under this program are reported in Other long-term liabilities on the balance sheet and are disclosed in Note I.

58492_12_ITEM15_P149_S0	(2) Stock-Based Retirement Plans We have two stock-based retirement plans: the tax-qualified Stock Bonus Plan (SBP) for non-highly compensated employees, and the non-qualified Executive Stock Unit Program (ESUP) for highly compensated employees.
58492_12_ITEM15_P149_S1	We make matching contributions to both plans.
58492_12_ITEM15_P149_S2	In addition to the automatic 50% match, we will make another matching contribution of up to 50% of the employee s contributions for the year if certain profitability levels, as defined in the SBP and the ESUP, are obtained.
58492_12_ITEM15_P150_S0	Participants in the SBP may contribute up to 6% of their compensation above a certain threshold to purchase Leggett stock or other investment alternatives at market prices.
58492_12_ITEM15_P150_S1	We immediately match 50% of the employee contributions.
58492_12_ITEM15_P150_S2	Employees are allowed to fully diversify their employee deferral accounts immediately and their employer accounts after three years of service.
58492_12_ITEM15_P151_S0	Dividends earned on Company stock held in the SBP are reinvested or paid in cash at the participant s election.

58492_12_ITEM15_P153_S8	Participant s diversified investment accounts are unfunded, unsecured obligations of the Company, and are presented as a component of Other current liabilities and Other long-term liabilities in the accompanying balance sheet and will be settled in cash.

58492_12_ITEM15_P179_S0	Plan assets are invested in diversified portfolios of equity, debt and government securities.
58492_12_ITEM15_P179_S1	The aggregate allocation of these investments is as follows: Our investment policy and strategies are established with a long-term view in mind.
58492_12_ITEM15_P179_S2	We strive for a sufficiently diversified asset mix to minimize the risk of a material loss to the portfolio value due to the devaluation of any single investment.
58492_12_ITEM15_P179_S3	In determining the appropriate asset mix, our financial strength and ability to fund potential shortfalls that might result from poor investment performance are considered.
58492_12_ITEM15_P179_S4	Approximately 60% of our significant plans (the frozen plans) are employing a Liability Driven Investment strategy and have a target allocation of 60% bonds and 40% equities.
58492_12_ITEM15_P179_S5	The remaining significant plans (the active plans) have a target allocation of 75% equities and 25% bonds, as historical equity returns have tended to exceed bond returns over the long term.
58492_12_ITEM15_P180_S0	Assets of our domestic plans represent the majority of plan assets and are allocated to six different investments: four mutual funds and two separate accounts.

58492_12_ITEM15_P183_S0	Long-term Bond Index: Diversified exposure to the long-term, investment-grade U.S. bond market; index sampling.
58492_12_ITEM15_P184_S0	Extended Duration Treasury Index: Diversified exposure to the long-term Treasury STRIPS market; using index sampling.
58492_12_ITEM15_P184_S1	The separate accounts are invested as follows:

58492_12_ITEM15_P204_S0	Q Fair Value We utilize fair value measures for both financial and non-financial assets and liabilities.
58492_12_ITEM15_P204_S1	The primary areas in which we utilize fair value measures of non-financial assets and liabilities are allocating purchase price to the assets and liabilities of acquired companies as discussed in Note R and evaluating long-term assets for potential impairment as discussed in Notes B and C. The areas in which we utilize fair value measures of financial assets and liabilities are presented in the table below.
58492_12_ITEM15_P205_S0	Fair value measurements are established using a three level valuation hierarchy that prioritizes the inputs to valuation techniques used to measure fair value into the following categories:
58492_12_ITEM15_P206_S0	Level 1: Quoted prices for identical assets or liabilities in active markets.
58492_12_ITEM15_P207_S0	Level 2: Inputs other than quoted prices included in Level 1 that are observable for the asset or liability either directly or indirectly.
58492_12_ITEM15_P207_S1	Short-term investments in this category are valued using discounted cash flow techniques with all significant inputs derived from or corroborated by observable market data.
58492_12_ITEM15_P207_S2	Derivative assets and liabilities in this category are valued using models that consider various assumptions and information from market-corroborated sources.
58492_12_ITEM15_P207_S3	The models used are primarily industry-standard models that consider items such as quoted prices, market interest rate curves applicable to the instruments being valued as of the end of each period, discounted cash flows, volatility factors, current market and contractual prices for the underlying instruments, as well as other relevant economic measures.
58492_12_ITEM15_P207_S4	Substantially all of these assumptions are observable in the marketplace, can be derived from observable data or are supported by observable levels at which transactions are executed in the marketplace.
58492_12_ITEM15_P208_S0	Level 3: Unobservable inputs that are not corroborated by market data.
58492_12_ITEM15_P209_S0	The following tables present assets and liabilities that were accounted for at fair value on a recurring basis.

58492_12_ITEM15_P215_S0	S Derivative Financial Instruments Risk Management Strategy Objectives We are subject to market and financial risks related to interest rates, foreign currency, and commodities.
58492_12_ITEM15_P215_S1	In the normal course of business, we utilize derivative instruments (individually or in combinations) to manage these risks.
58492_12_ITEM15_P215_S2	We seek to use derivative contracts that qualify for hedge accounting treatment; however, some instruments may not qualify for hedge accounting treatment.
58492_12_ITEM15_P215_S3	It is our policy not to speculate using derivative instruments.
58492_12_ITEM15_P215_S4	We have recorded the following assets and liabilities representing the fair value for our most significant derivative financial instruments for the periods presented below.
58492_12_ITEM15_P215_S5	The fair values of the derivatives reflect the change in the market value of the derivative from the date of the trade execution, and do not consider the offsetting underlying hedged item.
58492_12_ITEM15_P216_S0	Cash Flow Hedges Derivative financial instruments that we use to hedge forecasted transactions and anticipated cash flows are as follows:
58492_12_ITEM15_P217_S0	The commodity cash flow hedges manage natural gas commodity price risk.
58492_12_ITEM15_P217_S1	All commodity hedges at December 31, 2011 had maturities of less than two years.
58492_12_ITEM15_P217_S2	We routinely hedge commodity price risk up to 36 months.
58492_12_ITEM15_P218_S0	The foreign currency hedges manage risk associated with exchange rate volatility of various currencies.
58492_12_ITEM15_P218_S1	The foreign currency cash flow hedges outstanding at December 31, 2011 had maturity dates within one year.
58492_12_ITEM15_P218_S2	In general, foreign currency cash flow hedges have maturities within two years.
58492_12_ITEM15_P219_S0	In anticipation of long-term debt maturing in April 2013, we entered into forward starting interest swaps in 2010.
58492_12_ITEM15_P219_S1	The swap contracts manage benchmark interest rate risk associated with $200 of planned debt issuance in August 2012.
58492_12_ITEM15_P219_S2	The swaps have a weighted average interest rate of 4.0% and hedge the benchmark rate of an expected issuance of $200 of debt.
58492_12_ITEM15_P219_S3	The credit spread over the benchmark bonds will continue to fluctuate until the time of issuance.
58492_12_ITEM15_P219_S4	The effective changes in fair value of unexpired contracts are recorded in accumulated other comprehensive income and reclassified to income or expense in the period in which earnings are impacted and are presented as operating cash flows when the contracts are settled.
58492_12_ITEM15_P220_S0	Our fair value hedges manage foreign currency risk associated with subsidiaries inter-company assets and liabilities.
58492_12_ITEM15_P220_S1	Hedges designated as fair value hedges recognize gain or loss currently in earnings and are presented as operating cash flows when the contracts are settled.
58492_12_ITEM15_P220_S2	These fair value hedges generally have a maturity date within one year.
58492_12_ITEM15_P221_S0	Hedge Effectiveness We have deemed all ineffectiveness to be immaterial, and as a result, have not recorded any amounts for ineffectiveness.
58492_12_ITEM15_P221_S1	If a hedge was not highly effective, the portion of the change in fair value considered to be ineffective would be recognized immediately in the consolidated condensed statements of operations.

58492_12_ITEM15_P222_S1	Gains or losses on these transactions are recorded directly to income and expense in the period impacted, and offset the majority of gains and losses on the underlying Euro inter-company debt.

58492_12_ITEM15_P224_S1	When it is probable, in management s judgment, that we may incur monetary damages or other costs resulting from these proceedings or other claims, and we can reasonably estimate the amounts, we record appropriate liabilities in the financial statements and make charges against earnings.

58492_12_ITEM15_P225_S0	NPI Lawsuit On January 18, 2008, National Products, Inc. ( NPI ) sued Gamber-Johnson, LLC ( Gamber ), our wholly-owned subsidiary, in Case C08-0049C-JLR, in the United States District Court, Western District of Washington, alleging that portions of a Gamber marketing video contained false and misleading statements.
58492_12_ITEM15_P225_S1	NPI and Gamber compete in the market for vehicle computer mounting systems.
58492_12_ITEM15_P225_S2	NPI sought: (a) injunctive relief requiring Gamber to stop using the video and to notify customers; (b) damages for its alleged lost profits; and (c) disgorgement of Gamber s profits in an unspecified amount.
58492_12_ITEM15_P225_S3	Although part of the claims were dismissed by the Court before and during trial, a jury, on April 12, 2010, found four statements in the video were false and deliberate and awarded $10 in disgorgement damages against Gamber.
58492_12_ITEM15_P225_S4	On August 16, 2010, the Court: (a) reduced the jury verdict to approximately $0.5; (b) granted NPI attorney fees and costs in an amount to be determined; and (c) granted an injunction requiring Gamber to notify its distributors and resellers of the verdict.
58492_12_ITEM15_P225_S5	The Court subsequently awarded NPI $2.0 in attorney fees and costs.
58492_12_ITEM15_P226_S0	On September 17, 2010, NPI filed an appeal to the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals.
58492_12_ITEM15_P226_S1	On September 7, 2011, a three judge panel of the Court of Appeals affirmed the trial court s decision.
58492_12_ITEM15_P226_S2	Each party filed a request for rehearing en banc (a rehearing by the full court), which was denied on October 24, 2011.
58492_12_ITEM15_P226_S3	On November 22, 2011, our insurance carrier paid the judgment and attorney fee awards in full (roughly $2.5).
58492_12_ITEM15_P227_S0	Shareholder Derivative Lawsuit On August 10, 2010, a shareholder derivative suit was filed by the New England Carpenters Pension Fund in the Circuit Court of Jasper County, Missouri as Case No. 10AO-CC00284 ( 2010 Suit ).
58492_12_ITEM15_P227_S1	The 2010 Suit was substantially similar to a prior suit filed by the same plaintiff, in the same court, on February 5, 2009 ( 2009 Suit ).
58492_12_ITEM15_P227_S2	The 2009 Suit was dismissed without prejudice based on the plaintiff s failure to make demand on our Board and shareholders.
58492_12_ITEM15_P227_S3	As before, the plaintiff did not make such demand.
58492_12_ITEM15_P227_S4	On April 6, 2011, the 2010 Suit was dismissed without prejudice.
58492_12_ITEM15_P228_S0	On May 12, 2011, the plaintiff filed an appeal to the Missouri Court of Appeals.
58492_12_ITEM15_P228_S1	The briefing process began January 2012.
58492_12_ITEM15_P228_S2	We do not expect a ruling from the Court of Appeals for several months.
58492_12_ITEM15_P228_S3	The 2010 Suit was purportedly brought on our behalf, naming us as a nominal defendant, and certain current and former officers and directors as individual defendants including David S. Haffner, Karl G. Glassman, Matthew C. Flanigan, Ernest C. Jett, Harry M. Cornell, Jr., Felix E. Wright, Robert Ted Enloe, III, Richard T. Fisher, Judy C. Odom, Maurice E. Purnell, Jr., Ralph W. Clark and Michael A. Glauber.
58492_12_ITEM15_P228_S4	The plaintiff alleged, among other things, that the individual defendants: breached their fiduciary duties; backdated and received backdated stock options violating our stock plans; caused or allowed us to issue false and misleading financial statements and proxy statements; sold our stock while possessing material non-public information; committed gross mismanagement; wasted corporate assets; committed fraud; violated the Missouri Securities Act; and were unjustly enriched.
58492_12_ITEM15_P228_S5	The plaintiff was seeking, among other things: unspecified monetary damages against the individual defendants; certain equitable and other relief relating to the profits from the alleged improper conduct; the adoption of certain corporate governance proposals; the imposition of a constructive trust over the defendants stock options and proceeds; punitive damages; the rescission of certain unexercised options; and the reimbursement of litigation costs.
58492_12_ITEM15_P228_S6	The plaintiff was not seeking monetary relief from us.
58492_12_ITEM15_P229_S0	We have director and officer liability insurance in force subject to customary limits and exclusions.
58492_12_ITEM15_P230_S0	prices that we believe was flawed; the plaintiff failed to state a substantive claim; the common law fraud claim was not pled with sufficient particularity; and the statute of limitations has expired on the fraud claim and all the alleged challenged grants except the December 30, 2005 grant.
58492_12_ITEM15_P230_S1	As to this grant, the motions to dismiss advised the Court that it was made under our Deferred Compensation Program, which (i) provided that options would be dated on the last business day of December, and (ii) was filed with the SEC on December 2, 2005 setting out the pricing mechanism well before the grant date.
