58492_12_ITEM15_P231_S0	Antitrust Lawsuits Beginning in August 2010, a series of civil lawsuits was initiated in several U.S. federal courts and in Canada against over 20 defendants alleging that competitors of our carpet underlay business unit and other manufacturers of polyurethane foam products had engaged in price fixing in violation of U.S. and Canadian antitrust laws.
58492_12_ITEM15_P231_S1	A number of these lawsuits have been voluntarily dismissed without prejudice.
58492_12_ITEM15_P231_S2	Of the U.S. cases remaining, we have been named as a defendant in (a) three direct purchaser class action cases (the first on November 15, 2010) and a consolidated amended class action complaint filed on February 28, 2011 on behalf of a class of all direct purchasers of polyurethane foam products; (b) an indirect purchaser class consolidated amended complaint filed on March 21, 2011 (although the underlying lawsuits do not name us as a defendant); and an indirect purchaser class action case filed on May 23, 2011; and (c) eleven individual direct purchaser cases, one filed March 22, 2011, another amended August 24, 2011 to remove class allegations, one amended August 25, 2011 to name us as a defendant, four others filed October 31, 2011, one filed November 4, 2011 and three filed December 6, 19 and 30, respectively.
58492_12_ITEM15_P231_S3	All of the pending U.S. cases in which we have been named as a defendant, have been filed in or transferred to the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio under the name In re: Polyurethane Foam Antitrust Litigation , Case No. 1:10-MD-02196.
58492_12_ITEM15_P231_S4	In the U.S. actions, the plaintiffs, on behalf of themselves and/or a class of purchasers, seek three times the amount of unspecified damages allegedly suffered as a result of alleged overcharges in the price of polyurethane foam products from at least 1999 to the present.
58492_12_ITEM15_P231_S5	Each plaintiff also seeks attorney fees, pre-judgment and post-judgment interest, court costs, and injunctive relief against future violations.
58492_12_ITEM15_P232_S0	On April 15 and May 6, 2011, we filed motions to dismiss the U.S. direct purchaser and indirect purchaser class actions in the consolidated case in Ohio, for failure to state a legally valid claim.
58492_12_ITEM15_P232_S1	On July 19, 2011, the Ohio Court denied the motions to dismiss.
58492_12_ITEM15_P233_S0	Discovery is underway in the U.S. actions.
58492_12_ITEM15_P233_S1	Limited and Hickory Springs Manufacturing Company, et.al.
58492_12_ITEM15_P233_S2	in the Ontario Superior Court of Justice (Windsor), Court File Nos. CV-10-15164 and CV-11-17279.
58492_12_ITEM15_P234_S0	In each of the Canadian cases, the plaintiffs, on behalf of themselves and/or a class of purchasers, seek from over 15 defendants restitution of the amount allegedly overcharged, general and special damages in the amount of $100, punitive damages of $10, pre-judgment and post-judgment interest, and the costs of the action.
58492_12_ITEM15_P234_S1	We have not yet filed our defenses in the Canadian actions.

58492_12_ITEM15_P236_S0	Brazilian Value-Added Tax Matters On December 22, 2011, the Brazilian Finance Ministry, Federal Revenue Office issued a notice of violation against our wholly-owned subsidiary, Leggett Platt do Brasil Ltda.
58492_12_ITEM15_P237_S0	approximately $4, under Case No. 10855.724660/2011-43.
58492_12_ITEM15_P238_S0	The Brazilian Revenue Office claimed that for the period beginning November 2006 and continuing through December 2007, L P Brazil used an incorrect tax rate for the collection and payment of value-added tax primarily on the sale of mattress innersprings in Brazil.
58492_12_ITEM15_P238_S1	The Brazilian Revenue Office has communicated that it will likely expand the audit to the tax years 2008 through January 2011.
58492_12_ITEM15_P238_S2	As a result, it is possible that we may receive an additional notice of violation on the same subject matter.
58492_12_ITEM15_P238_S3	L P Brazil responded to the notice of violation on January 25, 2012 denying the violation.
58492_12_ITEM15_P239_S0	L P Brazil is also party to a proceeding involving the State of Sao Paulo, Brazil where the State of Sao Paulo, on April 16, 2009, issued a Notice of Tax Assessment and Imposition of Fine to L P Brazil seeking approximately $3.3 for the tax years 2006 and 2007.
58492_12_ITEM15_P239_S1	The State of Sao Paulo argued that L P Brazil was using an incorrect tax rate for the collection and payment of value-added tax on mattress innerspring sales in the State of Sao Paulo.
58492_12_ITEM15_P239_S2	On September 29, 2010, the Court of Tax and Fees of the State of Sao Paulo ruled in favor of L P Brazil nullifying the tax assessment.
58492_12_ITEM15_P239_S3	The State filed an appeal, which is currently pending.
58492_12_ITEM15_P239_S4	We deny all of the allegations in these actions.
58492_12_ITEM15_P239_S5	We believe that we have valid bases upon which to contest such actions and will vigorously defend ourselves.
58492_12_ITEM15_P239_S6	However, these contingencies are subject to many uncertainties.

58492_12_ITEM15_P240_S0	Patent Infringement Claim On January 24, 2012, in a case in the United States District Court for the Central District of California, the jury entered a verdict against us in the amount of $5 based upon an allegation by plaintiff that we infringed three patents on an automatic stapling machine and on methods used to assemble box springs.
58492_12_ITEM15_P240_S1	This action was originally filed on October 4, 2010, as case number CV10-07416 RGK (SSx) under the caption Imaginal Systematic, LLC v. Leggett Platt, Incorporated; Simmons Bedding Company; and Does 1 through 10, inclusive.
58492_12_ITEM15_P240_S2	Leggett is contractually obligated to defend and indemnify Simmons Bedding Company against a claim for infringement.
58492_12_ITEM15_P241_S0	At trial, the plaintiff alleged damages of $16.2.
58492_12_ITEM15_P241_S1	We disputed each patent s validity; the methodology used to calculate damages; and denied that we infringed any patent.
58492_12_ITEM15_P241_S2	The plaintiff has also requested pre-judgment interest and royalties for future use of the machines and attorneys fees and costs.
58492_12_ITEM15_P241_S3	We intend to object to all of these claims.
58492_12_ITEM15_P241_S4	We intend to appeal the case to the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals and believe we have valid bases upon which to appeal.
58492_12_ITEM15_P241_S5	We do not believe that it is probable that the judgment will be upheld on appeal in its current form.
58492_12_ITEM15_P241_S6	We also filed reexamination proceedings in the Patent Office (Case Nos. 95/001,543 filed February 11, 2011; 95/001,546 and 95/001,547 filed February 16, 2011), challenging the validity of each patent at issue.
58492_12_ITEM15_P241_S7	The Patent Office ruled in our favor on the pertinent claims of two of the three patents.
58492_12_ITEM15_P241_S8	With respect to the third patent, we intend to appeal the Patent Office s decision upholding validity; however, due to a change made to all of the machines we do not believe that the machines are currently using the feature alleged to have infringed the third patent.
58492_12_ITEM15_P241_S9	At this time, we do not believe it is probable that this matter will have a material adverse effect on our financial condition, operating cash flows or results of operations.

58492_12_ITEM15_P296_S0	An Option may be exercised only by a Participant during his life or, in the case of Disability, by his guardian or legal representative.
58492_12_ITEM15_P296_S1	Upon the death of a Participant, the Option may be exercised by his Beneficiary or, if the Participant fails to designate a Beneficiary, by his legal representative.
58492_12_ITEM15_P296_S2	If any Option has not been fully exercised on the Expiration Date, the unexercised portion of the Option shall be deemed exercised on such Expiration Date, provided the then market price of a share of L P Common Stock exceeds the per share Exercise Price.
58492_12_ITEM15_P296_S3	In such event, shares of Common Stock will not be issued until the Exercise Price and any other required amounts have been paid.
58492_12_ITEM15_P296_S4	If the Company has not received payment of the Exercise Price and any other required amounts within 30 days after the Expiration Date, the exercise will be void and the Company will have no further obligation to the Participant with respect to the expired Option.
58492_12_ITEM15_P296_S5	Although the Company intends to settle the Option exercise in stock, notwithstanding any other provision of the Program, the Company reserves the right to settle the Option exercise in cash in lieu of shares of Common Stock.
58492_12_ITEM15_P296_S6	If settled in cash, the amount of the payment will be equal to the Fair Market Value (as defined in the Company s Flexible Stock Plan) of the number of shares of Common Stock that would otherwise be issued upon Option exercise.
58492_12_ITEM15_P296_S7	Fair Market Value shall be determined at the date of exercise, in the same manner as if the exercise would have been settled in shares of Common Stock.
58492_12_ITEM15_P297_S0	All Options will be non-qualified options that are not entitled to special tax treatment under 422 of the Internal Revenue Code.
58492_12_ITEM15_P298_S0	A Participant will have no rights as a shareholder with respect to the shares covered by his Option until stock has been issued for the shares.
58492_12_ITEM15_P298_S1	No adjustment will be made for dividends or other rights for which the record date is before the issuance date.
58492_12_ITEM15_P299_S0	STOCK UNIT AND L P CASH DEFERRALS 5.1 Stock Units .
58492_12_ITEM15_P299_S1	An account will be established to track Stock Units for each Participant who elects a Stock Unit deferral.
58492_12_ITEM15_P299_S2	Compensation will be deferred on a bi-weekly basis or as Compensation otherwise would have been paid, unless the Committee determines otherwise.
58492_12_ITEM15_P300_S0	All deferrals and Dividend Contributions to a Participant s account will be used to acquire Stock Units at a price equal to 80% of the fair market value of a share of Common Stock on the date such deferrals and Dividend Contributions are made.
58492_12_ITEM15_P300_S1	On the date a cash dividend is paid on Common Stock, the Company will make a Dividend Contribution equal to the per share cash dividend on the number of Stock Units credited to the Participant s account on the dividend record date.
58492_12_ITEM15_P300_S2	Prior to distribution, Stock Units will be converted to the appropriate number of whole shares of Common Stock.
58492_12_ITEM15_P300_S3	The Company will make the distributions by January 31 st of the elected distribution year.
58492_12_ITEM15_P301_S0	For installment elections, each annual distribution will be equal to the balance of Stock Units in the Participant s account divided by the number of payments remaining.
58492_12_ITEM15_P301_S1	The Company will withhold from the shares distributed any amount required to pay applicable taxes (at the Company s required withholding rate).
58492_12_ITEM15_P301_S2	Alternatively, the Participant may pay such taxes in cash if he elects to do so before the distribution date.
58492_12_ITEM15_P301_S3	The Company may, at any time, require a Participant to settle the tax liability in cash.
58492_12_ITEM15_P301_S4	Although the Company intends to settle Participants accounts in stock, notwithstanding any other provision of the Program, the Company reserves the right to pay Stock Units in cash in lieu of shares of Common Stock.
58492_12_ITEM15_P301_S5	If settled in cash, the amount of the distribution will be equal to the Fair Market Value (as defined in the Company s Flexible Stock Plan) of the number of shares of Common Stock that would otherwise be issued.
58492_12_ITEM15_P301_S6	Fair Market Value shall be determined at the date the shares would otherwise have been issued.
58492_12_ITEM15_P301_S7	5.4 Interest on L P Cash Deferral .
58492_12_ITEM15_P301_S8	L P Cash Deferrals will bear interest at a rate established by the Committee.
58492_12_ITEM15_P301_S9	The interest will begin accruing on the date the Deferred Compensation would have been paid but for the deferral.
58492_12_ITEM15_P301_S10	Until the Committee determines otherwise, the Chief Financial Officer will determine the interest rates.
58492_12_ITEM15_P302_S0	5.5 Timing and Form of Distribution .
58492_12_ITEM15_P302_S1	The Participant will select the timing and form of distribution for Stock Unit and L P Cash Deferrals on his Election form.
58492_12_ITEM15_P302_S2	The first payment date may not be earlier than two years after the Election is made or such other date as the Committee determines.
58492_12_ITEM15_P302_S3	The Committee may establish maximum deferral periods and maximum payout periods.
58492_12_ITEM15_P302_S4	Until otherwise determined, distribution payouts must begin within 10 years of the effective date of the deferral, and all amounts subject to the deferral must be distributed within 10 years of the first distribution payout.
58492_12_ITEM15_P302_S5	The Participant may make an election to extend the payout period or change the form of distribution for Stock Unit and L P Cash Deferrals, not to exceed any maximum payout period established by the Committee.
58492_12_ITEM15_P302_S6	For purposes of the foregoing, each payout date in an installment distribution election will be treated as a separate election.
58492_12_ITEM15_P302_S7	Unless otherwise permitted under rules applicable to Section 409A, the election change must be made not less than 12 months before the scheduled payment date and must extend the distribution payment by at least five years.
58492_12_ITEM15_P303_S0	In the event of an Unforeseeable Emergency, the Committee may, in its sole discretion and as permitted under applicable law, authorize an early distribution of a Participant s vested L P Cash Deferral or Stock Unit account and cancellation of the Participant s election.
58492_12_ITEM15_P303_S1	Amounts distributed due to an Unforeseeable Emergency must be limited to the amount reasonably necessary to satisfy the emergency need.
58492_12_ITEM15_P304_S0	The Company s obligation to a Participant for Stock Unit and L P Cash Deferrals is a mere promise to pay shares or money in the future and the Participant will have the status of a general unsecured creditor of the Company.
58492_12_ITEM15_P304_S1	The Committee and the Company s Secretary will make all determinations regarding benefits under the Program in accordance with ERISA.
58492_12_ITEM15_P304_S2	If a Participant believes he is entitled to receive a distribution under the Program and he does not receive such distribution, he must make a claim in writing to the Committee.
58492_12_ITEM15_P304_S3	The Committee will review the claim.
58492_12_ITEM15_P304_S4	If the claim is denied, the Committee will provide a written notice of denial within 90 days setting out: the reasons for the denial; provisions of the Program upon which the denial is based; any additional information to perfect the claim and why such information is necessary; the steps to be taken if a review is sought, including, as applicable, the right to file an action under Section 502(a) of ERISA following an adverse determination; and the time limits for requesting a review and for review.
58492_12_ITEM15_P304_S5	If a claim is denied and the Participant desires a review, he will notify the Secretary in writing within 60 days of the receipt of notice of denial.
58492_12_ITEM15_P305_S0	In requesting a review, the Participant may review the Program or any related document and submit any written statement he deems appropriate.
58492_12_ITEM15_P305_S1	The Secretary will then review the claim and, if the decision is adverse to the Participant, provide a written decision within 60 days setting out: the reasons for the denial; provisions of the Program upon which the denial is based; a statement that the Participant is entitled to receive, upon request and free of charge, copies of documents relied upon in making the decision; and, as applicable, the Participant s right to bring an action under Section 502(a) of ERISA.
58492_12_ITEM15_P306_S0	COMPANY BENEFIT PLANS 6.1 Impact on Benefit Plans .
58492_12_ITEM15_P306_S1	The deferral of Compensation under the Program is not intended to affect other Employer benefit plans in which the Participant is participating or may be eligible to participate.
58492_12_ITEM15_P306_S2	The impact of the Program on other benefits is described below.
58492_12_ITEM15_P307_S0	401(k) Plans Participation in the Program will reduce compensation eligible for contributions under an Employer 401(k) plan in the year the compensation is earned.
58492_12_ITEM15_P307_S1	For Participants in the Company s Retirement 401(k) ( Retirement K ), this could result in a corresponding reduction of the Company s matching contributions in the Retirement K. The Company s Retirement K Excess Program is intended to address this limitation and other limitations affecting matching contributions in the Retirement K.
58492_12_ITEM15_P307_S2	In certain circumstances, the Retirement K Excess Program will make a cash payment equal to the lost matching contribution to the Retirement K. When previously deferred compensation comes out of the Program, the compensation will be considered eligible compensation for a contribution under the L P 401(k) Plan.
58492_12_ITEM15_P308_S0	For stock distributions (e.g. a Stock Unit distribution or an Option exercise), the Company must, to the extent possible, take the 401(k) contribution from a Participant s other cash compensation in the calendar year.
58492_12_ITEM15_P309_S0	Executive Stock Unit Program The amount of payroll deduction for Stock Units under the Company s Executive Stock Unit Program ( ESU Program ) will be calculated as if no deferral had occurred.
58492_12_ITEM15_P309_S1	In the case of an ESU Program Participant who defers 100% of Compensation under the Deferred Compensation Program, the Company will make the Matching Contribution and Additional Matching Contribution under the ESU Program as though the full Participant s Contribution had been made.
58492_12_ITEM15_P310_S0	Discount Stock Plan Contributions under the Discount Stock Plan will be calculated as if no deferral had occurred.
58492_12_ITEM15_P311_S0	Life Insurance and Disability Benefits To the extent the level of benefits is based upon a Participant s compensation, Deferred Compensation will be included when it would have otherwise become payable but for the deferral.
58492_12_ITEM15_P311_S1	Except as provided in Section 6.1, the Participant must make contributions and payments under all Employer benefit plans in which he is participating in the amounts required as if no deferral had occurred.
58492_12_ITEM15_P311_S2	If there is not sufficient Compensation after deferral from which to withhold required contributions and payments, the Participant must make arrangements suitable to the Company for payment of the required amounts.
58492_12_ITEM15_P312_S0	Except to the extent the Committee otherwise designates pursuant to Section 7.2(e), the Committee will control and manage the operation and administration of the Program.
58492_12_ITEM15_P312_S1	The Committee will have such authority as may be necessary to discharge its responsibilities under the Program, including the authority to: (a) interpret the provisions of the Program; (b) adopt rules of procedure consistent with the Program; (c) determine questions relating to Benefits and rights under the Program; (d) maintain records concerning the Program; (e) designate any Company employee or committee to carry out any of the Committee s duties, including authority to manage the operation and administration of the Program; and (f) determine the content and form of the Participant s Election and all other documents required to carry out the Program.

58492_13_ITEM1_P0_S0	Leggett Platt, Incorporated was founded as a partnership in Carthage, Missouri in 1883 and was incorporated in 1901.
58492_13_ITEM1_P0_S1	The Company, a pioneer of the steel coil bedspring, has become an international diversified manufacturer that conceives, designs and produces a wide range of engineered components and products found in many homes, offices, retail stores, automobiles and commercial aircraft.
58492_13_ITEM1_P0_S2	As discussed below, our operations are organized into 20 business units, which are divided into 10 groups under our four segments: Residential Furnishings; Commercial Fixturing Components; Industrial Materials; and Specialized Products.
58492_13_ITEM1_P1_S0	Our Residential Furnishings segment began in 1883 with the manufacture of steel coiled bedsprings.
58492_13_ITEM1_P1_S1	Today, we supply a variety of components used by bedding and upholstered furniture manufacturers in the assembly of their finished products.
58492_13_ITEM1_P1_S2	Our range of products offers our customers a single source for many of their component needs.
58492_13_ITEM1_P2_S0	Efficient manufacturing methods, internal production of key raw materials, and numerous manufacturing and assembly locations allow us to supply many customers with components at a lower cost than they can produce themselves.
58492_13_ITEM1_P2_S1	In addition to cost savings, sourcing components from us allows our customers to focus on designing, merchandising and marketing their products.
58492_13_ITEM1_P3_S0	Products manufactured or distributed by our Residential Furnishings groups include:
58492_13_ITEM1_P4_S0	Most of our Residential Furnishings customers are manufacturers of finished bedding products (mattresses and foundations) or upholstered furniture for residential use.
58492_13_ITEM1_P4_S1	We also sell many products, including ornamental beds, bed frames, adjustable beds, carpet underlay, and top-of-bed accessories, directly to retailers and distributors.
58492_13_ITEM1_P4_S2	We sell Geo Components products primarily to dealers, contractors, landscapers, road construction companies and government agencies.
58492_13_ITEM1_P5_S0	Our Store Fixtures group designs, produces, installs and manages our customers store fixtures projects.
58492_13_ITEM1_P6_S0	Our Office Furniture Components group designs, manufactures, and distributes a wide range of engineered components targeted for the office seating market.
58492_13_ITEM1_P7_S0	Products manufactured or distributed by our Commercial Fixturing Components groups include:
58492_13_ITEM1_P8_S0	Customers of the Commercial Fixturing Components segment include:
58492_13_ITEM1_P9_S0	We believe that the quality of our products and services, together with low cost, have made us the leading U.S. supplier of drawn steel wire and a major producer of welded steel tubing.
58492_13_ITEM1_P9_S1	Our Wire group operates a steel rod mill with an annual output of approximately 500,000 tons, of which a substantial majority is used by our own wire mills.
58492_13_ITEM1_P9_S2	We have four wire mills that supply virtually all the wire consumed by our other domestic businesses.
58492_13_ITEM1_P9_S3	Our Steel Tubing business unit also supplies nearly all of our internal needs for welded steel tubing.
58492_13_ITEM1_P9_S4	In addition to supporting our internal requirements, we supply many external customers with wire and steel tubing products.
58492_13_ITEM1_P10_S0	On January 12, 2012, we completed the acquisition of Western Pneumatic Tube Holding, LLC (Western).
58492_13_ITEM1_P10_S1	Western is a leading provider of integral components for critical aircraft systems, and forms the Aerospace Products business unit within the Tubing Group.
58492_13_ITEM1_P10_S2	Western specializes in fabricating thin-walled, large diameter, welded tubing and specialty formed products from titanium, nickel and other specialty materials for leading aerospace suppliers and OEMs.
58492_13_ITEM1_P10_S3	For further information about acquisitions, see Note R on page 104 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
58492_13_ITEM1_P11_S0	Products manufactured or distributed by our Industrial Materials groups include:
58492_13_ITEM1_P12_S0	We use about half of our wire output and about one-quarter of our steel tubing output to manufacture our own products.
58492_13_ITEM1_P12_S1	For example, we use our wire and steel tubing to make:
58492_13_ITEM1_P13_S0	The Industrial Materials segment also has a diverse group of external customers, including:
58492_13_ITEM1_P14_S0	Our Specialized Products segment designs, produces and sells components for automotive seating, specialized machinery and equipment, and service van interiors.
58492_13_ITEM1_P15_S0	development have made us a leader in innovation.
58492_13_ITEM1_P15_S1	We also benefit from our broad geographic presence and our internal production of key raw materials and components.
58492_13_ITEM1_P16_S0	Products manufactured or distributed by our Specialized Products groups include:
58492_13_ITEM1_P17_S0	Our primary customers for the Specialized Products segment include:
58492_13_ITEM1_P18_S0	Total Shareholder Return (TSR), relative to peer companies, is the key financial measure that we use to assess long-term performance.
58492_13_ITEM1_P18_S1	TSR = (Change in Stock Price + Dividends)/Beginning Stock Price).
58492_13_ITEM1_P18_S2	Our goal is to achieve TSR in the top 1/3 of the S P 500 over the long term through a balanced approach that employs all four TSR sources: revenue growth, margin expansion, dividends, and share repurchases.
58492_13_ITEM1_P19_S0	We monitor our TSR performance (relative to the S P 500) on a rolling three-year basis.
58492_13_ITEM1_P19_S1	For the three-year measurement period that ended December 31, 2012 we generated TSR of 16% per year, on average, which places us in the top 37% of the S P 500.
58492_13_ITEM1_P19_S2	In addition, our TSR has exceeded that of the S P 500 index for five consecutive years.
58492_13_ITEM1_P20_S0	Our incentive programs reward return generation.

58492_13_ITEM1_P26_S0	We utilize a rigorous strategic planning process to help guide future decisions regarding business unit roles, capital allocation priorities, and new areas in which to grow.
58492_13_ITEM1_P26_S1	We review the portfolio classification of each unit on an annual basis to determine its appropriate role (Grow, Core, Fix, or Divest).
58492_13_ITEM1_P26_S2	This review includes criteria such as competitive position, market attractiveness, business unit size, and fit within our overall objectives, as well as financial indicators such as growth of earnings before interest and taxes (EBIT) and earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization (EBITDA), operating cash flows, and return on assets.
58492_13_ITEM1_P27_S0	Business units in the Grow category should provide avenues for profitable growth from competitively advantaged positions in attractive markets.
58492_13_ITEM1_P28_S0	Core business units are expected to enhance productivity, maintain market share, and generate cash flow from operations while using minimal capital.
58492_13_ITEM1_P28_S1	To remain in the portfolio, business units are expected to consistently generate after-tax returns in excess of our cost of capital.
58492_13_ITEM1_P28_S2	Business units that fail to consistently attain minimum return goals will be moved to the Fix or Divest categories.
58492_13_ITEM1_P29_S0	Long-term, we aim to eventually achieve consistent, profitable growth of 4-5% annually.
58492_13_ITEM1_P29_S1	To attain this goal, we will need to supplement the approximate 2-3% growth that our markets typically produce (in normal economic times) with two additional areas of opportunity.
58492_13_ITEM1_P30_S0	First, we must enhance our success rate at developing and commercializing innovative new products within markets in which we already enjoy strong competitive positions.
58492_13_ITEM1_P30_S1	Second, we need to uncover new growth platforms; opportunities in markets new to us containing margins and growth higher than the Company's average, and in which we would possess a competitive advantage.
58492_13_ITEM1_P31_S0	Our long-term, 4-5% annual growth objective envisions periodic acquisitions.
58492_13_ITEM1_P31_S1	We seek acquisitions within our growth businesses, and look for opportunities to enter new, higher growth markets (carefully screened for sustainable competitive advantage).
58492_13_ITEM1_P32_S0	competitive advantage, and a strong fit with the Company; (b) create value by enhancing Total Shareholder Return and have an internal rate of return in excess of 10%; (c) for stand-alone companies: generally, revenue in excess of $50 million, strong management and future growth opportunity with a strong market position in a market growing faster than GDP; and (d) for add-on companies: generally, revenue in excess of $15 million, significant synergies, and a strategic fit with an existing business unit.

58492_13_ITEM1_P62_S0	We continue to face pressure from foreign competitors as some of our customers source a portion of their components and finished products offshore.
58492_13_ITEM1_P62_S1	In addition to lower labor rates, foreign competitors benefit (at times) from lower raw material costs.
58492_13_ITEM1_P62_S2	They may also benefit from currency factors and more lenient regulatory climates.
58492_13_ITEM1_P63_S0	We typically remain price competitive, even versus many foreign manufacturers, as a result of our efficient operations, low labor content, vertical integration in steel and wire, and large scale purchasing of raw materials and commodities.
58492_13_ITEM1_P63_S1	However, we have also reacted to foreign competition in certain cases, by selectively adjusting prices, and by developing new proprietary products that help our customers reduce total costs.
58492_13_ITEM1_P64_S0	Premium non-innerspring mattresses (those that have either a foam or air core) have experienced rapid growth in the U.S. bedding market in recent years.
58492_13_ITEM1_P64_S1	While still a relatively small portion of the total market in units (approximately 10%-15%), these products represent a much larger portion of the total market in dollars (approximately 25%-30%) due to their higher average selling prices.
58492_13_ITEM1_P64_S2	We expect these products to continue to grow.
58492_13_ITEM1_P64_S3	Some of our traditional bedding customers are now offering mattresses that combine an innerspring core with top layers comprised of specialty foam and gel.
58492_13_ITEM1_P64_S4	These hybrid products, which allow our bedding customers to address a consumer preference for the feel of a specialty mattress and the characteristics of an innerspring, are being well received by consumers.
58492_13_ITEM1_P65_S0	Since early 2009, there have been antidumping duty rates on innerspring imports from China, South Africa and Vietnam, ranging from 116% to 234%.
58492_13_ITEM1_P65_S1	These rates are expected to remain in effect at least until early 2014.
58492_13_ITEM1_P65_S2	Imported innersprings from these countries are now supposed to be sold at fair prices, however the duties on certain innersprings are being evaded by various means including shipping the goods through a third country and falsely identifying the country of origin.
58492_13_ITEM1_P65_S3	Leggett, along with several U.S. manufacturers of products with active antidumping or antidumping/countervailing duty orders, formed a coalition and are working with Members of Congress, the U.S. Department of Commerce, and U.S. Customs and Border Protection to seek stronger enforcement of existing antidumping and/or countervailing duty orders.
58492_13_ITEM1_P66_S0	As a diversified manufacturer, we generally have not experienced significant seasonality.

58492_13_ITEM1_P67_S0	Historically, for the Company as a whole, the second and third quarters typically have proportionately greater sales, while the first and fourth quarters are generally lower.
58492_13_ITEM1_P68_S0	Residential Furnishings: typically does not exhibit any significant seasonality, except for a reduction in fourth quarter sales.
58492_13_ITEM1_P69_S0	Commercial Fixturing Components: generally has modestly stronger third quarter sales of its store fixture products, with the fourth quarter significantly lower.
58492_13_ITEM1_P69_S1	This aligns with the retail industry s normal construction cycle the opening of new stores and completion of remodeling projects in advance of the holiday season.
58492_13_ITEM1_P70_S0	Industrial Materials: minimal variation in sales throughout the year.
58492_13_ITEM1_P71_S0	Specialized Products: relatively little quarter-to-quarter variation in sales, although the automotive business is typically somewhat heavier in the second and fourth quarters of the year and lower in the third quarter due to model changeovers and plant shutdowns in the automobile industry during the summer.

58492_13_ITEM1A_P0_S0	Investing in our securities involves risk.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P0_S1	Set forth below and elsewhere in this report are risk factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from the results contemplated by the forward-looking statements contained in this report.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P0_S2	We may amend or supplement these risk factors from time to time by other reports we file with the SEC.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P1_S0	We have exposure to economic and other factors that affect market demand for our products which may negatively impact our sales, operating cash flow and earnings.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P2_S0	As a supplier of products to a variety of industries, we are adversely affected by general economic downturns.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P2_S1	Our operating performance is heavily influenced by market demand for our components and products.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P2_S2	Market demand for the majority of our products is most heavily influenced by consumer confidence.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P2_S3	To a lesser extent, market demand is impacted by other broad economic factors, including disposable income levels, employment levels, housing turnover, energy costs and interest rates.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P2_S4	All of these factors influence consumer spending on durable goods, and drive demand for our products.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P2_S5	Some of these factors also influence business spending on facilities and equipment, which impacts approximately one-quarter of our sales.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P3_S0	Demand weakness in our markets can lead to lower unit orders, sales and earnings in our businesses.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P4_S0	Several factors, including a weak global economy, a depressed housing market, or low consumer confidence could contribute to conservative spending habits by consumers around the world.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P5_S0	Short lead times in most of our markets allow for limited visibility into demand trends.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P5_S1	Many consumers continue to postpone spending on larger ticket items such as bedding and furniture.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P6_S0	If economic and market conditions deteriorate, we may experience material negative impacts on our business, financial condition, operating cash flows and results of operations.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P7_S0	Costs of raw materials could negatively affect our profit margins and earnings.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P8_S0	Raw material cost increases (and our ability to respond to cost increases through selling price increases) can significantly impact our earnings.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P8_S1	We typically have short-term commitments from our suppliers; therefore, our raw material costs move with the market.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P8_S2	When we experience significant increases in raw material costs, we typically implement price increases to recover the higher costs.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P8_S3	Inability to recover cost increases (or a delay in the recovery time) can negatively impact our earnings.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P8_S4	Conversely, if raw material costs decrease, we generally pass through reduced selling prices to our customers.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P8_S5	Reduced selling prices combined with higher cost inventory can reduce our segment margins and earnings.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Steel is our principal raw material.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P9_S1	The global steel markets are cyclical in nature and have been volatile in recent years.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P9_S2	This volatility can result in large swings in pricing and margins from year to year.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P9_S3	Our operations can also be impacted by changes in the cost of fabrics and foam scrap.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P9_S4	We experienced significant fluctuations in the cost of these commodities in recent years.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P10_S0	As a producer of steel rod, we are also impacted by volatility in metal margins (the difference in the cost of steel scrap and the market price for steel rod).
58492_13_ITEM1A_P10_S1	If scrap costs raise more rapidly than the price of steel rod, the metal margins within our rod producing operation will be compressed.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P10_S2	Compressed metal margins could negatively impact our result of operations.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P11_S0	Higher raw material costs in recent years led some of our customers to modify their product designs, changing the quantity and mix of our components in their finished goods.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P11_S1	In some cases, higher cost components were replaced with lower cost components.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P11_S2	This primarily impacted our Residential Furnishings and Industrial Materials product mix and decreased profit margins.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P11_S3	This trend could further negatively impact our results of operations.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P12_S0	Competition could adversely affect our market share, sales, profit margins and earnings.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P13_S0	We operate in markets that are highly competitive.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P13_S1	We believe that most companies in our lines of business compete primarily on price, but, depending upon the particular product, we experience competition based on quality, performance and availability as well.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P13_S2	We face ongoing pressure from foreign competitors as some of our customers source a portion of their components and finished products from Asia and Europe.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P13_S3	In addition to lower labor rates, foreign competitors benefit (at times) from lower raw material costs.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P13_S4	They may also benefit from currency factors and more lenient regulatory climates.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P14_S0	If we are unable to purchase key raw materials, such as steel, at prices competitive with those of foreign suppliers, our ability to maintain market share and profit margins could be harmed by foreign competitors.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P15_S0	Premium non-innerspring mattresses (those that have either a foam or air core) have experienced rapid growth in the U.S. bedding market in recent years.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P15_S1	While still a relatively small portion of the total market in units (approximately 10%-15%), these products represent a much larger portion of the total market in dollars (approximately 25%-30%) due to their higher average selling prices.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P15_S2	If sales of foam or air core mattresses continue to grow appreciably, it could reduce our market share in the U.S. bedding market, and negatively impact our sales and earnings.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P16_S0	Our goodwill and other long-lived assets are subject to potential impairment which could negatively impact our earnings.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P17_S0	A significant portion of our assets consists of goodwill and other long-lived assets, the carrying value of which may be reduced if we determine that those assets are impaired.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P17_S1	At December 31, 2012, goodwill and other intangible assets represented approximately $1.2 billion, or approximately 37% of our total assets.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P17_S2	In addition, net property, plant and equipment and sundry assets totaled approximately $718 million, or approximately 22% of total assets.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P18_S0	We review our ten reporting units for potential goodwill impairment in June as part of our annual goodwill impairment testing, and more often if an event or circumstance occurs making it likely that impairment exists.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P18_S1	In addition, we test for the recoverability of long-lived assets at year end, and more often if an event or circumstance indicates the carrying value may not be recoverable.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P18_S2	We conduct impairment testing based on our current business strategy in light of present industry and economic conditions, as well as future expectations.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P18_S3	The annual goodwill impairment review performed in June 2012 indicated no goodwill impairments, but fair market value for one of our ten reporting units (Store Fixtures) only exceeded book value by approximately 10%.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P18_S4	The fair market values of all other reporting units exceeded book value by more than 35%.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P18_S5	The goodwill associated with the Store Fixtures reporting unit was $111 million at December 31, 2012.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P19_S0	The unit is dependent upon capital spending by retailers on both new stores and remodeling of existing stores.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P19_S1	Although recent performance has met expectations, the predictability of future results is less certain than that of our other reporting units due to the project nature of this business.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P19_S2	If we are not able to maintain current performance levels, future impairments could be possible.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P20_S0	If actual results differ from the assumptions and estimates used in the goodwill and long-lived asset calculations, we could incur impairment charges, which could negatively impact our earnings.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P21_S0	We are exposed to foreign currency risk which may negatively impact our competitiveness, profit margins and earnings.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P22_S0	We expect that international sales will continue to represent a significant percentage of our total sales, which exposes us to currency exchange rate fluctuations.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P22_S1	In 2012, 27% of our sales were generated by international operations.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P22_S2	The revenues and expenses of our foreign operations are generally denominated in local currencies; however, certain of our operations experience currency-related gains and losses where sales or purchases are denominated in currencies other than their local currency.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P22_S3	Further, our competitive position may be affected by the relative strength of the currencies in countries where our products are sold.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P22_S4	Foreign currency exchange risks inherent in doing business in foreign countries may have a material adverse effect on our future operations and financial results.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P23_S0	Technology failures or cyber security breaches could have a material adverse effect on our operations.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P24_S0	We rely on information systems to obtain, process, analyze and manage data, as well as to facilitate the manufacture and distribution of inventory to and from our facilities.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P24_S1	We receive, process and ship orders, manage the billing of, and collections from, our customers, and manage the accounting for, and payment to, our vendors.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P24_S2	Security breaches of this infrastructure can create system disruptions or unauthorized disclosure of confidential information.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P24_S3	If this occurs, our operations could be disrupted, or we may suffer financial loss because of lost or misappropriated information.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P24_S4	We cannot be certain that advances in criminal capabilities or new discoveries in the field of cryptography will not compromise our technology protecting information systems.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P24_S5	If these systems are interrupted or damaged by these events or fail for any extended period of time, then our results of operations could be adversely affected.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P25_S0	New conflict minerals regulations may adversely affect the sourcing, availability and pricing of conflict minerals or components which contain conflict minerals, and may result in loss of sales, additional expenses and reduced profitability.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P26_S0	On August 22, 2012, as mandated by the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act of 2010, the SEC adopted new disclosure regulations for public companies that manufacture products that contain certain minerals and their derivatives, namely tin, tantalum, tungsten or gold, known as conflict minerals, if these minerals are necessary to the functionality or production of the company's products.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P26_S1	These regulations require such issuers to report annually whether or not such minerals originate from the Democratic Republic of Congo and adjoining countries and in some cases to perform extensive due diligence on their supply chains for such minerals.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P26_S2	The implementation of these new requirements could adversely affect the sourcing, availability and pricing of conflict minerals used in the manufacture of certain electronic components, including those assembled into our products.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P26_S3	In addition, we may incur additional costs to comply with the disclosure requirements, including costs related to determining the source of any of the relevant minerals used in our products.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P26_S4	Since our supply chain is complex, the due diligence procedures that we implement may not enable us to ascertain the origins for these minerals or determine that these minerals are DRC conflict-free, which may harm our reputation.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P26_S5	We may also face difficulties in satisfying customers who may require that our products be certified as DRC conflict-free, which could harm our relationships with these customers and lead to a loss of sales.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P26_S6	These new requirements also could have the effect of limiting the pool of suppliers from which we source these minerals, and we may be unable to obtain conflict-free minerals at competitive prices, which could increase our costs and adversely affect our manufacturing operations and our profitability.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P26_S7	Deteriorating financial condition of our customers could negatively affect our sales, earnings, cash flows and liquidity.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P27_S0	We serve customers in a variety of industries, some of which have and are continuing to experience low levels of demand.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P27_S1	A sustained economic downturn increases the possibility that one or more of our significant customers, or a group of less significant customers, could become insolvent, which could adversely impact our sales, earnings, cash flow and liquidity.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P28_S0	We may not be able to realize deferred tax assets on our balance sheet depending upon the amount and source of future taxable income.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P29_S0	Our ability to realize deferred tax assets on our balance sheet is dependent upon the amount and source of future taxable income.
58492_13_ITEM1A_P29_S1	Economic uncertainty or tax law changes could change our underlying assumptions on which valuation reserves are established and negatively affect future period earnings and balance sheets.

58492_13_ITEM7_P4_S1	Only two other S P 500 companies can claim as high a rate of dividend growth for as many years.

58492_13_ITEM7_P5_S2	We ended the year with the entire $600 million available under our existing commercial paper program and revolver facility.
58492_13_ITEM7_P6_S0	We assess our overall performance by comparing our Total Shareholder Return (TSR) to that of peer companies on a rolling three-year basis.
58492_13_ITEM7_P6_S1	We target TSR in the top one-third of the S P 500 over the long term.
58492_13_ITEM7_P6_S2	For the three years ended December 31, 2012, we generated TSR of 16% per year on average.
58492_13_ITEM7_P6_S3	That places us in the top 37% of the S P 500, just shy of our top one-third goal.
58492_13_ITEM7_P7_S0	These topics are discussed in more detail in the sections that follow.
58492_13_ITEM7_P8_S0	Total Shareholder Return (TSR), relative to peer companies, is the key financial measure that we use to assess long-term performance.
58492_13_ITEM7_P8_S1	TSR is driven by the change in our share price and the dividends we pay [TSR = (Change in Stock Price + Dividends) / Beginning Stock Price].
58492_13_ITEM7_P8_S2	We seek to achieve TSR in the top one-third of the S P 500 over the long-term through a balanced approach that employs all four TSR sources: revenue growth, margin expansion, dividends, and share repurchases.
58492_13_ITEM7_P9_S0	We monitor our TSR performance (relative to the S P 500) on a rolling three-year basis.
58492_13_ITEM7_P9_S1	For the three-year measurement period that ended December 31, 2012, we generated TSR of 16% per year on average, compared to 11% for the S P 500 index.
58492_13_ITEM7_P9_S2	That places us in the top 37% of the S P 500, just shy of our top one-third goal.
58492_13_ITEM7_P10_S0	Our incentive programs reward improved return on investment.
58492_13_ITEM7_P11_S0	Senior executives participate in a TSR-based incentive program (based on our performance compared to the performance of a group of approximately 320 peers).
58492_13_ITEM7_P12_S0	Business unit bonuses emphasize the achievement of higher returns on the assets under the unit s direct control.
58492_13_ITEM7_P13_S0	We serve a broad suite of customers, with our largest customer representing approximately 6% of our sales.
58492_13_ITEM7_P13_S1	Many are companies whose names are widely recognized; they include most manufacturers of furniture and bedding, a variety of other manufacturers, and many major retailers.
58492_13_ITEM7_P14_S0	Many factors impact our business, but those that generally have the greatest impact are market demand, raw material cost trends, and competition.
58492_13_ITEM7_P15_S0	Market demand (including product mix) is impacted by several economic factors, with consumer confidence being most significant.
58492_13_ITEM7_P15_S1	Other important factors include disposable income levels, employment levels, housing turnover, and interest rates.
58492_13_ITEM7_P15_S2	All these factors influence consumer spending on durable goods, and therefore affect demand for our components and products.
58492_13_ITEM7_P15_S3	Some of these factors also influence business spending on facilities and equipment, which impacts approximately one-quarter of our sales.
58492_13_ITEM7_P16_S0	Demand improved in several of our markets during 2012.
58492_13_ITEM7_P16_S1	As expected, we realized significant earnings leverage as unit volumes grew, and this led to improved margins.
58492_13_ITEM7_P17_S0	Over the last few years we have significantly reduced our fixed cost structure, but purposely retained spare production capacity.
58492_13_ITEM7_P17_S1	Accordingly, unit sales can increase appreciably without the need for large capital investment.
58492_13_ITEM7_P17_S2	We have meaningful operating leverage that should further benefit earnings as market demand continues to improve.
58492_13_ITEM7_P17_S3	With our current utilization levels, we should be able to readily accommodate over $4 billion in revenue (assuming current sales mix).
58492_13_ITEM7_P17_S4	Until our spare capacity is fully utilized, each additional $100 million of sales from incremental unit volume is expected to generate approximately $25 million to $35 million of additional pre-tax earnings.
58492_13_ITEM7_P18_S0	In many of our businesses, we enjoy a cost advantage from buying large quantities of raw materials.
58492_13_ITEM7_P18_S1	This purchasing leverage is a benefit that many of our competitors generally do not have.
58492_13_ITEM7_P18_S2	Still, our costs can vary significantly as market prices for raw materials (many of which are commodities) fluctuate.
58492_13_ITEM7_P19_S0	We typically have short-term commitments from our suppliers; accordingly, our raw material costs generally move with the market.
58492_13_ITEM7_P19_S1	Our ability to recover higher costs (through selling price increases) is crucial.
58492_13_ITEM7_P19_S2	When we experience significant increases in raw material costs, we typically implement price increases to recover the higher costs.
58492_13_ITEM7_P19_S3	Conversely, when costs decrease significantly, we generally pass those lower costs through to our customers.
58492_13_ITEM7_P19_S4	The timing of our price increases or decreases is important; we typically experience a lag in recovering higher costs, so we also expect to realize a lag as costs decline.
58492_13_ITEM7_P20_S0	Steel is our principal raw material and at various times in past years we have experienced extreme cost fluctuations in this commodity.
58492_13_ITEM7_P20_S1	In most cases, the major changes (both increases and decreases) were passed through to customers with selling price adjustments.
58492_13_ITEM7_P20_S2	In late 2010, steel costs began increasing, and we raised our selling prices in early 2011 to recover the majority of the higher costs.
58492_13_ITEM7_P20_S3	By mid-year 2011, market prices for certain types of steel had begun to decrease.
58492_13_ITEM7_P20_S4	The margin pressure we experienced in the last half of 2011 resulted in part from lowering our selling prices (selectively) in advance of our average cost of steel declining, in order to maintain market share and minimize deterioration in product mix.
58492_13_ITEM7_P20_S5	The alignment of costs and pricing improved in 2012.
58492_13_ITEM7_P20_S6	During the year, we experienced month-to-month variability in steel costs, but overall for 2012, costs decreased slightly.
58492_13_ITEM7_P21_S0	As a producer of steel rod, we are also impacted by volatility in metal margins (the difference in the cost of steel scrap and the market price for steel rod).
58492_13_ITEM7_P21_S1	Steel scrap costs (and metal margins) were relatively stable for the majority of 2011.
58492_13_ITEM7_P21_S2	As mentioned above, in 2012 we experienced month-to-month variability in steel scrap costs and steel rod pricing, however for the full year, metal margins were comparable to 2011.
58492_13_ITEM7_P22_S0	Our other raw materials include woven and non-woven fabrics, foam scrap, and chemicals.
58492_13_ITEM7_P22_S1	We have experienced changes in the cost of these materials in recent years, and in most years, have been able to pass them through to our customers.
58492_13_ITEM7_P23_S0	When we raise our prices to recover higher raw material costs, this sometimes causes customers to modify their product designs and replace higher cost components with lower cost components.
58492_13_ITEM7_P23_S1	We experienced this de-contenting effect in our Residential Furnishings segment in the back half of 2011 (however selective selling price reductions helped contain this activity).
58492_13_ITEM7_P23_S2	As our customers changed the quantity and mix of components in their finished goods to address commodity inflation, our profit margins were negatively impacted.
58492_13_ITEM7_P23_S3	We must continue to find ways to assist our customers in improving the functionality and reducing the cost of their products, while providing higher margin and profit contribution for our operations.
58492_13_ITEM7_P24_S0	Many of our markets are highly competitive with the number of competitors varying by product line.
58492_13_ITEM7_P24_S1	In general, our competitors tend to be smaller, private companies.
58492_13_ITEM7_P24_S2	Many of our competitors, both domestic and foreign, compete primarily on the basis of price.
58492_13_ITEM7_P24_S3	Our success has stemmed from the ability to remain price competitive, while delivering better product quality, innovation, and customer service.
58492_13_ITEM7_P25_S0	We continue to face pressure from foreign competitors as some of our customers source a portion of their components and finished products offshore.
58492_13_ITEM7_P25_S1	In addition to lower labor rates, foreign competitors benefit (at times) from lower raw material costs.
58492_13_ITEM7_P25_S2	They may also benefit from currency factors and more lenient regulatory climates.
58492_13_ITEM7_P26_S0	We typically remain price competitive, even versus many foreign manufacturers, as a result of our highly efficient operations, low labor content, vertical integration in steel and wire, and large scale purchasing of raw materials and commodities.
58492_13_ITEM7_P26_S1	However, we have also reacted to foreign competition in certain cases by selectively adjusting prices, and by developing new proprietary products that help our customers reduce total costs.
58492_13_ITEM7_P26_S2	The margin pressure we experienced in the last half of 2011 resulted in part from price competition in certain of our businesses as we reduced prices (selectively) to maintain market share in light of depressed industry volume.
58492_13_ITEM7_P27_S0	Premium non-innerspring mattresses (those that have either a foam or air core) have experienced rapid growth in the U.S. bedding market in recent years.
58492_13_ITEM7_P27_S1	While still a relatively small portion of the total market in units (approximately 10%-15%), these products represent a much larger portion of the total market in dollars (approximately 25%-30%) due to their higher average selling prices.
58492_13_ITEM7_P27_S2	We expect these products to continue to grow.
58492_13_ITEM7_P27_S3	Some of our traditional bedding customers are now offering mattresses that combine an innerspring core with top layers comprised of specialty foam and gel.
58492_13_ITEM7_P27_S4	These hybrid products, which allow our bedding customers to address a consumer preference for the feel of a specialty mattress and the characteristics of an innerspring, are being well received by consumers.
58492_13_ITEM7_P28_S0	We filed an antidumping suit related to innerspring imports from China, South Africa and Vietnam which was brought to a favorable conclusion in early 2009.
58492_13_ITEM7_P28_S1	The current antidumping duty rates on innersprings from these countries are significant, ranging from 116% to 234%, and should remain in effect at least until early 2014.
58492_13_ITEM7_P28_S2	Imported innersprings from these countries are now supposed to be sold at fair prices, however the duties on certain innersprings are being evaded by various means including shipping the goods through a third country and falsely identifying the country of origin.
58492_13_ITEM7_P28_S3	In 2009, Leggett, along with several U.S. manufacturers of products with active antidumping or antidumping/countervailing duty orders, formed a coalition and are working with Members of Congress, the U.S. Department of Commerce, and U.S. Customs and Border Protection to seek stronger enforcement of existing antidumping and/or countervailing duty orders.
58492_13_ITEM7_P29_S0	In December 2011, we approved a restructuring plan to reduce our overhead costs and improve ongoing profitability.
58492_13_ITEM7_P30_S0	The activities primarily entailed the closure of four underperforming facilities.
58492_13_ITEM7_P30_S1	We incurred a $37 million pre-tax (largely non-cash) charge in the 4 th quarter of 2011 primarily related to this plan, which included $31 million of long-lived asset impairments and $6 million of other restructuring-related costs.
58492_13_ITEM7_P30_S2	During 2012, we incurred an additional $2 million of restructuring-related costs and $1 million of long-lived asset impairments related to this plan.
58492_13_ITEM7_P30_S3	These activities were substantially complete by the end of 2012 and no significant additional costs related to the plan are expected.

58492_13_ITEM7_P116_S0	Earnings consist principally of income from continuing operations before income taxes, plus fixed charges.

58492_13_ITEM7_P118_S0	Long-term debt to total capitalization as reported in the previous table.

58492_13_ITEM7_P120_S0	We believe that adjusting this measure for cash and current maturities allows a more useful comparison to periods during which cash fluctuates significantly.
58492_13_ITEM7_P120_S1	We use these adjusted measures to monitor our financial leverage.

58492_13_ITEM7_P123_S1	This results in a fully weighted effective interest rate of 5.0% associated with the notes.

58492_13_ITEM7_P124_S2	The credit agreement allows us to issue letters of credit up to $250 million.

58492_13_ITEM7_P134_S0	We prepare our consolidated financial statements in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
58492_13_ITEM7_P134_S1	To do so, we must make estimates and judgments that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues, expenses, and disclosures.
58492_13_ITEM7_P134_S2	If we used different estimates or judgments our financial statements would change, and some of those changes could be significant.
58492_13_ITEM7_P134_S3	Our estimates are frequently based upon historical experience and are considered by management, at the time they are made, to be reasonable and appropriate.
58492_13_ITEM7_P135_S0	Estimates are adjusted for actual events, as they occur.
58492_13_ITEM7_P136_S0	Critical accounting estimates are those that are: a) subject to uncertainty and change, and b) of material impact to our financial statements.
58492_13_ITEM7_P136_S1	Listed below are the estimates and judgments which we believe could have the most significant effect on our financial statements.
58492_13_ITEM7_P137_S0	We provide additional details regarding our significant accounting policies in Note A to the Consolidated Financial Statements on page 71.
58492_13_ITEM7_P138_S0	Goodwill is assessed for impairment annually as of June 30 and as triggering events occur.
58492_13_ITEM7_P138_S1	In the past three years, no impairments have been recorded as a result of the annual impairment reviews.
58492_13_ITEM7_P139_S0	In order to assess goodwill for potential impairment, judgment is required to estimate the fair market value of each reporting unit (which is one level below reportable segments) using the combination of a discounted cash flow model and a market approach using price to earnings ratios for comparable publicly traded companies with characteristics similar to the reporting unit.
58492_13_ITEM7_P140_S0	The cash flow model contains uncertainties related to the forecast of future results as many outside economic and competitive factors can influence future performance.
58492_13_ITEM7_P140_S1	Margins, sales growth, and discount rates are the most critical estimates in determining enterprise values using the cash flow model.
58492_13_ITEM7_P141_S0	Fair market value for one of the 10 reporting units (Store Fixtures) exceeded book value by approximately 10%.
58492_13_ITEM7_P141_S1	The goodwill associated with this reporting unit is $111 million, and is dependent on capital spending by retailers on both new stores and remodeling of existing stores.
58492_13_ITEM7_P141_S2	Retailer activity was roughly flat in 2012, and the Store Fixtures reporting unit met full-year expectations.
58492_13_ITEM7_P141_S3	However, due to the project nature of this business, the predictability of future results is less certain than that of other reporting units.
58492_13_ITEM7_P141_S4	If we are not able to maintain current performance levels, future impairments could be possible.
58492_13_ITEM7_P142_S0	The remaining reporting units have fair market values that exceed carrying value by more than 35%, and have goodwill of $880 million.
58492_13_ITEM7_P143_S0	The market approach requires judgment to determine the appropriate price to earnings ratio.
58492_13_ITEM7_P144_S0	Ratios are derived from comparable publicly-traded companies that operate in the same or similar industry as the reporting unit.
58492_13_ITEM7_P145_S0	Information regarding material assumptions used to determine if a goodwill impairment exists can be found in Note C on page 75.
58492_13_ITEM7_P146_S0	Other long-lived assets are tested for recoverability at year-end and whenever events or circumstances indicate the carrying value may not be recoverable.
58492_13_ITEM7_P147_S0	For other long-lived assets we estimate fair value at the lowest level where cash flows can be measured (usually at a branch level).
58492_13_ITEM7_P148_S0	Impairments of other long-lived assets usually occur when major restructuring activities take place, or we decide to discontinue product lines completely.
58492_13_ITEM7_P149_S0	Our impairment assessments have uncertainties because they require estimates of future cash flows to determine if undiscounted cash flows are sufficient to recover carrying values of these assets.
58492_13_ITEM7_P150_S0	For assets where future cash flows are not expected to recover carrying value, fair value is estimated which requires an estimate of market value based upon asset appraisals for like assets.
58492_13_ITEM7_P151_S0	Impairments were $2 million in 2012, $35 million in 2011, and $2 million in 2010.
58492_13_ITEM7_P152_S0	The 2011 impairments were largely the result of lowered future business expectations at several underperforming locations that resulted in the decision to exit some unprofitable lines of business.
58492_13_ITEM7_P152_S1	Prior forecasts assumed a recovery in business levels (primarily housing related industries) that had not materialized by late 2011.
58492_13_ITEM7_P153_S0	We reduce the carrying value of inventories to reflect an estimate of net realizable value for obsolete and slow-moving inventory.
58492_13_ITEM7_P154_S0	Our inventory reserve contains uncertainties because the calculation requires management to make assumptions about the value of products that are obsolete or slow-moving (i.e. not selling very quickly).
58492_13_ITEM7_P155_S0	At December 31, 2012, the reserve for obsolete and slow-moving inventory was $36 million (approximately 6% of FIFO inventories).
58492_13_ITEM7_P156_S0	If we have had no sales of a given product for 12 months, those items are generally deemed to have no value and are written down completely.
58492_13_ITEM7_P157_S0	If we have more than a one-year s supply of a product, we value that inventory at net realizable value (what we think we will recover).
58492_13_ITEM7_P158_S0	Changes in customer behavior and requirements can cause inventory to quickly become obsolete or slow moving.
58492_13_ITEM7_P159_S0	The calculation also uses an estimate of the ultimate recoverability of items identified as slow moving based upon historical experience (65% on average).
58492_13_ITEM7_P160_S0	Additions to inventory reserves in 2012 were $10 million, which were comparable to the previous year.
58492_13_ITEM7_P160_S1	We do not expect obsolescence to change from current levels.
58492_13_ITEM7_P161_S0	We are substantially self-insured for costs related to workers compensation, and this requires us to estimate the liability associated with this obligation.
58492_13_ITEM7_P162_S0	Our estimates of self-insured reserves contain uncertainties regarding the potential amounts we might have to pay (since we are self-insured).
58492_13_ITEM7_P162_S1	We consider a number of factors, including historical claim experience, demographic factors, and potential recoveries from third party insurance carriers.
58492_13_ITEM7_P163_S0	Over the past five years, we have incurred, on average, $10 million annually for costs associated with workers compensation.
58492_13_ITEM7_P163_S1	Average year-to-year variation over the past five years has been approximately $1 million.
58492_13_ITEM7_P163_S2	At December 31, 2012, we had accrued $33 million to cover future self-insurance liabilities.
58492_13_ITEM7_P164_S0	Internal safety statistics and cost trends have improved in the last several years.
58492_13_ITEM7_P164_S1	We expect worker compensation costs to remain at current lower levels for the foreseeable future.
58492_13_ITEM7_P165_S0	For accounts and notes receivable, we estimate a bad debt reserve for the amount that will ultimately be uncollectible.
58492_13_ITEM7_P166_S0	When we become aware of a specific customer s potential inability to pay, we record a bad debt reserve for the amount we believe may not be collectible.
58492_13_ITEM7_P167_S0	Our bad debt reserve contains uncertainties because it requires management to estimate the amount uncollectible based upon an evaluation of several factors such as the length of time that receivables are past due, the financial health of the customer, industry and macroeconomic considerations, and historical loss experience.
58492_13_ITEM7_P168_S0	A significant change in the financial status of a large customer could impact our estimates.
58492_13_ITEM7_P169_S0	The average annual amount of customer-related credit losses was $6 million (less than 1% of annual net sales) over the last three years.
58492_13_ITEM7_P169_S1	At December 31, 2012, our reserves for doubtful accounts totaled $20 million (about 5% of our accounts and customer-related notes receivable of $434 million).
58492_13_ITEM7_P170_S0	Our customers are diverse and many are small-to-medium sized companies, with some being highly leveraged.
58492_13_ITEM7_P170_S1	Bankruptcy can occur with some of these customers relatively quickly and with little warning.
58492_13_ITEM7_P171_S0	In 2012 and 2011, bad debt expense averaged $7 million.
58492_13_ITEM7_P172_S0	We have not experienced any significant individual customer bankruptcies in the past two years.
58492_13_ITEM7_P172_S1	We believe the financial health of our major customers has modestly improved, but some are highly leveraged, and this could cause circumstances to change in the future.
58492_13_ITEM7_P173_S0	At December 31, 2012, we had $11 million of non-customer notes receivable, primarily related to divested businesses, and have recorded reserves of $1 million for these notes.
58492_13_ITEM7_P173_S1	Most of these notes are to be paid by highly leveraged entities, which could result in the need for additional reserves in the future.
58492_13_ITEM7_P174_S0	For our pension plans, we must estimate the cost of benefits to be provided (well into the future) and the current value of those benefit obligations.
58492_13_ITEM7_P175_S0	The pension liability calculation contains uncertainties because it requires management to estimate an appropriate discount rate to calculate the present value of future benefits paid, which also impacts current year pension expense.
58492_13_ITEM7_P176_S0	Determination of pension expense requires an estimate of expected return on pension assets based upon the mix of investments held (bonds and equities).
58492_13_ITEM7_P177_S0	The discount rates used to calculate the pension liability for our most significant plans decreased approximately 50 basis points in 2012 due to lower corporate bond yields.
58492_13_ITEM7_P177_S1	Each 25 basis point decrease in the discount rate increases pension expense by $.5 million and increases the plans benefit obligation by $9.6 million.
58492_13_ITEM7_P178_S0	Other assumptions include rates of compensation increases, withdrawal and mortality rates, and retirement ages.
58492_13_ITEM7_P178_S1	These estimates impact the pension expense or income we recognize and our reported benefit obligations.
58492_13_ITEM7_P179_S0	The expected return on assets in 2012 decreased to 6.6%, compared to 6.7% in 2011 and 6.8% in 2010.
58492_13_ITEM7_P179_S1	A 25 basis point reduction in the expected return on assets would increase pension expense by $.5 million, but have no effect on the plans funded status.
58492_13_ITEM7_P180_S0	Assuming a long-term investment horizon, we do not expect a material change to the return on asset assumption.
58492_13_ITEM7_P181_S0	In the ordinary course of business, we must make estimates of the tax treatment of many transactions, even though the ultimate tax outcome may remain uncertain for some time.
58492_13_ITEM7_P181_S1	These estimates become part of the annual income tax expense reported in our financial statements.
58492_13_ITEM7_P181_S2	Subsequent to year end, we finalize our tax analysis and file income tax returns.
58492_13_ITEM7_P181_S3	Tax authorities periodically audit these income tax returns and examine our tax filing positions, including (among other things) the timing and amounts of deductions, and the allocation of income among tax jurisdictions.
58492_13_ITEM7_P182_S0	We adjust income tax expense in our financial statements in the periods in which the actual outcome becomes more certain.
58492_13_ITEM7_P183_S0	Our tax liability for unrecognized tax benefits contains uncertainties because management is required to make assumptions and to apply judgment to estimate the exposures related to our various filing positions.
58492_13_ITEM7_P184_S0	Our effective tax rate is also impacted by changes in tax laws, the current mix of earnings by taxing jurisdiction, and the results of current tax audits and assessments.
58492_13_ITEM7_P185_S0	Potential changes in tax laws could impact assumptions related to the non-repatriation of certain foreign earnings.
58492_13_ITEM7_P185_S1	In 2012, we accrued $11 million for taxes on earnings that are no longer indefinitely reinvested in China.
58492_13_ITEM7_P185_S2	If all non-repatriated earnings were taxed, we would incur additional taxes of approximately $42 million.
58492_13_ITEM7_P186_S0	Tax audits by various taxing authorities are expected to increase as governments continue to look for ways to raise additional revenue.
58492_13_ITEM7_P186_S1	Based upon past experience, we do not expect any material changes to our tax liability as a result of this increased audit activity; however, we could incur additional tax expense if we have audit adjustments higher than recent historical experience.
58492_13_ITEM7_P187_S0	At December 31, 2012 and 2011, we had $39 million and $14 million, respectively, of net deferred tax assets on our balance sheet related to operating loss and tax credit carryforwards.
58492_13_ITEM7_P187_S1	The ultimate realization of these deferred tax assets is dependent upon the amount, source, and timing of future taxable income.
58492_13_ITEM7_P187_S2	Valuation allowances are established against future potential tax benefits to reflect the amounts we believe have no more than a 50% probability of being realized.
58492_13_ITEM7_P188_S0	In addition, assumptions have been made regarding the non-repatriation of earnings from certain subsidiaries.
58492_13_ITEM7_P188_S1	Those assumptions may change in the future, thereby affecting future period results for the tax impact of possible repatriation.
58492_13_ITEM7_P189_S0	The recovery of net operating losses (NOL s) has been closely evaluated for the likelihood of recovery based upon factors such as the age of losses, viable tax planning strategies, and future taxable earnings expectations.
58492_13_ITEM7_P189_S1	We believe that appropriate valuation allowances have been recorded as necessary.
58492_13_ITEM7_P189_S2	However, if earnings expectations or other assumptions change such that additional valuation allowances are required, we could incur additional tax expense.
58492_13_ITEM7_P190_S0	We assessed our ability to recover Canadian NOL's and other deferred tax assets, and determined that previously recorded valuation allowances were no longer necessary.
58492_13_ITEM7_P190_S1	Therefore, we recorded income of $38 million in the fourth quarter of 2012 related to this reversal.
58492_13_ITEM7_P191_S0	We evaluate various legal, environmental, and other potential claims against us to determine if an accrual or disclosure of the contingency is appropriate.
58492_13_ITEM7_P191_S1	If it is probable that an ultimate loss will be incurred, we accrue a liability for the reasonable estimate of the ultimate loss.
58492_13_ITEM7_P192_S0	Our disclosure and accrual of loss contingencies (i.e., losses that may or may not occur) contain uncertainties because they are based on our assessment of the likelihood that the expenses will actually occur, and our estimate of the likely cost.
58492_13_ITEM7_P192_S1	Our estimates and judgments are subjective and can involve matters in litigation, the results of which are generally very unpredictable.
58492_13_ITEM7_P193_S0	We have several environmental clean-up activities related to current and closed facilities that mostly involve soil and groundwater contamination.
58492_13_ITEM7_P193_S1	Based upon facts available at this time, we believe reserves are adequate, however cost estimates could change as we determine more about the severity and cost of remediation.
