58492_13_ITEM7_P195_S1	Our estimates and judgments are subjective and can involve matters in litigation, the results of which are generally very unpredictable.
58492_13_ITEM7_P196_S0	Shareholder Derivative Lawsuit On August 10, 2010, a shareholder derivative suit was filed by the New England Carpenters Pension Fund in the Circuit Court of Jasper County, Missouri as Case No. 10AO-CC284 ( 2010 Suit ).
58492_13_ITEM7_P196_S1	The 2010 Suit was substantially similar to a prior suit filed by the same plaintiff, in the same court, on February 5, 2009 ( 2009 Suit ).
58492_13_ITEM7_P196_S2	The 2009 Suit was dismissed without prejudice based on the plaintiff's failure to make demand on our Board and shareholders.
58492_13_ITEM7_P196_S3	As before, the plaintiff did not make such demand.
58492_13_ITEM7_P196_S4	On April 6, 2011, the 2010 Suit was dismissed without prejudice.
58492_13_ITEM7_P197_S0	On May 12, 2011, the plaintiff filed an appeal to the Missouri Court of Appeals.
58492_13_ITEM7_P197_S1	On November 28, 2012, the Missouri Court of Appeals reversed the trial court's dismissal, and remanded the case back to the trial court finding that plaintiff sufficiently pled demand on the Board and shareholders.
58492_13_ITEM7_P197_S2	We filed a request for transfer to the Missouri Supreme Court on December 12, 2012, which was denied by the Court of Appeals.
58492_13_ITEM7_P197_S3	On January 3, 2013, we filed a transfer petition to the Missouri Supreme Court.
58492_13_ITEM7_P197_S4	On February 26, 2013, the Missouri Supreme Court denied our request.
58492_13_ITEM7_P197_S5	The case will be sent back to Jasper County, Missouri for further proceedings.
58492_13_ITEM7_P198_S0	The 2010 Suit was purportedly brought on our behalf, naming us as a nominal defendant, and certain current and former officers and directors as individual defendants including David S. Haffner, Karl G. Glassman, Matthew C. Flanigan, Ernest C. Jett, Harry M. Cornell, Jr., Felix E. Wright, Robert Ted Enloe, III, Richard T. Fisher, Judy C. Odom, Maurice E. Purnell, Jr., Ralph W. Clark and Michael A. Glauber.
58492_13_ITEM7_P198_S1	The plaintiff alleged, among other things, that the individual defendants: breached their fiduciary duties; backdated and received backdated stock options violating our stock plans; caused or allowed us to issue false and misleading financial statements and proxy statements; sold our stock while possessing material non-public information; committed gross mismanagement; wasted corporate assets; committed fraud; violated the Missouri Securities Act; and were unjustly enriched.
58492_13_ITEM7_P198_S2	The plaintiff is seeking, among other things: unspecified monetary damages against the individual defendants; certain equitable and other relief relating to the profits from the alleged improper conduct; the adoption of certain corporate governance proposals; the imposition of a constructive trust over the defendants' stock options and proceeds; punitive damages; the rescission of certain unexercised options; and the reimbursement of litigation costs.
58492_13_ITEM7_P198_S3	The plaintiff is not seeking monetary relief from us.
58492_13_ITEM7_P198_S4	We have director and officer liability insurance in force subject to customary limits and exclusions.
58492_13_ITEM7_P198_S5	We and the individual defendants filed motions to dismiss the 2010 Suit in late October 2010, asserting: the plaintiff failed to make demand on our Board and shareholders as required by Missouri law, and, consistent with the Court's ruling in the 2009 Suit, this failure to make demand should not be excused; the dismissal of the 2009 Suit precludes the 2010 Suit; the plaintiff is not a representative shareholder; the 2010 Suit was based on a statistical analysis of stock option grants and our stock prices that we believe was flawed; the plaintiff failed to state a substantive claim; the common law fraud claim was not pled with sufficient particularity; and the statute of limitations has expired on the fraud claim and all the alleged challenged grants except the December 30, 2005 grant.
58492_13_ITEM7_P198_S6	As to this grant, the motions to dismiss advised the Court that it was made under our Deferred Compensation Program, which (i) provided that options would be dated on the last business day of December, and (ii) was filed with the SEC on December 2, 2005 setting out the pricing mechanism well before the grant date.
58492_13_ITEM7_P198_S7	We do not expect that the outcome of this matter will have a material adverse effect on our financial condition, operating cash flows or results of operations.
58492_13_ITEM7_P199_S0	Antitrust Lawsuits Beginning in August 2010, a series of civil lawsuits was initiated in several U.S. federal courts and in Canada against over 20 defendants alleging that competitors of our carpet underlay business unit and other manufacturers of polyurethane foam products had engaged in price fixing in violation of U.S. and Canadian antitrust laws.
58492_13_ITEM7_P199_S1	A number of these lawsuits have been voluntarily dismissed, most without prejudice.
58492_13_ITEM7_P199_S2	Of the U.S. cases remaining, we have been named as a defendant in (a) three direct purchaser class action cases (the first on November 15, 2010) and a consolidated amended class action complaint filed on February 28, 2011 on behalf of a class of all direct purchasers of polyurethane foam products; (b) an indirect purchaser class consolidated amended complaint filed on March 21, 2011 (although the underlying lawsuits do not name us as a defendant); and an indirect purchaser class action case filed on May 23, 2011; (c) 36 individual direct purchaser cases, (i) one filed March 22, 2011, (ii) another amended August 24, 2011 to remove class allegations, (iii) one amended August 25, 2011 to name us as a defendant, (iv) three others filed October 31, 2011, (v) one filed November 4, 2011, (vi) three filed December 6, 19 and 30, 2011, respectively, (vii) one filed January 27, 2012, (viii) five filed March 19, 2012, (ix) one amended March 30, 2012 to name us as a defendant, (x) one filed April 27, 2012, (xi) two filed April 30, 2012, (xii) two filed May 11, 2012, (xiii) one filed May 17, 2012, (xiv) four filed May 25, 2012, (xv) one filed June 12, 2012, (xvi) four filed August 8, 2012, (xvii) one filed September 21, 2012, (xviii) one filed November 7, 2012 (which suit also makes indirect purchaser claims), and (xix) two filed January 9 and 15, 2013, respectively; and (d) a direct and indirect purchaser class action filed on November 29, 2012 asserting claims under the Kansas Restraint of Trade Act.
58492_13_ITEM7_P199_S3	All of the pending U.S. federal cases in which we have been named as a defendant, have been filed in or have been transferred to the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio under the name In re: Polyurethane Foam Antitrust Litigation , Case No. 1:10-MD-2196.
58492_13_ITEM7_P199_S4	In the U.S. actions, the plaintiffs, on behalf of themselves and/or a class of purchasers, seek three times the amount of unspecified damages allegedly suffered as a result of alleged overcharges in the price of polyurethane foam products from at least 1999 to the present.
58492_13_ITEM7_P199_S5	Each plaintiff also seeks attorney fees, pre-judgment and post-judgment interest, court costs, and injunctive relief against future violations.
58492_13_ITEM7_P200_S0	On April 15 and May 6, 2011, we filed motions to dismiss the U.S. direct purchaser and indirect purchaser class actions in the consolidated case in Ohio, for failure to state a legally valid claim.
58492_13_ITEM7_P200_S1	On July 19, 2011, the Ohio Court denied the motions to dismiss.
58492_13_ITEM7_P201_S0	Discovery is underway in the U.S. actions.
58492_13_ITEM7_P201_S1	Limited and Hickory Springs Manufacturing Company, et.al.
58492_13_ITEM7_P201_S2	in the Ontario Superior Court of Justice (Windsor), Court File Nos. CV-10-15164 (amended November 2, 2011) and CV-11-17279 (issued December 30, 2011).
58492_13_ITEM7_P202_S0	In each of the Canadian cases, the plaintiffs, on behalf of themselves and/or a class of purchasers, seek from over 15 defendants restitution of the amount allegedly overcharged, general and special damages in the amount of $100 million, punitive damages of $10 million, pre-judgment and post-judgment interest, and the costs of the investigation and the action.
58492_13_ITEM7_P202_S1	We are not yet required to file our defenses in the Canadian actions.
58492_13_ITEM7_P202_S2	In addition, on July 10, 2012, plaintiff in a class action case (for direct and indirect purchasers of polyurethane foam products) styled Option Consommateurs and Karine Robillard v. Produits Vitafoam Canada Limit e, et.
58492_13_ITEM7_P202_S3	No. 500-6-524-104, filed an amended motion for authorization seeking to add us and other manufacturers of polyurethane foam products as defendants in this case.
58492_13_ITEM7_P203_S0	On June 22, 2012, we were also made party to a lawsuit brought in the 16 th Judicial Circuit Court, Jackson County, Missouri, Case Number 1216-CV15179 under the caption Dennis Baker, on Behalf of Himself and all Others Similarly Situated vs. Leggett Platt, Incorporated - Polyurethane Foam Class Action.
58492_13_ITEM7_P203_S1	The plaintiff, on behalf of himself and/or a class of indirect purchasers of polyurethane foam products in the State of Missouri, alleged that we violated the Missouri Merchandising Practices Act based upon our alleged illegal price inflation of flexible polyurethane foam products.
58492_13_ITEM7_P203_S2	The plaintiffs seek unspecified actual damages, punitive damages and the recovery of reasonable attorney fees.
58492_13_ITEM7_P203_S3	We filed a motion to dismiss this action, which was denied on November 5, 2012.
58492_13_ITEM7_P204_S0	We deny all of the allegations in all of the above actions and will vigorously defend ourselves.
58492_13_ITEM7_P205_S0	These contingencies are subject to many uncertainties.
58492_13_ITEM7_P205_S1	Therefore, based on the information available to date, we cannot estimate the amount or range of potential loss, if any, because, at this juncture of the proceedings, the damages sought by plaintiffs are unspecified, unsupported, and unexplained; discovery is incomplete (no depositions have been taken, class certification issues are not yet ripe, expert liability reports have not been exchanged); and because the litigation involves unsettled legal theories.
58492_13_ITEM7_P206_S0	Brazilian Value-Added Tax Matters On December 22, 2011, the Brazilian Finance Ministry, Federal Revenue Office issued a notice of violation against our wholly-owned subsidiary, Leggett Platt do Brasil Ltda.
58492_13_ITEM7_P206_S1	( L P Brazil ) in the amount of approximately $4 million, under Case No. 10855.724660/2011-43.
58492_13_ITEM7_P207_S0	The Brazilian Revenue Office claimed that for the period beginning November 2006 and continuing through December 2007, L P Brazil used an incorrect tariff code for the collection and payment of value-added tax primarily on the sale of mattress innerspring units in Brazil.
58492_13_ITEM7_P207_S1	L P Brazil responded to the notice of violation on January 25, 2012 denying the violation.
58492_13_ITEM7_P207_S2	On December 17, 2012, the Brazilian Revenue Office issued an additional notice of violation in the amount of approximately $6.2 million under MPF Case No. 0811000.2011.00438 covering the period from January 1, 2008 through December 31, 2010 on the same subject matter.
58492_13_ITEM7_P207_S3	L P Brazil responded to the notice of violation on January 17, 2013 denying the violation.
58492_13_ITEM7_P207_S4	It is possible that we may receive an additional notice of violation for years 2011 and 2012.
58492_13_ITEM7_P207_S5	In addition, L P Brazil received assessments on December 22, 2011, and June 26, July 2 and November 5, 2012 from the Brazilian Revenue Office where the Revenue Office challenged L P Brazil's use of certain tax credits in the years 2006 through 2010.
58492_13_ITEM7_P207_S6	Such credits are generated based upon the tariff classification and rate used by L P Brazil for value-added tax on the sale of mattress innersprings.
58492_13_ITEM7_P207_S7	Combined with prior assessments, L P Brazil has received assessments totaling approximately $2.0 million on the same or similar denial of tax credit matters.
58492_13_ITEM7_P208_S0	L P Brazil is also party to a proceeding involving the State of Sao Paulo, Brazil where the State of Sao Paulo, on April 16, 2009, issued a Notice of Tax Assessment and Imposition of Fine to L P Brazil seeking approximately $3.3 million for the tax years 2006 and 2007, under Case No. 3.111.006 (DRT n .04-256.169/2009).
58492_13_ITEM7_P208_S1	The State of Sao Paulo argued that L P Brazil was using an incorrect tariff code for the collection and payment of value-added tax on sales of mattress innerspring units in the State of Sao Paulo.
58492_13_ITEM7_P208_S2	On September 29, 2010, the Court of Tax and Fees of the State of Sao Paulo ruled in favor of L P Brazil nullifying the tax assessment.
58492_13_ITEM7_P208_S3	The State filed a special appeal and the Special Appeals court remanded the case back to the Court of Tax and Fees for further findings.
58492_13_ITEM7_P208_S4	On November 9, 2012, the Court of Tax and Fees again ruled in favor of L P Brazil and nullified the tax assessment.
58492_13_ITEM7_P208_S5	On November 28, 2012, the State filed another special appeal.
58492_13_ITEM7_P208_S6	The determination to accept the special appeal was made on December 26, 2012, and L P responded to this special appeal on January 24, 2013.
58492_13_ITEM7_P208_S7	We were also informed on October 4, 2012 that the State of Sao Paulo issued an Auto-Infringement and Imposition of a Fine dated May 29, 2012 under Procedure Number 4.003.484 against L P Brazil in the amount of approximately $2.3 million for the tax years 2009 through 2011.
58492_13_ITEM7_P208_S8	Similar to the prior assessment, the State of Sao Paulo argues that L P Brazil was using an incorrect tax rate for the collection and payment of value-added tax on sales of mattress innerspring units in the State of Sao Paulo.
58492_13_ITEM7_P208_S9	On December 18, 2012, the State of Minas Gerais, Brazil issued a tax assessment to L P Brazil relating to L P Brazil's classifications of innersprings for the collection and payment of value-added tax on the sale of mattress innersprings in Minas Gerais from March 1, 2008 through August 31, 2012 in the amount of approximately $.7 million, under PTA Case No. 01.000.182756-62.
58492_13_ITEM7_P208_S10	L P Brazil filed its response denying any violation on January 17, 2013.
58492_13_ITEM7_P209_S0	We deny all of the allegations in these actions.
58492_13_ITEM7_P209_S1	We believe that we have valid bases upon which to contest such actions and will vigorously defend ourselves.
58492_13_ITEM7_P209_S2	However, these contingencies are subject to many uncertainties.
58492_13_ITEM7_P209_S3	At this time, we do not believe it is probable that this matter will have a material adverse effect on our financial condition, operating cash flows or results of operations.
58492_13_ITEM7_P210_S0	Patent Infringement Claim On January 24, 2012, in a case in the United States District Court for the Central District of California, the jury entered a verdict against us in the amount of $5 million based upon an allegation by plaintiff that we infringed three patents on an automatic stapling machine and on methods used to assemble box springs.
58492_13_ITEM7_P210_S1	This action was originally filed on October 4, 2010, as case number CV10-7416 RGK (SSx) under the caption Imaginal Systematic, LLC v. Leggett Platt, Incorporated; Simmons Bedding Company; and Does 1 through 10, inclusive.
58492_13_ITEM7_P210_S2	Leggett is contractually obligated to defend and indemnify Simmons Bedding Company against a claim for infringement.
58492_13_ITEM7_P210_S3	On summary judgment motions, we unsuccessfully disputed each patent's validity and denied that we infringed any patent.
58492_13_ITEM7_P211_S0	At the jury trial on damages issues, the plaintiff alleged damages of $16.2 million.
58492_13_ITEM7_P211_S1	The court denied plaintiff's attempt to win an attorney fee award and triple the pre-verdict damages.
58492_13_ITEM7_P211_S2	On April 9, 2012 we appealed the case to the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals.
58492_13_ITEM7_P211_S3	Oral argument was held on February 6, 2013 before a three judge appeal panel in the Federal Circuit in Washington D.C. On February 14, 2013, the Court of Appeals issued a judgment affirming the $5 million verdict against us.
58492_13_ITEM7_P211_S4	We intend to request a rehearing of the Court of Appeals decision.
58492_13_ITEM7_P211_S5	If a rehearing is not granted, we have the right to request further review to the U.S. Supreme Court.
58492_13_ITEM7_P211_S6	If the case is finally affirmed and remanded to the trial court, the plaintiff might also request royalties for post-verdict use of the machines.
58492_13_ITEM7_P211_S7	If so, we intend to object to such request.
58492_13_ITEM7_P211_S8	We also filed reexamination proceedings in the Patent Office (Case Nos. 95/001,543 filed February 11, 2011; 95/001,546 and 95/001,547 filed February 16, 2011), challenging the validity of each patent at issue.
58492_13_ITEM7_P211_S9	The Patent Office examiner ruled in our favor on the pertinent claims of one of the three patents.
58492_13_ITEM7_P211_S10	The Patent Office examiner initially ruled in our favor on the pertinent claims of the second patent, but subsequently reversed that decision.
58492_13_ITEM7_P211_S11	With respect to the third patent, the Patent Office examiner's decision upheld the validity of all claims.
58492_13_ITEM7_P211_S12	All three of these proceedings are currently on appeal before the Board of Patent Appeals.
58492_13_ITEM7_P211_S13	Due to a change made to all of the machines, we do not believe that the machines currently use the feature alleged to have infringed the third patent.
58492_13_ITEM7_P211_S14	At this time, we do not believe it is probable that this matter will have a material adverse effect on our financial condition, operating cash flows or results of operations.

58492_13_ITEM7_P212_S1	The Financial Accounting Standards Board has also issued accounting guidance effective for future periods, but we do not believe this new guidance will materially impact our future financial statements.

58492_13_ITEM7A_P3_S2	The Company seeks to use derivative contracts that qualify for hedge accounting treatment; however, some instruments may not qualify for hedge accounting treatment.

58492_13_ITEM10_P0_S0	The subsections entitled Proposal 1 Election of Directors, Corporate Governance, Board and Committee Composition and Meetings, Consideration of Director Nominees and Diversity, Section 16(a) Beneficial Ownership Reporting Compliance and Director Independence in the Company s definitive Proxy Statement for the Company s Annual Meeting of Shareholders to be held on May 9, 2013, are incorporated by reference.
58492_13_ITEM10_P1_S0	Directors are normally elected annually at the Annual Meeting of Shareholders and hold office until the next annual meeting of shareholders or until their successors are elected and qualified.
58492_13_ITEM10_P1_S1	All current directors have been nominated for re-election at the Company s Annual Meeting of Shareholders to be held May 9, 2013, except for Maurice E. Purnell, Jr.
58492_13_ITEM10_P1_S2	Mr. Purnell will retire from the Board on the date of the Annual Shareholder Meeting.
58492_13_ITEM10_P2_S0	In order to be nominated for election as a director, a nominee must submit a contingent resignation to the Nominating Corporate Governance Committee (N CG Committee).
58492_13_ITEM10_P2_S1	The resignation will become effective only if (i) the director nominee fails to receive an affirmative majority of the votes cast in the director election; and (ii) the Board accepts the resignation.
58492_13_ITEM10_P2_S2	If a nominee fails to receive an affirmative majority of the votes cast in the director election, the N CG Committee will make a recommendation to the Board of Directors whether to accept or reject the director s resignation and whether any other action should be taken.
58492_13_ITEM10_P2_S3	If a director s resignation is not accepted, that director will continue to serve until the Company s next annual meeting or until his or her successor is duly elected and qualified.
58492_13_ITEM10_P2_S4	If the Board accepts the director s resignation, it may, in its sole discretion, either fill the resulting vacancy or decrease the size of the Board to eliminate the vacancy.
58492_13_ITEM10_P3_S0	The Company s Bylaws and Corporate Governance Guidelines set the director retirement age at 72; however, the Board Chair, CEO or President may request a waiver for any director.
58492_13_ITEM10_P3_S1	At the request of Leggett s CEO, the N CG Committee recommended, and the full Board granted, retirement age waivers for Directors Clark, Enloe and Fisher so they may stand for re-election at the 2013 annual meeting.

58492_13_ITEM15_P5_S0	Management of Leggett Platt, Incorporated is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting as defined in Exchange Act Rule 13a-15(f).
58492_13_ITEM15_P5_S1	Leggett Platt s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
58492_13_ITEM15_P5_S2	The Company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that:
58492_13_ITEM15_P6_S0	Provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use or disposition of Leggett Platt assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
58492_13_ITEM15_P7_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
58492_13_ITEM15_P7_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
58492_13_ITEM15_P8_S0	Under the supervision and with the participation of management (including ourselves), we conducted an evaluation of the effectiveness of Leggett Platt s internal control over financial reporting, as of December 31, 2012 , based on the criteria in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.
58492_13_ITEM15_P8_S1	Based on the evaluation under this framework, we concluded that Leggett Platt s internal control over financial reporting was effective as of December 31, 2012 .

58492_13_ITEM15_P12_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
58492_13_ITEM15_P12_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (i) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (ii) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (iii) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
58492_13_ITEM15_P13_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
58492_13_ITEM15_P13_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.

58492_13_ITEM15_P19_S0	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of Leggett Platt, Incorporated and its majority-owned subsidiaries ( we or our ).
58492_13_ITEM15_P20_S0	Prior to 2010, many subsidiaries outside of the United States were consolidated as of and for a fiscal year ended November 30.
58492_13_ITEM15_P20_S1	As of December 31, 2010, these subsidiaries converted to a calendar reporting year.

58492_13_ITEM15_P20_S3	Management does not expect foreign exchange restrictions to significantly impact the ultimate realization of amounts consolidated in the accompanying financial statements for subsidiaries located outside the United States.
58492_13_ITEM15_P21_S0	All intercompany transactions and accounts have been eliminated in consolidation.
58492_13_ITEM15_P22_S0	ESTIMATES: The preparation of financial statements in conformity with generally accepted accounting principles requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses and the disclosure of contingencies.
58492_13_ITEM15_P23_S0	Legal costs are accrued when a loss is probable and reasonably estimable.
58492_13_ITEM15_P23_S1	If a range of outcomes are possible, the most likely outcome is used to accrue these costs.
58492_13_ITEM15_P24_S0	Any insurance recovery is recorded separately if it is determined that a recovery is probable.
58492_13_ITEM15_P24_S1	Legal fees are accrued when incurred.
58492_13_ITEM15_P25_S0	CASH EQUIVALENTS: Cash equivalents include cash in excess of daily requirements which is invested in various financial instruments with original maturities of three months or less.
58492_13_ITEM15_P26_S0	ACCOUNTS AND OTHER RECEIVABLES AND ALLOWANCE FOR DOUBTFUL ACCOUNTS: Trade accounts receivable are recorded at the invoiced amount and generally do not bear interest.
58492_13_ITEM15_P26_S1	Credit is also occasionally extended in the form of a trade note receivable to facilitate our customers operating cycles.
58492_13_ITEM15_P26_S2	Nontrade notes receivable are established in special circumstances, such as in partial payment for the sale of a business.
58492_13_ITEM15_P26_S3	Notes receivable generally bear interest at market rates commensurate with the corresponding credit risk on the date of origination.
58492_13_ITEM15_P27_S0	The allowance for doubtful accounts is an estimate of the amount of probable credit losses.
58492_13_ITEM15_P27_S1	Interest income is not recognized for accounts that are placed on nonaccrual status.
58492_13_ITEM15_P28_S0	Allowances and nonaccrual status designations are determined by individual account reviews by management, and are based on several factors such as the length of time that receivables are past due, the financial health of the companies involved, industry and macroeconomic considerations, and historical loss experience.
58492_13_ITEM15_P29_S0	Interest income is recorded on the date of cash receipt for nonaccrual status accounts.
58492_13_ITEM15_P29_S1	Account balances are charged off against the allowance when it is probable the receivable will not be recovered.
58492_13_ITEM15_P30_S0	All inventories are stated at the lower of cost or market.
58492_13_ITEM15_P30_S1	We generally use standard costs which include materials, labor and production overhead at normal production capacity.
58492_13_ITEM15_P30_S2	The cost for approximately 60% of our inventories is determined by the last-in, first-out (LIFO) method and is primarily used to value domestic inventories with raw material content consisting of steel, wire, chemicals and foam scrap.
58492_13_ITEM15_P30_S3	For the remainder of the inventories, we principally use the first-in, first-out (FIFO) method, which is representative of our standard costs.
58492_13_ITEM15_P30_S4	For these inventories, the FIFO cost for the periods presented approximated expected replacement cost.
58492_13_ITEM15_P31_S0	Inventories are reviewed at least quarterly for slow-moving and potentially obsolete items using actual inventory turnover, and if necessary, are written down to estimated net realizable value.
58492_13_ITEM15_P31_S1	We have had no material changes in inventory writedowns or slow-moving and obsolete inventory reserves in any of the years presented.
58492_13_ITEM15_P32_S0	Significant accounting policies associated with a decision to dispose of a business are discussed below:
58492_13_ITEM15_P33_S0	A business is classified as a discontinued operation when (i) the operations and cash flows of the business can be clearly distinguished and have been or will be eliminated from our ongoing operations; (ii) the business has either been disposed of or is classified as held for sale; and (iii) we will not have any significant continuing involvement in the operations of the business after the disposal transactions.
58492_13_ITEM15_P33_S1	Significant judgments are involved in determining whether a business meets the criteria for discontinued operations reporting and the period in which these criteria are met.
58492_13_ITEM15_P34_S0	If a business is reported as a discontinued operation, the results of operations through the date of sale, including any gain or loss recognized on the disposition, are presented on a separate line of the income statement.
58492_13_ITEM15_P34_S1	Interest on debt directly attributable to the discontinued operation is allocated to discontinued operations.
58492_13_ITEM15_P34_S2	Gains and losses related to the sale of businesses that do not meet the discontinued operation criteria are reported in continuing operations and separately disclosed if significant.
58492_13_ITEM15_P35_S0	Assets Held for Sale An asset or business is classified as held for sale when (i) management commits to a plan to sell and it is actively marketed; (ii) it is available for immediate sale and the sale is expected to be completed within one year; and (iii) it is unlikely significant changes to the plan will be made or that the plan will be withdrawn.
58492_13_ITEM15_P35_S1	In isolated instances, assets held for sale may exceed one year due to events or circumstances beyond our control.
58492_13_ITEM15_P36_S0	Upon being classified as held for sale, the recoverability of the carrying value must be assessed.
58492_13_ITEM15_P36_S1	Evaluating the recoverability of the assets of a business classified as held for sale follows a defined order in which property and intangible assets subject to amortization are considered only after the recoverability of goodwill and other assets are assessed.
58492_13_ITEM15_P36_S2	After the valuation process is completed, the assets held for sale are reported at the lower of the carrying value or fair value less cost to sell, and the assets are no longer depreciated or amortized.
58492_13_ITEM15_P36_S3	An impairment charge is recognized if the carrying value exceeds the fair value less cost to sell.
58492_13_ITEM15_P37_S0	The assets and related liabilities are aggregated and reported on separate lines of the balance sheet.
58492_13_ITEM15_P38_S0	If a decision to dispose of an asset or a business is made and the held for sale criteria are not met, it is considered held for use.
58492_13_ITEM15_P39_S0	Assets of the business are evaluated for recoverability in the following order: (i) assets other than goodwill, property and intangibles; (ii) property and intangibles subject to amortization; and (iii) goodwill.
58492_13_ITEM15_P40_S0	In evaluating the recoverability of property and intangible assets subject to amortization, in a held for use business, the carrying value is first compared to the sum of the undiscounted cash flows expected to result from the use and eventual disposition.
58492_13_ITEM15_P40_S1	If the carrying value exceeds the undiscounted expected cash flows, then a fair value analysis is performed.
58492_13_ITEM15_P40_S2	An impairment charge is recognized if the carrying value exceeds the fair value.
58492_13_ITEM15_P41_S0	PROPERTY, PLANT AND EQUIPMENT: Property, plant and equipment is stated at cost, less accumulated depreciation.
58492_13_ITEM15_P41_S1	Assets are depreciated by the straight-line method and salvage value, if any, is assumed to be minimal.
58492_13_ITEM15_P42_S0	The table below presents the depreciation periods of the estimated useful lives of our property, plant and equipment.
58492_13_ITEM15_P43_S0	Accelerated methods are used for tax purposes.
58492_13_ITEM15_P44_S0	Property is tested for recoverability at year end and whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that its carrying value may not be recoverable as discussed above.
58492_13_ITEM15_P45_S0	Goodwill results from the acquisition of existing businesses and is not amortized; it is assessed for impairment annually and as triggering events may occur.
58492_13_ITEM15_P45_S1	We perform our annual review in the second quarter of each year.
58492_13_ITEM15_P46_S0	Recoverability of goodwill is evaluated using a two-step process.
58492_13_ITEM15_P47_S0	The first step involves a comparison of the fair value of a reporting unit with its carrying value.
58492_13_ITEM15_P48_S0	Our reporting units are the 10 business groups one level below the operating segment level for which discrete financial information is available and reviewed by segment management.
58492_13_ITEM15_P49_S0	If the carrying value of the group exceeds its fair value, the second step of the process is necessary and involves a comparison of the implied fair value and the carrying value of the goodwill of that group.
58492_13_ITEM15_P49_S1	If the carrying value of the goodwill of a group exceeds the implied fair value of that goodwill, an impairment loss is recognized in an amount equal to the excess.
58492_13_ITEM15_P50_S0	In evaluating the recoverability of goodwill, it is necessary to estimate the fair values of the business groups.
58492_13_ITEM15_P50_S1	In making this assessment, we estimate the fair market values of our reporting units using a discounted cash flow model and comparable market values for similar entities using price-to-earnings ratios.
58492_13_ITEM15_P50_S2	Key assumptions and estimates used in the cash flow model include discount rate, internal sales growth, margins, capital expenditure requirements, and working capital requirements.
58492_13_ITEM15_P50_S3	Recent performance of the group is an important factor, but not the only factor, in our assessment.
58492_13_ITEM15_P51_S0	There are inherent assumptions and judgments required in the analysis of goodwill impairment.
58492_13_ITEM15_P51_S1	It is possible that assumptions underlying the impairment analysis will change in such a manner that impairment in value may occur in the future.
58492_13_ITEM15_P52_S0	Substantially all other intangible assets are amortized using the straight-line method over their estimated useful lives and are evaluated for impairment using a process similar to that used in evaluating the recoverability of property, plant and equipment.
58492_13_ITEM15_P53_S0	The cost of employee services received in exchange for all equity awards granted is based on the fair market value of the award as of the grant date.
58492_13_ITEM15_P53_S1	Expense is recognized net of an estimated forfeiture rate using the straight line method over the vesting period of the award.
58492_13_ITEM15_P54_S0	We recognize sales when title and risk of loss pass to the customer.
58492_13_ITEM15_P54_S1	The terms of our sales are split approximately evenly between FOB shipping point and FOB destination.
58492_13_ITEM15_P54_S2	The timing of our recognition of FOB destination sales is determined based on shipping date and distance to the destination.
58492_13_ITEM15_P54_S3	We have no significant or unusual price protection, right of return or acceptance provisions with our customers nor is it our practice to replace goods damaged or lost in transit.
58492_13_ITEM15_P55_S0	Sales allowances, discounts and rebates can be reasonably estimated throughout the period and are deducted from sales in arriving at net sales.
58492_13_ITEM15_P56_S0	SHIPPING AND HANDLING FEES AND COSTS: Shipping and handling costs are included as a component of Cost of goods sold.
58492_13_ITEM15_P57_S0	RESTRUCTURING COSTS: Restructuring costs are items such as employee termination, contract termination, plant closure and asset relocation costs related to exit activities.
58492_13_ITEM15_P57_S1	Restructuring-related items are inventory writedowns and gains or losses from sales of assets recorded as the result of exit activities.
58492_13_ITEM15_P58_S0	We recognize a liability for costs associated with an exit or disposal activity when the liability is incurred.
58492_13_ITEM15_P59_S0	Certain termination benefits for which employees are required to render service are recognized ratably over the respective future service periods.
58492_13_ITEM15_P60_S0	The provision for income taxes is determined using the asset and liability approach of accounting for income taxes.
58492_13_ITEM15_P60_S1	Under this approach, deferred taxes represent the future tax consequences expected to occur when the reported amounts of assets and liabilities are recovered or paid.
58492_13_ITEM15_P61_S0	The provision for income taxes represents income taxes paid or payable for the current year plus the change in deferred taxes during the year.
58492_13_ITEM15_P61_S1	Deferred taxes result from differences between the financial and tax basis of our assets and liabilities and are adjusted for changes in tax rates and laws, as appropriate.
58492_13_ITEM15_P61_S2	A valuation allowance is provided to reduce deferred tax assets when management cannot conclude that it is more likely than not that a tax benefit will be realized.
58492_13_ITEM15_P62_S0	A provision is also made for incremental taxes on undistributed earnings of foreign subsidiaries and related companies to the extent that such earnings are not deemed to be indefinitely invested.
58492_13_ITEM15_P63_S0	The calculation of our U.S., state, and foreign tax liabilities involves dealing with uncertainties in the application of complex global tax laws.
58492_13_ITEM15_P63_S1	We recognize potential liabilities for anticipated tax issues which might arise in the U.S. and other tax jurisdictions based on management s estimate of whether, and the extent to which, additional taxes will be due.
58492_13_ITEM15_P63_S2	If payment of these amounts ultimately proves to be unnecessary, the reversal of the liabilities would result in tax benefits being recognized in the period when we determine the liabilities are no longer necessary.
58492_13_ITEM15_P63_S3	Conversely, if the estimate of tax liabilities proves to be less than the ultimate tax assessment, a further charge to tax expense would result.
58492_13_ITEM15_P64_S0	CONCENTRATION OF CREDIT RISKS, EXPOSURES AND FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS: We manufacture, market, and distribute engineered products for the various end markets described in Note F.
58492_13_ITEM15_P64_S1	Our operations are principally located in the United States, although we also have operations in China, Europe, Canada, Mexico and other various countries.
58492_13_ITEM15_P65_S0	We maintain allowances for potential credit losses.
58492_13_ITEM15_P65_S1	We perform ongoing credit evaluations of our customers financial conditions and generally require no collateral from our customers, some of which are highly leveraged.
58492_13_ITEM15_P65_S2	Management also monitors the financial condition and status of noncustomer receivables.
58492_13_ITEM15_P66_S0	Noncustomer receivables primarily consist of notes accepted as partial payment for the divestiture of a business.
58492_13_ITEM15_P66_S1	Some of these companies are highly leveraged and the notes are not fully collateralized.
58492_13_ITEM15_P67_S0	We have no material guarantees or liabilities for product warranties which require disclosure.
58492_13_ITEM15_P68_S0	From time to time, we will enter into contracts to hedge foreign currency denominated transactions, natural gas purchases, and interest rates related to our debt.
58492_13_ITEM15_P69_S0	institutions that meet certain requirements are used.
58492_13_ITEM15_P69_S1	We do not anticipate that any of the financial institution counterparties will default on their obligations.
58492_13_ITEM15_P70_S0	The carrying value of cash and short-term financial instruments approximates fair value due to the short maturity of those instruments.
58492_13_ITEM15_P71_S0	Although we obtain insurance for workers compensation, automobile, product and general liability, property loss and medical claims, we have elected to retain a significant portion of expected losses through the use of deductibles.
58492_13_ITEM15_P71_S1	Accrued liabilities include estimates for unpaid reported claims and for claims incurred but not yet reported.
58492_13_ITEM15_P71_S2	Provisions for losses are recorded based upon reasonable estimates of the aggregate liability for claims incurred utilizing our prior experience and information provided by our third-party administrators and insurance carriers.
58492_13_ITEM15_P72_S0	DERIVATIVE FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS: We utilize derivative financial instruments to manage market and financial risks related to interest rates, foreign currency and commodities.
58492_13_ITEM15_P72_S1	We seek to use derivative contracts that qualify for hedge accounting treatment; however some instruments that economically manage currency risk may not qualify for hedge accounting treatment.
58492_13_ITEM15_P72_S2	It is our policy not to speculate using derivative instruments.
58492_13_ITEM15_P73_S0	Under hedge accounting, we formally document our hedge relationships, including identification of the hedging instruments and the hedged items, as well as our risk management objectives and strategies for entering into the hedge transaction.
58492_13_ITEM15_P73_S1	The process includes designating derivative instruments as hedges of specific assets, liabilities, firm commitments or forecasted transactions.
58492_13_ITEM15_P73_S2	We also formally assess both at inception and on a quarterly basis thereafter, whether the derivatives used in hedging transactions are highly effective in offsetting changes in either the fair value or cash flows of the hedged item.
58492_13_ITEM15_P73_S3	If it is determined that a derivative ceases to be highly effective, deferred gains or losses are recorded in the Consolidated Statements of Operations.
58492_13_ITEM15_P74_S0	On the date the contract is entered into, we designate the derivative as one of the following types of hedging instruments and account for it as follows:
58492_13_ITEM15_P75_S0	The hedge of a forecasted transaction or of the variability of cash flows to be received or paid related to a recognized asset or liability or anticipated transaction is designated as a cash flow hedge.
58492_13_ITEM15_P76_S0	The effective portion of the change in fair value is recorded in accumulated other comprehensive income.
58492_13_ITEM15_P76_S1	When the hedged item impacts the income statement, the gain or loss included in other comprehensive income is reported on the same line of the Consolidated Statements of Operations as the hedged item to match the gain or loss on the derivative to the gain or loss on the hedged item.
58492_13_ITEM15_P76_S2	Any ineffective portion of the changes in the fair value is immediately reported in the Consolidated Statements of Operations on the same line as the hedged item.
58492_13_ITEM15_P77_S0	Settlements associated with the sale or production of product are presented in operating cash flows and settlements associated with debt issuance are presented in financing cash flows.
58492_13_ITEM15_P78_S0	The hedge of a recognized asset or liability or an unrecognized firm commitment is designated as a fair value hedge.
58492_13_ITEM15_P78_S1	For fair value hedges, both the effective and ineffective portions of the changes in fair value of the derivative, along with the gain or loss on the hedged item that is attributable to the hedged risk, are recorded in earnings and reported in the Consolidated Statements of Operations on the same line as the hedged item.
58492_13_ITEM15_P79_S0	Cash flows from settled contracts are presented in the category consistent with the nature of the item being hedged.
58492_13_ITEM15_P80_S0	The functional currency for most foreign operations is the local currency.
58492_13_ITEM15_P80_S1	The translation of foreign currencies into U.S. dollars is performed for balance sheet accounts using current exchange rates in effect at the balance sheet date and for income and expense accounts using monthly average exchange rates.
58492_13_ITEM15_P80_S2	The cumulative effects of translating the functional currencies into the U.S. dollar are included in comprehensive income.
58492_13_ITEM15_P81_S0	Certain reclassifications have been made to the prior years consolidated financial statements to conform to the 2012 presentation:
58492_13_ITEM15_P82_S0	In the Consolidated Balance Sheets "Accounts and other receivables, net" is now presented separately as "Trade receivables, net" and "Other receivables, net".
58492_13_ITEM15_P83_S0	In the Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows Activity related to the change in commercial paper and short-term debt previously included in the Additions to/Payments on debt line items within Financing Activities is now presented separately.
58492_13_ITEM15_P84_S0	The FASB has issued accounting guidance effective for current and future periods.
58492_13_ITEM15_P84_S1	The new guidance did not have a material impact on our current financial statements, and we do not believe any of the new guidance will have a material impact on our future financial statements.
58492_13_ITEM15_P85_S0	Businesses divested in prior years and subsequent activity directly related to these divestitures have been reported as discontinued operations as follows:
58492_13_ITEM15_P86_S0	2012 - We received a cash litigation settlement in the second quarter of 2012 associated with our former Prime Foam Products unit.
58492_13_ITEM15_P87_S0	This unit was sold in March 2007 and was previously part of the Residential Furnishings segment.
58492_13_ITEM15_P88_S0	2010 - The Storage Products unit was sold in 2010 as part of a broad strategic change that occurred in 2007 and was previously part of the Commercial Fixturing Components Segment.

58492_13_ITEM15_P98_S0	Fair value of reporting units is determined using a combination of two valuation methods: a market approach and an income approach with each method given equal weight in determining the fair value assigned to each reporting unit.
58492_13_ITEM15_P98_S1	Absent an indication of fair value from a potential buyer or similar specific transaction, we believe that the use of these two methods provides a reasonable estimate of a reporting unit s fair value.
58492_13_ITEM15_P98_S2	Assumptions common to both methods are operating plans and economic projections, which are used to project future revenues, earnings, and after-tax cash flows for each reporting unit.
58492_13_ITEM15_P98_S3	These assumptions are applied consistently for both methods.
58492_13_ITEM15_P99_S0	The market approach estimates fair value by first determining price-to-earnings ratios for comparable publicly-traded companies with similar characteristics of the reporting unit.
58492_13_ITEM15_P99_S1	The price-to-earnings ratio for comparable companies is based upon current enterprise value compared to projected earnings for the next two years.
58492_13_ITEM15_P99_S2	The enterprise value is based upon current market capitalization and includes a 25% control premium.
58492_13_ITEM15_P99_S3	Projected earnings are based upon market analysts projections.
58492_13_ITEM15_P99_S4	The earnings ratios are applied to the projected earnings of the comparable reporting unit to estimate fair value.
58492_13_ITEM15_P99_S5	Management believes this approach is appropriate because it provides a fair value estimate using multiples from entities with operations and economic characteristics comparable to our reporting units.
58492_13_ITEM15_P100_S0	The income approach is based on projected future (debt-free) cash flow that is discounted to present value using factors that consider the timing and risk of future cash flows.
58492_13_ITEM15_P100_S1	Management believes that this approach is appropriate because it provides a fair value estimate based upon the reporting unit s expected long-term operating cash flow performance.
58492_13_ITEM15_P101_S0	Discounted cash flow projections are based on 10 -year financial forecasts developed from operating plans and economic projections noted above, growth rates, estimates of future expected changes in operating margins, terminal value growth rates, future capital expenditures and changes in working capital requirements.

58492_13_ITEM15_P102_S1	Due to the limited nature and scope of changes to operations expected as a result of the 2011 Restructuring Plan, we concluded that a formal goodwill impairment review at December 31, 2011 was not necessary.

58492_13_ITEM15_P155_S0	When the tax deduction for an exercised stock option or converted stock unit exceeds the compensation cost that has been recognized in income, a windfall tax benefit is created.
58492_13_ITEM15_P155_S1	The windfall benefit is not recognized in income, but rather on the balance sheet as additional contributed capital.
58492_13_ITEM15_P156_S0	When the current tax deduction for an exercised stock option or converted stock unit is less than the deferred tax asset recorded in regard to the compensation cost that has been recognized in income, a tax shortfall is created.
58492_13_ITEM15_P156_S1	To the extent we have accumulated tax windfalls, the shortfall is recognized on the balance sheet as a reduction of additional contributed capital.
58492_13_ITEM15_P157_S0	We have granted stock options in the following areas:
58492_13_ITEM15_P158_S0	We have historically granted stock options annually on a discretionary basis to a broad group of employees.
58492_13_ITEM15_P158_S1	Options generally become exercisable in one-third increments at 18 months , 30 months and 42 months after the date of grant.
58492_13_ITEM15_P158_S2	Options have a maximum term of ten years and the exercise prices are equal to Leggett s closing stock price on the grant date.
58492_13_ITEM15_P159_S0	Grant date fair values are calculated using the Black-Scholes option pricing model and are amortized by the straight-line method over the options total vesting period, except for employees who terminate due to retirement.
58492_13_ITEM15_P160_S0	A retirement termination occurs if the employee is age 65 , or age 55 with 20 years of Company service at termination.
58492_13_ITEM15_P160_S1	For retirement terminations, options continue to vest and remain exercisable for three years, six months after termination of employment.
58492_13_ITEM15_P160_S2	Therefore, the expense for these options is accelerated when the employee is retirement eligible.
58492_13_ITEM15_P161_S0	In connection with the January 2010 grant, officers received stock option awards.
58492_13_ITEM15_P161_S1	We gave other participants the choice to receive stock options or to receive a cash payment in lieu of options.
58492_13_ITEM15_P161_S2	The value of the cash alternative (paid in the first quarter) was equal to approximately one-half of the Black Scholes value of the option grant the employee would have otherwise received.
58492_13_ITEM15_P162_S0	In connection with the January 2011 and 2012 grants, we offered two different option choice programs.
58492_13_ITEM15_P162_S1	One group of employees was offered the same option/cash choice as in 2010, with the cash alternative being equal to approximately one-half of the Black-Scholes value of the option grant foregone.
58492_13_ITEM15_P162_S2	Another group of employees, generally higher level employees, were offered a choice between stock options or restricted stock units (RSUs), on a ratio of four options foregone for every one RSU offered.
58492_13_ITEM15_P162_S3	The stock units vest in one-third increments at 12 months , 24 months and 36 months after the date of grant.
58492_13_ITEM15_P163_S0	Starting in 2013, options will only be offered in conjunction with the Deferred Compensation Program discussed below.
58492_13_ITEM15_P163_S1	Options will be replaced with either cash awards or RSUs as offered in 2011 and 2012.

58492_13_ITEM15_P165_S0	We offer a Deferred Compensation Program under which key managers and outside directors may elect to receive stock options, stock units or interest-bearing cash deferrals in lieu of cash compensation:
58492_13_ITEM15_P166_S0	Stock options under this program are granted on the last business day of the year prior to the year the compensation is earned.
58492_13_ITEM15_P166_S1	The number of options granted equals the deferred compensation times five , divided by the stock s market price on the date of grant.
58492_13_ITEM15_P166_S2	The option has a 10 -year term.
58492_13_ITEM15_P166_S3	It vests as the associated compensation is earned and becomes exercisable beginning 15 months after the grant date.
58492_13_ITEM15_P167_S0	Stock is issued when the option is exercised.
58492_13_ITEM15_P168_S0	Deferred stock units (DSU) under this program are acquired every two weeks (when the compensation would have otherwise been paid) at a 20% discount to the market price of our common stock on the acquisition date and they vest immediately.
58492_13_ITEM15_P169_S0	Expense is recorded as the compensation is earned.
58492_13_ITEM15_P169_S1	Stock units earn dividends at the same rate as cash dividends paid on our common stock.
58492_13_ITEM15_P169_S2	These dividends are used to acquire stock units at a 20% discount.
58492_13_ITEM15_P169_S3	Stock units are converted to common stock and distributed in accordance with the participant s pre-set election.
58492_13_ITEM15_P169_S4	Beginning in 2010, stock units may be settled in cash at the discretion of the Company.
58492_13_ITEM15_P169_S5	Participants must begin receiving distributions no later than ten years after the effective date of the deferral and installment distributions cannot exceed ten years.

58492_13_ITEM15_P177_S0	We have two stock-based retirement plans: the tax-qualified Stock Bonus Plan (SBP) for non-highly compensated employees, and the non-qualified Executive Stock Unit Program (ESUP) for highly compensated employees.

58492_13_ITEM15_P181_S4	Beginning April 1, 2011, participant contributions were credited to a diversified investment account established for the participant, and we made premium contributions to the diversified investment accounts equal to 17.65% of the participant s contribution.
58492_13_ITEM15_P181_S5	A participant s diversified investment account balance is adjusted to mirror the investment experience, whether positive or negative, of the diversified investments selected by the participant.
58492_13_ITEM15_P181_S6	Participants may change investment elections in the diversified investment accounts, but cannot purchase Company common stock or stock units in these accounts.
58492_13_ITEM15_P181_S7	The diversified investment accounts consist of various mutual funds and retirement target funds and are a component of Other current assets and Sundry long-term assets in the accompanying balance sheet.
58492_13_ITEM15_P181_S8	Participant s diversified investment accounts are unfunded, unsecured obligations of the Company, and are presented as a component of Other current liabilities and Other long-term liabilities in the accompanying balance sheet and will be settled in cash.

58492_13_ITEM15_P208_S0	We use the average of the Citigroup Pension Discount Curve rate and Merrill Lynch AA-AAA 10-year Bond Index rate to determine the discount rate used for our significant pension plans (rounded to the nearest 25 basis points).
58492_13_ITEM15_P209_S0	The Citigroup Pension Discount Curve rate is a calculated rate using yearly spot rates matched against expected future benefit payments.
58492_13_ITEM15_P209_S1	The Merrill Lynch Index rate is based on the weighted average yield of a portfolio of high grade Corporate Bonds with an average duration approximating the plans projected benefit payments, adjusted for any callable bonds included in the portfolio.
58492_13_ITEM15_P210_S0	The discount rates used for our other, primarily foreign, plans are based on rates appropriate for the respective country and the plan obligations.
58492_13_ITEM15_P211_S0	The overall, expected long-term rate of return is based on each plan s historical experience and our expectations of future returns based upon each plan s investment holdings, as discussed below.

58492_13_ITEM15_P218_S0	Our investment policy and strategies are established with a long-term view in mind.
58492_13_ITEM15_P218_S1	We strive for a sufficiently diversified asset mix to minimize the risk of a material loss to the portfolio value due to the devaluation of any single investment.
58492_13_ITEM15_P218_S2	In determining the appropriate asset mix, our financial strength and ability to fund potential shortfalls that might result from poor investment performance are considered.
58492_13_ITEM15_P219_S0	Of our three significant domestic plans, the frozen plan (representing approximately 60% of the total benefit obligation) employs a Liability Driven Investment strategy and has a target allocation of 60% bonds and 40% equities.
58492_13_ITEM15_P219_S1	The remaining significant plans have a target allocation of 75% equities and 25% bonds, as historical equity returns have tended to exceed bond returns over the long term.

58492_13_ITEM15_P260_S0	We utilize fair value measures for both financial and non-financial assets and liabilities.
58492_13_ITEM15_P261_S0	The primary areas in which we utilize fair value measures of non-financial assets and liabilities are allocating purchase price to the assets and liabilities of acquired companies as discussed in Note R and evaluating long-term assets for potential impairment as discussed in Note C.
58492_13_ITEM15_P262_S0	The areas in which we utilize fair value measures of financial assets and liabilities are presented in the table below.
58492_13_ITEM15_P263_S0	Fair value measurements are established using a three level valuation hierarchy that prioritizes the inputs to valuation techniques used to measure fair value into the following categories:
58492_13_ITEM15_P264_S0	Level 1: Quoted prices for identical assets or liabilities in active markets.
58492_13_ITEM15_P265_S0	Level 2: Inputs other than quoted prices included in Level 1 that are observable for the asset or liability either directly or indirectly.
58492_13_ITEM15_P265_S1	Short-term investments in this category are valued using discounted cash flow techniques with all significant inputs derived from or corroborated by observable market data.
58492_13_ITEM15_P265_S2	Derivative assets and liabilities in this category are valued using models that consider various assumptions and information from market-corroborated sources.
58492_13_ITEM15_P265_S3	The models used are primarily industry-standard models that consider items such as quoted prices, market interest rate curves applicable to the instruments being valued as of the end of each period, discounted cash flows, volatility factors, current market and contractual prices for the underlying instruments, as well as other relevant economic measures.
58492_13_ITEM15_P265_S4	Substantially all of these assumptions are observable in the marketplace, can be derived from observable data or are supported by observable levels at which transactions are executed in the marketplace.
58492_13_ITEM15_P266_S0	Level 3: Unobservable inputs that are not corroborated by market data.
58492_13_ITEM15_P267_S0	The following tables present assets and liabilities that were accounted for at fair value on a recurring basis.
58492_13_ITEM15_P268_S0	* - Includes both current and long-term amounts combined.

58492_13_ITEM15_P294_S0	Shareholder Derivative Lawsuit On August 10, 2010, a shareholder derivative suit was filed by the New England Carpenters Pension Fund in the Circuit Court of Jasper County, Missouri as Case No. 10AO-CC284 ( 2010 Suit ).
58492_13_ITEM15_P294_S1	The 2010 Suit was substantially similar to a prior suit filed by the same plaintiff, in the same court, on February 5, 2009 ( 2009 Suit ).
58492_13_ITEM15_P294_S2	The 2009 Suit was dismissed without prejudice based on the plaintiff's failure to make demand on our Board and shareholders.
58492_13_ITEM15_P294_S3	As before, the plaintiff did not make such demand.
58492_13_ITEM15_P294_S4	On April 6, 2011, the 2010 Suit was dismissed without prejudice.
58492_13_ITEM15_P295_S0	On May 12, 2011, the plaintiff filed an appeal to the Missouri Court of Appeals.
58492_13_ITEM15_P295_S1	On November 28, 2012, the Missouri Court of Appeals reversed the trial court's dismissal, and remanded the case back to the trial court finding that plaintiff sufficiently pled demand on the Board and shareholders.
58492_13_ITEM15_P295_S2	We filed a request for transfer to the Missouri Supreme Court on December 12, 2012, which was denied by the Court of Appeals.
58492_13_ITEM15_P295_S3	On January 3, 2013, we filed a transfer petition to the Missouri Supreme Court.
58492_13_ITEM15_P295_S4	On February 26, 2013, the Missouri Supreme Court denied our request.
58492_13_ITEM15_P295_S5	The case will be sent back to Jasper County, Missouri for further proceedings.
58492_13_ITEM15_P296_S0	The 2010 Suit was purportedly brought on our behalf, naming us as a nominal defendant, and certain current and former officers and directors as individual defendants including David S. Haffner, Karl G. Glassman, Matthew C. Flanigan, Ernest C. Jett, Harry M. Cornell, Jr., Felix E. Wright, Robert Ted Enloe, III, Richard T. Fisher, Judy C. Odom, Maurice E. Purnell, Jr., Ralph W. Clark and Michael A. Glauber.
58492_13_ITEM15_P297_S0	The plaintiff alleged, among other things, that the individual defendants: breached their fiduciary duties; backdated and received backdated stock options violating our stock plans; caused or allowed us to issue false and misleading financial statements and proxy statements; sold our stock while possessing material non-public information; committed gross mismanagement; wasted corporate assets; committed fraud; violated the Missouri Securities Act; and were unjustly enriched.
58492_13_ITEM15_P297_S1	The plaintiff is seeking, among other things: unspecified monetary damages against the individual defendants; certain equitable and other relief relating to the profits from the alleged improper conduct; the adoption of certain corporate governance proposals; the imposition of a constructive trust over the defendants' stock options and proceeds; punitive damages; the rescission of certain unexercised options; and the reimbursement of litigation costs.
58492_13_ITEM15_P297_S2	The plaintiff is not seeking monetary relief from us.
58492_13_ITEM15_P297_S3	We have director and officer liability insurance in force subject to customary limits and exclusions.
58492_13_ITEM15_P297_S4	We and the individual defendants filed motions to dismiss the 2010 Suit in late October 2010, asserting: the plaintiff failed to make demand on our Board and shareholders as required by Missouri law, and, consistent with the Court's ruling in the 2009 Suit, this failure to make demand should not be excused; the dismissal of the 2009 Suit precludes the 2010 Suit; the plaintiff is not a representative shareholder; the 2010 Suit was based on a statistical analysis of stock option grants and our stock prices that we believe was flawed; the plaintiff failed to state a substantive claim; the common law fraud claim was not pled with sufficient particularity; and the statute of limitations has expired on the fraud claim and all the alleged challenged grants except the December 30, 2005 grant.
58492_13_ITEM15_P297_S5	As to this grant, the motions to dismiss advised the Court that it was made under our Deferred Compensation Program, which (i) provided that options would be dated on the last business day of December, and (ii) was filed with the SEC on December 2, 2005 setting out the pricing mechanism well before the grant date.
58492_13_ITEM15_P297_S6	We do not expect that the outcome of this matter will have a material adverse effect on our financial condition, operating cash flows or results of operations.
58492_13_ITEM15_P298_S0	Antitrust Lawsuits Beginning in August 2010, a series of civil lawsuits was initiated in several U.S. federal courts and in Canada against over 20 defendants alleging that competitors of our carpet underlay business unit and other manufacturers of polyurethane foam products had engaged in price fixing in violation of U.S. and Canadian antitrust laws.
58492_13_ITEM15_P298_S1	A number of these lawsuits have been voluntarily dismissed, most without prejudice.
58492_13_ITEM15_P298_S2	Of the U.S. cases remaining, we have been named as a defendant in (a) three direct purchaser class action cases (the first on November 15, 2010) and a consolidated amended class action complaint filed on February 28, 2011 on behalf of a class of all direct purchasers of polyurethane foam products; (b) an indirect purchaser class consolidated amended complaint filed on March 21, 2011 (although the underlying lawsuits do not name us as a defendant); and an indirect purchaser class action case filed on May 23, 2011; (c) 36 individual direct purchaser cases, (i) one filed March 22, 2011, (ii) another amended August 24, 2011 to remove class allegations, (iii) one amended August 25, 2011 to name us as a defendant, (iv) three others filed October 31, 2011, (v) one filed November 4, 2011, (vi) three filed December 6, 19 and 30, 2011, respectively, (vii) one filed January 27, 2012, (viii) five filed March 19, 2012, (ix) one amended March 30, 2012 to name us as a defendant, (x) one filed April 27, 2012, (xi) two filed April 30, 2012, (xii) two filed May 11, 2012, (xiii) one filed May 17, 2012, (xiv) four filed May 25, 2012, (xv) one filed June 12, 2012, (xvi) four filed August 8, 2012, (xvii) one filed September 21, 2012, (xviii) one filed November 7, 2012 (which suit also makes indirect purchaser claims), and (xix) two filed January 9 and 15, 2013, respectively; and (d) a direct and indirect purchaser class action filed on November 29, 2012 asserting claims under the Kansas Restraint of Trade Act.
58492_13_ITEM15_P298_S3	All of the pending U.S. federal cases in which we have been named as a defendant, have been filed in or have been transferred to the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio under the name In re: Polyurethane Foam Antitrust Litigation , Case No. 1:10-MD-2196.

58492_13_ITEM15_P305_S0	Brazilian Value-Added Tax Matters On December 22, 2011, the Brazilian Finance Ministry, Federal Revenue Office issued a notice of violation against our wholly-owned subsidiary, Leggett Platt do Brasil Ltda.
58492_13_ITEM15_P305_S1	( L P Brazil ) in the amount of approximately $4 , under Case No. 10855.724660/2011-43.
58492_13_ITEM15_P306_S0	The Brazilian Revenue Office claimed that for the period beginning November 2006 and continuing through December 2007, L P Brazil used an incorrect tariff code for the collection and payment of value-added tax primarily on the sale of mattress innerspring units in Brazil.
58492_13_ITEM15_P306_S1	L P Brazil responded to the notice of violation on January 25, 2012 denying the violation.
58492_13_ITEM15_P306_S2	On December 17, 2012, the Brazilian Revenue Office issued an additional notice of violation in the amount of approximately $6.2 under MPF Case No. 0811000.2011.00438 covering the period from January 1, 2008 through December 31, 2010 on the same subject matter.
58492_13_ITEM15_P306_S3	L P Brazil responded to the notice of violation on January 17, 2013 denying the violation.
58492_13_ITEM15_P306_S4	It is possible that we may receive an additional notice of violation for years 2011 and 2012.
58492_13_ITEM15_P306_S5	In addition, L P Brazil received assessments on December 22, 2011, and June 26, July 2 and November 5, 2012 from the Brazilian Revenue Office where the Revenue Office challenged L P Brazil's use of certain tax credits in the years 2006 through 2010.
58492_13_ITEM15_P306_S6	Such credits are generated based upon the tariff classification and rate used by L P Brazil for value-added tax on the sale of mattress innersprings.
58492_13_ITEM15_P306_S7	Combined with prior assessments, L P Brazil has received assessments totaling approximately $2.0 on the same or similar denial of tax credit matters.
58492_13_ITEM15_P307_S0	L P Brazil is also party to a proceeding involving the State of Sao Paulo, Brazil where the State of Sao Paulo, on April 16, 2009, issued a Notice of Tax Assessment and Imposition of Fine to L P Brazil seeking approximately $3.3 for the tax years 2006 and 2007, under Case No. 3.111.006 (DRT n .04-256.169/2009).
58492_13_ITEM15_P307_S1	The State of Sao Paulo argued that L P Brazil was using an incorrect tariff code for the collection and payment of value-added tax on sales of mattress innerspring units in the State of Sao Paulo.
58492_13_ITEM15_P307_S2	On September 29, 2010, the Court of Tax and Fees of the State of Sao Paulo ruled in favor of L P Brazil nullifying the tax assessment.
58492_13_ITEM15_P307_S3	The State filed a special appeal and the Special Appeals court remanded the case back to the Court of Tax and Fees for further findings.
58492_13_ITEM15_P307_S4	On November 9, 2012, the Court of Tax and Fees again ruled in favor of L P Brazil and nullified the tax assessment.
58492_13_ITEM15_P307_S5	On November 28, 2012, the State filed another special appeal.
58492_13_ITEM15_P307_S6	The determination to accept the special appeal was made on December 26, 2012, and L P responded to this special appeal on January 24, 2013.
58492_13_ITEM15_P307_S7	We were also informed on October 4, 2012 that the State of Sao Paulo issued an Auto-Infringement and Imposition of a Fine dated May 29, 2012 under Procedure Number 4.003.484 against L P Brazil in the amount of approximately $2.3 for the tax years 2009 through 2011.
58492_13_ITEM15_P307_S8	Similar to the prior assessment, the State of Sao Paulo argues that L P Brazil was using an incorrect tax rate for the collection and payment of value-added tax on sales of mattress innerspring units in the State of Sao Paulo.
58492_13_ITEM15_P307_S9	On December 18, 2012, the State of Minas Gerais, Brazil issued a tax assessment to L P Brazil relating to L P Brazil's classifications of innersprings for the collection and payment of value-added tax on the sale of mattress innersprings in Minas Gerais from March 1, 2008 through August 31, 2012 in the amount of approximately $.7 , under PTA Case No. 01.000.182756-62.

58492_13_ITEM15_P309_S0	Patent Infringement Claim On January 24, 2012, in a case in the United States District Court for the Central District of California, the jury entered a verdict against us in the amount of $5 based upon an allegation by plaintiff that we infringed three patents on an automatic stapling machine and on methods used to assemble box springs.
58492_13_ITEM15_P309_S1	This action was originally filed on October 4, 2010, as case number CV10-7416 RGK (SSx) under the caption Imaginal Systematic, LLC v. Leggett Platt, Incorporated; Simmons Bedding Company; and Does 1 through 10, inclusive.
58492_13_ITEM15_P309_S2	Leggett is contractually obligated to defend and indemnify Simmons Bedding Company against a claim for infringement.
58492_13_ITEM15_P309_S3	On summary judgment motions, we unsuccessfully disputed each patent's validity and denied that we infringed any patent.
58492_13_ITEM15_P310_S0	At the jury trial on damages issues, the plaintiff alleged damages of $16.2 .
58492_13_ITEM15_P310_S1	The court denied plaintiff's attempt to win an attorney fee award and triple the pre-verdict damages.
58492_13_ITEM15_P310_S2	On April 9, 2012 we appealed the case to the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals.
58492_13_ITEM15_P310_S3	Oral argument was held on February 6, 2013 before a three judge appeal panel in the Federal Circuit in Washington D.C. On February 14, 2013, the Court of Appeals issued a judgment affirming the $5 verdict against us.
58492_13_ITEM15_P310_S4	We intend to request a rehearing of the Court of Appeals decision.
58492_13_ITEM15_P310_S5	If a rehearing is not granted, we have the right to request further review to the U.S. Supreme Court.
58492_13_ITEM15_P310_S6	If the case is finally affirmed and remanded to the trial court, the plaintiff might also request royalties for post-verdict use of the machines.
58492_13_ITEM15_P310_S7	If so, we intend to object to such request.
58492_13_ITEM15_P310_S8	We also filed reexamination proceedings in the Patent Office (Case Nos. 95/001,543 filed February 11, 2011; 95/001,546 and 95/001,547 filed February 16, 2011), challenging the validity of each patent at issue.
58492_13_ITEM15_P310_S9	The Patent Office examiner ruled in our favor on the pertinent claims of one of the three patents.
58492_13_ITEM15_P310_S10	The Patent Office examiner initially ruled in our favor on the pertinent claims of the second patent, but subsequently reversed that decision.
58492_13_ITEM15_P310_S11	With respect to the third patent, the Patent Office examiner's decision upheld the validity of all claims.
58492_13_ITEM15_P310_S12	All three of these proceedings are currently on appeal before the Board of Patent Appeals.
58492_13_ITEM15_P310_S13	Due to a change made to all of the machines, we do not believe that the machines currently use the feature alleged to have infringed the third patent.
58492_13_ITEM15_P310_S14	At this time, we do not believe it is probable that this matter will have a material adverse effect on our financial condition, operating cash flows or results of operations.

58492_13_ITEM15_P319_S0	1. NAME AND PURPOSE 1.1 Name .
58492_13_ITEM15_P319_S1	The name of this Program is the Leggett Platt, Incorporated 2005 Executive Stock Unit Program.
58492_13_ITEM15_P319_S2	This Program is intended to attract, motivate, retain and reward Key Employees by giving them the opportunity to build retirement savings while sharing in the appreciation in value of the Company s Common Stock and Diversified Investments.
58492_13_ITEM15_P319_S3	The Program is an unfunded deferred compensation plan for a select group of management and/or highly compensated employees as described in ERISA.
58492_13_ITEM15_P319_S4	The Program is established pursuant to the Leggett Platt, Incorporated Flexible Stock Plan.
58492_13_ITEM15_P320_S0	A separate book account established by the Company or its third party agent to track Stock Units and Diversified Investments for each Participant.

58492_13_ITEM15_P323_S0	The Flexible Stock Plan Committee of the Board or, except as to Section 16 Officers, the Management Committee or any person to whom the administrative authority has been delegated by the Committee.

58492_13_ITEM15_P326_S0	Compensation only once and will not be counted as Compensation in a future Calendar Year, even if the benefits derived from such compensation are includible in the Participant s taxable income in a subsequent year.

58492_13_ITEM15_P330_S2	If the Investment Committee replaces an underperforming fund with another similar investment, all the balances in the underperforming fund will be transferred to the new investment.
