58492_13_ITEM15_P344_S0	3. ELIGIBILITY AND PARTICIPATION 3.1 Selection of Participants .
58492_13_ITEM15_P345_S0	The Committee will select the Key Employees eligible to become Participants.
58492_13_ITEM15_P345_S1	Unless waived by the Committee, a Key Employee must have at least one Year of Service to be eligible to participate in the Program.
58492_13_ITEM15_P345_S2	The Committee may revoke a Participant s right to participate if he no longer meets the Program s eligibility requirements or for any other reason.
58492_13_ITEM15_P345_S3	If a Participant s employment is terminated for any reason, his right to participate in the Program will cease.
58492_13_ITEM15_P345_S4	Except as provided in Section 5.4, such termination will not affect Stock Units and Diversified Investments already credited to his Account.
58492_13_ITEM15_P346_S0	CONTRIBUTIONS AND PARTICIPANT ACCOUNTS 4.1 Accounts .
58492_13_ITEM15_P346_S1	An Account will be established for each Participant to track the Participant s Stock Units and Diversified Investments.
58492_13_ITEM15_P346_S2	An Account is a bookkeeping device only, established for the purpose of crediting and tracking notional investments made by the Participant in the Stock Units and Diversified Investments.
58492_13_ITEM15_P346_S3	Each Account will track Company Stock and Diversified Investments separately.
58492_13_ITEM15_P347_S0	Each Participant may elect to contribute to the Program a percentage of his Compensation above a certain threshold.
58492_13_ITEM15_P347_S1	For 2013, the threshold is $27,538 which amount may be increased for years after 2013.
58492_13_ITEM15_P347_S2	The Committee will determine the maximum Participant Contribution percentage.
58492_13_ITEM15_P347_S3	Participant s Contributions will be made by payroll deduction on a bi-weekly basis or as Compensation otherwise would have been paid, unless the Committee determines otherwise.
58492_13_ITEM15_P347_S4	All Participant Contributions will be directed into the Diversified Investments elected by the Participant and held in the Participant s Diversified Account.
58492_13_ITEM15_P347_S5	If a Participant has not elected Diversified Investments, Participant Contributions will be directed into the default Diversified Investment established by the Company s Investment Committee until the Participant elects other Diversified Investments.
58492_13_ITEM15_P347_S6	The Company will make a Premium Contribution equal to 17.65% of the Participant s Contribution (equivalent to the 15% discount purchase of Stock Units acquired in the Company Stock Account).
58492_13_ITEM15_P347_S7	Premium Contributions will be made at the same time as the Participant s Contributions and will be directed into the Diversified Investments elected by the Participant, or in the absence of an Investment Election, into the default Diversified Investment established by the Committee.
58492_13_ITEM15_P347_S8	The Company will make a Matching Contribution to the Participant s Company Stock Account equal to 50% of the Participant s Contribution.
58492_13_ITEM15_P347_S9	Matching Contributions will be made at the same time as the Participant s Contributions and will acquire Stock Units at a price equal to 85% of the Fair Market Value of a share of Common Stock on the date such Contributions are made.
58492_13_ITEM15_P347_S10	The Company will make an Additional Matching Contribution to the Participant s Company Stock Account equal to a percentage of the Participant s Contribution for the applicable Calendar Year if the Company s return on capital employed ( ROCE ) for the Calendar Year meets the threshold level established for corporate payouts under the Key Officers Incentive Plan (the Incentive Plan ).
58492_13_ITEM15_P347_S11	ROCE will be calculated in the same manner as it is calculated under the Incentive Plan for a given year.
58492_13_ITEM15_P348_S0	Matching Contribution will begin at 25% of the Participant s Contribution for the applicable Calendar Year for ROCE achievement at the threshold level and increase ratably to a maximum 50% of the Participant s Contribution for ROCE achievement at the target level, with such threshold and target levels to be determined by the Compensation Committee.
58492_13_ITEM15_P348_S1	Such Contribution will be credited to the Company Stock Account of each Participant who was employed as of the last business day of the Calendar Year, plus each Participant whose employment terminated prior to such date (a) due to Disability or death, or (b) after the Participant has attained 55 years of age and has at least 5 Years of Vesting Service.
58492_13_ITEM15_P348_S2	Additional Matching Contributions, if any, will be credited to the Participant s Company Stock Account by March 15 th following the applicable Calendar Year.
58492_13_ITEM15_P349_S0	On the date a cash dividend is paid on Common Stock, the Company will make a Dividend Contribution to the Participant s Company Stock Account equal to the per share cash dividend on the number of Stock Units credited to the Participant s Company Stock Account on the dividend record date.
58492_13_ITEM15_P350_S0	A Participant s Election (including contribution percentage and form of distribution) will be made in a form approved by the Committee.
58492_13_ITEM15_P350_S1	The Election must be made on or before December 31 for Compensation for services performed and to be earned and vested in the following Calendar Year, except that newly eligible Participants may, within 30 days of first becoming eligible for participation, make an Election for Compensation for services performed and earned subsequent to the date of Election.
58492_13_ITEM15_P350_S2	On or before December 31 of each year following the Participant s initial Election, the Participant may change his contribution percentage for the next Calendar Year or may terminate his Election for the next Calendar Year.
58492_13_ITEM15_P350_S3	If no change or termination is received by December 31, the Participant s Election will irrevocably carry forward for the next Calendar Year.
58492_13_ITEM15_P350_S4	The Participant may not change the form of distribution selected in the initial Election, except as provided in Section 5.7.
58492_13_ITEM15_P350_S5	The Committee may provide for Elections at any other times with respect to all or any part of Compensation or Contributions to the extent that such Elections are consistent with the requirements of Section 409A. 4.8 Participant s Investment Election .
58492_13_ITEM15_P351_S0	Participants may choose the percentage of their Participant Contributions they wish to direct into each Diversified Investment.
58492_13_ITEM15_P351_S1	Participants will make their Investment Elections online via secure Account access provided by the Company s third party record keeper.
58492_13_ITEM15_P351_S2	Participants may change their Investment Elections as to future Participant Contributions or the portion of existing Accounts consisting of Diversified Investments at any time subject to normal administrative procedures, unless otherwise determined by the Committee.
58492_13_ITEM15_P351_S3	Each Participant will be solely responsible for the selection of his or her investment choices.
58492_13_ITEM15_P352_S0	4.9 Treatment of Performance Compensation for Certain Newly Eligible Participants .
58492_13_ITEM15_P352_S1	A Participant may become newly eligible for the Program due to a Compensation increase, whereas he was previously eligible for a qualified Company benefit (e.g. the Stock Bonus Plan).
58492_13_ITEM15_P352_S2	A Participant may not defer performance compensation (e.g. an annual bonus) payable in his first year of eligibility if any portion of it was for services performed, or if it was earned and vested, prior to his becoming eligible to participate in the Program.
58492_13_ITEM15_P353_S0	as though the Participant s Contribution had been made with respect to performance compensation received in the first year of eligibility.
58492_13_ITEM15_P354_S0	In the event of a stock dividend, stock split, merger, consolidation or other recapitalization of the Company affecting the number of outstanding shares of Common Stock, the number of Stock Units credited to a Participant s Account will be appropriately adjusted.
58492_13_ITEM15_P355_S0	4.11 Impact of Deferred Compensation Program .
58492_13_ITEM15_P356_S0	Some Participants defer 100% of their Compensation under the Company s Deferred Compensation Program.
58492_13_ITEM15_P356_S1	Since the Compensation remaining after such a deferral is not sufficient to allow the Participant to make the full Participant s Contribution, the Company will make the Matching Contribution and any Additional Matching Contribution as though the full Participant s Contribution had been made.
58492_13_ITEM15_P357_S0	Except in the case of Specified Employees, distribution of a Participant s Account will be made within 90 days after Separation from Service, Disability or death.
58492_13_ITEM15_P357_S1	Distribution of a Specified Employee s Account will be made six months after Separation from Service (other than by Disability or death) in order to conform to Section 409A. Distribution of a Participant s Account will be based on the number of shares or units and market value of the investments held in the Account upon Separation of Service.
58492_13_ITEM15_P357_S2	A Participant s Diversified Investment Account will be settled in cash, and the Company Stock Account will be settled in shares of the Company s Common Stock.
58492_13_ITEM15_P357_S3	Prior to distribution, the Stock Units held in the Participant s Company Stock Account will be converted to whole shares of Common Stock, with any fractional share rounded to the nearest whole share.
58492_13_ITEM15_P357_S4	If Stock Units are credited to the Participant s Company Stock Account after a distribution has been made ( e.g. , as a result of Dividend Contributions or Additional Matching Contributions), a subsequent distribution of those Stock Units will be made within 60 days of the date the Stock Units are credited to the Participant s Company Stock Account, which distribution in the case of the Additional Matching Contribution will occur in the Calendar Year following the Calendar Year of Separation from Service.
58492_13_ITEM15_P357_S5	Although the Company intends to settle Participants Accounts in shares of the Company s Common Stock, notwithstanding any other provision of the Program, the Company reserves the right to pay Stock Units in cash in lieu of shares of Common Stock.
58492_13_ITEM15_P357_S6	If settled in cash, the amount of the distribution will be equal to the Fair Market Value of the number of shares of Common Stock that would otherwise be issued.
58492_13_ITEM15_P357_S7	Fair Market Value shall be determined at the date the shares would otherwise have been issued.
58492_13_ITEM15_P358_S0	Participants may elect to receive distributions of their Accounts in (a) a lump sum amount, or (b) annual installments for up to 15 years.
58492_13_ITEM15_P358_S1	Annual installment distributions will be made by January 31st of each Calendar Year following the Calendar Year of the initial distribution.
58492_13_ITEM15_P358_S2	Each annual distribution will be equal to the balance of the Account divided by the number of payments remaining.
58492_13_ITEM15_P358_S3	If a Participant does not elect a form of distribution in his initial Election or if a Participant s Account value does not exceed $50,000 upon Separation from Service, the distribution will be made in a lump sum.
58492_13_ITEM15_P359_S0	The Company will withhold from distributions any amount required to pay applicable taxes (at the Company s required withholding rate).
58492_13_ITEM15_P359_S1	The tax withholding for distributions from the Participant s Company Stock Account will be made in shares of Common Stock.
58492_13_ITEM15_P359_S2	Alternatively, the Participant may pay such taxes in cash if he makes suitable arrangements with the Company before the distribution date.
58492_13_ITEM15_P359_S3	The Company may, at any time, require a Participant to settle the tax liability in cash.
58492_13_ITEM15_P360_S0	5.4 Forfeiture of Stock Units .
58492_13_ITEM15_P360_S1	Notwithstanding the above, if a Participant who has less than 5 Years of Vesting Service has a Separation from Service, the Participant will forfeit any Stock Units acquired by Company Matching Contributions, Additional Matching Contributions or Dividend Contributions (unless the Committee determines otherwise).
58492_13_ITEM15_P360_S2	However, such Stock Units will not be forfeited if the Participant has a Separation from Service due to death or Disability.
58492_13_ITEM15_P360_S3	If a Participant dies before he has received all distributions due under the Program, the remaining distributions will be made to his Beneficiary.
58492_13_ITEM15_P361_S0	Each Participant may designate a Beneficiary and change his Beneficiary from time to time.
58492_13_ITEM15_P361_S1	Beneficiary designations are made and tracked through the company s record keeper.
58492_13_ITEM15_P361_S2	If a Participant has no living designated Beneficiary, then his Beneficiary will be his personal representative.
58492_13_ITEM15_P362_S0	5.6 Distribution Upon Unforeseeable Emergency or Change in Control.
58492_13_ITEM15_P362_S1	In the event of an Unforeseeable Emergency, the Committee may authorize an immediate distribution to the Participant as permitted under Section 409A. In addition, the Committee may terminate and liquidate the Program within 30 days preceding or 12 months after a Change in Control and direct all payments to be made within 12 months of its action to the extent permitted under Section 409A. 5.7 Change in Form of Distribution .
58492_13_ITEM15_P363_S0	A Participant may extend the payout period of an installment election or change the form of distribution, not to exceed the maximum payout period of 15 years or such other period determined by the Committee.
58492_13_ITEM15_P363_S1	For purposes of the foregoing, each payment in an installment distribution will be deemed a separate payment and each payout date in an installment distribution election will be treated as a separate election.
58492_13_ITEM15_P363_S2	The election change must be made not less than 12 months prior to Separation from Service and must extend the first distribution payment by at least 5 years, consistent with the requirements of Section 409A. 6.
58492_13_ITEM15_P364_S0	Except to the extent the Committee otherwise designates pursuant to Section 6.2(f), the Committee will control and manage the operation and administration of the Program.
58492_13_ITEM15_P364_S1	The Committee will have such authority and discretion as may be necessary to discharge its responsibilities under the Program, including the authority and discretion to: (a) interpret the provisions of the Program; (b) adopt rules of procedure consistent with the Program; (c) determine questions relating to benefits and rights under the Program; (d) maintain records concerning the Program; (e) determine the content and form of the Participant s Election and all other documents required to carry out the Program; and (f) designate any Company employee or committee, including the Management Committee, to carry out any of the Committee s duties, including authority to manage the operation and administration of the Program.
58492_13_ITEM15_P365_S0	Notwithstanding the foregoing, the Committee may not delegate its authority with respect to Section 16 Officers.
58492_13_ITEM15_P366_S0	6.4 Compliance with Applicable Law .
58492_13_ITEM15_P366_S1	Notwithstanding anything contained in the Program or in any document issued under the Program, it is intended that the Program will at all times meet the requirements of Section 409A and any regulations or other guidance issued thereunder, and that the provisions of the Program will be interpreted to meet such requirements.
58492_13_ITEM15_P367_S0	CLAIMS 7.1 Adjudication of Claims .
58492_13_ITEM15_P367_S1	The Committee and the Company s Secretary will make all determinations regarding benefits under the Program in accordance with ERISA.
58492_13_ITEM15_P368_S0	If a Participant (or other person entitled to file a claim for benefits under ERISA) (a claimant ) is denied a claim for benefits under the Program, the Committee shall provide to the claimant written notice of the denial within ninety (90) days (forty-five (45) days with respect to a denial of any claim for benefits due to the Participant s Disability) after the Committee receives the claim, unless special circumstances require an extension of time for processing the claim.
58492_13_ITEM15_P368_S1	If such an extension of time is required, written notice of the extension shall be furnished to the claimant prior to the termination of the initial 90-day or 45-day period, as applicable.
58492_13_ITEM15_P368_S2	In no event shall the extension exceed a period of ninety (90) days (thirty (30) days with respect to a claim for benefits due to the Participant s Disability) from the end of such initial period.
58492_13_ITEM15_P368_S3	With respect to a claim for benefits due to the Participant s Disability, an additional extension of up to thirty (30) days beyond the initial 30-day extension period may be required for processing the claim.
58492_13_ITEM15_P368_S4	In such event, written notice of the extension shall be furnished to the claimant within the initial 30-day extension period.
58492_13_ITEM15_P368_S5	Any extension notice shall indicate the special circumstances requiring the extension of time, the date by which the Committee expects to render the final decision, the standards on which entitlement to benefits are based, the unresolved issues that prevent a decision on the claim and the additional information needed to resolve those issues.
58492_13_ITEM15_P369_S0	7.3 Contents of Notice of Denial .
58492_13_ITEM15_P369_S1	If a claimant is denied a claim for benefits under the Program, the Committee shall provide to such claimant written notice of the denial which shall set forth: (a) the specific reasons for the denial; (b) specific references to the pertinent provisions of the Program on which the denial is based; (c) a description of any additional material or information necessary for the claimant to perfect the claim and an explanation of why such material or information is necessary; (d) an explanation of the Program s claim review procedures, and the time limits applicable to such procedures, including a statement of the claimant s right to bring a civil action under Section 502(a) of ERISA following an adverse benefit determination on review; (e) in the case of a claim for benefits due to a Participant s Disability, if an internal rule, guideline, protocol or other similar criterion is relied upon in making the adverse determination, either the specific rule, guideline, protocol or other similar criterion; or a statement that such rule, guideline, protocol or other similar criterion was relied upon in making the decision and that a copy of such rule, guideline, protocol or other similar criterion will be provided free of charge upon request; and (f) in the case of a claim for benefits due to a Participant s Disability, if a denial of the claim is based on a medical necessity or experimental treatment or similar exclusion or limit, an explanation of the scientific or clinical judgment for the denial, an explanation applying the terms of the Program to the claimant s medical circumstances or a statement that such explanation will be provided free of charge upon request.
58492_13_ITEM15_P370_S0	After receiving written notice of the denial of a claim, a claimant or his representative shall be entitled to: (a) request a full and fair review of the denial of the claim by written application to the Committee (or Appeals Fiduciary in the case of a claim for benefits payable due to a Participant s Disability); (b) request, free of charge, reasonable access to, and copies of, all documents, records, and other information relevant to the claim; (c) submit written comments, documents, records, and other information relating to the denied claim to the Committee or Appeals Fiduciary, as applicable; and (d) a review that takes into account all comments, documents, records, and other information submitted by the claimant relating to the claim, without regard to whether such information was submitted or considered in the initial benefit determination.
58492_13_ITEM15_P370_S1	(a) If a claimant wishes a review of the decision denying his claim to benefits under the Program, other than a claim described in Subsection (b) of this Section, he must submit the written application to the Committee within sixty (60) days after receiving written notice of the denial.
58492_13_ITEM15_P370_S2	(b) If the claimant wishes a review of the decision denying his claim to benefits under the Program due to a Participant s Disability, he must submit the written application to the Appeals Fiduciary within one hundred eighty (180) days after receiving written notice of the denial.
58492_13_ITEM15_P370_S3	With respect to any such claim, in deciding an appeal of any denial based in whole or in part on a medical judgment, the Appeals Fiduciary shall: (i) consult with a health care professional who has appropriate training and experience in the field of medicine involved in the medical judgment; and (ii) identify the medical and vocational experts whose advice was obtained on behalf of the Program in connection with the denial without regard to whether the advice was relied upon in making the determination to deny the claim.
58492_13_ITEM15_P370_S4	Notwithstanding the foregoing, the health care professional consulted pursuant to this Subsection (b) shall be an individual who was not consulted with respect to the initial denial of the claim that is the subject of the appeal or a subordinate of such individual.
58492_13_ITEM15_P371_S0	Upon receiving a written application for review, the Committee or Appeals Fiduciary, as applicable, may schedule a hearing for purposes of reviewing the claimant s claim, which hearing shall take place not more than thirty (30) days from the date on which the Committee or Appeals Fiduciary received such written application for review.
58492_13_ITEM15_P371_S1	At least ten (10) days prior to the scheduled hearing, the claimant and his representative designated in writing by him, if any, shall receive written notice of the date, time, and place of such scheduled hearing.
58492_13_ITEM15_P371_S2	The claimant or his representative, if any, may request that the hearing be rescheduled, for his convenience, on another reasonable date or at another reasonable time or place.
58492_13_ITEM15_P371_S3	All claimants requesting a review of the decision denying their claim for benefits may employ counsel for purposes of the hearing.
58492_13_ITEM15_P372_S0	No later than sixty (60) days (forty-five (45) days with respect to a claim for benefits due to the Participant s Disability) following the receipt of the written application for review, the Committee or the Appeals Fiduciary, as applicable, shall submit its decision on the review in writing to the claimant involved and to his representative, if any, unless the Committee or Appeals Fiduciary determines that special circumstances (such as the need to hold a hearing) require an extension of time, to a day no later than one hundred twenty (120) days (ninety (90) days with respect to a claim for benefits due to the Participant s Disability) after the date of receipt of the written application for review.
58492_13_ITEM15_P373_S0	Appeals Fiduciary determines that the extension of time is required, the Committee or Appeals Fiduciary shall furnish to the claimant written notice of the extension before the expiration of the initial sixty (60) day (forty-five (45) days with respect to a claim for benefits due to the Participant s Disability) period.
58492_13_ITEM15_P373_S1	The extension notice shall indicate the special circumstances requiring an extension of time and the date by which the Committee or Appeals Fiduciary expects to render its decision on review.
58492_13_ITEM15_P374_S0	In the case of a decision adverse to the claimant, the Committee or Appeals Fiduciary shall provide to the claimant written notice of the denial which shall include: (a) the specific reasons for the decision; (b) specific references to the pertinent provisions of the Program on which the decision is based; (c) a statement that the claimant is entitled to receive, upon request and free of charge, reasonable access to, and copies of, all documents, records, and other information relevant to the claimant s claim for benefits; (d) a statement describing any available voluntary appeal procedures (if any) and of the claimant s right to obtain information about such procedures as required by ERISA and a statement of the claimant s right to bring an action under Section 502(a) of ERISA following the denial of the claim upon review; (e) in the case of a claim for benefits due to the Participant s Disability, if an internal rule, guideline, protocol or other similar criterion is relied upon in making the adverse determination, either the specific rule, guideline, protocol or other similar criterion; or a statement that such rule, guideline, protocol or other similar criterion was relied upon in making the decision and that a copy of such rule, guideline, protocol or other similar criterion will be provided free of charge upon request; (f) in the case of a claim for benefits due to a Participant s Disability, if a denial of the claim is based on a medical necessity or experimental treatment or similar exclusion or limit, an explanation of the scientific or clinical judgment for the denial, an explanation applying the terms of the Program to the claimant s medical circumstances or a statement that such explanation will be provided free of charge upon request; and (g) in the case of a claim for benefits due to a Participant s Disability, a statement regarding the availability of other voluntary alternative dispute resolution options.
58492_13_ITEM15_P374_S1	Nothing contained in the Program will restrict the right of the Employer to discharge a Participant or the right of a Participant to resign from employment.
58492_13_ITEM15_P374_S2	The Program should not be construed as an employment contract.
58492_13_ITEM15_P374_S3	No Participant or Beneficiary may transfer, assign or otherwise encumber any benefits payable by the Company under the Program.
58492_13_ITEM15_P374_S4	Such benefits may not be seized by any creditor of Participant or Beneficiary or transferred by operation of law in the event of bankruptcy, insolvency or death.
58492_13_ITEM15_P374_S5	Any attempted assignment or transfer will be void.
58492_13_ITEM15_P374_S6	No person will have any interest in the Company s assets by virtue of the Program.
58492_13_ITEM15_P374_S7	No Participant or Beneficiary will have any of the rights of a shareholder with respect to Stock Units.
58492_13_ITEM15_P374_S8	The Program and any action taken pursuant to the Program should not be construed as creating a trust or other fiduciary relationship between the Company, the Participant, his Beneficiary or any other person.
58492_13_ITEM15_P374_S9	The Program will be binding upon and inure to the benefit of the Company, its successors and assigns, and each Participant, his heirs, personal representatives, and Beneficiaries.
58492_13_ITEM15_P375_S0	The Company will have the right to amend or terminate the Program at any time.
58492_13_ITEM15_P375_S1	However, no such amendment or termination will deprive any Participant of the right to distribution of Stock Units previously credited to his Account.
58492_13_ITEM15_P375_S2	The Committee may require that distributions commence following termination and all distributions following termination be made in a lump sum to the extent permitted under Section 409A. Timing of distributions following termination will be made consistent with the requirements of Section 409A. 8.7 Governing Law .
58492_13_ITEM15_P375_S3	To the extent not preempted by ERISA, this Program will be governed by Missouri law.
58492_13_ITEM15_P375_S4	Any notice or claim given under the Program will be in writing and signed by the party giving the same.
58492_13_ITEM15_P375_S5	If such notice or claim is mailed, it will be sent by United States first class mail, postage prepaid, addressed to the recipient s last known address as shown on the Company s records.
58492_13_ITEM15_P375_S6	The date of such mailing will be deemed the date of notice.
58492_13_ITEM15_P375_S7	To the extent permitted by Section 409A, the Committee retains the right to delay a Participant distribution if the payment of such distribution would violate securities laws, eliminate or reduce the Company s tax deduction by application of Section 162(m) of the Internal Revenue Code, violate loan covenants or other contractual terms to which the Company is a party, or otherwise result in material harm to the Company.

58492_14_ITEM1_P0_S0	Leggett Platt, Incorporated was founded as a partnership in Carthage, Missouri in 1883 and was incorporated in 1901.
58492_14_ITEM1_P0_S1	The Company, a pioneer of the steel coil bedspring, has become an international diversified manufacturer that conceives, designs and produces a wide range of engineered components and products found in many homes, offices, retail stores, automobiles and commercial aircraft.
58492_14_ITEM1_P0_S2	As discussed below, our operations are organized into 20 business units, which are divided into 10 groups under our four segments: Residential Furnishings; Commercial Fixturing Components; Industrial Materials; and Specialized Products.
58492_14_ITEM1_P1_S0	Our Residential Furnishings segment began in 1883 with the manufacture of steel coiled bedsprings.
58492_14_ITEM1_P1_S1	Today, we supply a variety of components used by bedding and upholstered furniture manufacturers in the assembly of their finished products.
58492_14_ITEM1_P1_S2	Our range of products offers our customers a single source for many of their component needs.
58492_14_ITEM1_P2_S0	Efficient manufacturing methods, internal production of key raw materials and machinery, and numerous manufacturing and assembly locations allow us to supply many customers with components at a lower cost than they can produce themselves.
58492_14_ITEM1_P2_S1	In addition to cost savings, sourcing components from us allows our customers to focus on designing, merchandising and marketing their products.
58492_14_ITEM1_P3_S0	Products manufactured or distributed by our Residential Furnishings groups include:
58492_14_ITEM1_P4_S0	Our Store Fixtures group designs, produces, installs and manages our customers store fixtures projects.
58492_14_ITEM1_P5_S0	Our Office Furniture Components group designs, manufactures, and distributes a wide range of engineered components and products primarily for the office seating market.
58492_14_ITEM1_P6_S0	Products manufactured or distributed by our Commercial Fixturing Components groups include:
58492_14_ITEM1_P7_S0	Customers of the Commercial Fixturing Components segment include:
58492_14_ITEM1_P8_S0	We believe that the quality of our products and services, together with low cost, have made us the leading U.S. supplier of drawn steel wire.
58492_14_ITEM1_P8_S1	Our Wire group operates a steel rod mill with an annual output of approximately 500,000 tons, of which a substantial majority is used by our own wire mills.
58492_14_ITEM1_P8_S2	We have four wire mills that supply virtually all the wire consumed by our other domestic businesses.
58492_14_ITEM1_P8_S3	Our Steel Tubing business unit also supplies a portion of our internal needs for welded steel tubing.
58492_14_ITEM1_P8_S4	In addition to supporting our internal requirements, we supply many external customers with wire and steel tubing products.
58492_14_ITEM1_P9_S0	In 2012, we completed the acquisition of Western Pneumatic Tube (Western).
58492_14_ITEM1_P9_S1	Western is a leading provider of integral components for critical aircraft systems, and formed the Aerospace Products business unit within the Tubing Group.
58492_14_ITEM1_P9_S2	Western specializes in fabricating thin-walled, large diameter, welded tubing and specialty formed products from titanium, nickel and other specialty materials for leading aerospace suppliers and OEMs.
58492_14_ITEM1_P9_S3	In 2013, we expanded our Aerospace Products business unit with the acquisition of two companies.

58492_14_ITEM1_P17_S0	Total Shareholder Return (TSR), relative to peer companies, is the key financial measure that we use to assess long-term performance.
58492_14_ITEM1_P17_S1	TSR = (Change in Stock Price + Dividends)/Beginning Stock Price).
58492_14_ITEM1_P17_S2	Our goal is to achieve TSR in the top 1/3 of the S P 500 companies over rolling three-year periods through a balanced approach that employs all four TSR sources: revenue growth, margin expansion, dividends, and share repurchases.
58492_14_ITEM1_P17_S3	For the three-year measurement period that ended December 31, 2013 we generated TSR of 56% (16% per year on average), which placed us in the top one half of the S P 500.
58492_14_ITEM1_P18_S0	Our incentive programs reward return generation and profitable growth.
58492_14_ITEM1_P19_S0	Senior executives participate in a TSR-based incentive program (based on our performance compared to a group of approximately 320 peers).
58492_14_ITEM1_P20_S0	Business unit bonuses emphasize the achievement of higher returns on the assets under the unit s direct control.
58492_14_ITEM1_P21_S0	During the past three years, we generated $1.2 billion of operating cash, and we returned much of this cash to shareholders in the form of dividends and share repurchases.
58492_14_ITEM1_P21_S1	Dividends and share repurchases are expected to remain significant contributors to long-term TSR.
58492_14_ITEM1_P22_S0	We currently pay a quarterly dividend of $.30 per share.
58492_14_ITEM1_P22_S1	Our dividend payout target is 50-60% of earnings; however we have been above that target in recent years.
58492_14_ITEM1_P22_S2	Our dividend payout ratio (dividends declared per share/earnings per share) was 106%, 67% and 88% in 2011, 2012 and 2013, respectively.
58492_14_ITEM1_P22_S3	As our markets recover, we expect to move into our target payout range.
58492_14_ITEM1_P22_S4	In the meantime, we expect to generate enough cash to continue to pay and modestly grow the dividend.
58492_14_ITEM1_P22_S5	The Company has consistently (for over 20 years) generated operating cash in excess of our annual requirement for capital expenditures and dividends.
58492_14_ITEM1_P23_S0	We expect to use cash (after repayment of debt and funding capital expenditures, dividends, and growth opportunities) for share repurchases.
58492_14_ITEM1_P23_S1	During the past three years, we have repurchased 18 million shares of our stock (and issued 11 million shares through employee benefit plans), which reduced the net outstanding shares by approximately 5%.
58492_14_ITEM1_P23_S2	In 2013, we repurchased 6 million shares at an average per share price of $30.81 (and issued 3 million shares through employee benefit plans).
58492_14_ITEM1_P23_S3	In 2013, our shares outstanding was reduced by approximately 2% to 139.4 million at year-end.
58492_14_ITEM1_P24_S0	We utilize a rigorous strategic planning process to help guide future decisions regarding business unit roles, capital allocation priorities, and new areas in which to grow.
58492_14_ITEM1_P24_S1	We review the portfolio classification of each unit on an annual basis to determine its appropriate role (Grow, Core, Fix, or Divest).
58492_14_ITEM1_P24_S2	This review includes criteria such as competitive position, market attractiveness, business unit size, and fit within our overall objectives, as well as financial indicators such as growth of EBIT (earnings before interest and taxes) and EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization), operating cash flows, and return on assets.
58492_14_ITEM1_P25_S0	Business units in the Grow category should provide avenues for profitable growth from competitively advantaged positions in attractive markets.
58492_14_ITEM1_P26_S0	Core business units are expected to enhance productivity, maintain market share, and generate cash flow from operations while using minimal capital.
58492_14_ITEM1_P26_S1	To remain in the portfolio, business units are expected to consistently generate after-tax returns in excess of our cost of capital.
58492_14_ITEM1_P26_S2	Business units that fail to consistently attain minimum return goals will be moved to the Fix or Divest categories.
58492_14_ITEM1_P27_S0	Long-term, we aim to achieve consistent, profitable growth of 4-5% annually.
58492_14_ITEM1_P27_S1	To attain this goal, we will need to supplement the approximate 2-3% growth that our markets typically produce (in normal economic times) with two additional areas of opportunity.
58492_14_ITEM1_P28_S0	First, we must enhance our success rate at developing and commercializing innovative new products within markets in which we already enjoy strong competitive positions.
58492_14_ITEM1_P28_S1	Second, we need to uncover new growth platforms: opportunities in markets new to us containing margins and growth higher than the Company's average, and in which we would possess a competitive advantage.
58492_14_ITEM1_P29_S0	Our long-term, 4-5% annual growth objective envisions periodic acquisitions.
58492_14_ITEM1_P29_S1	We seek acquisitions within our Grow businesses, and look for opportunities to enter new, higher growth markets (carefully screened for sustainable competitive advantage).
58492_14_ITEM1_P29_S2	We expect all acquisitions to (a) have a clear strategic rationale, a sustainable competitive advantage, a strong fit with the Company, and be in an attractive and growing market; (b) create value by enhancing Total Shareholder Return; (c) for stand-alone companies: generally, revenue in excess of $50 million, strong management and future growth opportunity with a strong market position in a market growing faster than GDP; and (d) for add-on companies: generally, revenue in excess of $15 million, significant synergies, and a strategic fit with an existing business unit.
58492_14_ITEM1_P30_S0	In 2013, we expanded our Aerospace Products business unit with the acquisition of two companies.

58492_14_ITEM1_P30_S2	The second was a French-based company acquired in July that added small-diameter, high-pressure seamless tubing to our product portfolio.
58492_14_ITEM1_P30_S3	With these acquisitions, our Aerospace Products business unit, which is part of the Industrial Materials segment, has an annual revenue run rate in excess of $120 million.

58492_14_ITEM1_P32_S0	Western fabricates products from specialty materials, such as titanium, nickel, stainless steel, and other high strength metals for use in aircraft systems, including fuel, hydraulic, pneumatic, environmental, life support, stability, and cooling systems.

58492_14_ITEM1_P60_S0	Many companies offer products that compete with those we manufacture and sell.
58492_14_ITEM1_P60_S1	The number of competing companies varies by product line, but many of the markets for our products are highly competitive.

58492_14_ITEM1_P61_S0	We believe we are the largest U.S. manufacturer, in terms of revenue, of the following:
58492_14_ITEM1_P62_S0	We continue to face pressure from foreign competitors as some of our customers source a portion of their components and finished products offshore.
58492_14_ITEM1_P62_S1	In addition to lower labor rates, foreign competitors benefit (at times) from lower raw material costs.
58492_14_ITEM1_P62_S2	They may also benefit from currency factors and more lenient regulatory climates.
58492_14_ITEM1_P63_S0	We typically remain price competitive, even versus many foreign manufacturers, as a result of our efficient operations, low labor content, vertical integration in steel and wire, logistics and distribution efficiencies, and large scale purchasing of raw materials and commodities.
58492_14_ITEM1_P63_S1	However, we have also reacted to foreign competition in certain cases, by selectively adjusting prices, and by developing new proprietary products that help our customers reduce total costs.
58492_14_ITEM1_P64_S0	Premium non-innerspring mattresses (those that have either a foam or air core) experienced rapid growth in the U.S. bedding market in recent years.
58492_14_ITEM1_P64_S1	These products represent a relatively small portion of the bedding market in units (approximately 10%-12%), but comprise a larger portion of the market in dollars (approximately 25%-30%) due to their higher average selling prices.
58492_14_ITEM1_P64_S2	In 2013, non-innerspring mattress sales declined and the proportion of the total bedding market that they represent also decreased.
58492_14_ITEM1_P64_S3	Most traditional bedding manufacturers (who are our customers) now offer mattresses that combine an innerspring core with top layers comprised of specialty foam and gel.
58492_14_ITEM1_P64_S4	These hybrid products, which allow our customers to address a consumer preference for the feel of a specialty mattress and the characteristics of an innerspring, have been well received by consumers.
58492_14_ITEM1_P65_S0	For the past five years, there have been antidumping duty orders on innerspring imports from China, South Africa and Vietnam, ranging from 116% to 234%.
58492_14_ITEM1_P65_S1	The orders remain in effect while t he Department of Commerce (DOC) and the International Trade Commission (ITC) conduct separate reviews to determine whether to extend the duties through February 2019 (for China) and December 2018 (for South Africa and Vietnam).
58492_14_ITEM1_P65_S2	If it is determined that the revocation of the duties would likely lead to the continuation or recurrence of dumping of innersprings (determined by the DOC) and material injury to the U.S. innerspring industry (determined by the ITC), the duties will be extended.
58492_14_ITEM1_P65_S3	We believe that, without the extension, it is likely that dumping will recur and the U.S. innerspring industry will be materially injured.
58492_14_ITEM1_P65_S4	As a result, we are actively participating in the DOC and ITC reviews.
58492_14_ITEM1_P65_S5	We expect the DOC and ITC to issue their respective determinations in March 2014.
58492_14_ITEM1_P65_S6	If the duties are not extended, they will be retroactively revoked to February 2014 (for China) and December 2013 (for South Africa and Vietnam).
58492_14_ITEM1_P66_S0	In addition, because of the documented evasion of antidumping orders by shipping of goods through third countries and falsely identifying the countries of origin, Leggett, along with several U.S. manufacturers have formed a coalition and are working with members of Congress, the DOC, and U.S. Customs and Border Protection to seek stronger enforcement of existing antidumping and/or countervailing duty orders.
58492_14_ITEM1_P67_S0	As a diversified manufacturer, we generally have not experienced significant seasonality.
58492_14_ITEM1_P67_S1	The timing of acquisitions, dispositions, and economic factors in any year can distort the underlying seasonality in certain of our businesses.
58492_14_ITEM1_P68_S0	Historically, for the Company as a whole, the second and third quarters typically have proportionately greater sales, while the first and fourth quarters are generally lower.
58492_14_ITEM1_P69_S0	Residential Furnishings: typically does not exhibit any significant seasonality, except for a reduction in fourth quarter sales.
58492_14_ITEM1_P70_S0	Commercial Fixturing Components: generally has stronger third quarter sales of its store fixture products, with the fourth quarter significantly lower.
58492_14_ITEM1_P70_S1	This aligns with the retail industry s normal construction cycle the opening of new stores and completion of remodeling projects in advance of the holiday season.
58492_14_ITEM1_P71_S0	Industrial Materials: minimal variation in sales throughout the year.
58492_14_ITEM1_P72_S0	Specialized Products: relatively little quarter-to-quarter variation in sales, although the automotive business is typically somewhat heavier in the second and fourth quarters of the year and lower in the third quarter due to model changeovers and plant shutdowns in the automobile industry during the summer.
58492_14_ITEM1_P73_S0	Our customer relationships and our manufacturing and inventory practices do not create a material amount of backlog orders for any of our segments.

58492_14_ITEM1A_P0_S0	Investing in our securities involves risk.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P0_S1	Set forth below and elsewhere in this report are risk factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from the results contemplated by the forward-looking statements contained in this report.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P0_S2	We may amend or supplement these risk factors from time to time by other reports we file with the SEC.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P1_S0	We have exposure to economic and other factors that affect market demand for our products which may negatively impact our sales, operating cash flow and earnings.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P2_S0	As a supplier of products to a variety of industries, we are adversely affected by general economic downturns.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P2_S1	Our operating performance is heavily influenced by market demand for our components and products.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P2_S2	Market demand for the majority of our products is most heavily influenced by consumer confidence.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P2_S3	To a lesser extent, market demand is impacted by other broad economic factors, including disposable income levels, employment levels, housing turnover and interest rates.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P2_S4	All of these factors influence consumer spending on durable goods, and drive demand for our components and products.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P2_S5	Some of these factors also influence business spending on facilities and equipment, which impacts approximately one-third of our sales.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P3_S0	Demand weakness in our markets can lead to lower unit orders, sales and earnings in our businesses.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P4_S0	Several factors, including a weak global economy, a depressed housing market, or low consumer confidence could contribute to conservative spending habits by consumers around the world.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P5_S0	Short lead times in most of our markets allow for limited visibility into demand trends.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P5_S1	Many consumers continue to postpone spending on larger ticket items such as bedding and furniture.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P6_S0	If economic and market conditions deteriorate, we may experience material negative impacts on our business, financial condition, operating cash flows and results of operations.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P7_S0	Costs of raw materials could negatively affect our profit margins and earnings.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P8_S0	Raw material cost increases (and our ability to respond to cost increases through selling price increases) can significantly impact our earnings.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P8_S1	We typically have short-term commitments from our suppliers; therefore, our raw material costs generally move with the market.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P8_S2	When we experience significant increases in raw material costs, we typically implement price increases to recover the higher costs.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P8_S3	Inability to recover cost increases (or a delay in the recovery time) can negatively impact our earnings.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P8_S4	Conversely, if raw material costs decrease, we generally pass through reduced selling prices to our customers.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P8_S5	Reduced selling prices combined with higher cost inventory can reduce our segment margins and earnings.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Steel is our principal raw material.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P9_S1	The global steel markets are cyclical in nature and have been volatile in recent years.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P9_S2	This volatility can result in large swings in pricing and margins from year to year.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P10_S0	In late 2013, steel costs increased unexpectedly, and the timing of the increase (late in the year) resulted in a concentration of LIFO expense in the fourth quarter.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P10_S1	We are implementing price increases in early 2014 to recover these higher costs.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P10_S2	Our operations can also be impacted by changes in the cost of fabrics and foam scrap.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P10_S3	We experienced significant fluctuations in the cost of these commodities in recent years.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P11_S0	As a producer of steel rod, we are also impacted by volatility in metal margins (the difference in the cost of steel scrap and the market price for steel rod).
58492_14_ITEM1A_P11_S1	In the later half of 2013, metal margins within our rod production operation were compressed due to downward pressure on steel rod prices from Chinese imports.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P12_S0	raise more rapidly than the price of steel rod, the metal margins will be compressed.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P12_S1	In either instance, compressed metal margins could negatively impact our result of operations.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P13_S0	Higher raw material costs in recent years led some of our customers to modify their product designs, changing the quantity and mix of our components in their finished goods.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P13_S1	In some cases, higher cost components were replaced with lower cost components.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P13_S2	This primarily impacted our Residential Furnishings and Industrial Materials product mix and decreased profit margins.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P13_S3	This trend could further negatively impact our results of operations.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P14_S0	Competition could adversely affect our market share, sales, profit margins and earnings.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P15_S0	We operate in markets that are highly competitive.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P15_S1	We believe that most companies in our lines of business compete primarily on price, but, depending upon the particular product, we experience competition based on quality, performance and availability as well.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P15_S2	We face ongoing pressure from foreign competitors as some of our customers source a portion of their components and finished products from Asia and Europe.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P15_S3	In addition to lower labor rates, foreign competitors benefit (at times) from lower raw material costs.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P15_S4	They may also benefit from currency factors and more lenient regulatory climates.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P16_S0	If we are unable to purchase key raw materials, such as steel, at prices competitive with those of foreign suppliers, our ability to maintain market share and profit margins could be harmed by foreign competitors.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P17_S0	Premium non-innerspring mattresses (those that have either a foam or air core) have experienced rapid growth in the U.S. bedding market in recent years.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P17_S1	While still a relatively small portion of the total market in units (approximately 10%-12%), these products represent a much larger portion of the total market in dollars (approximately 25%-30%) due to their higher average selling prices.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P17_S2	If sales of foam or air core mattresses continue to grow appreciably, it could reduce our market share in the U.S. bedding market, and negatively impact our sales and earnings.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P18_S0	The revocation of duties on imports of innersprings from China, South Africa and Vietnam could reduce our market share, sales, profit margins and earnings.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P19_S0	For the past five years, there have been antidumping duty orders on innerspring imports from China, South Africa and Vietnam, ranging from 116% to 234%.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P19_S1	The orders remain in effect while t he Department of Commerce (DOC) and the International Trade Commission (ITC) conduct separate reviews to determine whether to extend the duties through early 2019 (for China) and late 2018 (for South Africa and Vietnam).
58492_14_ITEM1A_P19_S2	If it is determined that the revocation of the duties would likely lead to the continuation or recurrence of dumping of innersprings (determined by the DOC) and material injury to the U.S. innerspring industry (determined by the ITC), the duties will be extended.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P19_S3	We believe that, without the extension, it is likely that dumping will recur and the U.S. innerspring industry will be materially injured.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P19_S4	As a result, we are actively participating in the DOC and ITC reviews.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P19_S5	We expect the DOC and ITC to issue their respective determinations in March 2014.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P19_S6	If the DOC and ITC revoke the duties it could reduce our share in the innersprings market, our sales, profit margins and earnings.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P20_S0	Our goodwill and other long-lived assets are subject to potential impairment which could negatively impact our earnings.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P21_S0	A significant portion of our assets consists of goodwill and other long-lived assets, the carrying value of which may be reduced if we determine that those assets are impaired.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P21_S1	At December 31, 2013, goodwill and other intangible assets represented approximately $1.1 billion, or approximately 36% of our total assets.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P21_S2	In addition, net property, plant and equipment and sundry assets totaled approximately $696 million, or approximately 22% of total assets.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P22_S0	If actual results differ from the assumptions and estimates used in the goodwill and long-lived asset valuation calculations, we could incur impairment charges, which could negatively impact our earnings.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P23_S0	We review our ten reporting units for potential goodwill impairment in June as part of our annual goodwill impairment testing, and more often if an event or circumstance occurs making it likely that impairment exists.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P24_S0	indicates the carrying value may not be recoverable.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P25_S0	We conduct impairment testing based on our current business strategy in light of present industry and economic conditions, as well as future expectations.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P25_S1	The annual goodwill impairment review performed in June 2013 indicated no goodwill impairments, but fair market value for one of our ten reporting units (Store Fixtures) exceeded book value by approximately 18%.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P25_S2	The goodwill associated with the Store Fixtures reporting unit was approximately $109 million at December 31, 2013.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P26_S0	The unit is dependent upon capital spending by retailers on both new stores and remodeling of existing stores.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P26_S1	Although 2012 performance was better than expected, 2013 fell short of expectations.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P26_S2	The predictability of future results is less certain than that of our other reporting units due to the project nature of this business.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P26_S3	If we are not able to achieve projected performance levels in Store Fixtures, future impairments could be possible, which would negatively impact our earnings.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P27_S0	We had been reviewing the Commercial Vehicle Products (CVP) group, which is part of the Specialized Products segment, as part of our ongoing strategic planning process with one possible strategic alternative being to divest all or part of the group.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P27_S1	During this process, an unexpected decline in CVP group sales, earnings and operating cash flows occurred.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P27_S2	Consequently, we received a lower than previously expected indication of value relating to the potential disposition of the business.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P27_S3	As a result, we conducted an interim valuation of the CVP group goodwill and other long-lived assets and, in December, concluded that an impairment charge was required primarily relating to goodwill of the CVP group.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P27_S4	We recorded a goodwill impairment charge of $63 million in the fourth quarter.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P27_S5	A further decline in the CVP group business could result in future impairments which would negatively impact our earnings.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P28_S0	We are exposed to foreign currency risk which may negatively impact our competitiveness, profit margins and earnings.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P29_S0	We expect that international sales will continue to represent a significant percentage of our total sales, which exposes us to currency exchange rate fluctuations.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P29_S1	In 2013, 28% of our sales were generated by international operations.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P29_S2	The revenues and expenses of our foreign operations are generally denominated in local currencies; however, certain of our operations experience currency-related gains and losses where sales or purchases are denominated in currencies other than their local currency.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P29_S3	Further, our competitive position may be affected by the relative strength of the currencies in countries where our products are sold.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P29_S4	Foreign currency exchange risks inherent in doing business in foreign countries may have a material adverse effect on our future operations and financial results.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P30_S0	Technology failures or cyber security breaches could have a material adverse effect on our operations.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P31_S0	We rely on information systems to obtain, process, analyze and manage data, as well as to facilitate the manufacture and distribution of inventory to and from our facilities.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P31_S1	We receive, process and ship orders, manage the billing of, and collections from, our customers, and manage the accounting for, and payment to, our vendors.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P31_S2	Security breaches of this infrastructure can create system disruptions or unauthorized disclosure of confidential information.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P31_S3	If this occurs, our operations could be disrupted, or we may suffer financial loss because of lost or misappropriated information.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P31_S4	We cannot be certain that advances in criminal capabilities or new discoveries in the field of cryptography will not compromise our technology protecting information systems.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P31_S5	If these systems are interrupted or damaged by these events or fail for any extended period of time, then our results of operations could be adversely affected.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P32_S0	We may not be able to realize deferred tax assets on our balance sheet depending upon the amount and source of future taxable income.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P33_S0	Our ability to realize deferred tax assets on our balance sheet is dependent upon the amount and source of future taxable income.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P33_S1	Economic uncertainty or tax law changes could impact our underlying assumptions on which valuation reserves are established and negatively affect future period earnings and balance sheets.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P34_S0	We are exposed to legal contingencies related to various lawsuits and other claims that, if realized, could have a material negative impact on our earnings and cash flows.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P35_S0	We are a defendant in various legal proceedings, including antitrust lawsuits related to the alleged price fixing of prime foam and carpet underlay products, and other proceedings and claims.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P35_S1	When it is probable, in management's judgment, that we may incur monetary damages or other costs resulting from these proceedings or other claims, and we can reasonably estimate the amounts, we record appropriate liabilities in the financial statements and make charges against earnings.
58492_14_ITEM1A_P35_S2	If our assumptions or analysis regarding these contingencies is incorrect, we could incur damages which could have a material negative impact on our earnings and cash flows.

58492_14_ITEM3_P1_S0	Environmental Matter Involving Potential Monetary Sanctions of $100,000 or More On March 27, 2013, Region 5 of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency issued a Notice of Violation("NOV") alleging that our subsidiary, Sterling Steel Company, violated the Clean Air Act and the Illinois State Implementation Plan currently in place.
58492_14_ITEM3_P2_S0	Sterling operates a steel rod mill in Sterling, Illinois.
58492_14_ITEM3_P3_S0	The NOV alleges that Sterling, since 2008, has exceeded the allowable annual particulate matter and manganese emission limits for its arc furnace.
58492_14_ITEM3_P3_S1	Sterling requested a conference with the EPA to discuss the alleged violations.
58492_14_ITEM3_P3_S2	The conference was held on May 20, 2013.
58492_14_ITEM3_P4_S0	On July 23, 2013, the EPA issued a Finding of Violation alleging that Sterling violated the opacity limitations of its air permit and Federal and state regulations.
58492_14_ITEM3_P4_S1	A conference to discuss the Finding of Violation occurred in the third quarter.
58492_14_ITEM3_P5_S0	Sterling intends to vigorously defend these matters in any enforcement action that may be pursued by the EPA.
58492_14_ITEM3_P5_S1	The EPA did not specify any amount of penalty or injunctive relief being sought in the NOV, Finding of Violation or in any conference.
58492_14_ITEM3_P5_S2	Any settlement or adverse finding could result in the payment by Sterling of fines, penalties, capital expenditures, or some combination thereof.
58492_14_ITEM3_P5_S3	Although the outcome of these matters cannot be predicted with certainty, we do not expect them, either individually or in the aggregate, to have a material adverse effect on our financial position, cash flows or results of operations.
58492_14_ITEM3_P6_S0	For the past five years, there have been antidumping duty orders on innerspring imports from China, South Africa and Vietnam, ranging from 116% to 234%.
58492_14_ITEM3_P6_S1	The orders remain in effect while t he U.S. Department of Commerce (DOC) and the International Trade Commission (ITC) each conduct separate reviews (one for each country) to determine whether to extend the duties through February 2019 (for China) and December 2018 (for South Africa and Vietnam).
58492_14_ITEM3_P7_S0	A-570-928; A-791-821; and A-552-803) and ITC reviews (Investigation Nos.
58492_14_ITEM3_P7_S1	731-TA-1140; 731-TA-1141; and 731-TA-1142) were self-initiated on November 1, 2013.
58492_14_ITEM3_P8_S0	We filed three Statements of Intent to Participate in the DOC reviews on December 2, 2013 (one for each country).
58492_14_ITEM3_P8_S1	We also filed a Statement of Willingness to Participate in the ITC reviews on December 2, 2013 (one collective filing).
58492_14_ITEM3_P9_S0	If it is determined that the revocation of the duties would likely lead to the continuation or recurrence of dumping of innersprings (determined by the DOC) and material injury to the U.S. innerspring industry (determined by the ITC), the duties will be extended.

58492_14_ITEM7_P6_S0	We assess our overall performance by comparing our Total Shareholder Return (TSR) to that of peer companies on a rolling three-year basis.
58492_14_ITEM7_P6_S1	We target TSR in the top one-third of the S P 500 over the long term.
58492_14_ITEM7_P6_S2	For the three years ended December 31, 2013, we generated TSR of 16% per year on average.
58492_14_ITEM7_P6_S3	That places us in the top half of the S P 500, but shy of our top one-third goal.
58492_14_ITEM7_P7_S0	These topics are discussed in more detail in the sections that follow.
58492_14_ITEM7_P8_S0	Total Shareholder Return (TSR), relative to peer companies, is the key financial measure that we use to assess long-term performance.
58492_14_ITEM7_P8_S1	TSR is driven by the change in our share price and the dividends we pay [TSR = (Change in Stock Price + Dividends) / Beginning Stock Price].
58492_14_ITEM7_P8_S2	We seek to achieve TSR in the top one-third of the S P 500 over the long-term through a balanced approach that employs all four TSR sources: revenue growth, margin expansion, dividends, and share repurchases.
58492_14_ITEM7_P9_S0	We monitor our TSR performance (relative to the S P 500) on a rolling three-year basis.
58492_14_ITEM7_P9_S1	For the three-year measurement period that ended December 31, 2013, we generated TSR of 16% per year on average, matching the return of the S P 500 index.
58492_14_ITEM7_P9_S2	That performance placed us in the top half of the S P 500 companies, but shy of our goal to be in the top third.
58492_14_ITEM7_P10_S0	We serve a broad suite of customers, with our largest customer representing approximately 6% of our sales.
58492_14_ITEM7_P10_S1	Many are companies whose names are widely recognized; they include most manufacturers of furniture and bedding, a variety of other manufacturers, and many major retailers.
58492_14_ITEM7_P11_S0	Many factors impact our business, but those that generally have the greatest impact are market demand, raw material cost trends, and competition.
58492_14_ITEM7_P12_S0	Market demand (including product mix) is impacted by several economic factors, with consumer confidence being most significant.
58492_14_ITEM7_P12_S1	Other important factors include disposable income levels, employment levels, housing turnover, and interest rates.
58492_14_ITEM7_P12_S2	All of these factors influence consumer spending on durable goods, and therefore affect demand for our components and products.
58492_14_ITEM7_P12_S3	Some of these factors also influence business spending on facilities and equipment, which impacts approximately one-third of our sales.
58492_14_ITEM7_P13_S0	We continue to retain more production capacity than we currently utilize.
58492_14_ITEM7_P13_S1	Accordingly, unit sales can increase by approximately $400 million (based on current sales mix) without the need for large capital investment.
58492_14_ITEM7_P13_S2	We have meaningful operating leverage that should benefit earnings as market demand improves.
58492_14_ITEM7_P13_S3	Until our spare capacity is fully utilized, each additional $100 million of sales from incremental unit volume is expected to generate approximately $25 million to $35 million of additional pre-tax earnings.
58492_14_ITEM7_P14_S0	In many of our businesses, we enjoy a cost advantage from being vertically integrated into steel wire and rod.
58492_14_ITEM7_P14_S1	This is a benefit that our competitors do not have.
58492_14_ITEM7_P14_S2	We also experience favorable purchasing leverage from buying large quantities of raw materials.
58492_14_ITEM7_P14_S3	Still, our costs can vary significantly as market prices for raw materials (many of which are commodities) fluctuate.
58492_14_ITEM7_P15_S0	We typically have short-term commitments from our suppliers; accordingly, our raw material costs generally move with the market.
58492_14_ITEM7_P15_S1	Our ability to recover higher costs (through selling price increases) is crucial.
58492_14_ITEM7_P15_S2	When we experience significant increases in raw material costs, we typically implement price increases to recover the higher costs.
58492_14_ITEM7_P15_S3	Conversely, when costs decrease significantly, we generally pass those lower costs through to our customers.
58492_14_ITEM7_P15_S4	The timing of our price increases or decreases is important; we typically experience a lag in recovering higher costs, so we also expect to realize a lag as costs decline.
58492_14_ITEM7_P16_S0	Steel is our principal raw material.
58492_14_ITEM7_P16_S1	At various times in past years we have experienced extreme cost fluctuations in this commodity.
58492_14_ITEM7_P16_S2	In most cases, the major changes (both increases and decreases) were passed through to customers with selling price adjustments.
58492_14_ITEM7_P17_S0	In late 2013, steel costs increased unexpectedly, and the timing of the increase (late in the year) resulted in a concentration of LIFO expense in the fourth quarter.
58492_14_ITEM7_P17_S1	We are implementing price increases in early 2014, and expect to recover these higher costs.
58492_14_ITEM7_P18_S0	As a producer of steel rod, we are also impacted by volatility in metal margins (the difference in the cost of steel scrap and the market price for steel rod).
58492_14_ITEM7_P19_S0	Metal margins within the steel industry have been volatile during certain periods in recent years.
58492_14_ITEM7_P19_S1	In the back half of 2013, metal margins decreased due to downward pressure on steel rod prices from Chinese imports.
58492_14_ITEM7_P20_S0	Our other raw materials include woven and non-woven fabrics, foam scrap, and chemicals.
58492_14_ITEM7_P20_S1	We have experienced changes in the cost of these materials in recent years, and in most years, have been able to pass them through to our customers.
58492_14_ITEM7_P21_S0	When we raise our prices to recover higher raw material costs, this sometimes causes customers to modify their product designs and replace higher cost components with lower cost components.
58492_14_ITEM7_P21_S1	We must continue to find ways to assist our customers in improving the functionality and reducing the cost of their products, while providing higher margin and profit contribution for our operations.
58492_14_ITEM7_P22_S0	Many of our markets are highly competitive, with the number of competitors varying by product line.
58492_14_ITEM7_P22_S1	In general, our competitors tend to be smaller, private companies.
58492_14_ITEM7_P22_S2	Many of our competitors, both domestic and foreign, compete primarily on the basis of price.
58492_14_ITEM7_P22_S3	Our success has stemmed from the ability to remain price competitive, while delivering better product quality, innovation, and customer service.
58492_14_ITEM7_P23_S0	We continue to face pressure from foreign competitors as some of our customers source a portion of their components and finished products offshore.
58492_14_ITEM7_P23_S1	In addition to lower labor rates, foreign competitors benefit (at times) from lower raw material costs.
58492_14_ITEM7_P23_S2	They may also benefit from currency factors and more lenient regulatory climates.
58492_14_ITEM7_P24_S0	We typically remain price competitive, even versus many foreign manufacturers, as a result of our highly efficient operations, low labor content, vertical integration in steel and wire, logistics and distribution efficiencies, and large scale purchasing of raw materials and commodities.
58492_14_ITEM7_P24_S1	However, we have also reacted to foreign competition in certain cases by selectively adjusting prices, and by developing new proprietary products that help our customers reduce total costs.
58492_14_ITEM7_P25_S0	Premium non-innerspring mattresses (those that have either a foam or air core) experienced rapid growth in the U.S. bedding market in recent years.
58492_14_ITEM7_P25_S1	These products represent a relatively small portion of the bedding market in units (approximately 10%-12%), but comprise a larger portion of the market in dollars (approximately 25%-30%) due to their higher average selling prices.
58492_14_ITEM7_P25_S2	In 2013, non-innerspring mattress sales declined and the proportion of the total bedding market that they represent also decreased.
58492_14_ITEM7_P25_S3	Most traditional bedding manufacturers (who are our customers) now offer mattresses that combine an innerspring core with top layers comprised of specialty foam and gel.
58492_14_ITEM7_P25_S4	These hybrid products, which allow our customers to address a consumer preference for the feel of a specialty mattress and the characteristics of an innerspring, have been well received by consumers.
58492_14_ITEM7_P26_S0	For the past five years, there have been antidumping duty orders on innerspring imports from China, South Africa and Vietnam, ranging from 116% to 234%.
58492_14_ITEM7_P26_S1	The orders remain in effect while the Department of Commerce (DOC) and the International Trade Commission (ITC) conduct separate reviews to determine whether to extend the duties through February 2019 (for China) and December 2018 (for South Africa and Vietnam).
58492_14_ITEM7_P26_S2	If it is determined that the revocation of the duties would likely lead to the continuation or recurrence of dumping of innersprings (determined by the DOC) and material injury to the U.S. innerspring industry (determined by the ITC), the duties will be extended.
58492_14_ITEM7_P26_S3	We have argued that, without the extension, it is likely that dumping will recur, the U.S. innerspring industry will be materially injured, and as such, the duty orders should be extended.
58492_14_ITEM7_P26_S4	If the orders are revoked, the revocation would occur retroactively to February 19, 2014 (for China) and December 10, 2013 (for South Africa and Vietnam).
58492_14_ITEM7_P26_S5	We expect the DOC and ITC to issue their respective determinations in March 2014.
58492_14_ITEM7_P27_S0	In addition, because of the documented evasion of antidumping orders by shipping of goods through third countries and falsely identifying the countries of origin, Leggett, along with several U.S. manufacturers have formed a coalition and are working with members of Congress, the DOC, and U.S. Customs and Border Protection to seek stronger enforcement of existing antidumping and/or countervailing duty orders.

58492_14_ITEM7_P37_S1	In our consolidated financials, an adjustment is made at the corporate level (i.e., outside the segments) to convert about 55% of our inventories to the last-in, first-out (LIFO) method.
58492_14_ITEM7_P37_S2	These are primarily our domestic, steel-related inventories.
58492_14_ITEM7_P37_S3	In 2012, lower commodity costs led to a LIFO benefit of $15 million.

58492_14_ITEM7_P131_S0	We prepare our consolidated financial statements in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
58492_14_ITEM7_P131_S1	To do so, we must make estimates and judgments that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues, expenses, and disclosures.
58492_14_ITEM7_P131_S2	If we used different estimates or judgments our financial statements would change, and some of those changes could be significant.
58492_14_ITEM7_P131_S3	Our estimates are frequently based upon historical experience and are considered by management, at the time they are made, to be reasonable and appropriate.
58492_14_ITEM7_P132_S0	Estimates are adjusted for actual events, as they occur.
58492_14_ITEM7_P133_S0	Critical accounting estimates are those that are: a) subject to uncertainty and change, and b) of material impact to our financial statements.
58492_14_ITEM7_P133_S1	Listed below are the estimates and judgments which we believe could have the most significant effect on our financial statements.
