58492_14_ITEM7_P135_S0	Goodwill is assessed for impairment annually as of June 30 and as triggering events occur.
58492_14_ITEM7_P135_S1	In the past three years, no impairments have been recorded as a result of the annual impairment reviews.
58492_14_ITEM7_P135_S2	In December 2013, we concluded that an impairment was required relating to the goodwill of the Commercial Vehicle Products (CVP) group.
58492_14_ITEM7_P135_S3	A non-cash charge of $63 million was recorded in the fourth quarter of 2013.
58492_14_ITEM7_P136_S0	In order to assess goodwill for potential impairment, judgment is required to estimate the fair market value of each reporting unit (which is one level below reportable segments) using the combination of a discounted cash flow model and a market approach using price to earnings ratios for comparable publicly traded companies with characteristics similar to the reporting unit.
58492_14_ITEM7_P137_S0	The cash flow model contains uncertainties related to the forecast of future results as many outside economic and competitive factors can influence future performance.
58492_14_ITEM7_P137_S1	Margins, sales growth, and discount rates are the most critical estimates in determining enterprise values using the cash flow model.
58492_14_ITEM7_P138_S0	The remaining goodwill associated with the CVP reporting unit is $13 million.
58492_14_ITEM7_P138_S1	A further decline in the long-term outlook for the business could result in future impairments.
58492_14_ITEM7_P138_S2	Fair value for one of the 10 reporting units (Store Fixtures) exceeded book value by approximately 18%.
58492_14_ITEM7_P138_S3	The goodwill associated with this reporting unit is $109 million.
58492_14_ITEM7_P139_S0	This business is dependent upon capital spending by retailers for both new stores and remodeling of existing stores.
58492_14_ITEM7_P139_S1	Although 2012 performance was better than expected, 2013 fell short of expectations.
58492_14_ITEM7_P139_S2	The predictability of future results is less certain than that of other reporting units because of the project nature of this business.
58492_14_ITEM7_P139_S3	If we are not able to meet projected performance levels, future impairments could be possible.
58492_14_ITEM7_P140_S0	The market approach requires judgment to determine the appropriate price to earnings ratio.
58492_14_ITEM7_P141_S0	Ratios are derived from comparable publicly-traded companies that operate in the same or similar industry as the reporting unit.
58492_14_ITEM7_P142_S0	The remaining reporting units have fair market values that exceed carrying value by more than 40%, and have goodwill of $818 million.
58492_14_ITEM7_P142_S1	Information regarding material assumptions used to determine if a goodwill impairment exists can be found in Note C on page 79.
58492_14_ITEM7_P143_S0	Other long-lived assets are tested for recoverability at year-end and whenever events or circumstances indicate the carrying value may not be recoverable.
58492_14_ITEM7_P144_S0	For other long-lived assets we estimate fair value at the lowest level where cash flows can be measured (usually at a branch level).
58492_14_ITEM7_P145_S0	Impairments of other long-lived assets usually occur when major restructuring activities take place, or we decide to discontinue product lines completely.
58492_14_ITEM7_P146_S0	Our impairment assessments have uncertainties because they require estimates of future cash flows to determine if undiscounted cash flows are sufficient to recover carrying values of these assets.
58492_14_ITEM7_P147_S0	For assets where future cash flows are not expected to recover carrying value, fair value is estimated which requires an estimate of market value based upon asset appraisals for like assets.
58492_14_ITEM7_P148_S0	Impairments were $2 million in 2013 and 2012, and $35 million in 2011.
58492_14_ITEM7_P149_S0	The 2011 impairments were largely the result of lowered future business expectations at several underperforming locations that resulted in the decision to exit some unprofitable lines of business.
58492_14_ITEM7_P149_S1	Prior forecasts assumed a recovery in business levels (primarily housing related industries) that had not materialized by late 2011.
58492_14_ITEM7_P150_S0	We reduce the carrying value of inventories to reflect an estimate of net realizable value for obsolete and slow-moving inventory.
58492_14_ITEM7_P151_S0	Our inventory reserve contains uncertainties because the calculation requires management to make assumptions about the value of products that are obsolete or slow-moving (i.e. not selling very quickly).
58492_14_ITEM7_P152_S0	At December 31, 2013, the reserve for obsolete and slow-moving inventory was $36 million (approximately 6% of FIFO inventories).
58492_14_ITEM7_P152_S1	This is consistent with the December 31, 2012 and 2011 reserves of $36 million and $39 million, representing 6% and 7% of FIFO inventories, respectively.
58492_14_ITEM7_P153_S0	Generally a reserve is not required unless we have more than a one-year's supply of the product.
58492_14_ITEM7_P153_S1	If we have had no sales of a given product for 12 months, those items are generally deemed to have no value and are written down completely.
58492_14_ITEM7_P154_S0	Changes in customer behavior and requirements can cause inventory to quickly become obsolete or slow moving.
58492_14_ITEM7_P155_S0	The calculation also uses an estimate of the ultimate recoverability of items identified as slow moving based upon historical experience (65% on average).
58492_14_ITEM7_P156_S0	Additions to inventory reserves in 2013 were $12 million, which were comparable to the previous year.
58492_14_ITEM7_P156_S1	We do not expect obsolescence to change from current levels.
58492_14_ITEM7_P157_S0	We are substantially self-insured for costs related to workers compensation, and this requires us to estimate the liability associated with this obligation.
58492_14_ITEM7_P158_S0	Our estimates of self-insured reserves contain uncertainties regarding the potential amounts we might have to pay (since we are self-insured).
58492_14_ITEM7_P158_S1	We consider a number of factors, including historical claim experience, demographic factors, and potential recoveries from third party insurance carriers.
58492_14_ITEM7_P159_S0	Over the past five years, we have incurred, on average, $9 million annually for costs associated with workers compensation.
58492_14_ITEM7_P159_S1	Average year-to-year variation over the past five years has been approximately $1 million.
58492_14_ITEM7_P159_S2	At December 31, 2013, we had accrued $35 million to cover future self-insurance liabilities.
58492_14_ITEM7_P160_S0	Internal safety statistics and cost trends have improved in the last several years and are expected to remain at current lower levels for the foreseeable future.
58492_14_ITEM7_P161_S0	For accounts and notes receivable, we estimate a bad debt reserve for the amount that will ultimately be uncollectible.
58492_14_ITEM7_P162_S0	When we become aware of a specific customer s potential inability to pay, we record a bad debt reserve for the amount we believe may not be collectible.
58492_14_ITEM7_P163_S0	Our bad debt reserve contains uncertainties because it requires management to estimate the amount uncollectible based upon an evaluation of several factors such as the length of time that receivables are past due, the financial health of the customer, industry and macroeconomic considerations, and historical loss experience.
58492_14_ITEM7_P164_S0	A significant change in the financial status of a large customer could impact our estimates.
58492_14_ITEM7_P165_S0	The average annual amount of customer-related bad debt expense was $5 million (less than 1% of annual net sales) over the last three years.
58492_14_ITEM7_P165_S1	At December 31, 2013, our reserves for doubtful accounts totaled $17 million (about 4% of our accounts and customer-related notes receivable of $452 million).
58492_14_ITEM7_P166_S0	Our customers are diverse and many are small-to-medium sized companies, with some being highly leveraged.
58492_14_ITEM7_P166_S1	Bankruptcy can occur with some of these customers relatively quickly and with little warning.
58492_14_ITEM7_P167_S0	We have not experienced any significant individual customer bankruptcies in the past three years.
58492_14_ITEM7_P167_S1	We believe the financial health of our major customers has modestly improved, but some are highly leveraged, and this could cause circumstances to change in the future.
58492_14_ITEM7_P168_S0	At December 31, 2013, we had $11 million of non-customer notes receivable, primarily related to divested businesses, and have recorded reserves of $1 million for these notes.
58492_14_ITEM7_P168_S1	Most of these notes are to be paid by highly leveraged entities, which could result in the need for additional reserves in the future.
58492_14_ITEM7_P169_S0	For our pension plans, we must estimate the cost of benefits to be provided (well into the future) and the current value of those benefit obligations.
58492_14_ITEM7_P170_S0	The pension liability calculation contains uncertainties because it requires management to estimate an appropriate discount rate to calculate the present value of future benefits paid, which also impacts current year pension expense.
58492_14_ITEM7_P171_S0	Determination of pension expense requires an estimate of expected return on pension assets based upon the mix of investments held (bonds and equities).
58492_14_ITEM7_P171_S1	Other assumptions include rates of compensation increases, withdrawal and mortality rates, and retirement ages.
58492_14_ITEM7_P171_S2	These estimates impact the pension expense or income we recognize and our reported benefit obligations.
58492_14_ITEM7_P172_S0	The discount rates used to calculate the pension liability for our most significant plans increased approximately 80 basis points in 2013 due to higher corporate bond yields.
58492_14_ITEM7_P172_S1	Each 25 basis point increase in the discount rate decreases pension expense by $.6 million and decreases the plans benefit obligation by $9 million.
58492_14_ITEM7_P172_S2	The expected return on assets was 6.6% in 2013 and 2012, and 6.7% in 2011.
58492_14_ITEM7_P172_S3	A 25 basis point reduction in the expected return on assets would increase pension expense by $.5 million, but have no effect on the plans funded status.
58492_14_ITEM7_P173_S0	Assuming a long-term investment horizon, we do not expect a material change to the return on asset assumption.
58492_14_ITEM7_P174_S0	In the ordinary course of business, we must make estimates of the tax treatment of many transactions, even though the ultimate tax outcome may remain uncertain for some time.
58492_14_ITEM7_P174_S1	These estimates become part of the annual income tax expense reported in our financial statements.
58492_14_ITEM7_P174_S2	Subsequent to year end, we finalize our tax analysis and file income tax returns.
58492_14_ITEM7_P174_S3	Tax authorities periodically audit these income tax returns and examine our tax filing positions, including (among other things) the timing and amounts of deductions, and the allocation of income among tax jurisdictions.
58492_14_ITEM7_P175_S0	We adjust income tax expense in our financial statements in the periods in which the actual outcome becomes more certain.
58492_14_ITEM7_P176_S0	Our tax liability for unrecognized tax benefits contains uncertainties because management is required to make assumptions and to apply judgment to estimate the exposures related to our various filing positions.
58492_14_ITEM7_P177_S0	Our effective tax rate is also impacted by changes in tax laws, the current mix of earnings by taxing jurisdiction, and the results of current tax audits and assessments.
58492_14_ITEM7_P177_S1	At December 31, 2013 and 2012, we had $43 million and $39 million, respectively, of net deferred tax assets on our balance sheet related to operating loss and tax credit carryforwards.
58492_14_ITEM7_P177_S2	The ultimate realization of these deferred tax assets is dependent upon the amount, source, and timing of future taxable income.
58492_14_ITEM7_P177_S3	Valuation allowances are established against future potential tax benefits to reflect the amounts we believe have no more than a 50% probability of being realized.
58492_14_ITEM7_P178_S0	In addition, assumptions have been made regarding the non-repatriation of earnings from certain subsidiaries.
58492_14_ITEM7_P178_S1	Those assumptions may change in the future, thereby affecting future period results for the tax impact of possible repatriation.
58492_14_ITEM7_P179_S0	Potential changes in tax laws could impact assumptions related to the non-repatriation of certain foreign earnings.
58492_14_ITEM7_P179_S1	If all non-repatriated earnings were taxed, we would incur additional taxes of approximately $63 million.
58492_14_ITEM7_P180_S0	Audits by various taxing authorities continue to increase as governments look for ways to raise additional revenue.
58492_14_ITEM7_P180_S1	Based upon past experience, we do not expect any material changes to our tax liability as a result of this increased audit activity; however, we could incur additional tax expense if we have audit adjustments higher than recent historical experience.
58492_14_ITEM7_P181_S0	The recovery of net operating losses (NOL s) has been closely evaluated for the likelihood of recovery based upon factors such as the age of losses, viable tax planning strategies, and future taxable earnings expectations.
58492_14_ITEM7_P181_S1	We believe that appropriate valuation allowances have been recorded as necessary.
58492_14_ITEM7_P181_S2	However, if earnings expectations or other assumptions change such that additional valuation allowances are required, we could incur additional tax expense.
58492_14_ITEM7_P182_S0	We evaluate various legal, environmental, and other potential claims against us to determine if an accrual or disclosure of the contingency is appropriate.
58492_14_ITEM7_P182_S1	If it is probable that an ultimate loss will be incurred, we accrue a liability for the reasonable estimate of the ultimate loss.
58492_14_ITEM7_P183_S0	Our disclosure and accrual of loss contingencies (i.e., losses that may or may not occur) contain uncertainties because they are based on our assessment of the likelihood that the expenses will actually occur, and our estimate of the likely cost.
58492_14_ITEM7_P183_S1	Our estimates and judgments are subjective and can involve matters in litigation, the results of which are generally unpredictable.
58492_14_ITEM7_P184_S0	Legal contingencies are related to numerous lawsuits and claims described beginning on page 54.
58492_14_ITEM7_P184_S1	Over the past five years, the largest annual cost for litigation claims was $6 million (excluding legal fees).
58492_14_ITEM7_P185_S0	As discussed in Note T on page 113, we are defendants in a group of antitrust lawsuits related to alleged price fixing of prime foam and carpet underlay products.
58492_14_ITEM7_P185_S1	We will vigorously defend ourselves in this matter.
58492_14_ITEM7_P185_S2	However, if we are not able to prevail in future court proceedings this could have a negative impact on future cash flows and earnings.
58492_14_ITEM7_P185_S3	Due to the number of variables and uncertainties in this matter, we are unable to estimate the range of potential exposure at this time.
58492_14_ITEM7_P186_S0	Our disclosure and accrual of loss contingencies (i.e., losses that may or may not occur) are based on our assessment of the probability that the expenses will actually occur, and our reasonable estimate of the likely cost.
58492_14_ITEM7_P186_S1	Our estimates and judgments are subjective and can involve matters in litigation, the results of which are generally very unpredictable.
58492_14_ITEM7_P187_S0	Shareholder Derivative Lawsuit On August 10, 2010, a shareholder derivative suit was filed by the New England Carpenters Pension Fund in the Circuit Court of Jasper County, Missouri as Case No. 10AO-CC284.
58492_14_ITEM7_P187_S1	The suit was purportedly brought on our behalf, naming us as a nominal defendant, and certain current and former officers and directors as individual defendants including David S. Haffner, Karl G. Glassman, Matthew C. Flanigan, Ernest C. Jett, Harry M. Cornell, Jr., Felix E. Wright, Robert Ted Enloe, III, Richard T. Fisher, Judy C. Odom, Maurice E. Purnell, Jr., Ralph W. Clark and Michael A. Glauber.
58492_14_ITEM7_P187_S2	The plaintiff alleged, among other things, that the individual defendants: breached their fiduciary duties; backdated and received backdated stock options violating our stock plans; caused or allowed us to issue false and misleading financial statements and proxy statements; sold our stock while possessing material non-public information; committed gross mismanagement; wasted corporate assets; committed fraud; violated the Missouri Securities Act; and were unjustly enriched.
58492_14_ITEM7_P187_S3	The plaintiff is seeking, among other things: unspecified monetary damages against the individual defendants; certain equitable and other relief relating to the profits from the alleged improper conduct; the adoption of certain corporate governance proposals; the imposition of a constructive trust over the defendants stock options and proceeds; punitive damages; the rescission of certain unexercised options; and the reimbursement of litigation costs.
58492_14_ITEM7_P187_S4	The plaintiff is not seeking monetary relief from us.
58492_14_ITEM7_P187_S5	We have director and officer liability insurance in force subject to customary limits and exclusions.
58492_14_ITEM7_P187_S6	We and the individual defendants filed motions to dismiss the suit in late October 2010, asserting: the plaintiff failed to make demand on our Board and shareholders as required by Missouri law, and this failure to make demand should not be excused; the dismissal of the substantially similar suit in 2009 precludes the 2010 suit; the plaintiff is not a representative shareholder; the suit was based on a statistical analysis of stock option grants and our stock prices that we believe was flawed; the plaintiff failed to state a substantive claim; the common law fraud claim was not pled with sufficient particularity; and the statute of limitations has expired on the fraud claim and all the alleged challenged grants except the December 30, 2005 grant.
58492_14_ITEM7_P187_S7	As to this grant, the motions to dismiss advised the Court that it was made under our Deferred Compensation Program, which (i) provided that options would be dated on the last business day of December, and (ii) was filed with the SEC on December 2, 2005 setting out the pricing mechanism well before the grant date.
58492_14_ITEM7_P187_S8	On April 6, 2011, the suit was dismissed without prejudice.
58492_14_ITEM7_P188_S0	On May 12, 2011, the plaintiff filed an appeal to the Missouri Court of Appeals.
58492_14_ITEM7_P188_S1	On November 28, 2012, the Missouri Court of Appeals reversed the trial court's dismissal finding that plaintiff sufficiently pleaded it would be futile to make demand on the Board and shareholders.
58492_14_ITEM7_P188_S2	The Court of Appeals did not address the other grounds that had been raised in the motions to dismiss.
58492_14_ITEM7_P188_S3	We filed a request for transfer to the Missouri Supreme Court on December 12, 2012, which was denied by the Court of Appeals.
58492_14_ITEM7_P188_S4	On January 3, 2013, we filed a transfer petition to the Missouri Supreme Court.
58492_14_ITEM7_P188_S5	On February 26, 2013, the Missouri Supreme Court denied our request.
58492_14_ITEM7_P188_S6	The case was sent back to Jasper County, Missouri for further proceedings.
58492_14_ITEM7_P188_S7	At the parties' request, on June 4, 2013, the circuit court stayed all proceedings to allow the parties to mediate the dispute.
58492_14_ITEM7_P188_S8	The stay of litigation remains in effect.
58492_14_ITEM7_P188_S9	We do not expect that the outcome of this matter will have a material adverse effect on our financial condition, operating cash flows or results of operations.

58492_14_ITEM7_P189_S1	A number of these lawsuits have been voluntarily dismissed, most without prejudice.

58492_14_ITEM7_P189_S3	All of the pending U.S. federal cases in which we have been named as a defendant, have been filed in or have been transferred to the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio under the name In re: Polyurethane Foam Antitrust Litigation , Case No. 1:10-MD-2196.

58492_14_ITEM7_P199_S0	Brazilian Value-Added Tax Matters On December 22, 2011, the Brazilian Finance Ministry, Federal Revenue Office issued a notice of violation against our wholly-owned subsidiary, Leggett Platt do Brasil Ltda.
58492_14_ITEM7_P199_S1	( L P Brazil ) in the amount of $3.1 million, under Case No. 10855.724660/2011-43.
58492_14_ITEM7_P200_S0	The Brazilian Revenue Office claimed that for the period beginning November 2006 and continuing through December 2007, L P Brazil used an incorrect tariff code for the collection and payment of value-added tax primarily on the sale of mattress innerspring units in Brazil.
58492_14_ITEM7_P200_S1	L P Brazil responded to the notice of violation on January 25, 2012 denying the violation.
58492_14_ITEM7_P200_S2	The Federal Revenue Office, on August 9, 2013, denied L P Brazil's defenses and upheld the assessment at the first administrative level.
58492_14_ITEM7_P200_S3	L P Brazil was notified about this judgment on October 16, 2013, and has filed an appeal.

58492_14_ITEM7_P206_S0	Patent Infringement Claim On January 24, 2012, in a case in the United States District Court for the Central District of California, the jury entered a verdict against us in the amount of $5 million based upon an allegation by plaintiff that we infringed three patents on an automatic stapling machine and on methods used to assemble box springs.
58492_14_ITEM7_P206_S1	This action was originally filed on October 4, 2010, as case number CV10-7416 RGK (SSx) under the caption Imaginal Systematic, LLC v. Leggett Platt, Incorporated; Simmons Bedding Company; and Does 1 through 10, inclusive.
58492_14_ITEM7_P206_S2	Leggett is contractually obligated to defend and indemnify Simmons Bedding Company against a claim for infringement.
58492_14_ITEM7_P206_S3	On summary judgment motions, we unsuccessfully disputed each patent's validity and denied that we infringed any patent.
58492_14_ITEM7_P207_S0	At the jury trial on damages issues, the plaintiff alleged damages of $16.2 million.
58492_14_ITEM7_P207_S1	The court denied plaintiff's attempt to win an attorney fee award and triple the pre-verdict damages.
58492_14_ITEM7_P207_S2	On April 9, 2012 we appealed the case to the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals.
58492_14_ITEM7_P207_S3	Oral argument was held on February 6, 2013 before a three judge appeal panel in the Federal Circuit in Washington D.C. On February 14, 2013, the Court of Appeals issued a judgment affirming the $5 million verdict against us, which was fully accrued for in the first quarter of 2013 and then paid in the second quarter of 2013.
58492_14_ITEM7_P207_S4	We filed a petition for a rehearing of the Court of Appeals decision on March 18, 2013, which was denied by the Court of Appeals.
58492_14_ITEM7_P207_S5	The plaintiff requested royalties for post-verdict use of the machines, and requested pre-judgment interest in the amount of $.7 million.
58492_14_ITEM7_P207_S6	On July 3, 2013, the District Court ruled that the plaintiff was not entitled to additional ongoing royalties for our continued use of the machines, but did award pre-judgment interest of $.5 million.
58492_14_ITEM7_P207_S7	On August 2, 2013, both parties filed a notice of appeal of this order to the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals, but plaintiff has since withdrawn its appeal.
58492_14_ITEM7_P208_S0	In 2011, we also filed reexamination proceedings in the Patent Office (Case Nos. 95/001,543 filed February 11, 2011; 95/001,546 and 95/001,547 filed February 16, 2011), challenging the validity of each patent at issue in the lawsuit the plaintiff brought.
58492_14_ITEM7_P208_S1	The Patent Office examiner ruled in our favor on the key claims of one of the three patents.
58492_14_ITEM7_P208_S2	The Patent Office examiner initially ruled in our favor on the pertinent claims of the second of the patents, but subsequently reversed that decision.
58492_14_ITEM7_P208_S3	With respect to the third patent, the Patent Office's examiner decision upheld the validity of all claims.
58492_14_ITEM7_P208_S4	All three of these proceedings were appealed to the Board of Patent Appeals.
58492_14_ITEM7_P209_S0	Due to a change made to all of the machines, we do not believe that the machines currently use the feature alleged to have infringed the third patent.
58492_14_ITEM7_P210_S0	On April 25, 2013, the plaintiff filed petitions to terminate all re-examination proceedings based on the final ruling of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals.
58492_14_ITEM7_P210_S1	The Patent Office terminated all three re-examination proceedings, two on December 16, and one on December 18, 2013.

58492_14_ITEM10_P1_S0	Directors are normally elected annually at the Annual Meeting of Shareholders and hold office until the next annual meeting of shareholders or until their successors are elected and qualified.
58492_14_ITEM10_P1_S1	All current directors have been nominated for re-election at the Company s Annual Meeting of Shareholders to be held May 7, 2014.
58492_14_ITEM10_P2_S0	In order to be nominated for election as a director, a nominee must submit a contingent resignation to the Nominating Corporate Governance Committee (N CG Committee).
58492_14_ITEM10_P2_S1	The resignation will become effective only if (i) the director nominee fails to receive an affirmative majority of the votes cast in the director election; and (ii) the Board accepts the resignation.
58492_14_ITEM10_P2_S2	If a nominee fails to receive an affirmative majority of the votes cast in the director election, the N CG Committee will make a recommendation to the Board of Directors whether to accept or reject the director s resignation and whether any other action should be taken.
58492_14_ITEM10_P2_S3	If a director s resignation is not accepted, that director will continue to serve until the Company s next annual meeting or until his or her successor is duly elected and qualified.
58492_14_ITEM10_P2_S4	If the Board accepts the director s resignation, it may, in its sole discretion, either fill the resulting vacancy or decrease the size of the Board to eliminate the vacancy.
58492_14_ITEM10_P3_S0	The Company s Bylaws and Corporate Governance Guidelines set the director retirement age at 72; however, the Board Chair, CEO or President may request a waiver for any director.
58492_14_ITEM10_P3_S1	At the request of Leggett s CEO, the N CG Committee recommended, and the full Board granted, retirement age waivers for Directors Clark, Enloe and Fisher so they may stand for re-election at the 2014 annual meeting.

58492_14_ITEM15_P5_S0	Management of Leggett Platt, Incorporated is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting as defined in Exchange Act Rule 13a-15(f).
58492_14_ITEM15_P5_S1	Leggett Platt s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
58492_14_ITEM15_P5_S2	The Company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that:
58492_14_ITEM15_P6_S0	Provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use or disposition of Leggett Platt assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
58492_14_ITEM15_P7_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
58492_14_ITEM15_P7_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
58492_14_ITEM15_P8_S0	Under the supervision and with the participation of management (including ourselves), we conducted an evaluation of the effectiveness of Leggett Platt s internal control over financial reporting, as of December 31, 2013 , based on the criteria in Internal Control Integrated Framework (1992) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.
58492_14_ITEM15_P8_S1	Based on the evaluation under this framework, we concluded that Leggett Platt s internal control over financial reporting was effective as of December 31, 2013 .
58492_14_ITEM15_P9_S0	Leggett Platt s internal control over financial reporting, as of December 31, 2013 , has been audited by PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP, an independent registered public accounting firm, as stated in their report appearing on page 68 of this Form 10-K.

58492_14_ITEM15_P11_S3	The Company s management is responsible for these financial statements and financial statement schedule, for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting, included in the accompanying Management s Annual Report on Internal Control over Financial Reporting.
58492_14_ITEM15_P11_S4	Our responsibility is to express opinions on these financial statements, on the financial statement schedule, and on the Company s internal control over financial reporting based on our integrated audits.
58492_14_ITEM15_P11_S5	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
58492_14_ITEM15_P11_S6	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audits to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement and whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
58492_14_ITEM15_P11_S7	Our audits of the financial statements included examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements, assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, and evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
58492_14_ITEM15_P11_S8	Our audit of internal control over financial reporting included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, and testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk.
58492_14_ITEM15_P11_S9	Our audits also included performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
58492_14_ITEM15_P11_S10	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinions.
58492_14_ITEM15_P12_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
58492_14_ITEM15_P12_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (i) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (ii) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (iii) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
58492_14_ITEM15_P13_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
58492_14_ITEM15_P13_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.

58492_14_ITEM15_P21_S0	ESTIMATES: The preparation of financial statements in conformity with generally accepted accounting principles requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses and the disclosure of contingencies.
58492_14_ITEM15_P22_S0	Legal costs are accrued when a loss is probable and reasonably estimable.
58492_14_ITEM15_P22_S1	If a range of outcomes are possible, the most likely outcome is used to accrue these costs.
58492_14_ITEM15_P23_S0	Any insurance recovery is recorded separately if it is determined that a recovery is probable.
58492_14_ITEM15_P23_S1	Legal fees are accrued when incurred.
58492_14_ITEM15_P24_S0	CASH EQUIVALENTS: Cash equivalents include cash in excess of daily requirements which is invested in various financial instruments with original maturities of three months or less.
58492_14_ITEM15_P25_S0	TRADE AND OTHER RECEIVABLES AND ALLOWANCE FOR DOUBTFUL ACCOUNTS: Trade receivables are recorded at the invoiced amount and generally do not bear interest.
58492_14_ITEM15_P25_S1	Credit is also occasionally extended in the form of a note receivable to facilitate our customers operating cycles.
58492_14_ITEM15_P25_S2	Other notes receivable are established in special circumstances, such as in partial payment for the sale of a business.
58492_14_ITEM15_P25_S3	Other notes receivable generally bear interest at market rates commensurate with the corresponding credit risk on the date of origination.
58492_14_ITEM15_P26_S0	The allowance for doubtful accounts is an estimate of the amount of probable credit losses.
58492_14_ITEM15_P26_S1	Interest income is not recognized for accounts that are placed on nonaccrual status.
58492_14_ITEM15_P27_S0	Allowances and nonaccrual status designations are determined by individual account reviews by management, and are based on several factors such as the length of time that receivables are past due, the financial health of the companies involved, industry and macroeconomic considerations, and historical loss experience.
58492_14_ITEM15_P28_S0	Interest income is recorded on the date of cash receipt for nonaccrual status accounts.
58492_14_ITEM15_P28_S1	Account balances are charged off against the allowance when it is probable the receivable will not be recovered.
58492_14_ITEM15_P29_S0	All inventories are stated at the lower of cost or market.
58492_14_ITEM15_P29_S1	We generally use standard costs which include materials, labor and production overhead at normal production capacity.
58492_14_ITEM15_P29_S2	The cost for approximately 55% of our inventories is determined by the last-in, first-out (LIFO) method and is primarily used to value domestic inventories with raw material content consisting of steel, wire, chemicals and foam scrap.
58492_14_ITEM15_P29_S3	For the remainder of the inventories, we principally use the first-in, first-out (FIFO) method, which is representative of our standard costs.
58492_14_ITEM15_P29_S4	For these inventories, the FIFO cost for the periods presented approximated expected replacement cost.
58492_14_ITEM15_P30_S0	Inventories are reviewed at least quarterly for slow-moving and potentially obsolete items using actual inventory turnover, and if necessary, are written down to estimated net realizable value.
58492_14_ITEM15_P30_S1	We have had no material changes in inventory writedowns or slow-moving and obsolete inventory reserves in any of the years presented.
58492_14_ITEM15_P31_S0	Significant accounting policies associated with a decision to dispose of a business are discussed below:
58492_14_ITEM15_P32_S0	A business is classified as a discontinued operation when (i) the operations and cash flows of the business can be clearly distinguished and have been or will be eliminated from our ongoing operations; (ii) the business has either been disposed of or is classified as held for sale; and (iii) we will not have any significant continuing involvement in the operations of the business after the disposal transactions.
58492_14_ITEM15_P32_S1	Significant judgments are involved in determining whether a business meets the criteria for discontinued operations reporting and the period in which these criteria are met.
58492_14_ITEM15_P33_S0	If a business is reported as a discontinued operation, the results of operations through the date of sale, including any gain or loss recognized on the disposition, are presented on a separate line of the income statement.
58492_14_ITEM15_P33_S1	Interest on debt directly attributable to the discontinued operation is allocated to discontinued operations.
58492_14_ITEM15_P34_S0	businesses that do not meet the discontinued operation criteria are reported in continuing operations and separately disclosed if significant.
58492_14_ITEM15_P35_S0	Assets Held for Sale An asset or business is classified as held for sale when (i) management commits to a plan to sell and it is actively marketed; (ii) it is available for immediate sale and the sale is expected to be completed within one year; and (iii) it is unlikely significant changes to the plan will be made or that the plan will be withdrawn.
58492_14_ITEM15_P35_S1	In isolated instances, assets held for sale may exceed one year due to events or circumstances beyond our control.
58492_14_ITEM15_P36_S0	Upon being classified as held for sale, the recoverability of the carrying value must be assessed.
58492_14_ITEM15_P36_S1	Evaluating the recoverability of the assets of a business classified as held for sale follows a defined order in which property and intangible assets subject to amortization are considered only after the recoverability of goodwill and other assets are assessed.
58492_14_ITEM15_P36_S2	After the valuation process is completed, the assets held for sale are reported at the lower of the carrying value or fair value less cost to sell, and the assets are no longer depreciated or amortized.
58492_14_ITEM15_P36_S3	An impairment charge is recognized if the carrying value exceeds the fair value less cost to sell.
58492_14_ITEM15_P37_S0	The assets and related liabilities are aggregated and reported on separate lines of the balance sheet.
58492_14_ITEM15_P38_S0	If a decision to dispose of an asset or a business is made and the held for sale criteria are not met, it is considered held for use.
58492_14_ITEM15_P39_S0	Assets of the business are evaluated for recoverability in the following order: (i) assets other than goodwill, property and intangibles; (ii) property and intangibles subject to amortization; and (iii) goodwill.
58492_14_ITEM15_P40_S0	In evaluating the recoverability of property and intangible assets subject to amortization, the carrying value is first compared to the sum of the undiscounted cash flows expected to result from the use and eventual disposition.
58492_14_ITEM15_P40_S1	If the carrying value exceeds the undiscounted expected cash flows, then a fair value analysis is performed.
58492_14_ITEM15_P40_S2	An impairment charge is recognized if the carrying value exceeds the fair value.
58492_14_ITEM15_P41_S0	PROPERTY, PLANT AND EQUIPMENT: Property, plant and equipment is stated at cost, less accumulated depreciation.
58492_14_ITEM15_P41_S1	Assets are depreciated by the straight-line method and salvage value, if any, is assumed to be minimal.
58492_14_ITEM15_P42_S0	The table below presents the depreciation periods of the estimated useful lives of our property, plant and equipment.
58492_14_ITEM15_P43_S0	Accelerated methods are used for tax purposes.
58492_14_ITEM15_P44_S0	Property is reviewed for recoverability at year end and whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that its carrying value may not be recoverable as discussed above.
58492_14_ITEM15_P45_S0	Goodwill results from the acquisition of existing businesses and is not amortized; it is assessed for impairment annually and as triggering events may occur.
58492_14_ITEM15_P45_S1	We perform our annual review in the second quarter of each year.
58492_14_ITEM15_P46_S0	Recoverability of goodwill is evaluated using a two-step process.
58492_14_ITEM15_P47_S0	The first step involves a comparison of the fair value of a reporting unit with its carrying value.
58492_14_ITEM15_P48_S0	Our reporting units are the 10 business groups one level below the operating segment level for which discrete financial information is available and reviewed by segment management.
58492_14_ITEM15_P49_S0	If the carrying value of the group exceeds its fair value, the second step of the process is necessary and involves a comparison of the implied fair value and the carrying value of the goodwill of that group.
58492_14_ITEM15_P49_S1	If the carrying value of the goodwill of a group exceeds the implied fair value of that goodwill, an impairment loss is recognized in an amount equal to the excess.
58492_14_ITEM15_P50_S0	In evaluating the recoverability of goodwill, it is necessary to estimate the fair values of the business groups.
58492_14_ITEM15_P50_S1	In making this assessment, we estimate the fair market values of our reporting units using a discounted cash flow model and comparable market values for similar entities using price-to-earnings ratios.
58492_14_ITEM15_P50_S2	Key assumptions and estimates used in the cash flow model include discount rate, sales growth, margins, capital expenditure requirements, and working capital requirements.
58492_14_ITEM15_P51_S0	Recent performance of the group is an important factor, but not the only factor, in our assessment.
58492_14_ITEM15_P52_S0	There are inherent assumptions and judgments required in the analysis of goodwill impairment.
58492_14_ITEM15_P52_S1	It is possible that assumptions underlying the impairment analysis will change in such a manner that impairment in value may occur in the future.
58492_14_ITEM15_P53_S0	Substantially all other intangible assets are amortized using the straight-line method over their estimated useful lives and are evaluated for impairment using a process similar to that used in evaluating the recoverability of property, plant and equipment.
58492_14_ITEM15_P54_S0	The cost of employee services received in exchange for all equity awards granted is based on the fair market value of the award as of the grant date.
58492_14_ITEM15_P54_S1	Expense is recognized net of an estimated forfeiture rate using the straight line method over the vesting period of the award.
58492_14_ITEM15_P55_S0	We recognize sales when title and risk of loss pass to the customer.
58492_14_ITEM15_P55_S1	The terms of our sales are split approximately evenly between FOB shipping point and FOB destination.
58492_14_ITEM15_P55_S2	The timing of our recognition of FOB destination sales is determined based on shipping date and distance to the destination.
58492_14_ITEM15_P55_S3	We have no significant or unusual price protection, right of return or acceptance provisions with our customers.
58492_14_ITEM15_P56_S0	Sales allowances, discounts and rebates can be reasonably estimated throughout the period and are deducted from sales in arriving at net sales.
58492_14_ITEM15_P57_S0	SHIPPING AND HANDLING FEES AND COSTS: Shipping and handling costs are included as a component of Cost of goods sold.
58492_14_ITEM15_P58_S0	RESTRUCTURING COSTS: Restructuring costs are items such as employee termination, contract termination, plant closure and asset relocation costs related to exit activities.
58492_14_ITEM15_P58_S1	Restructuring-related items are inventory writedowns and gains or losses from sales of assets recorded as the result of exit activities.
58492_14_ITEM15_P59_S0	We recognize a liability for costs associated with an exit or disposal activity when the liability is incurred.
58492_14_ITEM15_P60_S0	Certain termination benefits for which employees are required to render service are recognized ratably over the respective future service periods.
58492_14_ITEM15_P61_S0	The provision for income taxes is determined using the asset and liability approach of accounting for income taxes.
58492_14_ITEM15_P61_S1	Under this approach, deferred taxes represent the future tax consequences expected to occur when the reported amounts of assets and liabilities are recovered or paid.
58492_14_ITEM15_P62_S0	The provision for income taxes represents income taxes paid or payable for the current year plus the change in deferred taxes during the year.
58492_14_ITEM15_P62_S1	Deferred taxes result from differences between the financial and tax basis of our assets and liabilities and are adjusted for changes in tax rates and laws, as appropriate.
58492_14_ITEM15_P62_S2	A valuation allowance is provided to reduce deferred tax assets when management cannot conclude that it is more likely than not that a tax benefit will be realized.
58492_14_ITEM15_P63_S0	A provision is also made for incremental taxes on undistributed earnings of foreign subsidiaries and related companies to the extent that such earnings are not deemed to be indefinitely invested.
58492_14_ITEM15_P64_S0	The calculation of our U.S., state, and foreign tax liabilities involves dealing with uncertainties in the application of complex global tax laws.
58492_14_ITEM15_P64_S1	We recognize potential liabilities for anticipated tax issues which might arise in the U.S. and other tax jurisdictions based on management s estimate of whether, and the extent to which, additional taxes will be due.
58492_14_ITEM15_P64_S2	If payment of these amounts ultimately proves to be unnecessary, the reversal of the liabilities would result in tax benefits being recognized in the period when we determine the liabilities are no longer necessary.
58492_14_ITEM15_P64_S3	Conversely, if the estimate of tax liabilities proves to be less than the ultimate tax assessment, a further charge to tax expense would result.
58492_14_ITEM15_P65_S0	CONCENTRATION OF CREDIT RISKS, EXPOSURES AND FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS: We manufacture, market, and distribute engineered products for the various end markets described in Note F.
58492_14_ITEM15_P65_S1	Our operations are principally located in the United States, although we also have operations in China, Europe, Canada, Mexico and other various countries.
58492_14_ITEM15_P66_S0	We maintain allowances for potential credit losses.
58492_14_ITEM15_P66_S1	We perform ongoing credit evaluations of our customers financial conditions and generally require no collateral from our customers, some of which are highly leveraged.
58492_14_ITEM15_P66_S2	Management also monitors the financial condition and status of other notes receivable.
58492_14_ITEM15_P67_S0	Other notes receivable primarily consist of notes accepted as partial payment for the divestiture of a business.
58492_14_ITEM15_P67_S1	Some of these companies are highly leveraged and the notes are not fully collateralized.
58492_14_ITEM15_P68_S0	We have no material guarantees or liabilities for product warranties which require disclosure.
58492_14_ITEM15_P69_S0	From time to time, we will enter into contracts to hedge foreign currency denominated transactions, natural gas purchases, and interest rates related to our debt.
58492_14_ITEM15_P70_S0	To minimize the risk of counterparty default, only highly-rated financial institutions that meet certain requirements are used.
58492_14_ITEM15_P70_S1	We do not anticipate that any of the financial institution counterparties will default on their obligations.
58492_14_ITEM15_P71_S0	The carrying value of cash and short-term financial instruments approximates fair value due to the short maturity of those instruments.
58492_14_ITEM15_P72_S0	Although we obtain insurance for workers compensation, automobile, product and general liability, property loss and medical claims, we have elected to retain a significant portion of expected losses through the use of deductibles.
58492_14_ITEM15_P72_S1	Accrued liabilities include estimates for unpaid reported claims and for claims incurred but not yet reported.
58492_14_ITEM15_P72_S2	Provisions for losses are recorded based upon reasonable estimates of the aggregate liability for claims incurred utilizing our prior experience and information provided by our third-party administrators and insurance carriers.
58492_14_ITEM15_P73_S0	DERIVATIVE FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS: We utilize derivative financial instruments to manage market and financial risks related to interest rates, foreign currency and commodities.
58492_14_ITEM15_P73_S1	We seek to use derivative contracts that qualify for hedge accounting treatment; however some instruments that economically manage currency risk may not qualify for hedge accounting treatment.
58492_14_ITEM15_P73_S2	It is our policy not to speculate using derivative instruments.
58492_14_ITEM15_P74_S0	Under hedge accounting, we formally document our hedge relationships, including identification of the hedging instruments and the hedged items, as well as our risk management objectives and strategies for entering into the hedge transaction.
58492_14_ITEM15_P74_S1	The process includes designating derivative instruments as hedges of specific assets, liabilities, firm commitments or forecasted transactions.
58492_14_ITEM15_P74_S2	We also formally assess both at inception and on a quarterly basis thereafter, whether the derivatives used in hedging transactions are highly effective in offsetting changes in either the fair value or cash flows of the hedged item.
58492_14_ITEM15_P74_S3	If it is determined that a derivative ceases to be highly effective, deferred gains or losses are recorded in the Consolidated Statements of Operations.
58492_14_ITEM15_P75_S0	On the date the contract is entered into, we designate the derivative as one of the following types of hedging instruments and account for it as follows:
58492_14_ITEM15_P76_S0	The hedge of a forecasted transaction or of the variability of cash flows to be received or paid related to a recognized asset or liability or anticipated transaction is designated as a cash flow hedge.
58492_14_ITEM15_P77_S0	The effective portion of the change in fair value is recorded in accumulated other comprehensive income.
58492_14_ITEM15_P77_S1	When the hedged item impacts the income statement, the gain or loss included in other comprehensive income is reported on the same line of the Consolidated Statements of Operations as the hedged item to match the gain or loss on the derivative to the gain or loss on the hedged item.
58492_14_ITEM15_P77_S2	Any ineffective portion of the changes in the fair value is immediately reported in the Consolidated Statements of Operations on the same line as the hedged item.
58492_14_ITEM15_P78_S0	Settlements associated with the sale or production of product are presented in operating cash flows and settlements associated with debt issuance are presented in financing cash flows.
58492_14_ITEM15_P79_S0	The hedge of a recognized asset or liability or an unrecognized firm commitment is designated as a fair value hedge.
58492_14_ITEM15_P79_S1	For fair value hedges, both the effective and ineffective portions of the changes in fair value of the derivative, along with the gain or loss on the hedged item that is attributable to the hedged risk, are recorded in earnings and reported in the Consolidated Statements of Operations on the same line as the hedged item.
58492_14_ITEM15_P80_S0	Cash flows from settled contracts are presented in the category consistent with the nature of the item being hedged.
58492_14_ITEM15_P81_S0	The functional currency for most foreign operations is the local currency.
58492_14_ITEM15_P81_S1	The translation of foreign currencies into U.S. dollars is performed for balance sheet accounts using current exchange rates in effect at the balance sheet date and for income and expense accounts using monthly average exchange rates.
58492_14_ITEM15_P81_S2	The cumulative effects of translating the functional currencies into the U.S. dollar are included in comprehensive income.
58492_14_ITEM15_P82_S0	Certain reclassifications have been made to the prior years consolidated financial statements to conform to the 2013 presentation, primarily in the Consolidated Statements of Operations and all related notes in which prior periods have been retrospectively adjusted to reflect the reclassification of certain operations to discontinued operations (See Note B).
58492_14_ITEM15_P83_S0	The FASB has issued accounting guidance effective for current and future periods.
58492_14_ITEM15_P83_S1	This guidance did not have a material impact on our current financial statements, and we do not believe it will have a material impact on our future financial statements.

58492_14_ITEM15_P97_S0	Fair value of reporting units is determined using a combination of two valuation methods: a market approach and an income approach.
58492_14_ITEM15_P97_S1	Each method is generally given equal weight in determining the fair value assigned to each reporting unit.
58492_14_ITEM15_P97_S2	Absent an indication of fair value from a potential buyer or similar specific transaction, we believe that the use of these two methods provides a reasonable estimate of a reporting unit s fair value.
58492_14_ITEM15_P97_S3	Assumptions common to both methods are operating plans and economic projections, which are used to project future revenues, earnings, and after-tax cash flows for each reporting unit.
58492_14_ITEM15_P97_S4	These assumptions are applied consistently for both methods.
58492_14_ITEM15_P98_S0	The market approach estimates fair value by first determining price-to-earnings ratios for comparable publicly-traded companies with similar characteristics of the reporting unit.
58492_14_ITEM15_P98_S1	The price-to-earnings ratio for comparable companies is based upon current enterprise value compared to projected earnings for the next two years.
58492_14_ITEM15_P98_S2	The enterprise value is based upon current market capitalization and includes a 25% control premium.
58492_14_ITEM15_P98_S3	Projected earnings are based upon market analysts projections.
58492_14_ITEM15_P98_S4	The earnings ratios are applied to the projected earnings of the comparable reporting unit to estimate fair value.
58492_14_ITEM15_P98_S5	Management believes this approach is appropriate because it provides a fair value estimate using multiples from entities with operations and economic characteristics comparable to our reporting units.
58492_14_ITEM15_P99_S0	The income approach is based on projected future (debt-free) cash flow that is discounted to present value using factors that consider the timing and risk of future cash flows.
58492_14_ITEM15_P99_S1	Management believes that this approach is appropriate because it provides a fair value estimate based upon the reporting unit s expected long-term operating cash flow performance.
58492_14_ITEM15_P100_S0	Discounted cash flow projections are based on 10 -year financial forecasts developed from operating plans and economic projections noted above, sales growth, estimates of future expected changes in operating margins, terminal value growth rates, future capital expenditures and changes in working capital requirements.
58492_14_ITEM15_P101_S0	If a triggering event occurs, special consideration is given to the new circumstances when determining the fair value of the impacted reporting unit.
58492_14_ITEM15_P102_S0	The goodwill impairment reviews performed in June of each year presented indicated no goodwill impairments.

58492_14_ITEM15_P163_S0	When the tax deduction for an exercised stock option or converted stock unit exceeds the compensation cost that has been recognized in income, a windfall tax benefit is created.
58492_14_ITEM15_P163_S1	The windfall benefit is not recognized in income, but rather on the balance sheet as additional contributed capital.
58492_14_ITEM15_P164_S0	When the current tax deduction for an exercised stock option or converted stock unit is less than the deferred tax asset recorded in regard to the compensation cost that has been recognized in income, a tax shortfall is created.
58492_14_ITEM15_P164_S1	To the extent we have accumulated tax windfalls, the shortfall is recognized on the balance sheet as a reduction of additional contributed capital.
58492_14_ITEM15_P165_S0	We have granted stock options in the following areas:
58492_14_ITEM15_P166_S0	We have historically granted stock options annually on a discretionary basis to a broad group of employees.
58492_14_ITEM15_P166_S1	Options generally become exercisable in one-third increments at 18 months , 30 months and 42 months after the date of grant.
58492_14_ITEM15_P166_S2	Options have a maximum term of ten years and the exercise prices are equal to Leggett s closing stock price on the grant date.
58492_14_ITEM15_P167_S0	Grant date fair values are calculated using the Black-Scholes option pricing model and are amortized by the straight-line method over the options total vesting period, except for employees who terminate due to retirement.
58492_14_ITEM15_P168_S0	A retirement termination occurs if the employee is age 65 , or age 55 with 20 years of Company service at termination.
58492_14_ITEM15_P168_S1	For retirement terminations, options continue to vest and remain exercisable for three years, six months after termination of employment.
58492_14_ITEM15_P168_S2	Therefore, the expense for these options is accelerated when the employee is retirement eligible.
58492_14_ITEM15_P169_S0	In connection with the January 2011 and 2012 grants, we offered two different option choice programs.
58492_14_ITEM15_P169_S1	One group of employees was offered the choice to receive stock options or to receive a cash payment in lieu of options, with the cash alternative being equal to approximately one-half of the Black-Scholes value of the option grant foregone.
58492_14_ITEM15_P169_S2	Another group of employees, generally higher level employees, were offered a choice between stock options or restricted stock units (RSUs), on a ratio of four options foregone for every one RSU offered.
58492_14_ITEM15_P169_S3	The stock units vest in one-third increments at 12 months , 24 months and 36 months after the date of grant.

58492_14_ITEM15_P176_S0	Expense is recorded as the compensation is earned.
58492_14_ITEM15_P176_S1	Stock units earn dividends at the same rate as cash dividends paid on our common stock.
58492_14_ITEM15_P176_S2	These dividends are used to acquire stock units at a 20% discount.

58492_14_ITEM15_P187_S0	We have two stock-based retirement plans: the tax-qualified Stock Bonus Plan (SBP) for non-highly compensated employees, and the non-qualified Executive Stock Unit Program (ESUP) for highly compensated employees.
58492_14_ITEM15_P187_S1	We make matching contributions to both plans.
58492_14_ITEM15_P187_S2	In addition to the automatic 50% match, we will make another matching contribution of up to 50% of the employee s contributions for the year if certain profitability levels, as defined in the SBP and the ESUP, are obtained.
58492_14_ITEM15_P188_S0	Participants in the SBP may contribute up to 6% of their compensation above a certain threshold to purchase Leggett stock or other investment alternatives at market prices.
58492_14_ITEM15_P188_S1	We immediately match 50% of the employee contributions.
58492_14_ITEM15_P188_S2	Employees are allowed to fully diversify their employee deferral accounts immediately and their employer accounts after three years of service.
58492_14_ITEM15_P189_S0	Dividends earned on Company stock held in the SBP are reinvested or paid in cash at the participant s election.
58492_14_ITEM15_P190_S0	Participants in the ESUP may contribute up to 10% (depending upon salary level) of their compensation above the same threshold applicable to the SBP.
58492_14_ITEM15_P190_S1	Participant contributions are credited to a diversified investment account established for the participant, and we make premium contributions to the diversified investment accounts equal to 17.65% of the participant s contribution.
58492_14_ITEM15_P190_S2	A participant s diversified investment account balance is adjusted to mirror the investment experience, whether positive or negative, of the diversified investments selected by the participant.
58492_14_ITEM15_P190_S3	Participants may change investment elections in the diversified investment accounts, but cannot purchase Company common stock or stock units.
58492_14_ITEM15_P190_S4	The diversified investment accounts consist of various mutual funds and retirement target funds and are unfunded, unsecured obligations of the Company that will be settled in cash.

58492_14_ITEM15_P224_S0	Plan assets are invested in diversified portfolios of equity, debt and government securities.

58492_14_ITEM15_P225_S0	Our investment policy and strategies are established with a long-term view in mind.
58492_14_ITEM15_P225_S1	We strive for a sufficiently diversified asset mix to minimize the risk of a material loss to the portfolio value due to the devaluation of any single investment.
58492_14_ITEM15_P225_S2	In determining the appropriate asset mix, our financial strength and ability to fund potential shortfalls that might result from poor investment performance are considered.
58492_14_ITEM15_P226_S0	Of our three significant domestic plans, the frozen plan (representing approximately 60% of the total benefit obligation) employs a Liability Driven Investment strategy and has a target allocation of 60% fixed income and 40% equities.
58492_14_ITEM15_P226_S1	The remaining significant plans have a target allocation of 75% equities and 25% fixed income, as historical equity returns have tended to exceed bond returns over the long term.

58492_14_ITEM15_P233_S0	Extended Duration Treasury Index: Diversified exposure to the long-term Treasury STRIPS market.

58492_14_ITEM15_P264_S0	We utilize fair value measures for both financial and non-financial assets and liabilities.
58492_14_ITEM15_P265_S0	The areas in which we utilize fair value measures of financial assets and liabilities are presented in the table below.
58492_14_ITEM15_P266_S0	Fair value measurements are established using a three level valuation hierarchy that prioritizes the inputs to valuation techniques used to measure fair value into the following categories:
58492_14_ITEM15_P267_S0	Level 1: Quoted prices for identical assets or liabilities in active markets.
58492_14_ITEM15_P268_S0	Level 2: Inputs other than quoted prices included in Level 1 that are observable for the asset or liability either directly or indirectly.
58492_14_ITEM15_P268_S1	Short-term investments in this category are valued using discounted cash flow techniques with all significant inputs derived from or corroborated by observable market data.
58492_14_ITEM15_P268_S2	Derivative assets and liabilities in this category are valued using models that consider various assumptions and information from market-corroborated sources.
58492_14_ITEM15_P268_S3	The models used are primarily industry-standard models that consider items such as quoted prices, market interest rate curves applicable to the instruments being valued as of the end of each period, discounted cash flows, volatility factors, current market and contractual prices for the underlying instruments, as well as other relevant economic measures.
58492_14_ITEM15_P268_S4	Substantially all of these assumptions are observable in the marketplace, can be derived from observable data or are supported by observable levels at which transactions are executed in the marketplace.
58492_14_ITEM15_P269_S0	Level 3: Unobservable inputs that are not corroborated by market data.
58492_14_ITEM15_P270_S0	* - Includes both current and long-term amounts combined.
58492_14_ITEM15_P271_S0	The fair value for fixed rate debt (Level 2) was less than its $830.0 carrying value by $3.2 at December 31, 2013 and greater than its $1,030.0 carrying value by $45.7 at December 31, 2012.
58492_14_ITEM15_P271_S1	We value this debt using discounted cash flow and secondary market rates provided by Bloomberg.
58492_14_ITEM15_P272_S0	The primary areas in which we utilize fair value measures of non-financial assets and liabilities are allocating purchase price to the assets and liabilities of acquired companies as discussed in Note R and evaluating long-term assets (including goodwill) for potential impairment as discussed in Note C. Determining fair values for these items requires significant judgment and includes a variety of methods and models that utilize significant Level 3 inputs.
58492_14_ITEM15_P273_S0	Long-lived assets, acquisitions and the second step of a goodwill impairment test utilize the following methodologies in determining fair value: (i) Buildings and machinery are valued at an estimated replacement cost for an asset of comparable age and condition.
58492_14_ITEM15_P273_S1	Market pricing of comparable assets are used to estimate replacement cost where available.
58492_14_ITEM15_P274_S0	The most common identified intangible assets are customer relationships and tradenames.
58492_14_ITEM15_P274_S1	Customer relationships are valued using an excess earnings method, using various inputs such as the estimated customer attrition rate, future earnings forecast, the amount of contributory asset charges, and a discount rate.
58492_14_ITEM15_P274_S2	Tradenames are valued using a relief from royalty method, which is based upon comparable market royalty rates for tradenames of similar value.
58492_14_ITEM15_P275_S0	(iii) Inventory is valued at current replacement cost for raw materials, with a step-up for work in process and finished goods items that reflects the amount of ultimate profit earned as the valuation date.
58492_14_ITEM15_P275_S1	(iv) Other working capital items are generally recorded at face value, unless there are known conditions that would impact the ultimate settlement amount of the particular item.

58492_14_ITEM15_P297_S1	If a hedge was not highly effective, the portion of the change in fair value considered to be ineffective would be recognized immediately in the consolidated statements of operations.

58492_14_ITEM15_P303_S0	Shareholder Derivative Lawsuit On August 10, 2010, a shareholder derivative suit was filed by the New England Carpenters Pension Fund in the Circuit Court of Jasper County, Missouri as Case No. 10AO-CC284.
58492_14_ITEM15_P303_S1	The suit was purportedly brought on our behalf, naming us as a nominal defendant, and certain current and former officers and directors as individual defendants including David S. Haffner, Karl G. Glassman, Matthew C. Flanigan, Ernest C. Jett, Harry M. Cornell, Jr., Felix E. Wright, Robert Ted Enloe, III, Richard T. Fisher, Judy C. Odom, Maurice E. Purnell, Jr., Ralph W. Clark and Michael A. Glauber.
58492_14_ITEM15_P303_S2	The plaintiff alleged, among other things, that the individual defendants: breached their fiduciary duties; backdated and received backdated stock options violating our stock plans; caused or allowed us to issue false and misleading financial statements and proxy statements; sold our stock while possessing material non-public information; committed gross mismanagement; wasted corporate assets; committed fraud; violated the Missouri Securities Act; and were unjustly enriched.
58492_14_ITEM15_P303_S3	The plaintiff is seeking, among other things: unspecified monetary damages against the individual defendants; certain equitable and other relief relating to the profits from the alleged improper conduct; the adoption of certain corporate governance proposals; the imposition of a constructive trust over the defendants stock options and proceeds; punitive damages; the rescission of certain unexercised options; and the reimbursement of litigation costs.
58492_14_ITEM15_P303_S4	The plaintiff is not seeking monetary relief from us.
58492_14_ITEM15_P303_S5	We have director and officer liability insurance in force subject to customary limits and exclusions.
58492_14_ITEM15_P303_S6	We and the individual defendants filed motions to dismiss the suit in late October 2010, asserting: the plaintiff failed to make demand on our Board and shareholders as required by Missouri law, and this failure to make demand should not be excused; the dismissal of the substantially similar suit in 2009 precludes the 2010 suit; the plaintiff is not a representative shareholder; the suit was based on a statistical analysis of stock option grants and our stock prices that we believe was flawed; the plaintiff failed to state a substantive claim; the common law fraud claim was not pled with sufficient particularity; and the statute of limitations has expired on the fraud claim and all the alleged challenged grants except the December 30, 2005 grant.
58492_14_ITEM15_P303_S7	As to this grant, the motions to dismiss advised the Court that it was made under our Deferred Compensation Program, which (i) provided that options would be dated on the last business day of December, and (ii) was filed with the SEC on December 2, 2005 setting out the pricing mechanism well before the grant date.
58492_14_ITEM15_P303_S8	On April 6, 2011, the suit was dismissed without prejudice.
58492_14_ITEM15_P304_S0	On May 12, 2011, the plaintiff filed an appeal to the Missouri Court of Appeals.
58492_14_ITEM15_P304_S1	On November 28, 2012, the Missouri Court of Appeals reversed the trial court's dismissal finding that plaintiff sufficiently pleaded it would be futile to make demand on the Board and shareholders.
58492_14_ITEM15_P304_S2	The Court of Appeals did not address the other grounds that had been raised in the motions to dismiss.
58492_14_ITEM15_P304_S3	We filed a request for transfer to the Missouri Supreme Court on December 12, 2012, which was denied by the Court of Appeals.
58492_14_ITEM15_P304_S4	On January 3, 2013, we filed a transfer petition to the Missouri Supreme Court.
58492_14_ITEM15_P304_S5	On February 26, 2013, the Missouri Supreme Court denied our request.
58492_14_ITEM15_P304_S6	The case was sent back to Jasper County, Missouri for further proceedings.
58492_14_ITEM15_P304_S7	At the parties' request, on June 4, 2013, the circuit court stayed all proceedings to allow the parties to mediate the dispute.
58492_14_ITEM15_P304_S8	The stay of litigation remains in effect.
58492_14_ITEM15_P304_S9	We do not expect that the outcome of this matter will have a material adverse effect on our financial condition, operating cash flows or results of operations.

58492_14_ITEM15_P321_S0	Patent Infringement Claim On January 24, 2012, in a case in the United States District Court for the Central District of California, the jury entered a verdict against us in the amount of $5 based upon an allegation by plaintiff that we infringed three patents on an automatic stapling machine and on methods used to assemble box springs.
58492_14_ITEM15_P321_S1	This action was originally filed on October 4, 2010, as case number CV10-7416 RGK (SSx) under the caption Imaginal Systematic, LLC v. Leggett Platt, Incorporated; Simmons Bedding Company; and Does 1 through 10, inclusive.
58492_14_ITEM15_P321_S2	Leggett is contractually obligated to defend and indemnify Simmons Bedding Company against a claim for infringement.
58492_14_ITEM15_P321_S3	On summary judgment motions, we unsuccessfully disputed each patent's validity and denied that we infringed any patent.
58492_14_ITEM15_P322_S0	At the jury trial on damages issues, the plaintiff alleged damages of $16.2 .
58492_14_ITEM15_P322_S1	The court denied plaintiff's attempt to win an attorney fee award and triple the pre-verdict damages.
58492_14_ITEM15_P322_S2	On April 9, 2012 we appealed the case to the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals.
58492_14_ITEM15_P322_S3	Oral argument was held on February 6, 2013 before a three judge appeal panel in the Federal Circuit in Washington D.C. On February 14, 2013, the Court of Appeals issued a judgment affirming the $5 verdict against us, which was fully accrued for in the first quarter of 2013 and then paid in the second quarter of 2013.
58492_14_ITEM15_P322_S4	We filed a petition for a rehearing of the Court of Appeals decision on March 18, 2013, which was denied by the Court of Appeals.
58492_14_ITEM15_P323_S0	The plaintiff requested royalties for post-verdict use of the machines and requested pre-judgment interest in the amount of $.7 .
58492_14_ITEM15_P324_S0	but did award pre-judgment interest of $.5 .
58492_14_ITEM15_P324_S1	On August 2, 2013, both parties filed a notice of appeal of this order to the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals, but plaintiff has since withdrawn its appeal.
58492_14_ITEM15_P325_S0	In 2011, we also filed reexamination proceedings in the Patent Office (Case Nos. 95/001,543 filed February 11, 2011; 95/001,546 and 95/001,547 filed February 16, 2011), challenging the validity of each patent at issue in the lawsuit the plaintiff brought.
58492_14_ITEM15_P325_S1	The Patent Office examiner ruled in our favor on the key claims of one of three patents.
58492_14_ITEM15_P325_S2	The Patent Office examiner initially ruled in our favor on the pertinent claims of the second of the patents, but subsequently reversed that decision.
58492_14_ITEM15_P325_S3	With respect to the third patent, the Patent Office examiner's decision upheld the validity of all claims.
58492_14_ITEM15_P325_S4	All three of these proceedings were appealed to the Board of Patent Appeals.
58492_14_ITEM15_P326_S0	Due to a change made to all of the machines, we do not believe that the machines currently use the feature alleged to have infringed the third patent.
58492_14_ITEM15_P327_S0	On April 25, 2013, the plaintiff filed petitions to terminate all re-examination proceedings based on the final ruling of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals.
58492_14_ITEM15_P327_S1	The Patent Office terminated all three re-examination proceedings, two on December 16, and one on December 18, 2013.
58492_14_ITEM15_P328_S0	On July 29, 2013, the plaintiff filed a second lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Central District of California, Case No.
58492_14_ITEM15_P328_S1	CV13-05463 alleging that we and Simmons Bedding Company have continued to infringe the three patents on an automatic stapling machine and the methods used to assemble box springs, and that the plaintiff is entitled to additional damages from January 24, 2012 forward.
58492_14_ITEM15_P328_S2	Leggett and Simmons Bedding Company filed their Answers on November 20, 2013, and intend to vigorously defend the allegations.
58492_14_ITEM15_P329_S0	At this time, we do not expect that the outcome of this matter will have a material adverse effect on our financial condition, operating cash flows or results of operations.
58492_14_ITEM15_P330_S0	Amounts for 2012 have been retrospectively adjusted to reflect the reclassification of certain businesses from continuing to discontinued operations in 2013.
58492_14_ITEM15_P331_S0	As discussed in Note R beginning on page 109, in the third quarter of 2013 we recorded a $9 bargain purchase gain related to an acquisition.
58492_14_ITEM15_P332_S0	Net earnings for 2012 include a fourth quarter $27 net tax benefit primarily related to the release of valuation allowances on certain Canadian deferred tax assets, partially offset by withholding taxes on earnings in China.

58492_14_ITEM15_P333_S1	(2) Federal tax effect of state and foreign net operating loss carryforwards and credits and changes in currency exchange rates.

58492_14_ITEM15_P393_S0	(2) The information contained in the Report fairly presents, in all material respects, the financial condition and results of operations of the Company.
