58492_15_ITEM15_P410_S1	A signed original of this written statement required by Section 906 has been provided to Leggett Platt, Incorporated and will be retained by Leggett Platt, Incorporated and furnished to the Securities and Exchange Commission or its staff upon request.
58492_16_ITEM1_P0_S0	Leggett Platt, Incorporated was founded as a partnership in Carthage, Missouri in 1883 and was incorporated in 1901.
58492_16_ITEM1_P0_S1	The Company, a pioneer of the steel coil bedspring, has become an international diversified manufacturer that conceives, designs and produces a wide range of engineered components and products found in many homes, offices, automobiles and commercial aircraft.
58492_16_ITEM1_P0_S2	As discussed below, our continuing operations are organized into 17 business units, which are divided into 10 groups under our four segments: Residential Furnishings; Commercial Products; Industrial Materials; and Specialized Products.
58492_16_ITEM1_P1_S0	Our Residential Furnishings segment began in 1883 with the manufacture of steel coiled bedsprings.
58492_16_ITEM1_P1_S1	Today, we supply a variety of components used by bedding and upholstered furniture manufacturers in the assembly of their finished products.
58492_16_ITEM1_P1_S2	Our range of products offers our customers a single source for many of their component needs.
58492_16_ITEM1_P2_S0	Innovative proprietary products and low cost have made us the largest U.S. manufacturer in many of these businesses.
58492_16_ITEM1_P2_S1	We strive to understand what drives consumer purchases in our markets and focus our product development activities on meeting those end-consumer needs.
58492_16_ITEM1_P2_S2	We attain a cost advantage from efficient manufacturing methods, internal production of key raw materials, purchasing leverage, and large-scale production.
58492_16_ITEM1_P2_S3	Sourcing components from us allows our customers to focus on designing, merchandising, and marketing their products.
58492_16_ITEM1_P3_S0	In our Commercial Products segment we design, manufacture, and distribute a wide range of components and finished products for the office seating and specialty retail markets.
58492_16_ITEM1_P3_S1	We are a major supplier of fashion beds and adjustable beds, with domestic manufacturing and distribution capability as well as established relationships with global sources.
58492_16_ITEM1_P4_S0	The quality of our products and service, together with our low cost, have made Leggett Platt the leading U.S. supplier of high carbon drawn steel wire.
58492_16_ITEM1_P4_S1	Our Wire group operates a steel rod mill with an annual output of approximately 500,000 tons, of which a substantial majority is used by our own wire mills.
58492_16_ITEM1_P4_S2	We have three wire mills that supply virtually all the wire consumed by our other domestic businesses.
58492_16_ITEM1_P4_S3	We also supply steel wire to external customers that operate in a broad range of markets.
58492_16_ITEM1_P5_S0	We sold our Steel Tubing business in the fourth quarter of 2015.
58492_16_ITEM1_P5_S1	This unit supplied steel tubing to many external customers, including automotive seat frame producers, and also supplied a portion of our internal needs.
58492_16_ITEM1_P6_S0	We use about 70% of our wire output to manufacture our own products, including:
58492_16_ITEM1_P7_S0	The Industrial Materials segment also has a diverse group of external customers that include:
58492_16_ITEM1_P8_S0	Our Specialized Products segment designs, manufactures and sells products including automotive seating components, tubing for the aerospace industry, specialized machinery and equipment, and service van interiors.
58492_16_ITEM1_P8_S1	Our established design capability and focus on product development have made us a leader in innovation.
58492_16_ITEM1_P8_S2	We also benefit from our broad geographic presence and our internal production of key raw materials and components.
58492_16_ITEM1_P9_S0	We are considering strategic alternatives for our CVP Group, including the possible divestiture of this business.
58492_16_ITEM1_P9_S1	For more information, please refer to Commercial Vehicle Products Divestiture on page 31.
58492_16_ITEM1_P10_S0	Total Shareholder Return (TSR), relative to peer companies, is the key financial measure that we use to assess long-term performance.
58492_16_ITEM1_P10_S1	TSR = (Change in Stock Price + Dividends)/Beginning Stock Price.
58492_16_ITEM1_P10_S2	Our goal is to achieve TSR in the top third of the S P 500 companies over rolling three-year periods through a balanced approach that employs four TSR sources: revenue growth, margin expansion, dividends, and share repurchases.
58492_16_ITEM1_P10_S3	For the three-year measurement period that ended December 31, 2015, we met our goal of producing TSR in the top third of the S P 500.
58492_16_ITEM1_P10_S4	We generated compounded annual TSR of 20% per year, on average, over the last three years, significantly better than the S P 500's 15% annual TSR over the same time period.
58492_16_ITEM1_P11_S0	Our incentive programs reward return generation and profitable growth.
58492_16_ITEM1_P12_S0	Senior executives participate in a TSR-based incentive program (based on our performance compared to a group of approximately 320 peers).
58492_16_ITEM1_P13_S0	Business unit bonuses emphasize the achievement of higher returns on the assets under the unit s direct control.
58492_16_ITEM1_P14_S0	During the past three years, we generated approximately $1.2 billion of operating cash, and we returned much of this cash to shareholders in the form of dividends and share repurchases.
58492_16_ITEM1_P14_S1	Dividends and share repurchases are expected to remain significant contributors to long-term TSR.
58492_16_ITEM1_P15_S0	We currently pay a quarterly dividend of $.32 per share.
58492_16_ITEM1_P15_S1	Our target for dividend payout is 50-60% of earnings, however actual payout has been higher in recent years (88% in 2013 and 179% in 2014, impacted by goodwill impairment in both years and litigation accruals in 2014).
58492_16_ITEM1_P15_S2	As a result, dividend growth has been modest, at about 3% per year.
58492_16_ITEM1_P15_S3	With significant earnings improvement in 2015, dividend payout for the year was 55%, within the target range.
58492_16_ITEM1_P15_S4	This allows us flexibility to consider future dividend growth that more closely aligns with EPS growth.
58492_16_ITEM1_P16_S0	We have consistently (for over 25 years) generated operating cash in excess of our annual requirement for capital expenditures and dividends.
58492_16_ITEM1_P17_S0	Our top priorities for use of cash are organic growth (capital expenditures), dividends, and strategic acquisitions.
58492_16_ITEM1_P17_S1	After funding those priorities, if there is still cash available, we generally intend to repurchase stock rather than repay debt early or stockpile cash.
58492_16_ITEM1_P17_S2	During the last three years, we repurchased a total of 15.6 million shares of our stock and issued 9.1 million shares (through employee benefit plans and stock option exercises), reducing outstanding shares by 5%.
58492_16_ITEM1_P17_S3	In 2015, we repurchased 4.3 million shares (at an average of $45.72) and issued 2.1 million shares (at an average of $23.61).
58492_16_ITEM1_P18_S0	We utilize a rigorous strategic planning process to help guide decisions regarding business unit roles, capital allocation priorities, and new areas in which to grow.
58492_16_ITEM1_P18_S1	We review the portfolio classification of each unit on an annual basis to determine its appropriate role (Grow, Core, Fix, or Divest).
58492_16_ITEM1_P18_S2	This review includes criteria such as competitive position, market attractiveness, business unit size, and fit within our overall objectives, as well as financial indicators such as growth of EBIT (earnings before interest and taxes) and EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization), operating cash flows, and return on assets.
58492_16_ITEM1_P19_S0	Business units in the Grow category should provide avenues for profitable growth from competitively advantaged positions in attractive markets.
58492_16_ITEM1_P20_S0	Core business units are expected to enhance productivity, improve market share, and generate cash flow from operations while using minimal capital.
58492_16_ITEM1_P20_S1	To remain in the portfolio, business units are expected to consistently generate after-tax returns in excess of our cost of capital.
58492_16_ITEM1_P20_S2	Business units that fail to consistently attain minimum return goals will be moved to the Fix or Divest categories.
58492_16_ITEM1_P21_S0	Long-term, we aim to achieve consistent, profitable growth of 4-5% annually.
58492_16_ITEM1_P21_S1	To attain this goal, we will need to supplement the approximate 2-3% growth that our markets typically produce (in normal economic times) with two additional areas of opportunity.
58492_16_ITEM1_P22_S0	First, we must develop and commercialize innovative new products within markets in which we already enjoy strong competitive positions.
58492_16_ITEM1_P22_S1	Second, we need to uncover new growth platforms: opportunities in markets new to us containing margins and growth higher than the Company's average, and in which we would possess a competitive advantage.
58492_16_ITEM1_P23_S0	Our long-term 4-5% annual growth objective envisions periodic acquisitions.
58492_16_ITEM1_P23_S1	We primarily seek acquisitions within our Grow businesses, and look for opportunities to enter new, higher growth markets (carefully screened for sustainable competitive advantage).
58492_16_ITEM1_P23_S2	We expect all acquisitions to (a) have a clear strategic rationale, a sustainable competitive advantage, a strong fit with the Company, and be in an attractive and growing market; (b) create value by enhancing TSR; (c) for stand-alone businesses: generally possess revenue in excess of $50 million, strong management and future growth opportunity with a strong market position in a market growing faster than GDP; and (d) for add-on businesses: generally possess revenue in excess of $15 million, significant synergies, and a strategic fit with an existing business unit.
58492_16_ITEM1_P24_S0	We acquired a 70% interest in a European private-label manufacturer of high-end upholstered furniture for office, commercial and other settings for a purchase price of $23 million.
58492_16_ITEM1_P24_S1	This business is complementary to our North American private-label operation and allows us to support our Work Furniture customers as they expand globally.
58492_16_ITEM1_P24_S2	We will acquire the remaining 30% over the next five years, under the terms of the agreement, and have recorded a long-term liability of approximately $10 million for the future payments.
58492_16_ITEM1_P25_S0	Future payments are based upon a calculation that incorporates future EBITDA.
58492_16_ITEM1_P25_S1	The recorded liability is based upon estimates and may fluctuate significantly until the 2018 and 2020 payment dates.
58492_16_ITEM1_P25_S2	Fluctuations in this liability will be reflected in interest income or expense on the Consolidated Statement of Operations.
58492_16_ITEM1_P26_S0	We acquired Tempur Sealy's three U.S. innerspring component production facilities for a purchase price of $45 million.
58492_16_ITEM1_P26_S1	This additional volume enhanced our economies of scale, benefited from our vertical integration in steel rod and wire, and allowed manufacturing optimization across a broad asset base.
58492_16_ITEM1_P26_S2	These factors contributed to the recognition of $18 million in goodwill from this acquisition.
58492_16_ITEM1_P27_S0	We also acquired a German designer and distributor of high-end, European-styled motion components for a purchase price of $17 million.
58492_16_ITEM1_P27_S1	This business allows us to meet varying design preferences and broadens the range of our furniture component products, which contributed to the recognition of $4 million in goodwill from this acquisition.
58492_16_ITEM1_P28_S0	We expanded our Aerospace Products business unit with the acquisition of two companies.
58492_16_ITEM1_P29_S0	The first was a UK-based business that extended our capability in aerospace tube fabrication.
58492_16_ITEM1_P29_S1	This business was acquired for a purchase price of $12 million, and $6 million of goodwill was recorded related to this acquisition.
58492_16_ITEM1_P29_S2	Factors that contributed to a purchase price resulting in the recognition of goodwill included its international presence and complimentary fit with our Aerospace Products business unit.
58492_16_ITEM1_P30_S0	The second was a French company that added small-diameter, high-pressure seamless tubing to our product portfolio for a cash purchase price of $15 million.
58492_16_ITEM1_P30_S1	This business was acquired at a price less than fair value of the net identifiable assets, and we recorded a $9 million non-taxable bargain purchase gain.
58492_16_ITEM1_P30_S2	The bargain purchase gain is reported in the "Other (income) expense, net" line of our Consolidated Statements of Operations.
58492_16_ITEM1_P31_S0	For more information regarding our acquisitions and factors that contributed to the bargain purchase price referenced above, please refer to Note R on page 109 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.

58492_16_ITEM1_P32_S1	These divestitures were reported in discontinued operations.

58492_16_ITEM1_P34_S1	The business was reported in our Specialized Products segment and did not meet the requirements for discontinued operations.

58492_16_ITEM1_P63_S0	Many companies offer products that compete with those we manufacture and sell.
58492_16_ITEM1_P63_S1	The number of competing companies varies by product line, but many of the markets for our products are highly competitive.
58492_16_ITEM1_P63_S2	We tend to attract and retain customers through product quality, innovation, competitive pricing and customer service.
58492_16_ITEM1_P63_S3	Many of our competitors try to win business primarily on price but, depending upon the particular product, we experience competition based on quality and performance as well.
58492_16_ITEM1_P63_S4	In general, our competitors tend to be smaller, private companies.
58492_16_ITEM1_P64_S0	We believe we are the largest U.S. manufacturer, in terms of revenue, of the following:
58492_16_ITEM1_P65_S0	We continue to face pressure from foreign competitors as some of our customers source a portion of their components and finished products offshore.
58492_16_ITEM1_P65_S1	In addition to lower labor rates, foreign competitors benefit (at times) from lower raw material costs.
58492_16_ITEM1_P65_S2	They may also benefit from currency factors and more lenient regulatory climates.
58492_16_ITEM1_P66_S0	We typically remain price competitive, even versus many foreign manufacturers, as a result of our efficient operations, low labor content, vertical integration in steel and wire, logistics and distribution efficiencies, and large scale purchasing of raw materials and commodities.
58492_16_ITEM1_P66_S1	However, we have also reacted to foreign competition in certain cases by selectively adjusting prices, and by developing new proprietary products that help our customers reduce total costs.
58492_16_ITEM1_P67_S0	Since 2009, there have been antidumping duty orders on innerspring imports from China, South Africa and Vietnam, ranging from 116% to 234%.
58492_16_ITEM1_P67_S1	In March 2014, the Department of Commerce (DOC) and the International Trade Commission (ITC) determined that the duties should be continued.
58492_16_ITEM1_P67_S2	In April 2014, the DOC published its final order continuing the duties through February 2019 (for China) and December 2018 (for South Africa and Vietnam).
58492_16_ITEM1_P67_S3	Also, a case brought in January 2014 by major U.S. steel wire rod producers resulted in a ruling in December 2014, and the implementation of antidumping duties of 106% to 110% and countervailing duties of 178% to 193% on imports of Chinese steel wire rod through December 2019.
58492_16_ITEM1_P68_S0	Because of the documented evasion of antidumping orders by certain importers, typically shipping goods through third countries and falsely identifying the countries of origin, Leggett, along with several U.S. manufacturers have formed a coalition and are working with members of Congress, the DOC, and U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) to seek stronger enforcement of existing antidumping and/or countervailing duty orders.
58492_16_ITEM1_P68_S1	As a result of these efforts, the U.S. Congress has passed the Enforcing Orders and Reducing Customs Evasion (ENFORCE) Act.
58492_16_ITEM1_P68_S2	The ENFORCE Act requires CBP to implement a transparent, time-limited process to investigate allegations of duty evasion and to assess duties where appropriate.
58492_16_ITEM1_P69_S0	As a diversified manufacturer, we generally have not experienced significant seasonality.
58492_16_ITEM1_P69_S1	However, unusual economic factors in any given year, along with acquisitions and dispositions, can create sales variability and obscure the underlying seasonality of our businesses.
58492_16_ITEM1_P70_S0	Historically, for the Company as a whole, the second and third quarters typically have slightly higher sales, while the first and fourth quarters have generally been lower.
58492_16_ITEM1_P70_S1	Segment level seasonality has also been relatively limited, however the Residential Furnishings segment usually has lower sales in the fourth quarter and the Specialized Products segment typically experiences lower sales in the third quarter.
58492_16_ITEM1_P71_S0	Our customer relationships and our manufacturing and inventory practices do not create a material amount of backlog orders for any of our segments.
58492_16_ITEM1_P71_S1	Production and inventory levels are geared primarily to the level of incoming orders and projected demand based on customer relationships.

58492_16_ITEM1A_P0_S0	Investing in our securities involves risk.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P0_S1	Set forth below and elsewhere in this report are risk factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from the results contemplated by the forward-looking statements contained in this report.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P0_S2	We may amend or supplement these risk factors from time to time by other reports we file with the SEC.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Costs of raw materials could negatively affect our profit margins and earnings.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P2_S0	Raw material cost increases (and our ability to respond to cost increases through selling price increases) can significantly impact our earnings.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P2_S1	We typically have short-term commitments from our suppliers; therefore, our raw material costs generally move with the market.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P2_S2	When we experience significant increases in raw material costs, we typically implement price increases to recover the higher costs.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P2_S3	Inability to recover cost increases (or a delay in the recovery time) can negatively impact our earnings.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P2_S4	Conversely, if raw material costs decrease, we generally pass through reduced selling prices to our customers.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P2_S5	Reduced selling prices combined with higher cost inventory can reduce our segment margins and earnings.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P3_S0	Steel is our principal raw material.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P3_S1	The global steel markets are cyclical in nature and have been volatile in recent years.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P3_S2	This volatility can result in large swings in pricing and margins from year to year.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P3_S3	Our operations can also be impacted by changes in the cost of fabrics and foam scrap.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P3_S4	We experienced significant fluctuations in the cost of these commodities in recent years.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P4_S0	As a producer of steel rod, we are also impacted by volatility in metal margins (the difference between the cost of steel scrap and the market price for steel rod).
58492_16_ITEM1A_P4_S1	If market conditions cause scrap costs and rod pricing to change at different rates (both in terms of timing and amount), metal margins could be compressed and this would negatively impact our results of operations.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P5_S0	Higher raw material costs in past years led some of our customers to modify their product designs, changing the quantity and mix of our components in their finished goods.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P5_S1	In some cases, higher cost components were replaced with lower cost components.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P5_S2	This primarily impacted our Residential Furnishings and Industrial Materials product mix and decreased profit margins.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P5_S3	If this was to occur again it could negatively impact our results of operations.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P6_S0	Competition could adversely affect our market share, sales, profit margins and earnings.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P7_S0	We operate in markets that are highly competitive.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P7_S1	We believe that most companies in our lines of business compete primarily on price, but, depending upon the particular product, we experience competition based on quality and performance.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P7_S2	We face ongoing pressure from foreign competitors as some of our customers source a portion of their components and finished products from Asia and Europe.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P7_S3	In addition to lower labor rates, foreign competitors benefit (at times) from lower raw material costs.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P7_S4	They may also benefit from currency factors and more lenient regulatory climates.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P8_S0	If we are unable to purchase key raw materials, such as steel, at prices competitive with those of foreign suppliers, our ability to maintain market share and profit margins could be harmed by foreign competitors.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P9_S0	We are exposed to litigation contingencies that, if realized, could have a material negative impact on our financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P9_S1	We previously disclosed that we were a party to a series of civil antitrust lawsuits involving the sale of polyurethane foam products.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P9_S2	During 2015, we settled the substantial majority of these cases but there are a few cases yet to be resolved.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P9_S3	Although we deny liability in all threatened or pending litigation proceedings and believe that we have valid bases to contest all claims made against us, we have, at December 31, 2015, an aggregate litigation contingency accrual of $8 million.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P9_S4	The accrual amount decreased from the prior year primarily due to cash payments for litigation settlements of $82 million.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P9_S5	Based on current facts and circumstances, aggregate reasonably possible (but not probable) losses in excess of the recorded accruals for litigation contingencies (which include Brazilian VAT, antitrust, patent, and other matters) are estimated to be $25 million.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P9_S6	If our assumptions or analysis regarding these contingencies is incorrect, or if facts and circumstances change, we could realize loss in excess of the recorded accruals (and in excess of the $25 million referenced above) which could have a material negative impact on our financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P9_S7	For more information regarding our legal contingencies, see Note T on page 114 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P10_S0	We are exposed to foreign currency risk which may negatively impact our competitiveness, profit margins and earnings.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P11_S0	We expect that international sales will continue to represent a significant percentage of our total sales, which exposes us to currency exchange rate fluctuations.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P11_S1	In 2015, 31% of our sales were generated by international operations.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P11_S2	The revenues and expenses of our foreign operations are generally denominated in local currencies; however, certain of our operations experience currency-related gains and losses where sales or purchases are denominated in currencies other than their local currency.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P11_S3	Further, our competitive position may be affected by the relative strength of the currencies in countries where our products are sold.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P11_S4	Foreign currency exchange risks inherent in doing business in foreign countries may have a material adverse effect on our future operations and financial results.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P12_S0	Our goodwill and other long-lived assets are subject to potential impairment which could negatively impact our earnings.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P13_S0	A significant portion of our assets consists of goodwill and other long-lived assets, the carrying value of which may be reduced if we determine that those assets are impaired.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P13_S1	At December 31, 2015, goodwill and other intangible assets represented $998 million, or 34% of our total assets.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P13_S2	In addition, net property, plant and equipment and sundry assets totaled $658 million, or 22% of total assets.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P14_S0	If actual results differ from the assumptions and estimates used in the goodwill and long-lived asset valuation calculations, we could incur impairment charges, which could negatively impact our earnings.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P15_S0	We review our reporting units for potential goodwill impairment in June as part of our annual goodwill impairment testing, and more often if an event or circumstance occurs making it likely that impairment exists.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P15_S1	In addition, we test for the recoverability of long-lived assets at year end, and more often if an event or circumstance indicates the carrying value may not be recoverable.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P15_S2	We conduct impairment testing based on our current business strategy in light of present industry and economic conditions, as well as future expectations.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P15_S3	If we are not able to achieve projected performance levels, future impairments could be possible, which would negatively impact our earnings.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P16_S0	For more information regarding potential goodwill and other long-lived asset impairment, refer to Note C on page 79 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P17_S0	Technology failures or cyber security breaches could have a material adverse effect on our operations.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P18_S0	We rely on information systems to obtain, process, analyze and manage data, as well as to facilitate the manufacture and distribution of inventory to and from our facilities.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P18_S1	We receive, process and ship orders, manage the billing of, and collections from, our customers, and manage the accounting for, and payment to, our vendors.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P18_S2	We expect to transition certain corporate-level shared service systems primarily related to our domestic U.S. operations for general ledger, sales invoicing, cash application, purchasing and accounts payable disbursements to a new platform during the last half of 2016 and the first half of 2017.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P19_S0	Technology failures or security breaches of a new or existing infrastructure could create system disruptions or unauthorized disclosure of confidential information.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P19_S1	If this occurs, our operations could be disrupted, or we may suffer financial loss because of lost or misappropriated information.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P19_S2	We cannot be certain that advances in criminal capabilities or new discoveries in the field of cryptography will not compromise our technology protecting information systems.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P19_S3	If these systems are interrupted or damaged by these events or fail for any extended period of time, then our results of operations could be adversely affected.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P20_S0	We may not be able to realize deferred tax assets on our balance sheet depending upon the amount and source of future taxable income.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P21_S0	Our ability to realize deferred tax assets on our balance sheet is dependent upon the amount and source of future taxable income.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P21_S1	Economic uncertainty or tax law changes could impact our underlying assumptions on which valuation reserves are established and negatively affect future period earnings and balance sheets.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P22_S0	We have exposure to economic and other factors that affect market demand for our products which may negatively impact our sales, operating cash flow and earnings.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P23_S0	As a supplier of products to a variety of industries, we are adversely affected by general economic downturns.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P23_S1	Our operating performance is heavily influenced by market demand for our components and products.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P23_S2	Market demand for the majority of our products is most heavily influenced by consumer confidence.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P23_S3	To a lesser extent, market demand is impacted by other broad economic factors, including disposable income levels, employment levels, housing turnover and interest rates.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P23_S4	All of these factors influence consumer spending on durable goods, and drive demand for our components and products.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P23_S5	Some of these factors also influence business spending on facilities and equipment, which impacts approximately one-quarter of our sales.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P24_S0	Demand weakness in our markets can lead to lower unit orders, sales and earnings in our businesses.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P25_S0	Several factors, including a weak global economy, low consumer confidence, or a depressed housing market could contribute to conservative spending habits by consumers around the world.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P26_S0	Short lead times in most of our markets allow for limited visibility into demand trends.
58492_16_ITEM1A_P26_S1	If economic and market conditions deteriorate, we may experience material negative impacts on our business, financial condition, operating cash flows and results of operations.
58492_16_ITEM2_P0_S0	The Company s corporate office is located in Carthage, Missouri.
58492_16_ITEM2_P0_S1	We currently have 130 manufacturing locations, of which 81 are located across the United States and 49 are located in 18 foreign countries.
58492_16_ITEM2_P0_S2	We also have various sales, warehouse and administrative facilities.
58492_16_ITEM2_P0_S3	However, our manufacturing plants are our most important properties.
58492_16_ITEM2_P1_S0	For more information regarding the geographic location of our manufacturing facilities refer to "Geographic Areas of Operation" under Item 1 Business on page 11.
58492_16_ITEM2_P2_S0	In 2015, seventy-one percent of the Company's net sales allocated to the 130 manufacturing facilities was produced by owned facilities.
58492_16_ITEM2_P2_S1	We also lease many of our manufacturing, warehouse and other facilities on terms that vary by lease (including purchase options, renewals and maintenance costs).
58492_16_ITEM2_P2_S2	For additional information regarding lease obligations, see Note K on page 92 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
58492_16_ITEM2_P3_S0	Of our 130 manufacturing facilities, none are subject to liens or encumbrances that are material to the segment in which they are reported or to the Company as a whole.
58492_16_ITEM2_P4_S0	None of our physical properties are, by themselves, material to the Company s overall manufacturing processes, except for our steel rod mill in Sterling, Illinois, which is reported in Industrial Materials.
58492_16_ITEM2_P4_S1	The rod mill consists of approximately 1 million square feet of production space and has annual output of approximately 500,000 tons of steel rod, of which a substantial majority is used by our own wire mills.
58492_16_ITEM2_P4_S2	Although we have alternative sources of steel rod from external sources, a prolonged disruption to the operation of the rod mill could have a material adverse effect on the Industrial Materials segment and the Company s results of operations.
58492_16_ITEM2_P5_S0	In the opinion of management, the Company s owned and leased facilities are suitable and adequate for the manufacture, assembly and distribution of our products.
58492_16_ITEM2_P5_S1	Our properties are located to allow quick and efficient delivery of products and services to our diverse customer base.
58492_16_ITEM2_P5_S2	Our productive capacity, in general, continues to exceed current operating levels.
58492_16_ITEM2_P5_S3	However, utilization has increased in many of our businesses with improving market demand, and we are investing to support rapid growth in a few of our businesses, including Automotive, U.S. Spring, European Spring and Adjustable Bed.
58492_16_ITEM3_P0_S0	The information in Note T beginning on page 114 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements is incorporated into this section by reference.
58492_16_ITEM3_P1_S0	On October 17, 2008, the Company, along with Carpenter Co., Flexible Foam Products, Inc., Foam Supplies, Inc., Hickory Springs Manufacturing Company, J.M. Huber Corporation, Lubrizol Advanced Materials, Inc., The Sherwin-Williams Company, Skypark Manufacturing, LLC, Vitafoam Incorporated; and their respective affiliates, as plaintiffs, filed a complaint in the United States District Court for the District of New Jersey under the caption Carpenter Co., et al. v. BASF SE, et al., Case No. 2:08-cv-05169 against BASF Corporation, The Dow Chemical Company, Huntsman International LLC, Lyondell Chemical Company, and their affiliates, alleging that defendants conspired to fix prices and allocate customers and markets for certain urethane chemical products.
58492_16_ITEM3_P1_S1	The Company previously settled its claims against certain defendants for immaterial amounts and all other defendants have been dismissed except for The Dow Chemical Company.
58492_16_ITEM3_P2_S0	The Company, along with co-plaintiffs, seeks to recover three times the amount of damages suffered as a result of the alleged overcharges in the price of the urethane chemical products purchased from the defendant from at least 1994 through at least 2004.
58492_16_ITEM3_P2_S1	The plaintiffs also seek attorney fees, pre-judgment interest and injunctive relief.
58492_16_ITEM3_P2_S2	Based on the maturation of the proceeding, discovery becoming substantially complete, and the scheduled trial date of March 7, 2016, the Company now believes that it is reasonably likely that it may recover material damages from the defendant.
58492_16_ITEM3_P2_S3	However, because of uncertainties, the Company cannot estimate the amount of recovery.
58492_16_ITEM3_P2_S4	Also, because of these uncertainties, it is possible that the Company may recover only an immaterial amount of the alleged damages, or recover no damages at all.
58492_16_ITEM3_P3_S0	On March 27, 2013, Region 5 of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) issued a Notice of Violation/Finding of Violation ("NOV/FOV") alleging that our subsidiary, Sterling Steel Company, violated the Clean Air Act and the Illinois State Implementation Plan currently in place.
58492_16_ITEM3_P4_S0	Sterling operates a steel rod mill in Sterling, Illinois.
58492_16_ITEM3_P4_S1	The NOV/FOV alleges that Sterling, since 2008, has exceeded the allowable annual particulate matter and manganese emission limits for its electric arc furnace.
58492_16_ITEM3_P4_S2	Sterling requested a conference with the EPA to discuss the alleged violations.
58492_16_ITEM3_P4_S3	The conference was held on May 20, 2013.
58492_16_ITEM3_P5_S0	On July 23, 2013, the EPA issued a Finding of Violation alleging that Sterling violated the opacity limitations of its air permit and Federal and state regulations.
58492_16_ITEM3_P5_S1	A conference to discuss the Finding of Violation occurred in the third quarter of 2013.
58492_16_ITEM3_P6_S0	There had been no material updates with respect to these matters until mid-July 2015 when the Company learned from counsel for the EPA that the matters had been referred to the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ).
58492_16_ITEM3_P6_S1	The Company met with representatives of the DOJ on February 2, 2016.
58492_16_ITEM3_P6_S2	At the meeting, the DOJ focused on Sterling s compliance with capture and control efficiency and fugitive emissions with its electric arc furnace.
58492_16_ITEM3_P6_S3	Sterling intends to vigorously defend these matters in any enforcement action that may be pursued by the EPA or DOJ.
58492_16_ITEM3_P6_S4	Neither the EPA nor DOJ specified any amount of penalty or injunctive relief being sought in the NOV/FOV, Finding of Violation or in any conference or meeting.
58492_16_ITEM3_P6_S5	Any settlement or adverse finding could result in the payment by Sterling of fines, penalties, capital expenditures, or some combination thereof.
58492_16_ITEM3_P6_S6	Although the outcome of these matters cannot be predicted with certainty, we do not expect them, either individually or in the aggregate, to have a material adverse effect on our financial position, cash flows or results of operations.

58492_16_ITEM7_P0_S0	Earnings from continuing operations increased significantly (versus 2014) reflecting several factors, including the benefit from higher sales, pricing discipline, and lower foam litigation expense.
58492_16_ITEM7_P1_S0	Sales from continuing operations also grew in 2015, with higher unit volume and acquisitions partially offset by raw material-related price deflation and currency impact.
58492_16_ITEM7_P1_S1	Nearly all of our businesses experienced unit volume growth during the year, from a combination of new program awards, market share gains, and broadly improving end market demand.
58492_16_ITEM7_P2_S0	A major component of our strategy since 2007 has been the optimization of our portfolio of businesses, by increasing investment in businesses that possess strong competitive advantage and reducing our exposure to businesses and markets that are less attractive.
58492_16_ITEM7_P2_S1	In 2015, we made further progress on both fronts.
58492_16_ITEM7_P2_S2	During the year, we expanded our operations to support continued growth of our Automotive business, invested in machinery to support the growing demand for ComfortCore innersprings, and added three new facilities to support growth in our Adjustable Bed business.
58492_16_ITEM7_P2_S3	We also acquired, in our Work Furniture business, a European private-label manufacturer of high-end upholstered furniture for office, commercial, and other settings.
58492_16_ITEM7_P2_S4	Additionally, in 2015, we completed the divestitures of several small operations including our Steel Tubing business, the two remaining Store Fixtures operations, and a small part of the Commercial Vehicle Products business.
58492_16_ITEM7_P3_S0	Operating cash decreased versus 2014 levels, primarily due to payments made to settle foam litigation.
58492_16_ITEM7_P3_S1	However, we once again generated more than enough cash from operations to comfortably fund dividends and capital expenditures, something we've accomplished for over 25 years.
58492_16_ITEM7_P4_S0	2015 marked the 44th consecutive annual dividend increase for the company, with a compound annual growth rate of 13% over that time period.
58492_16_ITEM7_P4_S1	Only one other S P 500 company can claim as high a rate of dividend growth for as many years.
58492_16_ITEM7_P5_S0	We ended 2015 with net debt to net capital comfortably within our long-standing targeted range of 30-40%.
58492_16_ITEM7_P5_S1	In August, we repaid $200 million of notes that matured.
58492_16_ITEM7_P5_S2	We ended the year with over $400 million available under our commercial paper program.
58492_16_ITEM7_P6_S0	We assess our overall performance by comparing our Total Shareholder Return (TSR) to that of peer companies on a rolling three-year basis.
58492_16_ITEM7_P6_S1	We target TSR in the top third of the S P 500 over the long term.
58492_16_ITEM7_P6_S2	For the three years ended December 31, 2015, we generated TSR of 20% per year on average.
58492_16_ITEM7_P6_S3	That placed us in the top third of the S P 500, meeting our long-term goal.
58492_16_ITEM7_P7_S0	These topics are discussed in more detail in the sections that follow.
58492_16_ITEM7_P8_S0	Total Shareholder Return (TSR), relative to peer companies, is the key financial measure that we use to assess long-term performance.
58492_16_ITEM7_P8_S1	TSR is driven by the change in our share price and the dividends we pay [TSR = (Change in Stock Price + Dividends) / Beginning Stock Price].
58492_16_ITEM7_P8_S2	We seek to achieve TSR in the top third of the S P 500 over the long-term through a balanced approach that employs four TSR drivers: revenue growth, margin expansion, dividends, and share repurchases.
58492_16_ITEM7_P9_S0	We monitor our TSR performance (relative to the S P 500) on a rolling three-year basis.
58492_16_ITEM7_P9_S1	For the three-year measurement period that ended December 31, 2015, we met our top third TSR goal.
58492_16_ITEM7_P9_S2	We generated TSR of 20% per year on average over the last three years, well above the S P 500's 15% annual TSR for that same time period.
58492_16_ITEM7_P10_S0	We serve a broad suite of customers, with our largest customer representing approximately 8% of our sales.
58492_16_ITEM7_P10_S1	Many are companies whose names are widely recognized.
58492_16_ITEM7_P10_S2	They include most producers of residential furniture and bedding, auto and office seating manufacturers, and a variety of other companies.
58492_16_ITEM7_P11_S0	Many factors impact our business, but those that generally have the greatest impact are market demand, raw material cost trends, and competition.
58492_16_ITEM7_P12_S0	Market demand (including product mix) is impacted by several economic factors, with consumer confidence being most significant.
58492_16_ITEM7_P12_S1	Other important factors include disposable income levels, employment levels, housing turnover, and interest rates.
58492_16_ITEM7_P12_S2	All of these factors influence consumer spending on durable goods, and therefore affect demand for our components and products.
58492_16_ITEM7_P12_S3	Some of these factors also influence business spending on facilities and equipment, which impacts approximately one-quarter of our sales.
58492_16_ITEM7_P13_S0	In many of our businesses, we enjoy a cost advantage from being vertically integrated into steel wire and rod.
58492_16_ITEM7_P13_S1	This is a benefit that our competitors do not have.
58492_16_ITEM7_P13_S2	We also experience favorable purchasing leverage from buying large quantities of raw materials.
58492_16_ITEM7_P13_S3	Still, our costs can vary significantly as market prices for raw materials (many of which are commodities) fluctuate.
58492_16_ITEM7_P14_S0	We typically have short-term commitments from our suppliers; accordingly, our raw material costs generally move with the market.
58492_16_ITEM7_P14_S1	Our ability to recover higher costs (through selling price increases) is crucial.
58492_16_ITEM7_P14_S2	When we experience significant increases in raw material costs, we typically implement price increases to recover the higher costs.
58492_16_ITEM7_P14_S3	Conversely, when costs decrease significantly, we generally pass those lower costs through to our customers.
58492_16_ITEM7_P14_S4	The timing of our price increases or decreases is important; we typically experience a lag in recovering higher costs and we also realize a lag as costs decline, as was the case in the last half of 2015.
58492_16_ITEM7_P15_S0	Steel is our principal raw material.
58492_16_ITEM7_P15_S1	At various times in past years we have experienced significant cost fluctuations in this commodity.
58492_16_ITEM7_P15_S2	In most cases, the major changes (both increases and decreases) were passed through to customers with selling price adjustments.
58492_16_ITEM7_P16_S0	Throughout 2015, market prices for steel scrap, rod, and flat-rolled products decreased significantly, leading to downward pressure on selling prices.
58492_16_ITEM7_P17_S0	pricing lag during the year, as costs generally decreased at a faster rate than selling prices.
58492_16_ITEM7_P17_S1	Assuming that steel costs stabilize, we expect that 2015's pricing lag benefit will not recur in 2016.
58492_16_ITEM7_P18_S0	As a producer of steel rod, we are also impacted by changes in metal margins (the difference between the cost of steel scrap and the market price for steel rod).
58492_16_ITEM7_P18_S1	Metal margins within the steel industry have been volatile during certain periods in recent years.
58492_16_ITEM7_P18_S2	In late 2013 and early 2014, metal margins decreased significantly as market conditions did not allow full recovery of higher scrap costs.
58492_16_ITEM7_P18_S3	An antidumping and countervailing duty case filed in January 2014 by major U.S. steel wire rod producers was concluded in December 2014, resulting in the implementation of duties on imports of Chinese steel wire rod.
58492_16_ITEM7_P18_S4	The antidumping duties range from 106% to 110% and the countervailing duties range from 178% to 193%.
58492_16_ITEM7_P18_S5	Both remain in effect through December 2019.
58492_16_ITEM7_P19_S0	Our other raw materials include woven and non-woven fabrics, foam scrap, and chemicals.
58492_16_ITEM7_P19_S1	We have experienced changes in the cost of these materials in recent years, and in most years, have been able to pass them through to our customers.
58492_16_ITEM7_P20_S0	When we raise our prices to recover higher raw material costs, this sometimes causes customers to modify their product designs and replace higher cost components with lower cost components.
58492_16_ITEM7_P20_S1	We must continue providing product options to our customers that enable them to improve the functionality and manage the cost of their products, while providing higher margin and profit contribution for our operations.
58492_16_ITEM7_P21_S0	Many of our markets are highly competitive, with the number of competitors varying by product line.
58492_16_ITEM7_P21_S1	In general, our competitors tend to be smaller, private companies.
58492_16_ITEM7_P21_S2	Many of our competitors, both domestic and foreign, compete primarily on the basis of price.
58492_16_ITEM7_P21_S3	Our success has stemmed from the ability to remain price competitive, while delivering better product quality, innovation, and customer service.
58492_16_ITEM7_P22_S0	We continue to face pressure from foreign competitors as some of our customers source a portion of their components and finished products offshore.
58492_16_ITEM7_P22_S1	In addition to lower labor rates, foreign competitors benefit (at times) from lower raw material costs.
58492_16_ITEM7_P22_S2	They may also benefit from currency factors and more lenient regulatory climates.
58492_16_ITEM7_P23_S0	We typically remain price competitive, even versus many foreign manufacturers, as a result of our highly efficient operations, low labor content, vertical integration in steel and wire, logistics and distribution efficiencies, and large scale purchasing of raw materials and commodities.
58492_16_ITEM7_P23_S1	However, we have also reacted to foreign competition in certain cases by selectively adjusting prices, and by developing new proprietary products that help our customers reduce total costs.
58492_16_ITEM7_P24_S0	Since 2009, there have been antidumping duty orders on innerspring imports from China, South Africa and Vietnam, ranging from 116% to 234%.
58492_16_ITEM7_P24_S1	In March 2014, the Department of Commerce (DOC) and the International Trade Commission (ITC) determined that the duties should be continued.
58492_16_ITEM7_P24_S2	In April 2014, the DOC published its final order continuing the duties through February 2019 (for China) and December 2018 (for South Africa and Vietnam).
58492_16_ITEM7_P25_S0	Because of the documented evasion of antidumping orders by certain importers, typically shipping goods through third countries and falsely identifying the countries of origin, Leggett, along with several U.S. manufacturers have formed a coalition and are working with members of Congress, the DOC, and U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) to seek stronger enforcement of existing antidumping and/or countervailing duty orders.
58492_16_ITEM7_P25_S1	As a result of these efforts, the U.S. Congress passed the Enforcing Orders and Reducing Customs Evasion (ENFORCE) Act.
58492_16_ITEM7_P25_S2	The ENFORCE Act requires CBP to implement a transparent, time-limited process to investigate allegations of duty evasion and to assess duties where appropriate.
58492_16_ITEM7_P26_S0	We previously disclosed that we were one of several defendants in a series of civil antitrust lawsuits involving the sale of polyurethane foam.
58492_16_ITEM7_P26_S1	During 2015, we settled the substantial majority of these cases.
58492_16_ITEM7_P26_S2	Although there are a few cases yet to be resolved, based upon current facts, we do not believe that the outcome of these remaining cases will have a material effect on our consolidated financial position, results of operations, or cash flow.
58492_16_ITEM7_P27_S0	Although we deny liability in all threatened or pending litigation proceedings and believe that we have valid bases to contest all claims made against us, we have an aggregate litigation contingency accrual of $8 million.
58492_16_ITEM7_P27_S1	The accrual amount decreased from the prior year primarily due to cash payments for litigation settlements of $82 million.
58492_16_ITEM7_P27_S2	Based upon current facts and circumstances, aggregate reasonably possible (but not probable) losses in excess of the recorded accruals for litigation contingencies are estimated to be $25 million.
58492_16_ITEM7_P27_S3	These include Brazilian VAT, antitrust, patent, and other matters.
58492_16_ITEM7_P27_S4	For more information regarding litigation contingency accruals and reasonably possible losses in excess of accruals, see Note T to the Consolidated Financial Statements on page 114.
58492_16_ITEM7_P28_S0	We are also a plaintiff in an antitrust case against The Dow Chemical Company.
58492_16_ITEM7_P28_S1	We, along with other plaintiffs, have alleged that several defendants conspired to fix prices and allocate customers and markets for certain urethane chemical products.
58492_16_ITEM7_P28_S2	The trial is scheduled to begin on March 7, 2016.
58492_16_ITEM7_P29_S0	We believe that it is reasonably likely that we may recover material damages.
58492_16_ITEM7_P29_S1	However, because of uncertainties we cannot estimate the amount of recovery, and it is possible that we won't recover any damages at all.
58492_16_ITEM7_P29_S2	For more information regarding our antitrust litigation, see Note T to the Consolidated Financial Statements on page 114.

58492_16_ITEM7_P100_S0	Under LIFO accounting, the most recent raw material purchases are assumed to be the first consumed in production.
58492_16_ITEM7_P100_S1	Significant steel price deflation resulted in a significant decrease in our LIFO reserves, particularly in the fourth quarter, making comparability to prior quarter's DIO difficult.

58492_16_ITEM7_P137_S0	We prepare our consolidated financial statements in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
58492_16_ITEM7_P137_S1	To do so, we must make estimates and judgments that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues, expenses, and disclosures.
58492_16_ITEM7_P137_S2	If we used different estimates or judgments our financial statements would change, and some of those changes could be significant.
58492_16_ITEM7_P137_S3	Our estimates are frequently based upon historical experience and are considered by management, at the time they are made, to be reasonable and appropriate.
58492_16_ITEM7_P138_S0	Estimates are adjusted for actual events, as they occur.
58492_16_ITEM7_P139_S0	Critical accounting estimates are those that are: a) subject to uncertainty and change, and b) of material impact to our financial statements.
58492_16_ITEM7_P139_S1	Listed below are the estimates and judgments which we believe could have the most significant effect on our financial statements.
58492_16_ITEM7_P140_S0	We provide additional details regarding our significant accounting policies in Note A to the Consolidated Financial Statements on page 72.
58492_16_ITEM7_P141_S0	Goodwill is assessed for impairment annually as of June 30 and as triggering events occur.

58492_16_ITEM7_P145_S0	In order to assess goodwill for potential impairment, judgment is required to estimate the fair market value of each reporting unit (which is one level below reportable segments) using the combination of a discounted cash flow model and a market approach using price to earnings ratios for comparable publicly traded companies with characteristics similar to the reporting unit.
58492_16_ITEM7_P146_S0	The cash flow model contains uncertainties related to the forecast of future results as many outside economic and competitive factors can influence future performance.
58492_16_ITEM7_P146_S1	Margins, sales growth, and discount rates are the most critical estimates in determining enterprise values using the cash flow model.
58492_16_ITEM7_P147_S0	The market approach requires judgment to determine the appropriate price to earnings ratio.
58492_16_ITEM7_P148_S0	Ratios are derived from comparable publicly-traded companies that operate in the same or similar industry as the reporting unit.
58492_16_ITEM7_P149_S0	The second quarter 2015 goodwill impairment review indicated no impairments, with all reporting units having fair values that exceed carrying value by more than 50%.

58492_16_ITEM7_P150_S2	If we are not able to meet projected performance levels, future impairments could be possible.
58492_16_ITEM7_P150_S3	Information regarding material assumptions used to determine if a goodwill impairment exists can be found in Note C to the Consolidated Financial Statements on page 79.
58492_16_ITEM7_P151_S0	Other long-lived assets are tested for recoverability at year-end and whenever events or circumstances indicate the carrying value may not be recoverable.
58492_16_ITEM7_P152_S0	For other long-lived assets we estimate fair value at the lowest level where cash flows can be measured (usually at a branch level).
58492_16_ITEM7_P153_S0	Impairments of other long-lived assets usually occur when major restructuring activities take place, or we decide to discontinue product lines completely.
58492_16_ITEM7_P154_S0	Our impairment assessments have uncertainties because they require estimates of future cash flows to determine if undiscounted cash flows are sufficient to recover carrying values of these assets.
58492_16_ITEM7_P155_S0	For assets where future cash flows are not expected to recover carrying value, fair value is estimated which requires an estimate of market value based upon asset appraisals for like assets.
58492_16_ITEM7_P156_S0	Impairments were $2 million in 2015, $1 million in 2014 and $2 million in 2013.
58492_16_ITEM7_P157_S0	We reduce the carrying value of inventories to reflect an estimate of net realizable value for obsolete and slow-moving inventory.
58492_16_ITEM7_P158_S0	We value inventory at net realizable value (what we think we will recover).
58492_16_ITEM7_P158_S1	Generally a reserve is not required unless we have more than a one-year's supply of the product.
58492_16_ITEM7_P158_S2	If we have had no sales of a given product for 12 months, those items are generally deemed to have no value and are written down completely.
58492_16_ITEM7_P159_S0	Our inventory reserve contains uncertainties because the calculation requires management to make assumptions about the value of products that are obsolete or slow-moving (i.e., not selling very quickly).
58492_16_ITEM7_P160_S0	Changes in customer behavior and requirements can cause inventory to quickly become obsolete or slow moving.
58492_16_ITEM7_P161_S0	The calculation also uses an estimate of the ultimate recoverability of items identified as slow moving based upon historical experience (65% on average).
58492_16_ITEM7_P162_S0	At December 31, 2015, the reserve for obsolete and slow-moving inventory was $33 million (approximately 6% of FIFO inventories).
58492_16_ITEM7_P162_S1	This is consistent with the December 31, 2014 and 2013 reserves of $30 million and $36 million, respectively, representing 6% of FIFO inventories.
58492_16_ITEM7_P163_S0	Additions to inventory reserves in 2015 were $10 million, which were comparable to the previous year.
58492_16_ITEM7_P163_S1	We do not expect obsolescence to change from current levels.
58492_16_ITEM7_P164_S0	We are substantially self-insured for costs related to workers compensation, and this requires us to estimate the liability associated with this obligation.
58492_16_ITEM7_P165_S0	Our estimates of self-insured reserves contain uncertainties regarding the potential amounts we might have to pay (since we are self-insured).
58492_16_ITEM7_P165_S1	We consider a number of factors, including historical claim experience, demographic factors, and potential recoveries from third party insurance carriers.
58492_16_ITEM7_P166_S0	Over the past five years, we have incurred, on average, $9 million annually for costs associated with workers compensation.
58492_16_ITEM7_P166_S1	Average year-to-year variation over the past five years has been approximately $1 million.
58492_16_ITEM7_P166_S2	At December 31, 2015, we had accrued $35 million to cover future self-insurance liabilities.
58492_16_ITEM7_P167_S0	Internal safety statistics and cost trends have improved in the last several years and are expected to remain at current lower levels for the foreseeable future.
58492_16_ITEM7_P168_S0	For accounts and notes receivable, we estimate a bad debt reserve for the amount that will ultimately be uncollectible.
58492_16_ITEM7_P169_S0	When we become aware of a specific customer s potential inability to pay, we record a bad debt reserve for the amount we believe may not be collectible.
58492_16_ITEM7_P170_S0	Our bad debt reserve contains uncertainties because it requires management to estimate the amount uncollectible based upon an evaluation of several factors such as the length of time that receivables are past due, the financial health of the customer, industry and macroeconomic considerations, and historical loss experience.
58492_16_ITEM7_P171_S0	Our customers are diverse and many are small-to-medium sized companies, with some being highly leveraged.
58492_16_ITEM7_P171_S1	Bankruptcy can occur with some of these customers relatively quickly and with little warning.
58492_16_ITEM7_P172_S0	A significant change in the financial status of a large customer could impact our estimates.
58492_16_ITEM7_P173_S0	The average annual amount of customer-related bad debt expense was $5 million (significantly less than 1% of annual net sales) over the last three years.
58492_16_ITEM7_P173_S1	At December 31, 2015, our reserves for doubtful accounts totaled $10 million (about 2% of our accounts and customer-related notes receivable of $459 million).
58492_16_ITEM7_P174_S0	We have not experienced any significant individual customer bankruptcies in the past three years.
58492_16_ITEM7_P174_S1	We believe the financial health of our major customers has modestly improved, but some are highly leveraged, and this could cause circumstances to change in the future.
58492_16_ITEM7_P175_S0	At December 31, 2015, we had less than $1 million of non-customer notes receivable.
58492_16_ITEM7_P176_S0	For our pension plans, we must estimate the cost of benefits to be provided (well into the future) and the current value of those benefit obligations.
58492_16_ITEM7_P177_S0	The pension liability calculation contains uncertainties because it requires management to estimate an appropriate discount rate to calculate the present value of future benefits paid, which also impacts current year pension expense.
58492_16_ITEM7_P178_S0	Determination of pension expense requires an estimate of expected return on pension assets based upon the mix of investments held (bonds and equities).
58492_16_ITEM7_P178_S1	Other assumptions include rates of compensation increases, withdrawal and mortality rates, and retirement ages.
58492_16_ITEM7_P178_S2	These estimates impact the pension expense or income we recognize and our reported benefit obligations.
58492_16_ITEM7_P179_S0	Each 25 basis point decrease in the discount rate increases pension expense by $.5 million and increases the plans benefit obligation by $9 million.
58492_16_ITEM7_P179_S1	A 25 basis point reduction in the expected return on assets would increase pension expense by $.4 million, but have no effect on the plans funded status.
58492_16_ITEM7_P180_S0	Assuming a long-term investment horizon, we do not expect a material change to the return on asset assumption.
58492_16_ITEM7_P181_S0	Mortality assumptions represent our best estimate of the duration of future benefit payments at the measurement date.
58492_16_ITEM7_P181_S1	These estimates are based on each plans' demographics and other relevant facts and circumstances.
58492_16_ITEM7_P181_S2	Longer life expectancies increased our pension liability for our most significant plans by approximately $20 million in 2014.
58492_16_ITEM7_P182_S0	We evaluate various legal, environmental, and other potential claims against us to determine if an accrual or disclosure of the contingency is appropriate.
58492_16_ITEM7_P182_S1	If it is probable that an ultimate loss will be incurred, we accrue a liability for the reasonable estimate of the ultimate loss.
58492_16_ITEM7_P183_S0	Our disclosure and accrual of loss contingencies (i.e., losses that may or may not occur) contain uncertainties because they are based on our assessment of the likelihood that the expenses will actually occur, and our estimate of the likely cost.
58492_16_ITEM7_P183_S1	Our estimates and judgments are subjective and can involve matters in litigation, the results of which are generally unpredictable.
58492_16_ITEM7_P184_S0	Legal contingencies are related to numerous lawsuits and claims described in Note T to the Consolidated Financial Statements on page 114.
58492_16_ITEM7_P184_S1	With the exception of 2014, our largest annual cost for litigation claims was $6 million for the five years ending December 31, 2015 (excluding legal fees).
58492_16_ITEM7_P185_S0	During 2014, we recorded expense of $92 million ($57 million for continuing operations and $35 million in discontinued operations) for various proceedings and other claims.
58492_16_ITEM7_P185_S1	By far the largest portion of these accruals was associated with a series of antitrust lawsuits involving the sale of polyurethane foam as discussed in Note T to the Consolidated Financial Statements on page 114.
58492_16_ITEM7_P185_S2	During 2015, we settled the substantial majority of these cases.
58492_16_ITEM7_P186_S0	In the ordinary course of business, we must make estimates of the tax treatment of many transactions, even though the ultimate tax outcome may remain uncertain for some time.
58492_16_ITEM7_P186_S1	These estimates become part of the annual income tax expense reported in our financial statements.
58492_16_ITEM7_P186_S2	Subsequent to year end, we finalize our tax analysis and file income tax returns.
58492_16_ITEM7_P186_S3	Tax authorities periodically audit these income tax returns and examine our tax filing positions, including (among other things) the timing and amounts of deductions, and the allocation of income among tax jurisdictions.
58492_16_ITEM7_P186_S4	If necessary, we adjust income tax expense in our financial statements in the periods in which the actual outcome becomes more certain.
58492_16_ITEM7_P187_S0	Our tax liability for unrecognized tax benefits contains uncertainties because management is required to make assumptions and to apply judgment to estimate the exposures related to our various filing positions.
58492_16_ITEM7_P188_S0	Our effective tax rate is also impacted by changes in tax laws, the current mix of earnings by taxing jurisdiction, and the results of current tax audits and assessments.
58492_16_ITEM7_P188_S1	At December 31, 2015 and 2014, we had $32 million and $34 million, respectively, of net deferred tax assets on our balance sheet related to net operating losses and other tax carryforwards.
58492_16_ITEM7_P188_S2	The ultimate realization of these deferred tax assets is dependent upon the amount, source, and timing of future taxable income.
58492_16_ITEM7_P188_S3	In cases where we believe it is more likely than not that we may not realize the future potential tax benefits, we establish a valuation allowance against them.
58492_16_ITEM7_P189_S0	In addition, assumptions have been made regarding the non-repatriation of earnings from certain subsidiaries.
58492_16_ITEM7_P189_S1	Those assumptions may change in the future, thereby affecting future period results for the tax impact of possible repatriation.
58492_16_ITEM7_P190_S0	Potential changes in tax laws could impact assumptions related to the non-repatriation of certain foreign earnings.
58492_16_ITEM7_P190_S1	If all non-repatriated earnings were taxed at current rates, we would incur additional taxes of approximately $107 million.
58492_16_ITEM7_P191_S0	Audits by various taxing authorities continue as governments look for ways to raise additional revenue.
58492_16_ITEM7_P191_S1	Based upon past audit experience, we do not expect any material changes to our tax liability as a result of this audit activity; however, we could incur additional tax expense if we have audit adjustments higher than recent historical experience.
58492_16_ITEM7_P192_S0	The likelihood of recovery of net operating losses and other tax carryforwards has been closely evaluated and is based upon such factors as the time remaining before expiration, viable tax planning strategies, and future taxable earnings expectations.
58492_16_ITEM7_P192_S1	We believe that appropriate valuation allowances have been recorded as necessary.
58492_16_ITEM7_P192_S2	However, if earnings expectations or other assumptions change such that additional valuation allowances are required, we could incur additional tax expense.
58492_16_ITEM7_P192_S3	Likewise, if fewer valuation allowances are needed, we could incur reduced tax expense.

58492_16_ITEM9A_P0_S0	An evaluation as of December 31, 2015, was carried out by the Company s management, with the participation of the Company s Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, of the effectiveness of the Company s disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Rule 13a-15(e) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended (the Exchange Act )).
58492_16_ITEM9A_P0_S1	Based upon this evaluation, the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer have concluded the Company s disclosure controls and procedures were effective, as of December 31, 2015, to provide assurance that information required to be disclosed by the Company in the reports that it files or submits under the Exchange Act is recorded, processed, summarized, and reported, within the time periods specified by the Securities and Exchange Commission s rules and forms.
58492_16_ITEM9A_P0_S2	Disclosure controls and procedures, include without limitation, controls and procedures designed to ensure that information required to be disclosed by the Company in the reports that it files or submits under the Exchange Act is accumulated and communicated to the Company s management, including its Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, or persons performing similar functions, as appropriate to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure.
58492_16_ITEM9A_P1_S0	Management s Annual Report on Internal Control over Financial Reporting can be found on page 65, and the Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm regarding the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting can be found on page 66 of this Form 10-K. Each is incorporated by reference into this Item 9A.
58492_16_ITEM9A_P2_S0	During the fourth quarter of 2015, we completed the design to transition certain corporate-level shared service systems for general ledger, sales invoicing, cash application, accounts payable, purchasing and accounts payable disbursements to a new platform.
58492_16_ITEM9A_P2_S1	The new platform is expected to further automate and enhance a number of existing processes and activities primarily related to our domestic U.S. operations.
58492_16_ITEM9A_P2_S2	We anticipate total capital outlay for this activity to be approximately $20 million over three years, and expect the majority of the systems to be transitioned during the last half of 2016 and the first half of 2017.
58492_16_ITEM9A_P3_S0	These improvements are ongoing system processes and system enhancements and are not being made in response to any control deficiency or weakness.
58492_16_ITEM9A_P3_S1	Our internal control over financial reporting has been and, we expect, will continue to be, effective through this transition.
58492_16_ITEM9A_P3_S2	Implementation risk will be controlled through an on-going process of monitoring and evaluation to mitigate potential risk.
58492_16_ITEM9A_P3_S3	The system deployments will include fully evaluating and updating our internal control over financial reporting, as well as significant testing and training.

58492_16_ITEM10_P1_S0	Directors are normally elected annually at the Annual Meeting of Shareholders and hold office until the next annual meeting of shareholders or until their successors are elected and qualified.
58492_16_ITEM10_P1_S1	Except for Richard T. Fisher, all current directors have been nominated for re-election at the Company s Annual Meeting of Shareholders to be held May 17, 2016.
58492_16_ITEM10_P1_S2	As previously reported in our Form 8-K filed August 17, 2015, David S. Haffner, retired from the Board effective December 31, 2015.
58492_16_ITEM10_P2_S0	In order to be nominated for election as a director, a nominee must submit a contingent resignation to the Nominating Corporate Governance Committee (N CG Committee).
58492_16_ITEM10_P2_S1	The resignation will become effective only if (i) the director nominee fails to receive an affirmative majority of the votes cast in the director election; and (ii) the Board accepts the resignation.
58492_16_ITEM10_P2_S2	If a nominee fails to receive an affirmative majority of the votes cast in the director election, the N CG Committee will make a recommendation to the Board of Directors whether to accept or reject the director s resignation and whether any other action should be taken.
58492_16_ITEM10_P2_S3	If a director s resignation is not accepted, that director will continue to serve until the Company s next annual meeting or until his or her successor is duly elected and qualified.
58492_16_ITEM10_P2_S4	If the Board accepts the director s resignation, it may, in its sole discretion, either fill the resulting vacancy or decrease the size of the Board to eliminate the vacancy.
58492_16_ITEM10_P2_S5	The Company s Bylaws and Corporate Governance Guidelines set the director retirement age at 72; however, the Board Chair, the Lead Director, CEO or President may request a waiver for any director.
58492_16_ITEM10_P2_S6	At the request of Leggett s CEO, the N CG Committee recommended, and the full Board granted, a retirement age waiver for R. Ted Enloe, III so he may stand for re-election at the 2016 annual meeting.

58492_16_ITEM15_P13_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
58492_16_ITEM15_P13_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (i) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (ii) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (iii) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
58492_16_ITEM15_P14_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
58492_16_ITEM15_P14_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.

58492_16_ITEM15_P23_S0	Legal costs are accrued when a loss is probable and reasonably estimable.
58492_16_ITEM15_P23_S1	If a range of outcomes are possible, the most likely outcome is used to accrue these costs.

58492_16_ITEM15_P25_S0	CASH EQUIVALENTS: Cash equivalents include cash in excess of daily requirements which is invested in various financial instruments with original maturities of three months or less.
58492_16_ITEM15_P26_S0	TRADE AND OTHER RECEIVABLES AND ALLOWANCE FOR DOUBTFUL ACCOUNTS: Trade receivables are recorded at the invoiced amount and generally do not bear interest.
58492_16_ITEM15_P26_S1	Credit is also occasionally extended in the form of a note receivable to facilitate our customers operating cycles.
58492_16_ITEM15_P26_S2	Other notes receivable are established in special circumstances, such as in partial payment for the sale of a business.
58492_16_ITEM15_P26_S3	Other notes receivable generally bear interest at market rates commensurate with the corresponding credit risk on the date of origination.
58492_16_ITEM15_P27_S0	The allowance for doubtful accounts is an estimate of the amount of probable credit losses.
58492_16_ITEM15_P28_S0	Interest income is not recognized for nonperforming accounts that are placed on nonaccrual status.
58492_16_ITEM15_P29_S0	Allowances and nonaccrual status designations are determined by individual account reviews by management, and are based on several factors such as the length of time that receivables are past due, the financial health of the companies involved, industry and macroeconomic considerations, and historical loss experience.
58492_16_ITEM15_P30_S0	Interest income is recorded on the date of cash receipt for nonaccrual status accounts.
58492_16_ITEM15_P30_S1	Account balances are charged off against the allowance when it is probable the receivable will not be recovered.
58492_16_ITEM15_P31_S0	All inventories are stated at the lower of cost or market.
58492_16_ITEM15_P31_S1	We generally use standard costs which include materials, labor and production overhead at normal production capacity.
58492_16_ITEM15_P31_S2	The cost for approximately 50% of our inventories is determined by the last-in, first-out (LIFO) method and is primarily used to value domestic inventories with raw material content consisting of steel, wire, chemicals and foam scrap.
58492_16_ITEM15_P31_S3	For the remainder of the inventories, we principally use the first-in, first-out (FIFO) method, which is representative of our standard costs.
58492_16_ITEM15_P31_S4	For these inventories, the FIFO cost for the periods presented approximated expected replacement cost.
58492_16_ITEM15_P32_S0	Inventories are reviewed at least quarterly for slow-moving and potentially obsolete items using actual inventory turnover, and if necessary, are written down to estimated net realizable value.
58492_16_ITEM15_P32_S1	We have had no material changes in inventory writedowns or slow-moving and obsolete inventory reserves in any of the years presented.
