58492_16_ITEM15_P34_S0	Significant accounting policies associated with a decision to dispose of a business are discussed below:
58492_16_ITEM15_P35_S0	In accordance with Accounting Standards Update (ASU) 2014-08 "Reporting Discontinued Operations and Disclosures of Disposals of Components of an Entity", beginning in 2015, a business is classified as discontinued operations if the disposal represents a strategic shift that will have a major effect on operations or financial results, meets the criteria to be classified as held for sale, is disposed of by sale or otherwise.
58492_16_ITEM15_P35_S1	For 2014 and previous years, a business was classified as a discontinued operation when (i) the operations and cash flows of the business were clearly distinguished and were eliminated from our ongoing operations; (ii) the business was either disposed of or was classified as held for sale; and (iii) we did not have any significant continuing involvement in the operations of the business after the disposal transactions.
58492_16_ITEM15_P36_S0	Significant judgments are involved in determining whether a business meets the criteria for discontinued operations reporting and the period in which these criteria are met.
58492_16_ITEM15_P37_S0	If a business is reported as a discontinued operation, the results of operations through the date of sale, including any gain or loss recognized on the disposition, are presented on a separate line of the income statement.
58492_16_ITEM15_P37_S1	Interest on debt directly attributable to the discontinued operation is allocated to discontinued operations.
58492_16_ITEM15_P37_S2	Gains and losses related to the sale of businesses that do not meet the discontinued operation criteria are reported in continuing operations and separately disclosed if significant.
58492_16_ITEM15_P38_S0	Assets Held for Sale An asset or business is classified as held for sale when (i) management commits to a plan to sell and it is actively marketed; (ii) it is available for immediate sale and the sale is expected to be completed within one year; and (iii) it is unlikely significant changes to the plan will be made or that the plan will be withdrawn.
58492_16_ITEM15_P38_S1	In isolated instances, assets held for sale may exceed one year due to events or circumstances beyond our control.
58492_16_ITEM15_P39_S0	Upon being classified as held for sale, the recoverability of the carrying value must be assessed.
58492_16_ITEM15_P39_S1	Evaluating the recoverability of the assets of a business classified as held for sale follows a defined order in which property and intangible assets subject to amortization are considered only after the recoverability of goodwill and other assets are assessed.
58492_16_ITEM15_P39_S2	After the valuation process is completed, the assets held for sale are reported at the lower of the carrying value or fair value less cost to sell, and the assets are no longer depreciated or amortized.
58492_16_ITEM15_P39_S3	An impairment charge is recognized if the carrying value exceeds the fair value less cost to sell.
58492_16_ITEM15_P40_S0	The assets and related liabilities are aggregated and reported on separate lines of the balance sheet.
58492_16_ITEM15_P41_S0	If a decision to dispose of an asset or a business is made and the held for sale criteria are not met, it is considered held for use.
58492_16_ITEM15_P42_S0	Assets of the business are evaluated for recoverability in the following order: (i) assets other than goodwill, property and intangibles; (ii) property and intangibles subject to amortization; and (iii) goodwill.
58492_16_ITEM15_P43_S0	In evaluating the recoverability of property and intangible assets subject to amortization, the carrying value is first compared to the sum of the undiscounted cash flows expected to result from the use and eventual disposition.
58492_16_ITEM15_P43_S1	If the carrying value exceeds the undiscounted expected cash flows, then a fair value analysis is performed.
58492_16_ITEM15_P43_S2	An impairment charge is recognized if the carrying value exceeds the fair value.
58492_16_ITEM15_P44_S0	PROPERTY, PLANT AND EQUIPMENT: Property, plant and equipment is stated at cost, less accumulated depreciation.
58492_16_ITEM15_P44_S1	Assets are depreciated by the straight-line method and salvage value, if any, is assumed to be minimal.
58492_16_ITEM15_P45_S0	The table below presents the depreciation periods of the estimated useful lives of our property, plant and equipment.
58492_16_ITEM15_P46_S0	Accelerated methods are used for tax purposes.
58492_16_ITEM15_P47_S0	Property is reviewed for recoverability at year end and whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that its carrying value may not be recoverable as discussed above.
58492_16_ITEM15_P48_S0	Goodwill results from the acquisition of existing businesses and is not amortized; it is assessed for impairment annually and as triggering events may occur.
58492_16_ITEM15_P48_S1	We perform our annual review in the second quarter of each year.
58492_16_ITEM15_P49_S0	Recoverability of goodwill is evaluated using a two-step process.
58492_16_ITEM15_P50_S0	The first step involves a comparison of the fair value of a reporting unit with its carrying value.
58492_16_ITEM15_P51_S0	Our ten reporting units are the business groups one level below the operating segment level for which discrete financial information is available.
58492_16_ITEM15_P52_S0	If the carrying value of the group exceeds its fair value, the second step of the process is necessary and involves a comparison of the implied fair value and the carrying value of the goodwill of that group.
58492_16_ITEM15_P52_S1	If the carrying value of the goodwill of a group exceeds the implied fair value of that goodwill, an impairment loss is recognized in an amount equal to the excess.
58492_16_ITEM15_P53_S0	In evaluating the recoverability of goodwill, it is necessary to estimate the fair values of the reporting units.
58492_16_ITEM15_P53_S1	In making this assessment, we estimate the fair market values of our reporting units using a discounted cash flow model and comparable market values for similar entities using price-to-earnings ratios.
58492_16_ITEM15_P53_S2	Key assumptions and estimates used in the cash flow model include discount rate, sales growth, margins, capital expenditure requirements, and working capital requirements.
58492_16_ITEM15_P54_S0	Recent performance of the group is an important factor, but not the only factor, in our assessment.
58492_16_ITEM15_P55_S0	There are inherent assumptions and judgments required in the analysis of goodwill impairment.
58492_16_ITEM15_P55_S1	It is possible that assumptions underlying the impairment analysis will change in such a manner that impairment in value may occur in the future.
58492_16_ITEM15_P56_S0	Substantially all other intangible assets are amortized using the straight-line method over their estimated useful lives and are evaluated for impairment using a process similar to that used in evaluating the recoverability of property, plant and equipment.
58492_16_ITEM15_P57_S0	The cost of employee services received in exchange for all equity awards granted is based on the fair market value of the award as of the grant date.
58492_16_ITEM15_P57_S1	Expense is recognized net of an estimated forfeiture rate using the straight-line method over the vesting period of the award.
58492_16_ITEM15_P58_S0	We recognize sales when title and risk of loss pass to the customer.
58492_16_ITEM15_P58_S1	The terms of our sales are split approximately evenly between FOB shipping point and FOB destination.
58492_16_ITEM15_P58_S2	The timing of our recognition of FOB destination sales is determined based on shipping date and distance to the destination.
58492_16_ITEM15_P58_S3	We have no significant or unusual price protection, right of return or acceptance provisions with our customers.
58492_16_ITEM15_P59_S0	Sales allowances, discounts and rebates can be reasonably estimated throughout the period and are deducted from sales in arriving at net sales.
58492_16_ITEM15_P60_S0	SHIPPING AND HANDLING FEES AND COSTS: Shipping and handling costs are included as a component of Cost of goods sold.
58492_16_ITEM15_P61_S0	RESTRUCTURING COSTS: Restructuring costs are items such as employee termination, contract termination, plant closure and asset relocation costs related to exit activities.
58492_16_ITEM15_P61_S1	Restructuring-related items are inventory writedowns and gains or losses from sales of assets recorded as the result of exit activities.
58492_16_ITEM15_P62_S0	We recognize a liability for costs associated with an exit or disposal activity when the liability is incurred.
58492_16_ITEM15_P63_S0	Certain termination benefits for which employees are required to render service are recognized ratably over the respective future service periods.
58492_16_ITEM15_P64_S0	The provision for income taxes is determined using the asset and liability approach of accounting for income taxes.
58492_16_ITEM15_P64_S1	Under this approach, deferred taxes represent the future tax consequences expected to occur when the reported amounts of assets and liabilities are recovered or paid.
58492_16_ITEM15_P65_S0	The provision for income taxes represents income taxes paid or payable for the current year plus the change in deferred taxes during the year.
58492_16_ITEM15_P65_S1	Deferred taxes result from differences between the financial and tax basis of our assets and liabilities and are adjusted for changes in tax rates and laws, as appropriate.
58492_16_ITEM15_P65_S2	A valuation allowance is provided to reduce deferred tax assets when management cannot conclude that it is more likely than not that a tax benefit will be realized.
58492_16_ITEM15_P66_S0	A provision is also made for incremental taxes on undistributed earnings of foreign subsidiaries and related companies to the extent that such earnings are not deemed to be indefinitely invested.
58492_16_ITEM15_P67_S0	The calculation of our U.S., state, and foreign tax liabilities involves dealing with uncertainties in the application of complex global tax laws.
58492_16_ITEM15_P67_S1	We recognize potential liabilities for anticipated tax issues which might arise in the U.S. and other tax jurisdictions based on management s estimate of whether, and the extent to which, additional taxes will be due.
58492_16_ITEM15_P67_S2	If payment of these amounts ultimately proves to be unnecessary, the reversal of the liabilities would result in tax benefits being recognized in the period when we determine the liabilities are no longer necessary.
58492_16_ITEM15_P67_S3	Conversely, if the estimate of tax liabilities proves to be less than the ultimate tax assessment, a further charge to tax expense would result.
58492_16_ITEM15_P68_S0	CONCENTRATION OF CREDIT RISKS, EXPOSURES AND FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS: We manufacture, market, and distribute products for the various end markets described in Note F.
58492_16_ITEM15_P68_S1	Our operations are principally located in the United States, although we also have operations in Europe, China, Canada, Mexico and other various countries.
58492_16_ITEM15_P69_S0	We maintain allowances for potential credit losses.
58492_16_ITEM15_P69_S1	We perform ongoing credit evaluations of our customers financial conditions and generally require no collateral from our customers, some of which are highly leveraged.
58492_16_ITEM15_P69_S2	Management also monitors the financial condition and status of other notes receivable.
58492_16_ITEM15_P70_S0	Other notes receivable have historically primarily consisted of notes accepted as partial payment for the divestiture of a business.
58492_16_ITEM15_P70_S1	Some of these companies are highly leveraged and the notes are not fully collateralized.
58492_16_ITEM15_P71_S0	We have no material guarantees or liabilities for product warranties which require disclosure.
58492_16_ITEM15_P72_S0	From time to time, we will enter into contracts to hedge foreign currency denominated transactions, natural gas purchases, and interest rates related to our debt.
58492_16_ITEM15_P73_S0	To minimize the risk of counterparty default, only highly-rated financial institutions that meet certain requirements are used.
58492_16_ITEM15_P73_S1	We do not anticipate that any of the financial institution counterparties will default on their obligations.
58492_16_ITEM15_P74_S0	The carrying value of cash and short-term financial instruments approximates fair value due to the short maturity of those instruments.
58492_16_ITEM15_P75_S0	Although we obtain insurance for workers compensation, automobile, product and general liability, property loss and medical claims, we have elected to retain a significant portion of expected losses through the use of deductibles.
58492_16_ITEM15_P75_S1	Accrued liabilities include estimates for unpaid reported claims and for claims incurred but not yet reported.
58492_16_ITEM15_P75_S2	Provisions for losses are recorded based upon reasonable estimates of the aggregate liability for claims incurred utilizing our prior experience and information provided by our third-party administrators and insurance carriers.
58492_16_ITEM15_P76_S0	DERIVATIVE FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS: We utilize derivative financial instruments to manage market and financial risks related to interest rates, foreign currency and commodities.
58492_16_ITEM15_P76_S1	We seek to use derivative contracts that qualify for hedge accounting treatment; however some instruments that economically manage currency risk may not qualify for hedge accounting treatment.
58492_16_ITEM15_P76_S2	It is our policy not to speculate using derivative instruments.
58492_16_ITEM15_P77_S0	Under hedge accounting, we formally document our hedge relationships, including identification of the hedging instruments and the hedged items, as well as our risk management objectives and strategies for entering into the hedge transaction.
58492_16_ITEM15_P77_S1	The process includes designating derivative instruments as hedges of specific assets, liabilities, firm commitments or forecasted transactions.
58492_16_ITEM15_P77_S2	We also formally assess both at inception and on a quarterly basis thereafter, whether the derivatives used in hedging transactions are highly effective in offsetting changes in either the fair value or cash flows of the hedged item.
58492_16_ITEM15_P77_S3	If it is determined that a derivative ceases to be highly effective, deferred gains or losses are recorded in the Consolidated Statements of Operations.
58492_16_ITEM15_P78_S0	On the date the contract is entered into, we designate the derivative as one of the following types of hedging instruments and account for it as follows:
58492_16_ITEM15_P79_S0	The hedge of a forecasted transaction or of the variability of cash flows to be received or paid related to a recognized asset or liability or anticipated transaction is designated as a cash flow hedge.
58492_16_ITEM15_P80_S0	The effective portion of the change in fair value is recorded in accumulated other comprehensive income.
58492_16_ITEM15_P80_S1	When the hedged item impacts the income statement, the gain or loss included in other comprehensive income is reported on the same line of the Consolidated Statements of Operations as the hedged item to match the gain or loss on the derivative to the gain or loss on the hedged item.
58492_16_ITEM15_P80_S2	Any ineffective portion of the changes in the fair value is immediately reported in the Consolidated Statements of Operations on the same line as the hedged item.
58492_16_ITEM15_P81_S0	Settlements associated with the sale or production of product are presented in operating cash flows and settlements associated with debt issuance are presented in financing cash flows.
58492_16_ITEM15_P82_S0	The hedge of a recognized asset or liability or an unrecognized firm commitment is designated as a fair value hedge.
58492_16_ITEM15_P82_S1	For fair value hedges, both the effective and ineffective portions of the changes in fair value of the derivative, along with the gain or loss on the hedged item that is attributable to the hedged risk, are recorded in earnings and reported in the Consolidated Statements of Operations on the same line as the hedged item.
58492_16_ITEM15_P83_S0	Cash flows from settled contracts are presented in the category consistent with the nature of the item being hedged.
58492_16_ITEM15_P84_S0	The functional currency for most foreign operations is the local currency.
58492_16_ITEM15_P84_S1	The translation of foreign currencies into U.S. dollars is performed for balance sheet accounts using current exchange rates in effect at the balance sheet date and for income and expense accounts using monthly average exchange rates.
58492_16_ITEM15_P84_S2	The cumulative effects of translating the functional currencies into the U.S. dollar are included in comprehensive income.

58492_16_ITEM15_P85_S1	The first reclassification was a result of changes in our management organizational structure and related internal reporting (See Note F - Segment Information); the final was for a balance sheet reclassification between Machinery and Equipment and Goodwill associated with a measurement period adjustment related to an acquisition.

58492_16_ITEM15_P116_S0	As discussed in Note A, we test other long-lived assets for recoverability at year end and whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying value may not be recoverable.
58492_16_ITEM15_P117_S0	Fair value and the resulting impairment charges noted above were based primarily upon offers from potential buyers or third party estimates of fair value less selling costs.
58492_16_ITEM15_P118_S0	Goodwill is required to be tested for impairment at least once a year and as triggering events may occur.
58492_16_ITEM15_P118_S1	We perform our annual goodwill impairment review in the second quarter of each year as discussed in Note A.
58492_16_ITEM15_P119_S0	Fair value of reporting units is determined using a combination of two valuation methods: a market approach and an income approach.
58492_16_ITEM15_P119_S1	Each method is generally given equal weight in determining the fair value assigned to each reporting unit.
58492_16_ITEM15_P119_S2	Absent an indication of fair value from a potential buyer or similar specific transaction, we believe that the use of these two methods provides a reasonable estimate of a reporting unit s fair value.
58492_16_ITEM15_P119_S3	Assumptions common to both methods are operating plans and economic projections, which are used to project future revenues, earnings, and after-tax cash flows for each reporting unit.
58492_16_ITEM15_P119_S4	These assumptions are applied consistently for both methods.
58492_16_ITEM15_P120_S0	The market approach estimates fair value by first determining price-to-earnings ratios for comparable publicly-traded companies with similar characteristics of the reporting unit.
58492_16_ITEM15_P120_S1	The price-to-earnings ratio for comparable companies is based upon current enterprise value compared to projected earnings for the next two years.
58492_16_ITEM15_P120_S2	The enterprise value is based upon current market capitalization and includes a 25% control premium.
58492_16_ITEM15_P120_S3	Projected earnings are based upon market analysts projections.
58492_16_ITEM15_P120_S4	The earnings ratios are applied to the projected earnings of the comparable reporting unit to estimate fair value.
58492_16_ITEM15_P121_S0	believes this approach is appropriate because it provides a fair value estimate using multiples from entities with operations and economic characteristics comparable to our reporting units.
58492_16_ITEM15_P122_S0	The income approach is based on projected future (debt-free) cash flow that is discounted to present value using factors that consider the timing and risk of future cash flows.
58492_16_ITEM15_P122_S1	Management believes that this approach is appropriate because it provides a fair value estimate based upon the reporting unit s expected long-term operating cash flow performance.
58492_16_ITEM15_P123_S0	Discounted cash flow projections are based on 10 -year financial forecasts developed from operating plans and economic projections noted above, sales growth, estimates of future expected changes in operating margins, terminal value growth rates, future capital expenditures and changes in working capital requirements.
58492_16_ITEM15_P124_S0	If a triggering event occurs, special consideration is given to the new circumstances when determining the fair value of the impacted reporting unit.
58492_16_ITEM15_P125_S0	The 2015 goodwill impairment review indicated no goodwill impairments.

58492_16_ITEM15_P129_S0	After completing our annual goodwill impairment review in June 2014, we concluded on July 14, 2014 that a goodwill impairment charge was required for one reporting unit, Store Fixtures which was recorded as discontinued operations, and was previously part of the Commercial Products segment.
58492_16_ITEM15_P130_S0	The Store Fixtures reporting unit was dependent upon capital spending by retailers on both new stores and remodeling of existing stores.
58492_16_ITEM15_P130_S1	Because of the seasonal nature of the fixture and display industry (where revenue and profitability were typically expected to increase in the second and third quarters assuming the normal historical pattern of heavy shipments during these months) we reasonably anticipated being awarded significant customer orders in the second quarter of 2014.
58492_16_ITEM15_P130_S2	However, as the second quarter progressed, anticipated orders did not materialize and the Store Fixtures business deteriorated, with declines most pronounced in May and June.
58492_16_ITEM15_P130_S3	Taking these developments into account, we lowered our projection of future margins and growth rates (from 4.8% in prior year's review to .5% in the current year for 10-year compound annual growth rate for EBIT plus depreciation and amortization) and increased the discount rate from 10.5% to 12% , causing fair value to fall below carrying value.
58492_16_ITEM15_P130_S4	The lower expectations of future revenue and profitability were due to reduced overall market demand for store fixtures, as many retailers were reducing their investments in traditional store space and focusing more on e-commerce initiatives.
58492_16_ITEM15_P131_S0	This resulted in a $108.0 goodwill impairment charge that was recorded in the second quarter of 2014.
58492_16_ITEM15_P131_S1	This charge reflected the complete impairment of all goodwill associated with the Store Fixtures reporting unit.
58492_16_ITEM15_P131_S2	The majority of the Store Fixtures business was divested in November 2014.
58492_16_ITEM15_P132_S0	As a result of the above circumstances, we also determined a triggering event had occurred in the second quarter to test other long-lived assets which were evaluated for impairment under the held for use model.
58492_16_ITEM15_P132_S1	No long-lived asset impairments (excluding goodwill) were indicated during this review.
58492_16_ITEM15_P132_S2	During the third quarter of 2014, all of the criteria to classify this unit as held for sale and discontinued operations were met as discussed in Note B.
58492_16_ITEM15_P133_S0	During 2013, we began considering strategic alternatives for our CVP unit, including possible divestiture of the business.
58492_16_ITEM15_P133_S1	Potential buyers' initial indications of value received during the second and third quarters were reasonably consistent with our fair value estimates used for the annual goodwill impairment test performed in June 2013.
58492_16_ITEM15_P134_S0	During 2013's fourth quarter, performance of the business deteriorated.
58492_16_ITEM15_P134_S1	It became apparent in December 2013 that current market values for CVP's assets had fallen below recorded book values.
58492_16_ITEM15_P134_S2	This decline in market values of the assets resulted from lower expectations of future revenue and profitability, reflecting reduced market demand for the racks, shelving, and cabinets used in telecom, cable and delivery vans.
58492_16_ITEM15_P135_S0	The events of the fourth quarter were considered a triggering event, which required us to perform an impairment review.
58492_16_ITEM15_P135_S1	Because the held for sale criteria for the CVP unit was not met, it was evaluated for impairment in December 2013 under the held for use model.
58492_16_ITEM15_P135_S2	No long-lived asset impairments (excluding goodwill) were indicated during the 2013 fourth quarter review.

58492_16_ITEM15_P187_S0	When the tax deduction for an exercised stock option or converted stock unit exceeds the compensation cost that has been recognized in income, a windfall tax benefit is created.
58492_16_ITEM15_P187_S1	The windfall benefit is not recognized in income, but rather on the balance sheet as additional contributed capital.
58492_16_ITEM15_P188_S0	When the current tax deduction for an exercised stock option or converted stock unit is less than the deferred tax asset recorded in regard to the compensation cost that has been recognized in income, a tax shortfall is created.
58492_16_ITEM15_P188_S1	To the extent we have accumulated tax windfalls, the shortfall is recognized on the balance sheet as a reduction of additional contributed capital.

58492_16_ITEM15_P190_S0	Starting in 2013, we discontinued the annual broad-based option grant, and replaced options with cash awards, RSU's, or, for certain key management employees, participation in the Profitable Growth Incentive (PGI).With the exception of a few key executive awards, options are now offered only in conjunction with the Deferred Compensation Program discussed below.
58492_16_ITEM15_P191_S0	Prior to 2013, we granted stock options annually on a discretionary basis to a broad group of employees.
58492_16_ITEM15_P191_S1	Options generally become exercisable in one-third increments at 18 months , 30 months and 42 months after the date of grant.
58492_16_ITEM15_P191_S2	Options have a maximum term of ten years and the exercise prices are equal to Leggett s closing stock price on the grant date.
58492_16_ITEM15_P192_S0	Grant date fair values are calculated using the Black-Scholes option pricing model and are amortized by the straight-line method over the options total vesting period, except for employees who are retirement eligible.
58492_16_ITEM15_P193_S0	Expense for employees who are retirement eligible is recognized immediately.
58492_16_ITEM15_P194_S0	A person is retirement eligible if the employee is age 65 , or age 55 with 20 years of Company service.
58492_16_ITEM15_P195_S0	We offer a Deferred Compensation Program under which key managers and outside directors may elect to receive stock options, stock units or interest-bearing cash deferrals in lieu of cash compensation:
58492_16_ITEM15_P196_S0	Stock options under this program are granted on the last business day of the year prior to the year the compensation is earned.
58492_16_ITEM15_P196_S1	The number of options granted equals the deferred compensation times five , divided by the stock s market price on the date of grant.
58492_16_ITEM15_P196_S2	The option has a 10 -year term.
58492_16_ITEM15_P196_S3	It vests as the associated compensation is earned and becomes exercisable beginning 15 months after the grant date.
58492_16_ITEM15_P197_S0	Stock is issued when the option is exercised.
58492_16_ITEM15_P198_S0	Deferred stock units (DSU) under this program are acquired every two weeks (when the compensation would have otherwise been paid) at a 20% discount to the market price of our common stock on each acquisition date and they vest immediately.
58492_16_ITEM15_P199_S0	Expense is recorded as the compensation is earned.
58492_16_ITEM15_P199_S1	Stock units earn dividends at the same rate as cash dividends paid on our common stock.
58492_16_ITEM15_P199_S2	These dividends are used to acquire stock units at a 20% discount.
58492_16_ITEM15_P199_S3	Stock units are converted to common stock and distributed in accordance with the participant s pre-set election.
58492_16_ITEM15_P199_S4	However, stock units may be settled in cash at our discretion.
58492_16_ITEM15_P199_S5	Participants must begin receiving distributions no later than ten years after the effective date of the deferral and installment distributions cannot exceed ten years.
58492_16_ITEM15_P200_S0	Interest-bearing cash deferrals under this program are reported in Other long-term liabilities on the balance sheet and are disclosed in Note I.

58492_16_ITEM15_P239_S0	We use the average of the Citigroup Pension Discount Curve rate and Merrill Lynch AA-AAA 10-year Bond Index rate to determine the discount rate used for our significant pension plans (rounded to the nearest 25 basis points).
58492_16_ITEM15_P240_S0	The Citigroup Pension Discount Curve rate is a calculated rate using yearly spot rates matched against expected future benefit payments.

58492_16_ITEM15_P248_S1	The aggregate allocation of these investments is as follows:
58492_16_ITEM15_P249_S0	Our investment policy and strategies are established with a long-term view in mind.
58492_16_ITEM15_P249_S1	We strive for a sufficiently diversified asset mix to minimize the risk of a material loss to the portfolio value due to the devaluation of any single investment.
58492_16_ITEM15_P249_S2	In determining the appropriate asset mix, our financial strength and ability to fund potential shortfalls that might result from poor investment performance are considered.
58492_16_ITEM15_P249_S3	Approximately 55% of our significant plans (the "frozen plans") are employing a Liability Driven Investment strategy and have a target allocation of 60% fixed income and 40% equities.
58492_16_ITEM15_P249_S4	The remaining significant plans (the "active" plans) have a target allocation of 75% equities and 25% fixed income, as historical equity returns have tended to exceed bond returns over the long term.
58492_16_ITEM15_P250_S0	Assets of our domestic plans represent the majority of plan assets and are allocated to seven different investments.
58492_16_ITEM15_P251_S0	Six are mutual funds, all of which are passively managed low-cost index funds, and include:
58492_16_ITEM15_P252_S0	Total Stock Market Index: Large -, mid-, and small-cap equity diversified across growth and value styles.
58492_16_ITEM15_P253_S0	Large-Cap Index: Large-cap equity diversified across growth and value styles.
58492_16_ITEM15_P254_S0	Small-Cap Index: Small-cap equity diversified across growth and value styles.
58492_16_ITEM15_P255_S0	World ex US Index: International equity; broad exposure across developed and emerging non-US equity markets around the world.
58492_16_ITEM15_P256_S0	Long-term Bond Index: Diversified exposure to the long-term, investment-grade U.S. bond market.
58492_16_ITEM15_P257_S0	Extended Duration Treasury Index: Diversified exposure to U.S. treasury's with maturities of 20-30 years.
58492_16_ITEM15_P258_S0	The Stable value fund consists of a fixed income portfolio offering consistent return and protection against interest rate volatility.

58492_16_ITEM15_P296_S0	We utilize fair value measures for both financial and non-financial assets and liabilities.
58492_16_ITEM15_P297_S0	The areas in which we utilize fair value measures of financial assets and liabilities are presented in the table below.
58492_16_ITEM15_P298_S0	Fair value measurements are established using a three level valuation hierarchy that prioritizes the inputs to valuation techniques used to measure fair value into the following categories:
58492_16_ITEM15_P299_S0	Level 1: Quoted prices for identical assets or liabilities in active markets.
58492_16_ITEM15_P300_S0	Level 2: Inputs other than quoted prices included in Level 1 that are observable for the asset or liability either directly or indirectly.
58492_16_ITEM15_P300_S1	Short-term investments in this category are valued using discounted cash flow techniques with all significant inputs derived from or corroborated by observable market data.
58492_16_ITEM15_P300_S2	Derivative assets and liabilities in this category are valued using models that consider various assumptions and information from market-corroborated sources.
58492_16_ITEM15_P300_S3	The models used are primarily industry-standard models that consider items such as quoted prices, market interest rate curves applicable to the instruments being valued as of the end of each period, discounted cash flows, volatility factors, current market and contractual prices for the underlying instruments, as well as other relevant economic measures.
58492_16_ITEM15_P300_S4	Substantially all of these assumptions are observable in the marketplace, can be derived from observable data or are supported by observable levels at which transactions are executed in the marketplace.
58492_16_ITEM15_P301_S0	Level 3: Unobservable inputs that are not corroborated by market data.
58492_16_ITEM15_P302_S0	______________________________________________ * Includes both current and long-term amounts combined.
58492_16_ITEM15_P303_S0	The fair value for fixed rate debt (Level 2) was not significantly different from its $950.0 carrying value at December 31, 2014 and greater than its $750.0 carrying value by approximately $13 at December 31, 2015.
58492_16_ITEM15_P303_S1	We value this debt using discounted cash flow and secondary market rates provided by Bloomberg.
58492_16_ITEM15_P304_S0	goodwill) for potential impairment as discussed in Note C. Determining fair values for these items requires significant judgment and includes a variety of methods and models that utilize significant Level 3 inputs.
58492_16_ITEM15_P305_S0	Long-lived assets, acquisitions and the second step of a goodwill impairment test utilize the following methodologies in determining fair value: (i) Buildings and machinery are valued at an estimated replacement cost for an asset of comparable age and condition.
58492_16_ITEM15_P305_S1	Market pricing of comparable assets are used to estimate replacement cost where available.
58492_16_ITEM15_P306_S0	The most common identified intangible assets are customer relationships and tradenames.
58492_16_ITEM15_P306_S1	Customer relationships are valued using an excess earnings method, using various inputs such as the estimated customer attrition rate, future earnings forecast, the amount of contributory asset charges, and a discount rate.
58492_16_ITEM15_P306_S2	Tradenames are valued using a relief from royalty method, which is based upon comparable market royalty rates for tradenames of similar value.
58492_16_ITEM15_P307_S0	(iii) Inventory is valued at current replacement cost for raw materials, with a step-up for work in process and finished goods items that reflects the amount of ultimate profit earned as of the valuation date.
58492_16_ITEM15_P307_S1	(iv) Other working capital items are generally recorded at face value, unless there are known conditions that would impact the ultimate settlement amount of the particular item.

58492_16_ITEM15_P312_S1	At December 31, 2015, there was no substantial remaining consideration payable, other than the liability associated with our 2015 acquisition discussed below.
58492_16_ITEM15_P313_S0	A brief description of our most significant acquisitions by year is included below.
58492_16_ITEM15_P314_S0	In March 2015, we acquired a 70% interest in a European private-label manufacturer of high-end upholstered furniture for office, commercial and other settings for a purchase price of $22.7 .
58492_16_ITEM15_P314_S1	This business is complementary to our North American private-label operation and allows us to support our Work Furniture customers as they expand globally.
58492_16_ITEM15_P314_S2	We will acquire the remaining 30% over the next five years, under the terms of the agreement, and have recorded a long-term liability of approximately $10 for the future payments.
58492_16_ITEM15_P315_S0	Future payments are based upon a calculation that incorporates future EBITDA.
58492_16_ITEM15_P315_S1	The recorded liability is based upon estimates and may fluctuate significantly until the 2018 and 2020 payment dates.
58492_16_ITEM15_P315_S2	Fluctuations in this liability will be reflected in interest income or expense on the Consolidated Statement of Operations.
58492_16_ITEM15_P316_S0	On June 30, we acquired Tempur Sealy's three U.S. innerspring component production facilities for a purchase price of $44.5 .
58492_16_ITEM15_P316_S1	This additional volume enhanced our economies of scale, benefited from our vertical integration in steel rod and wire, and allowed manufacturing optimization across a broad asset base.
58492_16_ITEM15_P316_S2	These factors contributed to the recognition of $17.8 in goodwill from this acquisition.
58492_16_ITEM15_P317_S0	We also acquired a German designer and distributor of high-end, European-styled motion components for a purchase price of $16.8 .
58492_16_ITEM15_P317_S1	This business allows us to meet varying design preferences and broadens the range of our furniture component products, which contributed to the recognition of $4.4 in goodwill from this acquisition.
58492_16_ITEM15_P318_S0	We expanded our Aerospace Products business unit with the acquisition of two companies.
58492_16_ITEM15_P319_S0	The first was a UK-based business that extended our capability in aerospace tube fabrication.
58492_16_ITEM15_P319_S1	This business was acquired for a purchase price of $11.7 , and $6.1 of goodwill was recorded related to this acquisition.
58492_16_ITEM15_P319_S2	Factors that contributed to a purchase price resulting in the recognition of goodwill included its international presence and complimentary fit with our Aerospace Products business unit.
58492_16_ITEM15_P320_S0	The second was a French company that added small-diameter, high-pressure seamless tubing to our product portfolio for a cash purchase price of $14.5 .
58492_16_ITEM15_P320_S1	This business was acquired at a price less than fair value of the net identifiable assets, and we recorded an $8.8 non-taxable bargain purchase gain.
58492_16_ITEM15_P320_S2	The bargain purchase gain is reported in the "Other (income) expense, net" line of our income statement.
58492_16_ITEM15_P321_S0	Prior to recognizing a bargain purchase gain, we reassessed whether all assets acquired and liabilities assumed had been correctly identified, the key valuation assumptions and business combination accounting procedures for this acquisition.
58492_16_ITEM15_P321_S1	After careful consideration and review, we concluded that the recognition of a bargain purchase gain was appropriate for this acquisition.
58492_16_ITEM15_P321_S2	Factors that contributed to the bargain purchase price were:
58492_16_ITEM15_P322_S0	The transaction was completed with a motivated seller that desired to restructure its operations in order to focus on its core competencies and exit in an expedient manner non-core businesses that no longer fit its strategy.
58492_16_ITEM15_P323_S0	We were able to complete the acquisition in an expedient manner, with a cash payment and without a financial contingency, which was a key attribute for the seller.
58492_16_ITEM15_P323_S1	The relatively small size of the transaction for us, the lack of required third-party financing and our expertise in completing similar transactions in the past gave the seller confidence that we could complete the transaction quickly and without difficulty.
58492_16_ITEM15_P324_S0	Because the seller of this business will continue to purchase these products in the future it was important to the seller that the acquiring company was a financially sound, integrated manufacturer that could provide a stable supply of high quality product for many years into the future.
58492_16_ITEM15_P324_S1	Due to the unique nature of the products and limited number of potential buyers for this business, the seller found it advantageous to accept our purchase price based upon our demonstrated ability to operate similar businesses, and financial strength that will enable us to be a long-term supplier of quality products into the future.
58492_16_ITEM15_P325_S0	We are subject to market and financial risks related to interest rates, foreign currency, and commodities.
58492_16_ITEM15_P325_S1	In the normal course of business, we utilize derivative instruments (individually or in combinations) to manage these risks.
58492_16_ITEM15_P325_S2	We seek to use derivative contracts that qualify for hedge accounting treatment; however, some instruments may not qualify for hedge accounting treatment.
58492_16_ITEM15_P325_S3	It is our policy not to speculate using derivative instruments.
58492_16_ITEM15_P326_S0	Derivative financial instruments that we use to hedge forecasted transactions and anticipated cash flows are as follows:
58492_16_ITEM15_P327_S0	Commodity Cash Flow Hedges We have historically used commodity cash flow hedges primarily to manage natural gas commodity price risk.
58492_16_ITEM15_P327_S1	Our last natural gas commodity hedge expired during 2013.
58492_16_ITEM15_P328_S0	Interest Rate Cash Flow Hedges On August 12, 2012, we issued $300 of 10 -year notes with a coupon rate of 3.40% .
58492_16_ITEM15_P328_S1	As a part of this transaction, we settled our $200 forward starting interest rate swaps we had entered into during 2010 and recognized a loss of $42.7 , which will be amortized out of accumulated other comprehensive income to interest expense over the life of the notes.
58492_16_ITEM15_P328_S2	In anticipation of the issuance of new debt, we entered into a treasury lock agreement in October 2014.
58492_16_ITEM15_P328_S3	The treasury lock managed benchmark treasury interest rate risk associated with $50 of the additional $300 debt issued in November 2014 and was therefore settled on that same date.
58492_16_ITEM15_P328_S4	The treasury lock had an interest rate of 2.36% .
58492_16_ITEM15_P329_S0	The settlement of the treasury lock did not result in a material gain or loss.
58492_16_ITEM15_P330_S0	The foreign currency hedges manage risk associated with exchange rate volatility of various currencies.
58492_16_ITEM15_P331_S0	The effective changes in fair value of unexpired contracts are recorded in accumulated other comprehensive income and reclassified to income or expense in the period in which earnings are impacted.
58492_16_ITEM15_P332_S0	Cash flows from settled contracts are presented in the category consistent with the nature of the item being hedged.
58492_16_ITEM15_P333_S0	Our fair value hedges typically manage foreign currency risk associated with subsidiaries assets and liabilities.
58492_16_ITEM15_P334_S0	Hedges designated as fair value hedges recognize gain or loss currently in earnings.
58492_16_ITEM15_P334_S1	Cash flows from settled contracts are presented in the category consistent with the nature of the item being hedged.
58492_16_ITEM15_P335_S0	We have deemed ineffectiveness to be immaterial, and as a result, have not recorded any amounts for ineffectiveness.
58492_16_ITEM15_P335_S1	If a hedge was not highly effective, the portion of the change in fair value considered to be ineffective would be recognized immediately in the consolidated statements of operations.
58492_16_ITEM15_P336_S0	We have recorded the following assets and liabilities representing the fair value for our most significant derivative financial instruments.
58492_16_ITEM15_P336_S1	The fair values of the derivatives reflect the change in the market value of the derivative from the date of the trade execution, and do not consider the offsetting underlying hedged item.
58492_16_ITEM15_P337_S0	We did not have any derivatives not designated as hedging instruments at December 31, 2014.

58492_16_ITEM15_P343_S0	Beginning in August 2010, a series of civil lawsuits was initiated in several U.S. federal courts and in Canada against several defendants alleging that competitors of our carpet cushion business unit and other manufacturers of polyurethane foam products had engaged in price fixing in violation of U.S. and Canadian antitrust laws.
58492_16_ITEM15_P343_S1	U.S. Direct Purchaser Class Action Cases.
58492_16_ITEM15_P343_S2	We were named as a defendant in three direct purchaser class action cases (the first on November 15, 2010) on behalf of a class of all direct purchasers of polyurethane foam products.
58492_16_ITEM15_P343_S3	The direct purchaser class action cases were all filed in or were transferred to the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio under the name In re: Polyurethane Foam Antitrust Litigation , Case No. 1:10-MD-2196.
58492_16_ITEM15_P344_S0	The plaintiffs, on behalf of themselves and/or a class of direct purchasers, sought three times the amount of damages allegedly suffered as a result of alleged overcharges in the price of polyurethane foam products from at least 1999 to the present.
58492_16_ITEM15_P344_S1	Each plaintiff also sought attorney fees, pre-judgment and post-judgment interest, court costs, and injunctive relief against future violations.
58492_16_ITEM15_P344_S2	We filed motions to dismiss the U.S. direct purchaser class actions, for failure to state a legally valid claim, which were denied by the Ohio Court.
58492_16_ITEM15_P344_S3	A motion for class certification was filed on behalf of the direct purchasers.
58492_16_ITEM15_P344_S4	A hearing on the motion was held and the Court certified the direct purchaser class.
58492_16_ITEM15_P344_S5	We filed a Petition for Permission to Appeal from Class Certification Order to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit which was denied.
58492_16_ITEM15_P345_S0	The Court ordered all parties to attend non-binding mediation with a mediator of their choosing.
58492_16_ITEM15_P346_S0	Settlement of U.S. Direct Purchaser Class Action Cases.
58492_16_ITEM15_P346_S1	We reached a tentative settlement of the U.S. direct purchaser class action cases on August 14, 2014, by agreeing to pay an aggregate amount of $39.8 , inclusive of plaintiff attorneys' fees and costs.
58492_16_ITEM15_P346_S2	We denied all allegations in the cases, but settled the direct purchaser class cases to avoid the risk, uncertainty, expense and distraction of litigation.
58492_16_ITEM15_P346_S3	The settlement was subject to Court approval.
58492_16_ITEM15_P346_S4	We recorded a $39.8 (pre-tax) accrual for the settlement in the third quarter 2014.
58492_16_ITEM15_P346_S5	In the fourth quarter of 2014, we paid $4 to the Court related to the settlement.
58492_16_ITEM15_P346_S6	A final fairness hearing was held on February 3, 2015, and on February 26, 2015, the Court entered a memorandum opinion and order granting the motion for final approval of the class settlement.
58492_16_ITEM15_P346_S7	Subsequently, final judgments of dismissal with prejudice were entered on March 13, 2015.
58492_16_ITEM15_P347_S0	On March 20, 2015, an objector filed a notice of appeal of the order approving the class settlement to the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals.
58492_16_ITEM15_P347_S1	On March 27, 2015, the direct purchaser class plaintiffs filed a motion to dismiss or, in the alternative, transfer the appeal.
58492_16_ITEM15_P347_S2	On May 1, 2015, the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals denied the motion to dismiss and transferred the appeal to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.
58492_16_ITEM15_P347_S3	On December 4, 2015, the Sixth Circuit issued an order terminating the appeal.
58492_16_ITEM15_P347_S4	We made the $35.8 payment to fully resolve this matter on December 16, 2015.

58492_16_ITEM15_P365_S0	On December 22, 2011, the Brazilian Finance Ministry, Federal Revenue Office issued a notice of violation against our wholly-owned subsidiary, Leggett Platt do Brasil Ltda.
58492_16_ITEM15_P365_S1	( L P Brazil ) in the amount of $1.8 , under Case No. 10855.724660/2011-43.
58492_16_ITEM15_P366_S0	The Brazilian Revenue Office claimed that for the period beginning November 2006 and continuing through December 2007, L P Brazil used an incorrect tariff code for the collection and payment of value-added tax primarily on the sale of mattress innerspring units in Brazil.
58492_16_ITEM15_P366_S1	L P Brazil responded to the notice of violation denying the violation.
58492_16_ITEM15_P366_S2	The Federal Revenue Office denied L P Brazil s defenses and upheld the assessment at the first administrative level.
58492_16_ITEM15_P366_S3	L P Brazil has filed an appeal.

58492_16_ITEM15_P366_S5	L P Brazil has filed its defense.
58492_16_ITEM15_P366_S6	On December 17, 2012, the Brazilian Revenue Office issued an additional notice of violation in the amount of $3.2 , under MPF Case No. 10855.725260/2012-36 covering the period from January 1, 2008 through December 31, 2010 on the same subject matter.
58492_16_ITEM15_P366_S7	L P Brazil responded to the notice of violation denying the violation.

58492_16_ITEM15_P366_S11	On November 16, 2015, the motion was denied, and the case was closed at the administrative level.

58492_16_ITEM15_P368_S0	In addition, L P Brazil received assessments on December 22, 2011, and June 26, July 2 and November 5, 2012, and September 13, 2013 from the Brazilian Federal Revenue Office where the Revenue Office challenged L P Brazil s use of certain tax credits in the years 2005 through 2010.

58492_16_ITEM15_P368_S2	On September 4, 2014, the tax authorities issued five additional assessments regarding this same issue (use of credits), covering certain periods of 2011 and 2012.
58492_16_ITEM15_P368_S3	L P Brazil has filed its defense to all of these assessments.
58492_16_ITEM15_P368_S4	Combined with the prior assessments, L P Brazil has received assessments totaling $2.1 on the same or similar denial of tax credit matters.
58492_16_ITEM15_P369_S0	On February 1, 2013, the Brazilian Finance Ministry filed a Tax Collection action against L P Brazil in the Camanducaia Judicial District Court, Case No. 0002222-35.2013.8.13.0878, alleging the untimely payment of $.1 of social contributions (social security and social assistance payments) for the period September to October 2010.
58492_16_ITEM15_P369_S1	L P Brazil filed its response, a Motion to Stay of Execution.
58492_16_ITEM15_P369_S2	L P Brazil argued the payments were not required to be made because of the application of certain tax credits that were generated by L P Brazil's use of a correct tariff code for the classification of value-added tax on the sale of mattress innersprings (i.e., the same underlying issue at stake in the other Brazilian matters).
58492_16_ITEM15_P369_S3	On June 26, 2014, the Brazilian Revenue Office issued a new notice of violation against L P Brazil in the amount of $.6 , under Case No. 10660.721523/2014-87, covering the period from 2011 through 2012 on the same subject matter.
58492_16_ITEM15_P369_S4	L P Brazil has filed its defense denying the assessments.
58492_16_ITEM15_P370_S0	The Brazilian Finance Ministry alleges that L P Brazil improperly offset $.1 of social contributions otherwise due in 2011.
58492_16_ITEM15_P370_S1	L P Brazil filed its response denying the allegations.
58492_16_ITEM15_P370_S2	L P Brazil is defending on the basis that the social contribution debts were correctly offset with certain tax credits that were generated by L P Brazil's use of a correct tariff code classification for value-added tax on the sale of mattress innersprings (i.e., the same underlying issue at stake in the other Federal Brazilian matters).
58492_16_ITEM15_P370_S3	On September 4, 2014, the Brazilian Federal Revenue issued an assessment against L P Brazil in the amount of $.1 , No. 10660.722021/2014-73 for the period of April 2011 through June 2012, as a penalty for L P Brazil s requests to offset certain tax credits.
58492_16_ITEM15_P370_S4	On December 22, 2015, we received a favorable decision at the first administrative level, accepting our defense and canceling the imposed penalty.
58492_16_ITEM15_P370_S5	Because there is no further appeal opportunities, this assessment is now fully resolved.
58492_16_ITEM15_P371_S0	On December 15, 2015, the Brazilian Federal Revenue issued an assessment against L P Brazil in the amount of $.1 , No. 10600.720142/2015-76 for the period of August 2010 through May 2011, as a penalty for L P Brazil s requests to offset certain tax credits.
58492_16_ITEM15_P371_S1	We filed our defense on January 8, 2016.
58492_16_ITEM15_P371_S2	State of S o Paulo, Brazil Cases.
58492_16_ITEM15_P372_S0	L P Brazil is party to a proceeding involving the State of S o Paulo, Brazil where the State of S o Paulo, on April 16, 2009, issued a Notice of Tax Assessment and Imposition of Fine to L P Brazil seeking $1.4 for the tax years 2006 and 2007, under Case No. 3.111.006 (DRT n .04-256.169/2009).
58492_16_ITEM15_P372_S1	The State of S o Paulo argued that L P Brazil was using an incorrect tariff code for the collection and payment of value-added tax on sales of mattress innerspring units in the State of S o Paulo.
58492_16_ITEM15_P372_S2	Paulo ruled in favor of L P Brazil nullifying the tax assessment.
58492_16_ITEM15_P372_S3	The State filed a special appeal and the Special Appeals Court remanded the case back to the Court of Tax and Fees for further findings.
58492_16_ITEM15_P372_S4	The Court of Tax and Fees again ruled in favor of L P Brazil and nullified the tax assessment.
58492_16_ITEM15_P373_S0	The State filed another special appeal.
58492_16_ITEM15_P373_S1	On April 17, 2014, the Court of Tax and Fees ruled in the State's favor upholding the original assessment of $1.4 .
58492_16_ITEM15_P374_S0	On July 31, 2014, L P Brazil filed an annulment action, Case No. 101712346.2014.8260602 in the Sorocaba State Court, seeking to have the Court of Tax and Fees ruling annulled for an updated assessment amount of $2.9 (which included interest from the original assessment date plus state attorney's fees of 20% ).
58492_16_ITEM15_P374_S1	This duplicative case was dismissed on August 14, 2015, while the annulment action continues.
58492_16_ITEM15_P375_S0	On October 4, 2012, the State of S o Paulo issued a Tax Assessment under Procedure Number 4.003.484 against L P Brazil in the amount of $1.2 for the tax years 2009 through 2011.
58492_16_ITEM15_P375_S1	Similar to the 2009 assessment, the State of S o Paulo argues that L P Brazil was using an incorrect tax rate for the collection and payment of value-added tax on sales of mattress innerspring units in the State of S o Paulo.
58492_16_ITEM15_P375_S2	On June 21, 2013, the State of S o Paulo's attorneys converted the Tax Assessment No. 4.003.484 to a tax collection action against L P Brazil in the amount of $1.5 , under Sorocaba Judicial District Court, Case No. 3005528-50.2013.8.26.0602.
58492_16_ITEM15_P375_S3	L P Brazil filed its response, a Motion to Stay of Execution denying the allegations.
58492_16_ITEM15_P375_S4	L P Brazil also received a Notice of Tax Assessment and Imposition of a Fine from the State of S o Paulo dated March 27, 2014, under Procedure Number 4.038.746-0 against L P Brazil in the amount of $0.7 for the tax years January 2011 through August 2012 regarding the same subject matter.
58492_16_ITEM15_P375_S5	L P filed its response denying the allegations.
58492_16_ITEM15_P375_S6	The first administrative level denied L P Brazil s defense and upheld the assessment.
58492_16_ITEM15_P375_S7	L P Brazil filed its appeal of this decision but the appeal was denied by the second administrative level on July 15, 2015.
58492_16_ITEM15_P375_S8	L P Brazil filed an appeal to the third administrative level on August 6, 2015.
58492_16_ITEM15_P376_S0	State of Minas Gerais, Brazil Cases.
58492_16_ITEM15_P376_S1	On December 18, 2012, the State of Minas Gerais, Brazil issued a tax assessment to L P Brazil relating to L P Brazil's classifications of innersprings for the collection and payment of value-added tax on the sale of mattress innersprings in Minas Gerais from March 1, 2008 through August 31, 2012 in the amount of $.4 , under PTA Case No. 01.000.182756-62.

58492_16_ITEM15_P378_S0	Patent Infringement Claim The patent proceedings discussed below have been fully resolved.
58492_16_ITEM15_P378_S1	The outcome of these matters did not have a material effect on the Company, its results of operations, financial condition or cash flows.
58492_16_ITEM15_P379_S0	On January 24, 2012, in a case in the United States District Court for the Central District of California, the jury entered a verdict against us in the amount of $5 based upon an allegation by plaintiff that we infringed three patents on an automatic stapling machine and on methods used to assemble boxsprings.
58492_16_ITEM15_P379_S1	This action was originally filed on October 4, 2010, as case number CV10-7416 RGK (SSx) under the caption Imaginal Systematic, LLC v. Leggett Platt, Incorporated; Simmons Bedding Company; and Does 1 through 10, inclusive.
58492_16_ITEM15_P379_S2	Leggett is contractually obligated to defend and indemnify Simmons Bedding Company against a claim for infringement.
58492_16_ITEM15_P379_S3	On summary judgment motions, we unsuccessfully disputed each patent s validity and denied that we infringed any patent.
58492_16_ITEM15_P380_S0	At the jury trial on damages issues, the plaintiff alleged damages of $16.2 .
58492_16_ITEM15_P380_S1	The court denied plaintiff s attempt to win an attorney fee award and triple the pre-verdict damages.
58492_16_ITEM15_P380_S2	We appealed the case to the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals.
58492_16_ITEM15_P381_S0	Oral argument was held before a three judge appeal panel in the Federal Circuit in Washington D.C.
58492_16_ITEM15_P381_S1	The Court of Appeals issued a judgment affirming the $5 verdict against us, which was fully accrued for in the first quarter of 2013 and then paid in the second quarter of 2013.
58492_16_ITEM15_P381_S2	We filed a petition for a rehearing of the Court of Appeals decision which was denied.
58492_16_ITEM15_P381_S3	We also filed re-examination proceedings in the Patent Office (Case Nos. 95/001,543 filed February 11, 2011; 95/001,546 and 95/001,547 filed February 16, 2011), challenging the validity of each patent at issue in the lawsuit the plaintiff brought.
58492_16_ITEM15_P381_S4	The Patent Office examiner ruled in our favor on the key claims of one of the three patents.
58492_16_ITEM15_P381_S5	The Patent Office examiner initially ruled in our favor on the pertinent claims of the second of the patents, but subsequently reversed that decision.
58492_16_ITEM15_P381_S6	With respect to the third patent, the Patent Office examiner's decision upheld the validity of all claims.
58492_16_ITEM15_P381_S7	All three of these proceedings were appealed to the Board of Patent Appeals.
58492_16_ITEM15_P382_S0	The plaintiff filed petitions to terminate all re-examination proceedings based on the final ruling of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals.
58492_16_ITEM15_P383_S0	The Patent Office terminated all three re-examination proceedings, and we requested an ex parte re-examination as to one of the patents.
58492_16_ITEM15_P383_S1	The Patent Office did not accept our request.
58492_16_ITEM15_P383_S2	The plaintiff requested royalties for post-verdict use of the machines, and requested pre-judgment interest in the amount of $.7 .
58492_16_ITEM15_P383_S3	The District Court ruled that the plaintiff was not entitled to additional ongoing royalties for our continued use of the machines, but did award pre-judgment interest of $.5 .
58492_16_ITEM15_P383_S4	Both parties filed a notice of appeal of this order to the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals, but plaintiff later withdrew its appeal.
58492_16_ITEM15_P384_S0	On July 29, 2013, the plaintiff filed a second lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Central District of California, Case No.
58492_16_ITEM15_P384_S1	CV13-05463 alleging that we and Simmons Bedding Company have continued to infringe the three patents on an automatic stapling machine and the methods used to assemble boxsprings, and that the plaintiff is entitled to additional damages from January 24, 2012 forward.
58492_16_ITEM15_P384_S2	Leggett and Simmons Bedding Company filed their answers, and the Court granted summary judgment finding that the use of an earlier version of the automatic stapling machines constituted infringement, but also finding that use of a redesigned version of the machine does not infringe any Imaginal patent.
58492_16_ITEM15_P384_S3	On October 17, 2014, the parties entered into a Confidential Settlement Agreement and Limited Release, whereby Leggett agreed to pay Imaginal a cash payment, which is not material to the Company, to settle the part of the case concerning the machines found to infringe and the pre-judgment interest issue from the first lawsuit.
58492_16_ITEM15_P384_S4	Imaginal appealed the summary judgment ruling that the redesigned stapling machines did not infringe to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit.
58492_16_ITEM15_P384_S5	On November 10, 2015 the Federal Circuit upheld the favorable decision that the Company s redesigned version of the machine did not infringe the Imaginal patent.
58492_16_ITEM15_P384_S6	Imaginal did not seek rehearing, nor did it seek a petition for certiorari review at the United States Supreme Court.
58492_16_ITEM15_P384_S7	As such, this lawsuit has been fully resolved.

58492_16_ITEM15_P389_S0	Leggett's Claim for Alleged Antitrust Violations On October 17, 2008, the Company, along with Carpenter Co., Flexible Foam Products, Inc., Foam Supplies, Inc., Hickory Springs Manufacturing Company, J.M. Huber Corporation, Lubrizol Advanced Materials, Inc., The Sherwin-Williams Company, Skypark Manufacturing, LLC, Vitafoam Incorporated; and their respective affiliates, as plaintiffs, filed a complaint in the United States District Court for the District of New Jersey under the caption Carpenter Co., et al. v. BASF SE, et al., Case No. 2:08-cv-05169 against BASF Corporation, The Dow Chemical Company, Huntsman International LLC, Lyondell Chemical Company, and their affiliates, alleging that defendants conspired to fix prices and allocate customers and markets for certain urethane chemical products.
58492_16_ITEM15_P389_S1	The Company previously settled its claims against certain defendants for immaterial amounts and all other defendants have been dismissed except for The Dow Chemical Company.
58492_16_ITEM15_P390_S0	We, along with co-plaintiffs, seek to recover three times the amount of damages suffered as a result of the alleged overcharges in the price of the urethane chemical products purchased from the defendant from at least 1994 through at least 2004.
58492_16_ITEM15_P390_S1	The plaintiffs also seek attorney fees, pre-judgment interest and injunctive relief.
58492_16_ITEM15_P391_S0	Based on the maturation of the proceeding, discovery becoming substantially complete, and the scheduled trial date of March 7, 2016, we now believe that it is reasonably likely that we may recover material damages from the defendant.
58492_16_ITEM15_P391_S1	However, because of uncertainties, we cannot estimate the amount of recovery.
58492_16_ITEM15_P391_S2	Also, because of these uncertainties, it is possible that we may recover only an immaterial amount of the alleged damages, or recover no damages at all.

58492_16_ITEM15_P415_S0	1. NAME AND PURPOSE 1.1 Name .
58492_16_ITEM15_P415_S1	The name of this Program is the Leggett Platt, Incorporated 2005 Executive Stock Unit Program.
58492_16_ITEM15_P415_S2	This Program is intended to attract, motivate, retain and reward Key Employees by giving them the opportunity to build retirement savings while sharing in the appreciation in value of the Company s Common Stock and Diversified Investments.
58492_16_ITEM15_P415_S3	The Program is an unfunded deferred compensation plan for a select group of management and/or highly compensated employees as described in ERISA.
58492_16_ITEM15_P415_S4	The Program is established pursuant to the Leggett Platt, Incorporated Flexible Stock Plan.
58492_16_ITEM15_P416_S0	A separate book account established by the Company or its third party agent to track Stock Units and Diversified Investments for each Participant.
58492_16_ITEM15_P416_S1	The Company s additional contribution of amounts to a Participant s Account made pursuant to Section 4.5.
58492_16_ITEM15_P417_S0	The person or persons designated as the recipient of a deceased Participant s benefits under the Program.

58492_16_ITEM15_P418_S1	Any calendar year beginning on or after January 1, 2005.

58492_16_ITEM15_P419_S0	The Flexible Stock Plan Committee of the Board or, except as to Section 16 Officers, the Management Committee or any person to whom the administrative authority has been delegated by the Committee.
58492_16_ITEM15_P420_S0	The Company s $.01 par value common stock.

58492_16_ITEM15_P424_S0	A Participant is considered disabled if the Participant (i) is unable to engage in any substantial gainful activity by reason of any medically determinable physical or mental impairment which can be expected to result in death or can be expected to last for a continuous period of not less than 12 months, or (ii) is, by reason of any medically determinable physical or mental impairment which can be expected to result in death or can be expected to last for a continuous period of not less than 12 months, receiving income replacement benefits for a period of not less than 3 months under an accident and health plan covering employees of the Participant s employer.
58492_16_ITEM15_P425_S0	That portion of a Participant s Account denominated in Diversified Investments.
58492_16_ITEM15_P426_S0	Various investments (including mutual funds, bonds, etc.) offered under the Program, intended to mirror the investment alternatives offered in the Company s 401(k) Plan.
58492_16_ITEM15_P426_S1	The Diversified Investments are subject to change, as determined by the Company s Investment Committee.
58492_16_ITEM15_P426_S2	If the Investment Committee replaces an underperforming fund with another similar investment, all the balances in the underperforming fund will be transferred to the new investment.
58492_16_ITEM15_P426_S3	If an investment category is deleted, the Investment Committee will determine to which investment option the assets should be mapped.
58492_16_ITEM15_P427_S0	The Company s contribution of dividend amounts to a Participant s Company Stock Account made pursuant to Section 4.6. 2.17 Election .

58492_16_ITEM15_P435_S1	2.29 Section 409A. Section 409A of the Internal Revenue Code, including all regulations and other guidance of general applicability issued thereunder.
58492_16_ITEM15_P436_S0	A termination of employment or other event as defined under Section 409A. Generally, a Separation of Service is deemed to have occurred when a Participant s services have been reduced to a rate that is expected to be 20% or less of the average rate of services performed by the Participant in the 36 months preceding the reduction.
58492_16_ITEM15_P436_S1	Any Participant meeting the definition of specified employee under Section 409A(a)(2)(B)(i).
58492_16_ITEM15_P437_S0	A unit of account deemed to equal a single share (or fractional share) of the Company s Common Stock.
