58492_16_ITEM15_P438_S0	Any calendar year in which the Participant completes 1,000 hours of service.
58492_16_ITEM15_P438_S1	An hour of service means any hour for which the Employer pays the Participant, including hours paid for vacation, holiday or disability.
58492_16_ITEM15_P439_S0	division acquired by the Company, the Participant s service will include hours of service with the acquired company for purposes of eligibility.
58492_16_ITEM15_P439_S1	However, for purposes of determining Years of Vesting Service under Section 5.4, the Participant s service will begin on the acquisition date.
58492_16_ITEM15_P440_S0	2.35 Year of Vesting Service .
58492_16_ITEM15_P440_S1	Any Year of Service except any year when the Participant is or was eligible to make contributions to this Program or the Stock Bonus Plan but declined to make such contributions.
58492_16_ITEM15_P441_S0	3. ELIGIBILITY AND PARTICIPATION 3.1 Selection of Participants .
58492_16_ITEM15_P442_S0	The Committee will select the Key Employees eligible to become Participants.
58492_16_ITEM15_P442_S1	Unless waived by the Committee, a Key Employee must have at least one Year of Service to be eligible to participate in the Program.
58492_16_ITEM15_P442_S2	The Committee may revoke a Participant s right to participate if he no longer meets the Program s eligibility requirements or for any other reason.
58492_16_ITEM15_P442_S3	If a Participant s employment is terminated for any reason, his right to participate in the Program will cease.
58492_16_ITEM15_P442_S4	Except as provided in Section 5.4, such termination will not affect Stock Units and Diversified Investments already credited to his Account.
58492_16_ITEM15_P443_S0	CONTRIBUTIONS AND PARTICIPANT ACCOUNTS 4.1 Accounts .
58492_16_ITEM15_P443_S1	An Account will be established for each Participant to track the Participant s Stock Units and Diversified Investments.
58492_16_ITEM15_P443_S2	An Account is a bookkeeping device only, established for the purpose of crediting and tracking notional investments made by the Participant in the Stock Units and Diversified Investments.
58492_16_ITEM15_P443_S3	Each Account will track Company Stock and Diversified Investments separately.
58492_16_ITEM15_P444_S0	Each Participant may elect to contribute to the Program a percentage of his Compensation above a certain threshold.
58492_16_ITEM15_P444_S1	For 2016, the threshold is $28,628 which amount may be increased for years after 2016.
58492_16_ITEM15_P444_S2	The Committee will determine the maximum Participant Contribution percentage.
58492_16_ITEM15_P444_S3	Participant s Contributions will be made by payroll deduction on a bi-weekly basis or as Compensation otherwise would have been paid, unless the Committee determines otherwise.
58492_16_ITEM15_P444_S4	All Participant Contributions will be directed into the Diversified Investments elected by the Participant and held in the Participant s Diversified Account.
58492_16_ITEM15_P444_S5	If a Participant has not elected Diversified Investments, Participant Contributions will be directed into the default Diversified Investment established by the Company s Investment Committee until the Participant elects other Diversified Investments.
58492_16_ITEM15_P444_S6	The Company will make a Premium Contribution equal to 17.65% of the Participant s Contribution (equivalent to the 15% discount purchase of Stock Units acquired in the Company Stock Account).
58492_16_ITEM15_P444_S7	Premium Contributions will be made at the same time as the Participant s Contributions and will be directed into the Diversified Investments elected by the Participant, or in the absence of an Investment Election, into the default Diversified Investment established by the Committee.
58492_16_ITEM15_P445_S0	The Company will make a Matching Contribution to the Participant s Company Stock Account equal to 50% of the Participant s Contribution.
58492_16_ITEM15_P445_S1	Matching Contributions will be made at the same time as the Participant s Contributions and will acquire Stock Units at a price equal to 85% of the Fair Market Value of a share of Common Stock on the date such Contributions are made.
58492_16_ITEM15_P445_S2	The Company will make an Additional Matching Contribution to the Participant s Company Stock Account equal to a percentage of the Participant s Contribution for the applicable Calendar Year if the Company s return on capital employed ( ROCE ) for the Calendar Year meets the threshold level established for corporate payouts under the Key Officers Incentive Plan (the Incentive Plan ).
58492_16_ITEM15_P445_S3	ROCE will be calculated in the same manner as it is calculated under the Incentive Plan for a given year.
58492_16_ITEM15_P445_S4	The Additional Matching Contribution will begin at 25% of the Participant s Contribution for the applicable Calendar Year for ROCE achievement at the threshold level and increase ratably to a maximum 50% of the Participant s Contribution for ROCE achievement at the target level, with such threshold and target levels to be determined by the Compensation Committee.
58492_16_ITEM15_P445_S5	Such Contribution will be credited to the Company Stock Account of each Participant who was employed as of the last business day of the Calendar Year, plus each Participant whose employment terminated prior to such date (a) due to Disability or death, or (b) after the Participant has attained 55 years of age and has at least 5 Years of Vesting Service.
58492_16_ITEM15_P445_S6	Additional Matching Contributions, if any, will be credited to the Participant s Company Stock Account by March 15 th following the applicable Calendar Year.
58492_16_ITEM15_P446_S0	On the date a cash dividend is paid on Common Stock, the Company will make a Dividend Contribution to the Participant s Company Stock Account equal to the per share cash dividend on the number of Stock Units credited to the Participant s Company Stock Account on the dividend record date.
58492_16_ITEM15_P447_S0	A Participant s Election (including contribution percentage and form of distribution) will be made in a form approved by the Committee.
58492_16_ITEM15_P447_S1	The Election must be made on or before December 31 for Compensation for services performed and to be earned and vested in the following Calendar Year, except that newly eligible Participants may, within 30 days of first becoming eligible for participation, make an Election for Compensation for services performed and earned subsequent to the date of Election.
58492_16_ITEM15_P447_S2	On or before December 31 of each year following the Participant s initial Election, the Participant may change his contribution percentage for the next Calendar Year or may terminate his Election for the next Calendar Year.
58492_16_ITEM15_P447_S3	If no change or termination is received by December 31, the Participant s Election will irrevocably carry forward for the next Calendar Year.
58492_16_ITEM15_P447_S4	The Participant may not change the form of distribution selected in the initial Election, except as provided in Section 5.7.
58492_16_ITEM15_P447_S5	The Committee may provide for Elections at any other times with respect to all or any part of Compensation or Contributions to the extent that such Elections are consistent with the requirements of Section 409A. 4.8 Participant s Investment Election .
58492_16_ITEM15_P448_S0	Participants may choose the percentage of their Participant Contributions they wish to direct into each Diversified Investment.
58492_16_ITEM15_P449_S0	make their Investment Elections online via secure Account access provided by the Company s third party record keeper.
58492_16_ITEM15_P449_S1	Participants may change their Investment Elections as to future Participant Contributions or the portion of existing Accounts consisting of Diversified Investments at any time subject to normal administrative procedures, unless otherwise determined by the Committee.
58492_16_ITEM15_P449_S2	Each Participant will be solely responsible for the selection of his or her investment choices.
58492_16_ITEM15_P450_S0	4.9 Treatment of Performance Compensation for Certain Newly Eligible Participants .
58492_16_ITEM15_P450_S1	A Participant may become newly eligible for the Program due to a Compensation increase, whereas he was previously eligible for a qualified Company benefit (e.g. the Stock Bonus Plan).
58492_16_ITEM15_P450_S2	A Participant may not defer performance compensation (e.g. an annual bonus) payable in his first year of eligibility if any portion of it was for services performed, or if it was earned and vested, prior to his becoming eligible to participate in the Program.
58492_16_ITEM15_P450_S3	In such a case, the Company will make the Matching Contribution and any Additional Matching Contribution as though the Participant s Contribution had been made with respect to performance compensation received in the first year of eligibility.
58492_16_ITEM15_P451_S0	In the event of a stock dividend, stock split, merger, consolidation or other recapitalization of the Company affecting the number of outstanding shares of Common Stock, the number of Stock Units credited to a Participant s Account will be appropriately adjusted.
58492_16_ITEM15_P452_S0	4.11 Impact of Deferred Compensation Program .
58492_16_ITEM15_P453_S0	Some Participants defer 100% of their Compensation under the Company s Deferred Compensation Program.
58492_16_ITEM15_P453_S1	Since the Compensation remaining after such a deferral is not sufficient to allow the Participant to make the full Participant s Contribution, the Company will make the Matching Contribution and any Additional Matching Contribution as though the full Participant s Contribution had been made.
58492_16_ITEM15_P454_S0	Except in the case of Specified Employees, distribution of a Participant s Account will be made within 90 days after Separation from Service, Disability or death.
58492_16_ITEM15_P454_S1	Distribution of a Specified Employee s Account will be made six months after Separation from Service (other than by Disability or death) in order to conform to Section 409A. Distribution of a Participant s Account will be based on the number of shares or units and market value of the investments held in the Account upon Separation of Service.
58492_16_ITEM15_P454_S2	A Participant s Diversified Investment Account will be settled in cash, and the Company Stock Account will be settled in shares of the Company s Common Stock.
58492_16_ITEM15_P454_S3	Prior to distribution, the Stock Units held in the Participant s Company Stock Account will be converted to whole shares of Common Stock, with any fractional share rounded to the nearest whole share.
58492_16_ITEM15_P454_S4	If Stock Units are credited to the Participant s Company Stock Account after a distribution has been made ( e.g. , as a result of Dividend Contributions or Additional Matching Contributions), a subsequent distribution of those Stock Units will be made within 60 days of the date the Stock Units are credited to the Participant s Company Stock Account, which distribution in the case of the Additional Matching Contribution will occur in the Calendar Year following the Calendar Year of Separation from Service.
58492_16_ITEM15_P455_S0	Although the Company intends to settle Participants Accounts in shares of the Company s Common Stock, notwithstanding any other provision of the Program, the Company reserves the right to pay Stock Units in cash in lieu of shares of Common Stock.
58492_16_ITEM15_P455_S1	If settled in cash, the amount of the distribution will be equal to the Fair Market Value of the number of shares of Common Stock that would otherwise be issued.
58492_16_ITEM15_P455_S2	Fair Market Value shall be determined at the date the shares would otherwise have been issued.
58492_16_ITEM15_P456_S0	Participants may elect to receive distributions of their Accounts in (a) a lump sum amount, or (b) annual installments for up to 15 years.
58492_16_ITEM15_P456_S1	Annual installment distributions will be made by January 31st of each Calendar Year following the Calendar Year of the initial distribution.
58492_16_ITEM15_P456_S2	Each annual distribution will be equal to the balance of the Account divided by the number of payments remaining.
58492_16_ITEM15_P457_S0	If a Participant does not elect a form of distribution in his initial Election or if a Participant s Account value does not exceed $50,000 upon Separation from Service, the distribution will be made in a lump sum.
58492_16_ITEM15_P458_S0	The Company will withhold from distributions any amount required to pay applicable taxes (at the Company s required withholding rate).
58492_16_ITEM15_P458_S1	The tax withholding for distributions from the Participant s Company Stock Account will be made in shares of Common Stock.
58492_16_ITEM15_P458_S2	Alternatively, the Participant may pay such taxes in cash if he makes suitable arrangements with the Company before the distribution date.
58492_16_ITEM15_P458_S3	The Company may, at any time, require a Participant to settle the tax liability in cash.
58492_16_ITEM15_P459_S0	5.4 Forfeiture of Stock Units .
58492_16_ITEM15_P459_S1	Notwithstanding the above, if a Participant who has less than 5 Years of Vesting Service has a Separation from Service, the Participant will forfeit any Stock Units acquired by Company Matching Contributions, Additional Matching Contributions or Dividend Contributions (unless the Committee determines otherwise).
58492_16_ITEM15_P459_S2	However, such Stock Units will not be forfeited if the Participant has a Separation from Service due to death or Disability.
58492_16_ITEM15_P459_S3	If a Participant dies before he has received all distributions due under the Program, the remaining distributions will be made to his Beneficiary.
58492_16_ITEM15_P460_S0	Each Participant may designate a Beneficiary and change his Beneficiary from time to time.
58492_16_ITEM15_P460_S1	Beneficiary designations are made and tracked through the company s record keeper.
58492_16_ITEM15_P460_S2	If a Participant has no living designated Beneficiary, then his Beneficiary will be his personal representative.
58492_16_ITEM15_P461_S0	5.6 Distribution Upon Unforeseeable Emergency or Change in Control.
58492_16_ITEM15_P461_S1	In the event of an Unforeseeable Emergency, the Committee may authorize an immediate distribution to the Participant as permitted under Section 409A. In addition, the Committee may terminate and liquidate the Program within 30 days preceding or 12 months after a Change in Control and direct all payments to be made within 12 months of its action to the extent permitted under Section 409A. 5.7 Change in Form of Distribution .
58492_16_ITEM15_P462_S0	A Participant may extend the payout period of an installment election or change the form of distribution, not to exceed the maximum payout period of 15 years or such other period determined by the Committee.
58492_16_ITEM15_P462_S1	For purposes of the foregoing, each payment in an installment distribution will be deemed a separate payment and each payout date in an installment distribution election will be treated as a separate election.
58492_16_ITEM15_P463_S0	be made not less than 12 months prior to Separation from Service and must extend the first distribution payment by at least 5 years, consistent with the requirements of Section 409A. 5.8 Distribution upon Section 409A Failure .
58492_16_ITEM15_P463_S1	Notwithstanding any of the foregoing provisions of Sections 5.1 through 5.7, if there is a failure of the Program to satisfy Section 409A of the Internal Revenue Code ( Section 409A ), the Company may in its sole discretion, but is not required to, distribute the portion of the Account of any Participant that must be included in the Participant s income as a result of the Section 409A failure; provided, however, in no event will a distribution from the Participant s Diversified Investment Account or the Participant s Company Stock Account exceed the balance of the Participant s Diversified Investment Account or the Participant s Company Stock Account, respectively, as most recently determined as of the date of distribution.
58492_16_ITEM15_P463_S2	Any such distribution shall be made as soon as is administratively feasible after the Company has both identified the Section 409A failure and determined to make the distribution.
58492_16_ITEM15_P463_S3	No Participant shall be provided the discretion to receive such distribution or a direct or indirect election as to whether the Company will make such distribution.
58492_16_ITEM15_P463_S4	Such distribution from the Participant s Diversified Investment Account shall be made in one lump sum in cash.
58492_16_ITEM15_P463_S5	Such distribution from the Participant s Company Stock Account shall be made in whole shares of the Company s Common Stock, rounded to the closest whole share.
58492_16_ITEM15_P463_S6	Although the Company intends that any such distribution be in shares of the Company s Common Stock, notwithstanding any other provision of the Program, the Company reserves the right to pay Stock Units in cash in lieu of shares of Common Stock.
58492_16_ITEM15_P463_S7	The number of shares of Common Stock to be distributed will be determined by dividing (a) the dollar value determined as of December 31 of the year of the Section 409A failure of the portion of the Participant s Company Stock Account determined as of that December 31 to which such Section 409A failure relates, by (b) the Fair Market Value per share of Common Stock as then in effect at the time of distribution.
58492_16_ITEM15_P464_S0	In addition to the tax withholding provided for in Section 5.3, the Company may withhold all federal, state, and local income and employment taxes that may have been previously required as a result of the Section 409A failure.
58492_16_ITEM15_P464_S1	Each Participant is responsible for payment of all taxes, including taxes that are due as a result of any Section 409A failure.
58492_16_ITEM15_P464_S2	The Company has no liability for any Participant s taxes.
58492_16_ITEM15_P465_S0	Except to the extent the Committee otherwise designates pursuant to Section 6.2(f), the Committee will control and manage the operation and administration of the Program.
58492_16_ITEM15_P465_S1	The Committee will have such authority and discretion as may be necessary to discharge its responsibilities under the Program, including the authority and discretion to: (a) interpret the provisions of the Program; (b) adopt rules of procedure consistent with the Program; (c) determine questions relating to benefits and rights under the Program; (d) maintain records concerning the Program; (e) determine the content and form of the Participant s Election and all other documents required to carry out the Program; and (f) designate any Company employee or committee, including the Management Committee, to carry out any of the Committee s duties, including authority to manage the operation and administration of the Program.
58492_16_ITEM15_P466_S0	Notwithstanding the foregoing, the Committee may not delegate its authority with respect to Section 16 Officers.
58492_16_ITEM15_P467_S0	6.4 Compliance with Applicable Law .
58492_16_ITEM15_P467_S1	Notwithstanding anything contained in the Program or in any document issued under the Program, it is intended that the Program will at all times meet the requirements of Section 409A and any regulations or other guidance issued thereunder, and that the provisions of the Program will be interpreted to meet such requirements.
58492_16_ITEM15_P468_S0	CLAIMS 7.1 Adjudication of Claims .
58492_16_ITEM15_P468_S1	The Committee and the Company s Secretary will make all determinations regarding benefits under the Program in accordance with ERISA.
58492_16_ITEM15_P469_S0	If a Participant (or other person entitled to file a claim for benefits under ERISA) (a claimant ) is denied a claim for benefits under the Program, the Committee shall provide to the claimant written notice of the denial within ninety (90) days (forty-five (45) days with respect to a denial of any claim for benefits due to the Participant s Disability) after the Committee receives the claim, unless special circumstances require an extension of time for processing the claim.
58492_16_ITEM15_P469_S1	If such an extension of time is required, written notice of the extension shall be furnished to the claimant prior to the termination of the initial 90-day or 45-day period, as applicable.
58492_16_ITEM15_P469_S2	In no event shall the extension exceed a period of ninety (90) days (thirty (30) days with respect to a claim for benefits due to the Participant s Disability) from the end of such initial period.
58492_16_ITEM15_P469_S3	With respect to a claim for benefits due to the Participant s Disability, an additional extension of up to thirty (30) days beyond the initial 30-day extension period may be required for processing the claim.
58492_16_ITEM15_P469_S4	In such event, written notice of the extension shall be furnished to the claimant within the initial 30-day extension period.
58492_16_ITEM15_P469_S5	Any extension notice shall indicate the special circumstances requiring the extension of time, the date by which the Committee expects to render the final decision, the standards on which entitlement to benefits are based, the unresolved issues that prevent a decision on the claim and the additional information needed to resolve those issues.
58492_16_ITEM15_P470_S0	7.3 Contents of Notice of Denial .
58492_16_ITEM15_P471_S0	medical circumstances or a statement that such explanation will be provided free of charge upon request.
58492_16_ITEM15_P472_S0	After receiving written notice of the denial of a claim, a claimant or his representative shall be entitled to: (a) request a full and fair review of the denial of the claim by written application to the Committee (or Appeals Fiduciary in the case of a claim for benefits payable due to a Participant s Disability); (b) request, free of charge, reasonable access to, and copies of, all documents, records, and other information relevant to the claim; (c) submit written comments, documents, records, and other information relating to the denied claim to the Committee or Appeals Fiduciary, as applicable; and (d) a review that takes into account all comments, documents, records, and other information submitted by the claimant relating to the claim, without regard to whether such information was submitted or considered in the initial benefit determination.
58492_16_ITEM15_P472_S1	(a) If a claimant wishes a review of the decision denying his claim to benefits under the Program, other than a claim described in Subsection (b) of this Section, he must submit the written application to the Committee within sixty (60) days after receiving written notice of the denial.
58492_16_ITEM15_P472_S2	(b) If the claimant wishes a review of the decision denying his claim to benefits under the Program due to a Participant s Disability, he must submit the written application to the Appeals Fiduciary within one hundred eighty (180) days after receiving written notice of the denial.
58492_16_ITEM15_P472_S3	With respect to any such claim, in deciding an appeal of any denial based in whole or in part on a medical judgment, the Appeals Fiduciary shall: (i) consult with a health care professional who has appropriate training and experience in the field of medicine involved in the medical judgment; and (ii) identify the medical and vocational experts whose advice was obtained on behalf of the Program in connection with the denial without regard to whether the advice was relied upon in making the determination to deny the claim.
58492_16_ITEM15_P472_S4	Notwithstanding the foregoing, the health care professional consulted pursuant to this Subsection (b) shall be an individual who was not consulted with respect to the initial denial of the claim that is the subject of the appeal or a subordinate of such individual.
58492_16_ITEM15_P473_S0	Upon receiving a written application for review, the Committee or Appeals Fiduciary, as applicable, may schedule a hearing for purposes of reviewing the claimant s claim, which hearing shall take place not more than thirty (30) days from the date on which the Committee or Appeals Fiduciary received such written application for review.
58492_16_ITEM15_P473_S1	At least ten (10) days prior to the scheduled hearing, the claimant and his representative designated in writing by him, if any, shall receive written notice of the date, time, and place of such scheduled hearing.
58492_16_ITEM15_P473_S2	The claimant or his representative, if any, may request that the hearing be rescheduled, for his convenience, on another reasonable date or at another reasonable time or place.
58492_16_ITEM15_P473_S3	All claimants requesting a review of the decision denying their claim for benefits may employ counsel for purposes of the hearing.
58492_16_ITEM15_P474_S0	(90) days with respect to a claim for benefits due to the Participant s Disability) after the date of receipt of the written application for review.
58492_16_ITEM15_P474_S1	If the Committee or Appeals Fiduciary determines that the extension of time is required, the Committee or Appeals Fiduciary shall furnish to the claimant written notice of the extension before the expiration of the initial sixty (60) day (forty-five (45) days with respect to a claim for benefits due to the Participant s Disability) period.
58492_16_ITEM15_P474_S2	The extension notice shall indicate the special circumstances requiring an extension of time and the date by which the Committee or Appeals Fiduciary expects to render its decision on review.
58492_16_ITEM15_P475_S0	In the case of a decision adverse to the claimant, the Committee or Appeals Fiduciary shall provide to the claimant written notice of the denial which shall include: (a) the specific reasons for the decision; (b) specific references to the pertinent provisions of the Program on which the decision is based; (c) a statement that the claimant is entitled to receive, upon request and free of charge, reasonable access to, and copies of, all documents, records, and other information relevant to the claimant s claim for benefits; (d) a statement describing any available voluntary appeal procedures (if any) and of the claimant s right to obtain information about such procedures as required by ERISA and a statement of the claimant s right to bring an action under Section 502(a) of ERISA following the denial of the claim upon review; (e) in the case of a claim for benefits due to the Participant s Disability, if an internal rule, guideline, protocol or other similar criterion is relied upon in making the adverse determination, either the specific rule, guideline, protocol or other similar criterion; or a statement that such rule, guideline, protocol or other similar criterion was relied upon in making the decision and that a copy of such rule, guideline, protocol or other similar criterion will be provided free of charge upon request; (f) in the case of a claim for benefits due to a Participant s Disability, if a denial of the claim is based on a medical necessity or experimental treatment or similar exclusion or limit, an explanation of the scientific or clinical judgment for the denial, an explanation applying the terms of the Program to the claimant s medical circumstances or a statement that such explanation will be provided free of charge upon request; and (g) in the case of a claim for benefits due to a Participant s Disability, a statement regarding the availability of other voluntary alternative dispute resolution options.
58492_16_ITEM15_P475_S1	Nothing contained in the Program will restrict the right of the Employer to discharge a Participant or the right of a Participant to resign from employment.
58492_16_ITEM15_P475_S2	The Program should not be construed as an employment contract.
58492_16_ITEM15_P475_S3	No Participant or Beneficiary may transfer, assign or otherwise encumber any benefits payable by the Company under the Program.
58492_16_ITEM15_P475_S4	Such benefits may not be seized by any creditor of Participant or Beneficiary or transferred by operation of law in the event of bankruptcy, insolvency or death.
58492_16_ITEM15_P475_S5	Any attempted assignment or transfer will be void.
58492_16_ITEM15_P475_S6	No person will have any interest in the Company s assets by virtue of the Program.
58492_16_ITEM15_P475_S7	No Participant or Beneficiary will have any of the rights of a shareholder with respect to Stock Units.
58492_16_ITEM15_P476_S0	The Program and any action taken pursuant to the Program should not be construed as creating a trust or other fiduciary relationship between the Company, the Participant, his Beneficiary or any other person.
58492_16_ITEM15_P476_S1	The Program will be binding upon and inure to the benefit of the Company, its successors and assigns, and each Participant, his heirs, personal representatives, and Beneficiaries.

58492_17_ITEM1_P0_S0	Leggett Platt, Incorporated was founded as a partnership in Carthage, Missouri in 1883 and was incorporated in 1901.
58492_17_ITEM1_P0_S1	The Company, a pioneer of the steel coil bedspring, has become an international diversified manufacturer that conceives, designs and produces a wide range of engineered components and products found in many homes, offices and automobiles.
58492_17_ITEM1_P0_S2	As discussed below, our continuing operations are organized into 17 business units, which are divided into 10 groups under our four segments: Residential Furnishings; Commercial Products; Industrial Materials; and Specialized Products.
58492_17_ITEM1_P1_S0	Our Residential Furnishings segment began in 1883 with the manufacture of steel coiled bedsprings.
58492_17_ITEM1_P1_S1	Today, we supply a variety of components used by bedding and upholstered furniture manufacturers in the assembly of their finished products.
58492_17_ITEM1_P1_S2	Our range of products offers our customers a single source for many of their component needs.
58492_17_ITEM1_P2_S0	Innovative proprietary products and low cost have made us the largest U.S. manufacturer in many of these businesses.
58492_17_ITEM1_P2_S1	We strive to understand what drives consumer purchases in our markets and focus our product development activities on meeting those end-consumer needs.
58492_17_ITEM1_P2_S2	We attain a cost advantage from efficient manufacturing methods, internal production of key raw materials, purchasing leverage, and large-scale production.
58492_17_ITEM1_P2_S3	Sourcing components from us allows our customers to focus on designing, merchandising, and marketing their products.
58492_17_ITEM1_P3_S0	In our Commercial Products segment we design, manufacture, and distribute a wide range of components and finished products for the office seating and sleep specialty, furniture and other retail markets.
58492_17_ITEM1_P3_S1	We are a major provider of adjustable beds and fashion beds, with domestic manufacturing and distribution capability as well as established relationships with global supply sources.
58492_17_ITEM1_P4_S0	The quality of our products and service, together with our low cost, have made Leggett Platt the leading U.S. supplier of high-carbon drawn steel wire.
58492_17_ITEM1_P4_S1	Our Wire group operates a steel rod mill with an annual output of approximately 500,000 tons, of which a substantial majority is used by our own wire mills.
58492_17_ITEM1_P4_S2	We have three wire mills that supply virtually all of the wire consumed by our other domestic businesses.
58492_17_ITEM1_P4_S3	We also supply steel wire to trade customers that operate in a broad range of markets.
58492_17_ITEM1_P5_S0	We use about 70% of our wire output to manufacture our own products, including:
58492_17_ITEM1_P6_S0	The Industrial Materials segment also has a diverse group of trade customers that include:
58492_17_ITEM1_P7_S0	Our Specialized Products segment designs, manufactures and sells products including automotive seating components, tubing assemblies for the aerospace industry, bedding industry machinery, and service van interiors.
58492_17_ITEM1_P7_S1	Our established design capability and focus on product development have made us a leader in innovation.
58492_17_ITEM1_P7_S2	We also benefit from our broad geographic presence and our internal production of key raw materials and components.
58492_17_ITEM1_P8_S0	For information about sales to trade customers, sales by product line, EBIT, and total assets of each of our segments, refer to Note E on page 86 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
58492_17_ITEM1_P9_S0	Our reportable segments are the same as our operating segments, which also correspond with our management organizational structure.
58492_17_ITEM1_P9_S1	Because of the divestiture of the majority of the Store Fixtures business in late 2014, along with the retirement of the Senior Operating Vice President of the Industrial Materials segment, our management organizational structure and all related internal reporting changed effective January 1, 2015.
58492_17_ITEM1_P10_S0	The Adjustable Bed and Fashion Bed businesses were moved from Residential Furnishings to Commercial Products.
58492_17_ITEM1_P10_S1	The Aerospace Products business was moved from Industrial Materials to Specialized Products.
58492_17_ITEM1_P10_S2	The Spuhl machinery operation (which produces wire forming equipment primarily for our internal use) was moved from Specialized Products to Residential Furnishings.
58492_17_ITEM1_P10_S3	Additionally, our logistics operations, which primarily include intercompany transportation activity, were moved from Residential Furnishings to Industrial Materials.
58492_17_ITEM1_P10_S4	These segment changes were retrospectively applied to all prior periods presented.
58492_17_ITEM1_P11_S0	For information regarding 2017 changes in segment reporting, see "Change in Segment Reporting for 2017" in Item 7, Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations beginning on page 33.
58492_17_ITEM1_P12_S0	Total Shareholder Return (TSR), relative to peer companies, is the key financial measure that we use to assess long-term performance.
58492_17_ITEM1_P12_S1	TSR = (Change in Stock Price + Dividends)/Beginning Stock Price.
58492_17_ITEM1_P12_S2	Our goal is to achieve TSR in the top third of the S P 500 companies over rolling three-year periods through an approach that employs four TSR sources: revenue growth, margin expansion, dividends, and share repurchases.
58492_17_ITEM1_P13_S0	Our incentive programs reward return generation and profitable growth.
58492_17_ITEM1_P14_S0	Senior executives participate in a TSR-based incentive program (based on our performance compared to a group of approximately 320 peers).
58492_17_ITEM1_P15_S0	For information about our TSR targets and performance see the discussion under "Total Shareholder Return" in Item 7, Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations on page 31.
58492_17_ITEM1_P16_S0	During the past three years, we generated $1.29 billion of operating cash, and we returned much of this cash to shareholders in the form of dividends and share repurchases.
58492_17_ITEM1_P16_S1	Our top priorities for use of cash are organic growth (capital expenditures), dividends, and strategic acquisitions.
58492_17_ITEM1_P16_S2	After funding those priorities, if there is still cash available, we generally intend to repurchase stock rather than repay debt early or stockpile cash.
58492_17_ITEM1_P17_S0	For information about dividends and share repurchases see the discussion under "Pay Dividends" and "Repurchase Stock" in Item 7, Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations beginning on page 46.
58492_17_ITEM1_P18_S0	We utilize a rigorous strategic planning process to help guide decisions regarding business unit roles, capital allocation priorities, and new areas in which to grow.
58492_17_ITEM1_P18_S1	We review the portfolio classification of each unit on an annual basis to determine its appropriate role (Grow, Core, Fix or Divest).
58492_17_ITEM1_P18_S2	This review includes criteria such as competitive position, market attractiveness, business unit size, and fit within our overall objectives, as well as financial indicators such as growth of EBIT (earnings before interest and taxes), EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization), operating cash flows, and return on assets.
58492_17_ITEM1_P19_S0	Business units in the Grow category should provide avenues for profitable growth from competitively advantaged positions in attractive markets.
58492_17_ITEM1_P20_S0	Core business units are expected to enhance productivity, improve market share, and generate cash flow from operations while using minimal capital.
58492_17_ITEM1_P20_S1	To remain in the portfolio, business units are expected to consistently generate after-tax returns in excess of our cost of capital.
58492_17_ITEM1_P20_S2	Business units that fail to consistently attain minimum return goals will be moved to the Fix or Divest categories.
58492_17_ITEM1_P21_S0	We revised our TSR framework in September 2016 to moderately increase the expected long-term contribution from revenue growth to 6-9% (from 4-5% previously).
58492_17_ITEM1_P21_S1	Over the last three years, our average annual revenue growth has been approximately 3%.
58492_17_ITEM1_P21_S2	Growth from the combination of increased unit volume and acquisitions has approximated 7% during that time period, but this was partially offset by a 4% reduction from divestitures, commodity deflation and currency impact.
58492_17_ITEM1_P22_S0	Our long-term 6-9% annual revenue growth objective envisions periodic acquisitions.
58492_17_ITEM1_P22_S1	We primarily seek acquisitions within our Grow businesses, and look for opportunities to enter new, higher growth markets (carefully screened for sustainable competitive advantage).
58492_17_ITEM1_P22_S2	We expect all acquisitions to (a) have a clear strategic rationale, a sustainable competitive advantage, a strong fit with the Company, and be in an attractive and growing market; (b) create value by enhancing TSR; (c) for stand-alone businesses: generally possess revenue in excess of $50 million, strong management and future growth opportunity with a strong market position in a market growing faster than GDP; and (d) for bolt-on businesses: generally possess revenue in excess of $15 million, significant synergies, and a strategic fit with an existing business unit.
58492_17_ITEM1_P23_S0	We acquired three small businesses for an aggregate purchase price of roughly $30 million.
58492_17_ITEM1_P24_S0	The first was a U.S. manufacturer of aerospace tube assemblies.
58492_17_ITEM1_P24_S1	This business further expands our tube forming and fabrication capabilities, and also adds precision machining to our aerospace platform.
58492_17_ITEM1_P24_S2	We also acquired a distributor of geo-synthetic products and a South African producer of mattress innersprings.
58492_17_ITEM1_P25_S0	In addition to these acquisitions, we purchased the remaining interest in an Automotive joint venture in China for $35 million.
58492_17_ITEM1_P25_S1	This business manufactures seat comfort products and lumbar support systems.
58492_17_ITEM1_P26_S0	We acquired a 70% interest in a European private-label manufacturer of high-end upholstered furniture.
58492_17_ITEM1_P26_S1	This business is complementary to our North American private-label operation and allows us to support our Work Furniture customers as they expand globally.
58492_17_ITEM1_P26_S2	The initial cash outlay for the 70% interest was $12 million and, per the terms of the agreement, we will acquire the remaining 30% in two equal parts, in 2018 and 2020.
58492_17_ITEM1_P26_S3	We have recorded a long-term liability of approximately $11 million for these future payments.
58492_17_ITEM1_P26_S4	The recorded liability is based upon estimates and may fluctuate significantly until the payment dates.
58492_17_ITEM1_P27_S0	We acquired Tempur Sealy's three U.S. innerspring production facilities for a purchase price of $45 million.
58492_17_ITEM1_P27_S1	This additional volume enhanced our economies of scale, benefited from our vertical integration in steel rod and wire, and allowed manufacturing optimization across a broad asset base.
58492_17_ITEM1_P28_S0	We also acquired a German designer and distributor of high-end, European-style motion furniture components for a purchase price of $17 million.
58492_17_ITEM1_P28_S1	This business allows us to meet varying design preferences and broadens the range of our furniture component products.
58492_17_ITEM1_P29_S0	For more information regarding our acquisitions, please refer to Note Q on page 111 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.

58492_17_ITEM1A_P0_S0	Investing in our securities involves risk.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P0_S1	Set forth below and elsewhere in this report are risk factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from the results contemplated by the forward-looking statements contained in this report.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P0_S2	We may amend or supplement these risk factors from time to time by other reports we file with the SEC.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Costs of raw materials could negatively affect our profit margins and earnings.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P2_S0	Raw material cost increases (and our ability to respond to cost increases through selling price increases) can significantly impact our earnings.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P2_S1	We typically have short-term commitments from our suppliers; therefore, our raw material costs generally move with the market.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P2_S2	When we experience significant increases in raw material costs, we typically implement price increases to recover the higher costs.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P2_S3	Inability to recover cost increases (or a delay in the recovery time) can negatively impact our earnings.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P2_S4	Conversely, if raw material costs decrease, we generally pass through reduced selling prices to our customers.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P2_S5	Reduced selling prices combined with higher cost inventory can reduce our segment margins and earnings.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P3_S0	Steel is our principal raw material.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P3_S1	The global steel markets are cyclical in nature and have been volatile in recent years.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P3_S2	This volatility can result in large swings in pricing and margins from year to year.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P3_S3	Our operations can also be impacted by changes in the cost of fabrics and foam scrap.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P3_S4	We experienced significant fluctuations in the cost of these commodities in past years.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P4_S0	As a producer of steel rod, we are also impacted by volatility in metal margins (the difference between the cost of steel scrap and the market price for steel rod).
58492_17_ITEM1A_P4_S1	If market conditions cause scrap costs and rod pricing to change at different rates (both in terms of timing and amount), metal margins could be compressed and this would negatively impact our results of operations.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P5_S0	Higher raw material costs in past years led some of our customers to modify their product designs, changing the quantity and mix of our components in their finished goods.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P5_S1	In some cases, higher cost components were replaced with lower cost components.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P5_S2	This primarily impacted our Residential Furnishings product mix and decreased profit margins.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P5_S3	If this was to occur again it could negatively impact our results of operations.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P6_S0	Competition could adversely affect our market share, sales, profit margins and earnings.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P7_S0	We operate in markets that are highly competitive.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P7_S1	We believe that most companies in our lines of business compete primarily on price, but, depending upon the particular product, we experience competition based on quality and performance.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P7_S2	We face ongoing pressure from foreign competitors as some of our customers source a portion of their components and finished products from Asia and Europe.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P7_S3	In addition to lower labor rates, foreign competitors benefit (at times) from lower raw material costs.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P7_S4	They may also benefit from currency factors and more lenient regulatory climates.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P8_S0	If we are unable to purchase key raw materials, such as steel, at prices competitive with those of foreign suppliers, our ability to maintain market share and profit margins could be harmed by foreign competitors.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P9_S0	We are exposed to litigation contingencies that, if realized, could have a material negative impact on our financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P9_S1	Although we deny liability in all currently threatened or pending litigation proceedings and believe that we have valid bases to contest all claims made against us, we have, at December 31, 2016, an aggregate litigation contingency accrual of $3 million.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P9_S2	Based on current facts and circumstances, aggregate reasonably possible (but not probable) losses in excess of the recorded accruals for litigation contingencies (which include Brazilian VAT and other matters) are estimated to be $26 million.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P9_S3	If our assumptions or analysis regarding these contingencies is incorrect, or if facts and circumstances change, we could realize loss in excess of the recorded accruals (and in excess of the $26 million referenced above) which could have a material negative impact on our financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P9_S4	For more information regarding our legal contingencies, see Note S on page 115 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P10_S0	We are exposed to foreign currency risk which may negatively impact our competitiveness, profit margins and earnings.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P11_S0	We expect that international sales will continue to represent a significant percentage of our total sales, which exposes us to currency exchange rate fluctuations.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P11_S1	In 2016, 34% of our sales were generated by international operations.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P11_S2	The revenues and expenses of our foreign operations are generally denominated in local currencies; however, certain of our operations experience currency-related gains and losses where sales or purchases are denominated in currencies other than their local currency.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P11_S3	Further, our competitive position may be affected by the relative strength of the currencies in countries where our products are sold.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P11_S4	Foreign currency exchange risks inherent in doing business in foreign countries may have a material adverse effect on our future operations and financial results.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P12_S0	Our goodwill and other long-lived assets are subject to potential impairment which could negatively impact our earnings.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P13_S0	A significant portion of our assets consists of goodwill and other long-lived assets, the carrying value of which may be reduced if we determine that those assets are impaired.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P13_S1	At December 31, 2016, goodwill and other intangible assets represented $956 million, or 32% of our total assets.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P13_S2	In addition, net property, plant and equipment and sundry assets totaled $703 million, or 24% of total assets.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P14_S0	If actual results differ from the assumptions and estimates used in the goodwill and long-lived asset valuation calculations, we could incur impairment charges, which could negatively impact our earnings.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P15_S0	We review our reporting units for potential goodwill impairment in June as part of our annual goodwill impairment testing, and more often if an event or circumstance occurs making it likely that impairment exists.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P15_S1	In addition, we test for the recoverability of long-lived assets at year end, and more often if an event or circumstance indicates the carrying value may not be recoverable.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P15_S2	We conduct impairment testing based on our current business strategy in light of present industry and economic conditions, as well as future expectations.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P15_S3	If we are not able to achieve projected performance levels, future impairments could be possible, which would negatively impact our earnings.

58492_17_ITEM1A_P22_S0	We have exposure to economic and other factors that affect market demand for our products which may negatively impact our sales, operating cash flow and earnings.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P23_S0	As a supplier of products to a variety of industries, we are adversely affected by general economic downturns.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P23_S1	Our operating performance is heavily influenced by market demand for our components and products.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P23_S2	Market demand for the majority of our products is most heavily influenced by consumer confidence.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P23_S3	To a lesser extent, market demand is impacted by other broad economic factors, including disposable income levels, employment levels, housing turnover and interest rates.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P23_S4	All of these factors influence consumer spending on durable goods, and drive demand for our components and products.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P23_S5	Some of these factors also influence business spending on facilities and equipment, which impacts approximately one-quarter of our sales.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P24_S0	Demand weakness in our markets can lead to lower unit orders, sales and earnings in our businesses.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P25_S0	Several factors, including a weak global economy, low consumer confidence, or a depressed housing market could contribute to conservative spending habits by consumers around the world.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P26_S0	Short lead times in most of our markets allow for limited visibility into demand trends.
58492_17_ITEM1A_P26_S1	If economic and market conditions deteriorate, we may experience material negative impacts on our business, financial condition, operating cash flows and results of operations.

58492_17_ITEM3_P0_S0	The information in Note S beginning on page 115 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements is incorporated into this section by reference.
58492_17_ITEM3_P1_S0	On March 27, 2013, Region 5 of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) issued a Notice of Violation/Finding of Violation ("NOV/FOV") alleging that our subsidiary, Sterling Steel Company, violated the Clean Air Act and the Illinois State Implementation Plan currently in place.
58492_17_ITEM3_P2_S0	Sterling operates a steel rod mill in Sterling, Illinois.
58492_17_ITEM3_P2_S1	The NOV/FOV alleges that Sterling, since 2008, has exceeded the allowable annual particulate matter and manganese emission limits for its arc furnace.
58492_17_ITEM3_P2_S2	Sterling requested a conference with the EPA to discuss the alleged violations.
58492_17_ITEM3_P2_S3	The conference was held on May 20, 2013.
58492_17_ITEM3_P3_S0	On July 23, 2013, the EPA issued a Finding of Violation alleging that Sterling violated the opacity limitations of its air permit and Federal and state regulations.
58492_17_ITEM3_P3_S1	A conference to discuss the Finding of Violation occurred in the third quarter of 2013.
58492_17_ITEM3_P4_S0	There had been no material updates with respect to these matters until mid-July 2015 when the Company learned from counsel for the EPA that the matters had been referred to the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ).
58492_17_ITEM3_P4_S1	The Company met with representatives of the EPA and the DOJ on February 2, May 25 and June 15, 2016.
58492_17_ITEM3_P4_S2	At the meetings, the government focused on Sterling's compliance with capture and control efficiency and fugitive emissions with its electric arc furnace.
58492_17_ITEM3_P5_S0	On September 26, 2016, the EPA directed Sterling to perform a ventilation study.
58492_17_ITEM3_P5_S1	Sterling submitted its proposed ventilation study to the EPA on November 15, 2016.
58492_17_ITEM3_P5_S2	On December 28, 2016, the EPA approved the proposed study.
58492_17_ITEM3_P5_S3	We expect to complete the study in the first half of 2017.
58492_17_ITEM3_P5_S4	Sterling intends to vigorously defend these matters in any enforcement action that may be pursued by the EPA or DOJ.
58492_17_ITEM3_P5_S5	Neither the EPA nor DOJ specified any amount of penalty being sought in any proceeding to enforce the NOV/FOV, Finding of Violation or in any conference or meeting.
58492_17_ITEM3_P5_S6	Any settlement or adverse finding could result in the payment by Sterling of fines, penalties, capital expenditures, or some combination thereof.

58492_17_ITEM7_P6_S0	We assess our overall performance by comparing our Total Shareholder Return (TSR) to that of peer companies on a rolling three-year basis.
58492_17_ITEM7_P6_S1	We target TSR in the top third of the S P 500 over the long term.
58492_17_ITEM7_P6_S2	For the three years ended December 31, 2016, we generated TSR in the top 11% of the S P 500.
58492_17_ITEM7_P7_S0	With this top-third TSR goal continuing to be our primary long-term financial objective, in September we revised our TSR framework to place a moderately higher emphasis on disciplined growth and a lesser requirement on further profit margin expansion.
58492_17_ITEM7_P8_S0	These topics are discussed in more detail in the sections that follow.
58492_17_ITEM7_P9_S0	Total Shareholder Return (TSR), relative to peer companies, is the key financial measure that we use to assess long-term performance.
58492_17_ITEM7_P9_S1	TSR is driven by the change in our share price and the dividends we pay: TSR = (Change in Stock Price + Dividends) / Beginning Stock Price.
58492_17_ITEM7_P9_S2	We seek to achieve TSR in the top third of the S P 500 over the long-term through an approach that employs four TSR drivers: revenue growth, margin expansion, dividends, and share repurchases.
58492_17_ITEM7_P10_S0	We monitor our TSR performance relative to the S P 500 on a rolling three-year basis.
58492_17_ITEM7_P10_S1	For the three-year measurement period that ended December 31, 2016, we generated TSR of 20% per year on average, well above the S P 500's 9% annual TSR for that same time period.
58492_17_ITEM7_P10_S2	That performance placed us in the top 11% of the S P 500, achieving our top-third goal.
58492_17_ITEM7_P11_S0	During 2016, we reevaluated our long-standing TSR framework and concluded that a few modifications were appropriate.
58492_17_ITEM7_P11_S1	We moderately increased the expected long-term contribution from revenue growth (to 6-9% per year on average) and reduced the expected benefit from additional EBIT margin increases.
58492_17_ITEM7_P11_S2	The table below shows the components of TSR, including our prior targets and our revised current targets.
58492_17_ITEM7_P11_S3	Accomplishing this level of performance over rolling three-year periods should enable us to consistently attain our top-third TSR goal.
58492_17_ITEM7_P12_S0	We serve a broad suite of customers, with our largest customer representing approximately 7% of our sales.
58492_17_ITEM7_P12_S1	Many are companies whose names are widely recognized.
58492_17_ITEM7_P12_S2	They include most producers of residential furniture and bedding, automotive and office seating manufacturers, and a variety of other companies.
58492_17_ITEM7_P13_S0	Many factors impact our business, but those that generally have the greatest impact are market demand, raw material cost trends, and competition.
58492_17_ITEM7_P14_S0	Market demand (including product mix) is impacted by several economic factors, with consumer confidence being most significant.
58492_17_ITEM7_P14_S1	Other important factors include disposable income levels, employment levels, housing turnover, and interest rates.
58492_17_ITEM7_P14_S2	All of these factors influence consumer spending on durable goods, and therefore affect demand for our components and products.
58492_17_ITEM7_P14_S3	Some of these factors also influence business spending on facilities and equipment, which impacts approximately 20% of our sales.
58492_17_ITEM7_P15_S0	In many of our businesses, we enjoy a cost advantage from being vertically integrated into steel wire and rod.
58492_17_ITEM7_P15_S1	This is a benefit that our competitors do not have.
58492_17_ITEM7_P15_S2	We also experience favorable purchasing leverage from buying large quantities of raw materials.
58492_17_ITEM7_P15_S3	Still, our costs can vary significantly as market prices for raw materials (many of which are commodities) fluctuate.
58492_17_ITEM7_P16_S0	We typically have short-term commitments from our suppliers; accordingly, our raw material costs generally move with the market.
58492_17_ITEM7_P16_S1	Our ability to recover higher costs (through selling price increases) is crucial.
58492_17_ITEM7_P16_S2	When we experience significant increases in raw material costs, we typically implement price increases to recover the higher costs.
58492_17_ITEM7_P16_S3	Conversely, when costs decrease significantly, we generally pass those lower costs through to our customers.
58492_17_ITEM7_P16_S4	The timing of our price increases or decreases is important; we typically experience a lag in recovering higher costs, and we also realize a lag as costs decline.
58492_17_ITEM7_P17_S0	Steel is our principal raw material.
58492_17_ITEM7_P17_S1	At various times in past years we have experienced significant cost fluctuations in this commodity.
58492_17_ITEM7_P17_S2	In most cases, the major changes (both increases and decreases) were passed through to customers with selling price adjustments.
58492_17_ITEM7_P18_S0	Throughout 2015, market prices for steel scrap, rod, and flat-rolled products decreased significantly, leading to downward pressure on selling prices.
58492_17_ITEM7_P18_S1	We realized a beneficial pricing lag during 2015, as costs generally decreased at a faster rate than selling prices.
58492_17_ITEM7_P18_S2	In 2016, steel costs have once again become volatile.
58492_17_ITEM7_P18_S3	Steel inflation during the first half of the year was followed by deflation in the third quarter, and significant inflation late in the year.
58492_17_ITEM7_P18_S4	With the normal lag in selling price increases, this cost inflation led to margin pressure in the fourth quarter.
58492_17_ITEM7_P18_S5	We are implementing price increases in early 2017 to begin recovering the higher costs.
58492_17_ITEM7_P19_S0	As a producer of steel rod, we are also impacted by changes in metal margins (the difference between the cost of steel scrap and the market price for steel rod).
58492_17_ITEM7_P19_S1	Metal margins within the steel industry have been volatile in past years and were moderately compressed in late 2016.
58492_17_ITEM7_P20_S0	Our other raw materials include woven and non-woven fabrics, foam scrap, and chemicals.
58492_17_ITEM7_P20_S1	We have experienced changes in the cost of these materials in past years and generally have been able to pass them through to our customers.
58492_17_ITEM7_P21_S0	When we raise our prices to recover higher raw material costs, this sometimes causes customers to modify their product designs and replace higher cost components with lower cost components.
58492_17_ITEM7_P21_S1	We must continue providing product options to our customers that enable them to improve the functionality of their products and manage their costs, while providing higher profits for our operations.
58492_17_ITEM7_P22_S0	Many of our markets are highly competitive, with the number of competitors varying by product line.
58492_17_ITEM7_P22_S1	In general, our competitors tend to be smaller, private companies.
58492_17_ITEM7_P22_S2	Many of our competitors, both domestic and foreign, compete primarily on the basis of price.
58492_17_ITEM7_P22_S3	Our success has stemmed from the ability to remain price competitive, while delivering innovation, better product quality, and customer service.
58492_17_ITEM7_P23_S0	We continue to face pressure from foreign competitors as some of our customers source a portion of their components and finished products offshore.
58492_17_ITEM7_P23_S1	In addition to lower labor rates, foreign competitors benefit (at times) from lower raw material costs.
58492_17_ITEM7_P23_S2	They may also benefit from currency factors and more lenient regulatory climates.
58492_17_ITEM7_P24_S0	We typically remain price competitive, even versus many foreign manufacturers, as a result of our highly efficient operations, low labor content, vertical integration in steel and wire, logistics and distribution efficiencies, and large scale purchasing of raw materials and commodities.
58492_17_ITEM7_P24_S1	However, we have also reacted to foreign competition in certain cases by selectively adjusting prices, and by developing new proprietary products that help our customers reduce total costs.
58492_17_ITEM7_P25_S0	Since 2009, there have been antidumping duty orders on innerspring imports from China, South Africa and Vietnam, ranging from 116% to 234%.
58492_17_ITEM7_P25_S1	In March 2014, the Department of Commerce (DOC) and the International Trade Commission (ITC) determined that the duties should be continued.
58492_17_ITEM7_P25_S2	In April 2014, the DOC published its final order continuing the duties through February 2019 (for China) and December 2018 (for South Africa and Vietnam).
58492_17_ITEM7_P26_S0	An antidumping and countervailing duty case filed in January 2014 by major U.S. steel wire rod producers was concluded in December 2014, resulting in the imposition of duties on imports of Chinese steel wire rod.
58492_17_ITEM7_P26_S1	The antidumping duties range from 106% to 110% and the countervailing duties range from 178% to 193%.
58492_17_ITEM7_P26_S2	Both remain in effect through December 2019.
58492_17_ITEM7_P27_S0	Because of the documented evasion of antidumping orders by certain importers, typically shipping goods through third countries and falsely identifying the countries of origin, Leggett and several other U.S. manufacturers formed a coalition to seek stronger enforcement of existing antidumping and/or countervailing duty orders.
58492_17_ITEM7_P27_S1	As a result of these efforts, the U.S. Congress passed the Enforcing Orders and Reducing Customs Evasion (ENFORCE) Act.
58492_17_ITEM7_P27_S2	The ENFORCE Act requires U.S. Customs and Border Protection to implement a transparent, time-limited process to investigate allegations of duty evasion and to assess duties where appropriate.
58492_17_ITEM7_P28_S0	We previously disclosed that we were a plaintiff in an antitrust case against The Dow Chemical Company.
58492_17_ITEM7_P28_S1	We, along with other plaintiffs, alleged that several defendants conspired to fix prices and allocate customers and markets for certain urethane chemical products.
58492_17_ITEM7_P28_S2	We reached a settlement for our antitrust claims against The Dow Chemical Company in 2016 by agreeing to release our claims regarding this matter for a net cash payment of approximately $38 million (pretax, after deducting expenses).
58492_17_ITEM7_P28_S3	We received payment in 2016 and recorded after-tax income of $25 million.
58492_17_ITEM7_P28_S4	Because the settlement is largely attributable to our former Prime Foam Products business, $20 million was reflected in discontinued operations.

58492_17_ITEM7_P38_S0	All of our segments use the first-in, first-out (FIFO) method for valuing inventory.
58492_17_ITEM7_P38_S1	In our consolidated financials, an adjustment is made at the corporate level (i.e., outside the segments) to convert about 50% of our inventories to the last-in, first-out (LIFO) method.
58492_17_ITEM7_P38_S2	These are primarily our domestic, steel-related inventories.
58492_17_ITEM7_P38_S3	In 2016, increasing steel costs, particularly in the fourth quarter, resulted in a full-year pretax LIFO expense of $11 million.
58492_17_ITEM7_P38_S4	In 2015, significant deflation in steel costs, particularly in the fourth quarter, resulted in a full-year pretax LIFO benefit of $46 million.

58492_17_ITEM7_P40_S0	Net interest expense in 2016 decreased slightly due to the repayment of a $200 million 5% note in August 2015.
58492_17_ITEM7_P41_S0	Our tax rate is determined by a combination of items, some recurring and some discrete.
58492_17_ITEM7_P41_S1	Recurring items include things like income earned in various tax jurisdictions, and differences in tax rates in those jurisdictions.
58492_17_ITEM7_P41_S2	These items tend to be relatively stable from year to year.
58492_17_ITEM7_P41_S3	Conversely, discrete items are things that may not be as consistent from year to year.
58492_17_ITEM7_P42_S0	While the U.S. statutory federal income tax rate was 35% in both years, our worldwide effective income tax rate on continuing operations was 25% in 2016, compared to 27% for 2015.
58492_17_ITEM7_P42_S1	In both years our tax rate benefited from earnings in non-U.S. jurisdictions, which reduced our effective tax rate by 6% in each year.
58492_17_ITEM7_P42_S2	In addition, the 2016 tax rate benefited by 3% related to the tax effects of stock-based compensation deductions in the year, and 1% (net) from other items.
58492_17_ITEM7_P42_S3	The 2015 tax rate benefited by 1% related to the reduction of a tax accrual for Chinese earnings that we decided to reinvest within China to acquire the remaining interest in a joint venture and 1% (net) from other items.
58492_17_ITEM7_P43_S0	In the first quarter of 2016 we adopted Accounting Standards Update (ASU) 2016-09, Improvements to Employee Share-Based Payment Accounting (see Note A to the Consolidated Financial Statements on page 79).
58492_17_ITEM7_P43_S1	This ASU provides that the tax effects of stock-based awards must be treated as discrete items affecting the tax rate in the interim reporting period in which the tax deductions occur.
58492_17_ITEM7_P43_S2	Many variables (such as timing of award settlements or expirations, changes in stock price over time, ultimate payout levels for awards with performance contingencies, shares cancelled before vesting, and the tax rules in effect at the time of settlement) will impact both the timing and the amount of the tax deductions.
58492_17_ITEM7_P43_S3	Thus, this ASU is likely to add more volatility to the effective tax rate of companies such as Leggett that use stock-based compensation plans.

58492_17_ITEM7_P66_S0	Our tax rate is determined by a combination of items, some recurring and some discrete.
58492_17_ITEM7_P66_S1	Recurring items include things like income earned in various tax jurisdictions, and differences in tax rates in those jurisdictions.
58492_17_ITEM7_P66_S2	These items tend to be relatively stable from year to year.
58492_17_ITEM7_P66_S3	Conversely, discrete items are things that may not be as consistent from year to year.

58492_17_ITEM7_P91_S0	We eliminate cash and current debt maturities from working capital to monitor our operating efficiency and performance related to trade receivables, total inventories, and accounts payable.
58492_17_ITEM7_P91_S1	We believe this provides a more useful measurement to investors since cash and current maturities can fluctuate significantly from period to period.

58492_17_ITEM7_P94_S0	Calculations of days are as follows: 1.
58492_17_ITEM7_P94_S1	Days sales outstanding: ((beginning of year trade receivables + end of year trade receivables) 2) (net trade sales number of days in the year).
58492_17_ITEM7_P94_S2	2. Days inventory on hand: ((beginning of year trade inventory + end of year inventory) 2) (cost of goods sold number of days in the year).
58492_17_ITEM7_P94_S3	Days payables outstanding: ((beginning of year accounts payable + end of year accounts payable) 2) (cost of goods sold number of days in the year).
58492_17_ITEM7_P95_S0	Trade Receivables - Our net trade receivables and our days sales outstanding at December 31, 2016 did not meaningfully change compared to the prior year.
58492_17_ITEM7_P95_S1	We continue to look for ways to improve speed of customer payments, including third party programs with early payment incentives in certain circumstances.
58492_17_ITEM7_P95_S2	We obtain credit applications, credit reports, bank and trade references, and periodic financial statements from our customers to establish credit limits and terms.
58492_17_ITEM7_P95_S3	In cases where a customer s payment performance or financial condition begins to deteriorate, we tighten our credit limits and terms and make appropriate reserves.
58492_17_ITEM7_P95_S4	Our provision for losses on accounts receivable has averaged $3 million and our allowance for bad debt as a percentage of our net receivables has averaged 2% for the last three years.
58492_17_ITEM7_P96_S0	Days inventory on hand of 66 days at the end of 2016 is within a reasonable historical range, and we believe the increase compared to the prior year does not indicate a greater risk of inventory obsolescence.
58492_17_ITEM7_P96_S1	We continuously monitor our slow moving and potentially obsolete inventory through reports on inventory quantities compared to usage within the previous 120 days.
58492_17_ITEM7_P96_S2	We also utilize cycle counting programs and complete physical counts of our inventory.
58492_17_ITEM7_P96_S3	When potential inventory obsolescence is indicated by these controls, we will take charges for write-downs to maintain an adequate level of reserves.
58492_17_ITEM7_P96_S4	We have averaged inventory obsolescence charges of $10 million annually for the last three years.
58492_17_ITEM7_P96_S5	Our reserve balances (not including our LIFO reserves) as a percentage of our year-end inventory were 6.4% at the end of 2016, which is consistent with our historical average.
