58492_17_ITEM7_P133_S2	Other obligations also include our current estimate of minimum contributions to defined benefit pension plans.
58492_17_ITEM7_P134_S0	We prepare our consolidated financial statements in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
58492_17_ITEM7_P134_S1	To do so, we must make estimates and judgments that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues, expenses, and disclosures.
58492_17_ITEM7_P134_S2	If we used different estimates or judgments our financial statements would change, and some of those changes could be significant.
58492_17_ITEM7_P134_S3	Our estimates are frequently based upon historical experience and are considered by management, at the time they are made, to be reasonable and appropriate.
58492_17_ITEM7_P135_S0	Estimates are adjusted for actual events, as they occur.
58492_17_ITEM7_P136_S0	Critical accounting estimates are those that are: a) subject to uncertainty and change, and b) of material impact to our financial statements.
58492_17_ITEM7_P136_S1	Listed below are the estimates and judgments which we believe could have the most significant effect on our financial statements.
58492_17_ITEM7_P137_S0	We provide additional details regarding our significant accounting policies in Note A to the Consolidated Financial Statements on page 75.
58492_17_ITEM7_P138_S0	Goodwill is assessed for impairment annually as of June 30 and as triggering events occur.
58492_17_ITEM7_P139_S0	In the second quarter of 2016, we sold one of our two remaining Commercial Vehicle Products (CVP) businesses, and real estate associated with the remaining CVP business reached held for sale status.
58492_17_ITEM7_P139_S1	As a result of these two events, the fair value of the CVP reporting unit had fallen below it's book value, and we fully impaired the remaining $4 million of goodwill for this reporting unit in the second quarter of 2016.
58492_17_ITEM7_P140_S0	During 2015, the Steel Tubing unit met the held for sale criteria.
58492_17_ITEM7_P140_S1	Because fair value less cost to sell had fallen below recorded book value, we fully impaired this unit's goodwill and incurred a non-cash charge of $4 million.
58492_17_ITEM7_P141_S0	In 2014, we concluded that an impairment was required related to the goodwill of the Store Fixtures group, which was formerly part of the Commercial Products segment and is now reported in discontinued operations.
58492_17_ITEM7_P141_S1	A non-cash charge of $108 million was recorded for the complete write-off of the goodwill associated with this business.
58492_17_ITEM7_P142_S0	Goodwill is evaluated annually for impairment as of June 30 using either a quantitative or qualitative analysis at the reporting unit level, which is one level below our operating segments.
58492_17_ITEM7_P142_S1	We begin with a qualitative assessment of whether it is more likely than not that a reporting unit's fair value is less than its carrying value before applying the two step goodwill impairment model.
58492_17_ITEM7_P142_S2	Judgment is required in the two step model to estimate fair value for the reporting unit.
58492_17_ITEM7_P143_S0	We estimate fair value using a combination of a discounted cash flow model and a market approach using price to earnings ratios for comparable publicly traded companies with characteristics similar to the reporting unit.
58492_17_ITEM7_P144_S0	The cash flow model contains uncertainties related to the forecast of future results as many outside economic and competitive factors can influence future performance.
58492_17_ITEM7_P144_S1	Margins, sales growth, and discount rates are the most critical estimates in determining enterprise values using the cash flow model.
58492_17_ITEM7_P145_S0	The market approach requires judgment to determine the appropriate price to earnings ratio.
58492_17_ITEM7_P146_S0	Ratios are derived from comparable publicly-traded companies that operate in the same or similar industry as the reporting unit.
58492_17_ITEM7_P147_S0	The June 2016 qualitative review indicated it was more likely than not that the fair value of the reporting units exceeded their carrying amount, except for our CVP reporting unit.
58492_17_ITEM7_P148_S0	Information regarding material assumptions used to determine if a goodwill impairment exists can be found in Note C to the Consolidated Financial Statements on page 83.
58492_17_ITEM7_P149_S0	At December 31, 2016, we had $791 million of goodwill.
58492_17_ITEM7_P150_S0	We conduct impairment testing based on our current business strategy in light of present industry and economic conditions, as well as future expectations.
58492_17_ITEM7_P150_S1	If we are not able to achieve projected performance levels, future impairments could be possible.
58492_17_ITEM7_P151_S0	Other long-lived assets are tested for recoverability at year-end and whenever events or circumstances indicate the carrying value may not be recoverable.
58492_17_ITEM7_P152_S0	For other long-lived assets we estimate fair value at the lowest level where cash flows can be measured (usually at a branch level).
58492_17_ITEM7_P153_S0	Impairments of other long-lived assets usually occur when major restructuring activities take place, or we decide to discontinue product lines completely.
58492_17_ITEM7_P154_S0	Our impairment assessments have uncertainties because they require estimates of future cash flows to determine if undiscounted cash flows are sufficient to recover carrying values of these assets.
58492_17_ITEM7_P155_S0	For assets where future cash flows are not expected to recover carrying value, fair value is estimated which requires an estimate of market value based upon asset appraisals for like assets.
58492_17_ITEM7_P156_S0	Impairments averaged less than $2 million per year over the last three years.
58492_17_ITEM7_P157_S0	At December 31, 2016, net property, plant and equipment was $566 million and net intangible assets other than goodwill was $165 million.
58492_17_ITEM7_P158_S0	We reduce the carrying value of inventories to reflect an estimate of net realizable value for obsolete and slow-moving inventory.
58492_17_ITEM7_P159_S0	We value inventory at net realizable value (what we think we will recover).
58492_17_ITEM7_P159_S1	Generally a reserve is not required unless we have more than a one-year's supply of the product.
58492_17_ITEM7_P159_S2	If we have had no sales of a given product for 12 months, those items are generally deemed to have no value and are written down completely.
58492_17_ITEM7_P160_S0	Our inventory reserve contains uncertainties because the calculation requires management to make assumptions about the value of products that are obsolete or slow-moving (i.e., not selling very quickly).
58492_17_ITEM7_P161_S0	Changes in customer behavior and requirements can cause inventory to quickly become obsolete or slow moving.
58492_17_ITEM7_P162_S0	The calculation also uses an estimate of the ultimate recoverability of items identified as slow moving based upon historical experience (65% on average).
58492_17_ITEM7_P163_S0	At December 31, 2016, the reserve for obsolete and slow-moving inventory was $33 million (approximately 6% of FIFO inventories).
58492_17_ITEM7_P163_S1	This is consistent with the December 31, 2015 and 2014 reserves of $33 million and $30 million, respectively, representing 6% of FIFO inventories.
58492_17_ITEM7_P164_S0	Additions to inventory reserves in 2016 were $9 million, which were comparable to the previous year.
58492_17_ITEM7_P164_S1	We do not expect obsolescence to change from current levels.
58492_17_ITEM7_P165_S0	We are substantially self-insured for costs related to workers compensation, and this requires us to estimate the liability associated with this obligation.
58492_17_ITEM7_P166_S0	Our estimates of self-insured reserves contain uncertainties regarding the potential amounts we might have to pay (since we are self-insured).
58492_17_ITEM7_P166_S1	We consider a number of factors, including historical claim experience, demographic factors, and potential recoveries from third party insurance carriers.
58492_17_ITEM7_P167_S0	Over the past five years, we have incurred, on average, $8 million annually for costs associated with workers compensation.
58492_17_ITEM7_P167_S1	Average year-to-year variation over the past five years has been approximately $1 million.
58492_17_ITEM7_P167_S2	At December 31, 2016, we had accrued $34 million to cover future self-insurance liabilities.
58492_17_ITEM7_P168_S0	Internal safety statistics and cost trends have improved in the last several years and are expected to remain at current lower levels for the foreseeable future.
58492_17_ITEM7_P169_S0	For accounts and notes receivable, we estimate a bad debt reserve for the amount that will ultimately be uncollectible.
58492_17_ITEM7_P170_S0	When we become aware of a specific customer s potential inability to pay, we record a bad debt reserve for the amount we believe may not be collectible.
58492_17_ITEM7_P171_S0	Our bad debt reserve contains uncertainties because it requires management to estimate the amount uncollectible based upon an evaluation of several factors such as the length of time that receivables are past due, the financial health of the customer, industry and macroeconomic considerations, and historical loss experience.
58492_17_ITEM7_P172_S0	Our customers are diverse and many are small-to-medium sized companies, with some being highly leveraged.
58492_17_ITEM7_P172_S1	Bankruptcy can occur with some of these customers relatively quickly and with little warning.
58492_17_ITEM7_P173_S0	A significant change in the financial status of a large customer could impact our estimates.
58492_17_ITEM7_P174_S0	The average annual amount of customer-related bad debt expense was $3 million (significantly less than 1% of annual net sales) over the last three years.
58492_17_ITEM7_P174_S1	At December 31, 2016, our allowances for doubtful accounts were less than $8 million (about 2% of our trade accounts and notes receivable of $458 million).
58492_17_ITEM7_P175_S0	We have not experienced any significant individual customer bankruptcies in the past three years.
58492_17_ITEM7_P175_S1	We believe the financial health of our major customers has modestly improved, but some are highly leveraged, and this could cause circumstances to change in the future.
58492_17_ITEM7_P176_S0	For our pension plans, we must estimate the cost of benefits to be provided (well into the future) and the current value of those benefit obligations.
58492_17_ITEM7_P177_S0	The pension liability calculation contains uncertainties because it requires management to estimate an appropriate discount rate to calculate the present value of future benefits paid, which also impacts current year pension expense.
58492_17_ITEM7_P178_S0	Determination of pension expense requires an estimate of expected return on pension assets based upon the mix of investments held (bonds and equities).
58492_17_ITEM7_P178_S1	Other assumptions include rates of compensation increases, withdrawal and mortality rates, and retirement ages.
58492_17_ITEM7_P178_S2	These estimates impact the pension expense or income we recognize and our reported benefit obligations.
58492_17_ITEM7_P179_S0	Each 25 basis point decrease in the discount rate increases pension expense by $.5 million and increases the plans benefit obligation by $9 million.
58492_17_ITEM7_P179_S1	A 25 basis point reduction in the expected return on assets would increase pension expense by $.4 million, but have no effect on the plans funded status.
58492_17_ITEM7_P180_S0	Assuming a long-term investment horizon, we do not expect a material change to the return on asset assumption.
58492_17_ITEM7_P181_S0	Mortality assumptions represent our best estimate of the duration of future benefit payments at the measurement date.
58492_17_ITEM7_P181_S1	These estimates are based on each plans' demographics and other relevant facts and circumstances.
58492_17_ITEM7_P181_S2	Longer life expectancies increased our pension liability for our most significant plans by approximately $20 million in 2014.
58492_17_ITEM7_P182_S0	We evaluate various legal, environmental, and other potential claims against us to determine if an accrual or disclosure of the contingency is appropriate.
58492_17_ITEM7_P182_S1	If it is probable that an ultimate loss will be incurred, we accrue a liability for the reasonable estimate of the ultimate loss.
58492_17_ITEM7_P183_S0	Our disclosure and accrual of loss contingencies (i.e., losses that may or may not occur) contain uncertainties because they are based on our assessment of the likelihood that the expenses will actually occur, and our reasonable estimate of the likely cost.
58492_17_ITEM7_P183_S1	Our estimates and judgments are subjective and can involve matters in litigation, the results of which are generally unpredictable.
58492_17_ITEM7_P184_S0	Legal contingencies are related to numerous lawsuits and claims described in Note S to the Consolidated Financial Statements on page 115.
58492_17_ITEM7_P185_S0	During the three year period ended December 31, 2016, we recorded accruals of $108 million ($70 million for continuing operations and $38 million in discontinued operations).
58492_17_ITEM7_P185_S1	A large percentage of these accruals related to a series of antitrust lawsuits involving the sale of polyurethane foam as discussed in Note S to the Consolidated Financial Statements.
58492_17_ITEM7_P185_S2	During 2015, we fully resolved the substantial majority of these cases for amounts not materially different than the amounts originally accrued.
58492_17_ITEM7_P185_S3	Additional details of the 2015 settlements can be found in Note T - Contingencies to the consolidated financial statements in our 2015 Form 10-K filed February 25, 2016.
58492_17_ITEM7_P186_S0	With the exception of antitrust matters, our largest annual accrual for litigation claims was $6 million for the five years ending December 31, 2016 (excluding legal fees).
58492_17_ITEM7_P187_S0	In the ordinary course of business, we must make estimates of the tax treatment of many transactions, even though the ultimate tax outcome may remain uncertain for some time.
58492_17_ITEM7_P187_S1	These estimates become part of the annual income tax expense reported in our financial statements.
58492_17_ITEM7_P187_S2	Subsequent to year end, we finalize our tax analysis and file income tax returns.
58492_17_ITEM7_P187_S3	Tax authorities periodically audit these income tax returns and examine our tax filing positions, including (among other things) the timing and amounts of deductions, and the allocation of income among tax jurisdictions.
58492_17_ITEM7_P187_S4	If necessary, we adjust income tax expense in our financial statements in the periods in which the actual outcome becomes more certain.
58492_17_ITEM7_P188_S0	Our tax liability for unrecognized tax benefits contains uncertainties because management is required to make assumptions and to apply judgment to estimate the exposures related to our various filing positions.
58492_17_ITEM7_P189_S0	Our effective tax rate is also impacted by changes in tax laws, the current mix of earnings by taxing jurisdiction, and the results of current tax audits and assessments.
58492_17_ITEM7_P189_S1	At December 31, 2016 and 2015, we had $26 million and $32 million, respectively, of net deferred tax assets on our balance sheet related to net operating losses and other tax carryforwards.
58492_17_ITEM7_P189_S2	The ultimate realization of these deferred tax assets is dependent upon the amount, source, and timing of future taxable income.
58492_17_ITEM7_P189_S3	In cases where we believe it is more likely than not that we may not realize the future potential tax benefits, we establish a valuation allowance against them.
58492_17_ITEM7_P190_S0	In addition, assumptions have been made regarding the non-repatriation of earnings from certain subsidiaries.
58492_17_ITEM7_P190_S1	Those assumptions may change in the future, thereby affecting future period results for the tax impact of possible repatriation.
58492_17_ITEM7_P191_S0	Changes in tax laws could impact assumptions related to the non-repatriation of certain foreign earnings.
58492_17_ITEM7_P191_S1	If all non-repatriated earnings were taxed at current rates, we would incur additional tax expense of approximately $131 million.
58492_17_ITEM7_P192_S0	Audits by various taxing authorities continue as governments look for ways to raise additional revenue.
58492_17_ITEM7_P192_S1	Based upon past audit experience, we do not expect any material changes to our tax liability as a result of this audit activity; however, we could incur additional tax expense if we have audit adjustments higher than recent historical experience.
58492_17_ITEM7_P193_S0	The likelihood of recovery of net operating losses and other tax carryforwards has been closely evaluated and is based upon such factors as the time remaining before expiration, viable tax planning strategies, and future taxable earnings expectations.
58492_17_ITEM7_P193_S1	We believe that appropriate valuation allowances have been recorded as necessary.
58492_17_ITEM7_P193_S2	However, if earnings expectations or other assumptions change such that additional valuation allowances are required, we could incur additional tax expense.
58492_17_ITEM7_P193_S3	Likewise, if fewer valuation allowances are needed, we could incur reduced tax expense.

58492_17_ITEM10_P0_S0	The subsections entitled Proposal 1 Election of Directors, Corporate Governance, Board and Committee Composition and Meetings, Consideration of Director Nominees and Diversity, Section 16(a) Beneficial Ownership Reporting Compliance and Director Independence in the Company s definitive Proxy Statement for the Company s Annual Meeting of Shareholders to be held on May 9, 2017, are incorporated by reference.
58492_17_ITEM10_P1_S0	Directors are normally elected annually at the Annual Meeting of Shareholders and hold office until the next annual meeting of shareholders or until their successors are elected and qualified.
58492_17_ITEM10_P1_S1	All current directors have been nominated for re-election at the Company s Annual Meeting of Shareholders to be held May 9, 2017.
58492_17_ITEM10_P1_S2	In order to be nominated for election as a director, a nominee must submit a contingent resignation to the Nominating Corporate Governance Committee (N CG Committee).
58492_17_ITEM10_P1_S3	The resignation will become effective only if (i) the director nominee fails to receive an affirmative majority of the votes cast in the director election; and (ii) the Board accepts the resignation.
58492_17_ITEM10_P1_S4	If a nominee fails to receive an affirmative majority of the votes cast in the director election, the N CG Committee will make a recommendation to the Board of Directors whether to accept or reject the director s resignation and whether any other action should be taken.
58492_17_ITEM10_P1_S5	If a director s resignation is not accepted, that director will continue to serve until the Company s next annual meeting or until his or her successor is duly elected and qualified.
58492_17_ITEM10_P1_S6	If the Board accepts the director s resignation, it may, in its sole discretion, either fill the resulting vacancy or decrease the size of the Board to eliminate the vacancy.
58492_17_ITEM10_P1_S7	The Company s Bylaws and Corporate Governance Guidelines set the director retirement age at 72; however, the Board Chair, the Lead Director, CEO or President may request a waiver for any director.
58492_17_ITEM10_P1_S8	At the request of Leggett s CEO, the N CG Committee recommended, and the full Board granted, a retirement age waiver for R. Ted Enloe, III so he may stand for re-election at the 2017 annual meeting.

58492_17_ITEM15_P5_S0	Management of Leggett Platt, Incorporated is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting as defined in Exchange Act Rule 13a-15(f).
58492_17_ITEM15_P5_S1	Leggett Platt s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
58492_17_ITEM15_P5_S2	The Company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that:
58492_17_ITEM15_P6_S0	Provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use or disposition of Leggett Platt assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
58492_17_ITEM15_P7_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
58492_17_ITEM15_P7_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
58492_17_ITEM15_P8_S0	Under the supervision and with the participation of management (including ourselves), we conducted an evaluation of the effectiveness of Leggett Platt s internal control over financial reporting, as of December 31, 2016 , based on the criteria in Internal Control Integrated Framework (2013) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.
58492_17_ITEM15_P8_S1	Based on the evaluation under this framework, we concluded that Leggett Platt s internal control over financial reporting was effective as of December 31, 2016 .

58492_17_ITEM15_P11_S4	Our responsibility is to express opinions on these financial statements, on the financial statement schedule, and on the Company's internal control over financial reporting based on our integrated audits.
58492_17_ITEM15_P11_S5	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
58492_17_ITEM15_P11_S6	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audits to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement and whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
58492_17_ITEM15_P11_S7	Our audits of the financial statements included examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements, assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, and evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
58492_17_ITEM15_P11_S8	Our audit of internal control over financial reporting included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, and testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk.
58492_17_ITEM15_P11_S9	Our audits also included performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
58492_17_ITEM15_P11_S10	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinions.
58492_17_ITEM15_P12_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
58492_17_ITEM15_P12_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (i) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (ii) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (iii) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
58492_17_ITEM15_P13_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
58492_17_ITEM15_P13_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.

58492_17_ITEM15_P21_S0	ESTIMATES: The preparation of financial statements in conformity with generally accepted accounting principles in the United States of America ("GAAP") requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses and the accrual and disclosure of loss contingencies.
58492_17_ITEM15_P22_S0	CASH EQUIVALENTS: Cash equivalents include cash in excess of daily requirements which is invested in various financial instruments with original maturities of three months or less.
58492_17_ITEM15_P23_S0	TRADE AND OTHER RECEIVABLES AND ALLOWANCE FOR DOUBTFUL ACCOUNTS: Trade receivables are recorded at the invoiced amount and generally do not bear interest.
58492_17_ITEM15_P23_S1	Credit is also occasionally extended in the form of a note receivable to facilitate our customers operating cycles.
58492_17_ITEM15_P23_S2	Other notes receivable are established in special circumstances, such as in partial payment for the sale of a business or to support other business opportunities.
58492_17_ITEM15_P23_S3	Other notes receivable generally bear interest at market rates commensurate with the corresponding credit risk on the date of origination.
58492_17_ITEM15_P24_S0	The allowance for doubtful accounts is an estimate of the amount of probable credit losses.
58492_17_ITEM15_P25_S0	Interest income is not recognized for nonperforming accounts that are placed on nonaccrual status.
58492_17_ITEM15_P26_S0	Allowances and nonaccrual status designations are determined by individual account reviews by management, and are based on several factors such as the length of time that receivables are past due, the financial health of the companies involved, industry and macroeconomic considerations, and historical loss experience.
58492_17_ITEM15_P27_S0	Interest income is recorded on the date of cash receipt for nonaccrual status accounts.
58492_17_ITEM15_P27_S1	Account balances are charged against the allowance when it is probable the receivable will not be recovered.
58492_17_ITEM15_P28_S0	All inventories are stated at the lower of cost or net realizable value.
58492_17_ITEM15_P28_S1	We generally use standard costs which include materials, labor and production overhead at normal production capacity.
58492_17_ITEM15_P28_S2	The cost for approximately 50% of our inventories is determined by the last-in, first-out (LIFO) method and is primarily used to value domestic inventories with raw material content consisting of steel, wire, chemicals and foam scrap.
58492_17_ITEM15_P28_S3	For the remainder of the inventories, we principally use the first-in, first-out (FIFO) method, which is representative of our standard costs.
58492_17_ITEM15_P28_S4	For these inventories, the FIFO cost for the periods presented approximated expected replacement cost.
58492_17_ITEM15_P29_S0	Inventories are reviewed at least quarterly for slow-moving and potentially obsolete items using actual inventory turnover, and if necessary, are written down to estimated net realizable value.
58492_17_ITEM15_P29_S1	We have had no material changes in inventory writedowns or slow-moving and obsolete inventory reserves in any of the years presented.

58492_17_ITEM15_P31_S0	Significant accounting policies associated with a decision to dispose of a business are discussed below:
58492_17_ITEM15_P32_S0	In accordance with Accounting Standards Update (ASU) 2014-08 "Reporting Discontinued Operations and Disclosures of Disposals of Components of an Entity", beginning in 2015, a business is classified as discontinued operations if the disposal represents a strategic shift that will have a major effect on operations or financial results, meets the criteria to be classified as held for sale, or is disposed of by sale or otherwise.
58492_17_ITEM15_P32_S1	For 2014 and previous years, a business was classified as a discontinued operation when (i) the operations and cash flows of the business were clearly distinguished and were eliminated from our ongoing operations; (ii) the business was either disposed of or was classified as held for sale; and (iii) we did not have any significant continuing involvement in the operations of the business after the disposal transactions.
58492_17_ITEM15_P33_S0	Significant judgments are involved in determining whether a business meets the criteria for discontinued operations reporting and the period in which these criteria are met.
58492_17_ITEM15_P34_S0	If a business is reported as a discontinued operation, the results of operations through the date of sale, including any gain or loss recognized on the disposition, are presented on a separate line of the income statement.
58492_17_ITEM15_P34_S1	Interest on debt directly attributable to the discontinued operation is allocated to discontinued operations.
58492_17_ITEM15_P34_S2	Gains and losses related to the sale of businesses that do not meet the discontinued operation criteria are reported in continuing operations and separately disclosed if significant.
58492_17_ITEM15_P35_S0	Assets Held for Sale An asset or business is classified as held for sale when (i) management commits to a plan to sell and it is actively marketed; (ii) it is available for immediate sale and the sale is expected to be completed within one year; and (iii) it is unlikely significant changes to the plan will be made or that the plan will be withdrawn.
58492_17_ITEM15_P35_S1	In isolated instances, assets held for sale may exceed one year due to events or circumstances beyond our control.
58492_17_ITEM15_P36_S0	Upon being classified as held for sale, the recoverability of the carrying value must be assessed.
58492_17_ITEM15_P36_S1	Evaluating the recoverability of the assets of a business classified as held for sale follows a defined order in which property and intangible assets subject to amortization are considered only after the recoverability of goodwill and other assets are assessed.
58492_17_ITEM15_P36_S2	After the valuation process is completed, the assets held for sale are reported at the lower of the carrying value or fair value less cost to sell, and the assets are no longer depreciated or amortized.
58492_17_ITEM15_P36_S3	An impairment charge is recognized if the carrying value exceeds the fair value less cost to sell.
58492_17_ITEM15_P37_S0	The assets and related liabilities are aggregated and reported on separate lines of the balance sheet.
58492_17_ITEM15_P38_S0	If a decision to dispose of an asset or a business is made and the held for sale criteria are not met, it is considered held for use.
58492_17_ITEM15_P39_S0	Assets of the business are evaluated for recoverability in the following order: (i) assets other than goodwill, property and intangibles; (ii) property and intangibles subject to amortization; and (iii) goodwill.
58492_17_ITEM15_P40_S0	In evaluating the recoverability of property and intangible assets subject to amortization, the carrying value is first compared to the sum of the undiscounted cash flows expected to result from the use and eventual disposition.
58492_17_ITEM15_P40_S1	If the carrying value exceeds the undiscounted expected cash flows, then a fair value analysis is performed.
58492_17_ITEM15_P40_S2	An impairment charge is recognized if the carrying value exceeds the fair value.
58492_17_ITEM15_P41_S0	Loss contingencies are accrued when a loss is probable and reasonably estimable.
58492_17_ITEM15_P41_S1	If a range of outcomes are possible, the most likely outcome is used to accrue these costs.
58492_17_ITEM15_P42_S0	Any insurance recovery is recorded separately if it is determined that a recovery is probable.
58492_17_ITEM15_P42_S1	Legal fees are accrued when incurred.
58492_17_ITEM15_P43_S0	PROPERTY, PLANT AND EQUIPMENT: Property, plant and equipment is stated at cost, less accumulated depreciation.
58492_17_ITEM15_P43_S1	Assets are depreciated by the straight-line method and salvage value, if any, is assumed to be minimal.
58492_17_ITEM15_P44_S0	The table below presents the depreciation periods of the estimated useful lives of our property, plant and equipment.
58492_17_ITEM15_P45_S0	Accelerated methods are used for tax purposes.
58492_17_ITEM15_P46_S0	Property is reviewed for recoverability at year end and whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that its carrying value may not be recoverable as discussed above.
58492_17_ITEM15_P47_S0	Goodwill results from the acquisition of existing businesses and is not amortized; it is assessed for impairment annually and as triggering events may occur.
58492_17_ITEM15_P47_S1	We perform our annual review in the second quarter of each year.
58492_17_ITEM15_P47_S2	Our ten reporting units are the business groups one level below the operating segment level for which discrete financial information is available.
58492_17_ITEM15_P48_S0	The Company has the option to first assess qualitative factors to determine whether events and circumstances indicate that it is more likely than not that goodwill is impaired.
58492_17_ITEM15_P48_S1	If after such an assessment, with regard to each reporting unit, the Company concludes that the goodwill of a reporting unit is not impaired, then no further action is required (commonly referred to as the Step Zero Analysis approach).
58492_17_ITEM15_P49_S0	For those reporting units where a significant change or event occurs, and where potential impairment indicators exist (based on the Step Zero Analysis approach), recoverability of goodwill is then evaluated using a two-step process.
58492_17_ITEM15_P50_S0	The first step involves a comparison of the fair value of a reporting unit with its carrying value.
58492_17_ITEM15_P51_S0	If the carrying value of the reporting unit exceeds its fair value, the second step of the process is necessary and involves a comparison of the implied fair value and the carrying value of the goodwill of that reporting unit.
58492_17_ITEM15_P51_S1	If the carrying value of the goodwill of a reporting unit exceeds the implied fair value of that goodwill, an impairment loss is recognized in an amount equal to the excess.
58492_17_ITEM15_P52_S0	Fair value of reporting units is determined using a combination of two valuation methods: a market approach and an income approach.
58492_17_ITEM15_P52_S1	Each method is generally given equal weight in determining the fair value assigned to each reporting unit.
58492_17_ITEM15_P52_S2	Absent an indication of fair value from a potential buyer or similar specific transaction, we believe that the use of these two methods provides a reasonable estimate of a reporting unit s fair value.
58492_17_ITEM15_P52_S3	Assumptions common to both methods are operating plans and economic projections, which are used to project future revenues, earnings, and after-tax cash flows for each reporting unit.
58492_17_ITEM15_P52_S4	These assumptions are applied consistently for both methods.
58492_17_ITEM15_P53_S0	The market approach estimates fair value by first determining price-to-earnings ratios for comparable publicly-traded companies with similar characteristics of the reporting unit.
58492_17_ITEM15_P53_S1	The price-to-earnings ratio for comparable companies is based upon current enterprise value compared to projected earnings for the next two years.
58492_17_ITEM15_P53_S2	The enterprise value is based upon current market capitalization and includes a control premium.
58492_17_ITEM15_P53_S3	Projected earnings are based upon market analysts projections.
58492_17_ITEM15_P53_S4	The earnings ratios are applied to the projected earnings of the comparable reporting unit to estimate fair value.
58492_17_ITEM15_P53_S5	Management believes this approach is appropriate because it provides a fair value estimate using multiples from entities with operations and economic characteristics comparable to our reporting units.
58492_17_ITEM15_P54_S0	The income approach is based on projected future (debt-free) cash flow that is discounted to present value using factors that consider the timing and risk of future cash flows.
58492_17_ITEM15_P54_S1	Management believes that this approach is appropriate because it provides a fair value estimate based upon the reporting unit s expected long-term operating cash flow performance.
58492_17_ITEM15_P55_S0	Discounted cash flow projections are based on 10-year financial forecasts developed from operating plans and economic projections noted above, sales growth, estimates of future expected changes in operating margins, terminal value growth rates, future capital expenditures and changes in working capital requirements.
58492_17_ITEM15_P56_S0	There are inherent assumptions and judgments required in the analysis of goodwill impairment.
58492_17_ITEM15_P56_S1	It is possible that assumptions underlying the impairment analysis will change in such a manner that impairment in value may occur in the future.
58492_17_ITEM15_P57_S0	Substantially all other intangible assets are amortized using the straight-line method over their estimated useful lives and are evaluated for impairment using a process similar to that used in evaluating the recoverability of property, plant and equipment.
58492_17_ITEM15_P58_S0	The cost of employee services received in exchange for all equity awards granted is based on the fair market value of the award as of the grant date.
58492_17_ITEM15_P58_S1	Expense is recognized net of an estimated forfeiture rate using the straight-line method over the vesting period of the award.
58492_17_ITEM15_P59_S0	We recognize sales when title and risk of loss pass to the customer.
58492_17_ITEM15_P59_S1	The terms of our sales are split approximately evenly between FOB shipping point and FOB destination.
58492_17_ITEM15_P59_S2	The timing of our recognition of FOB destination sales is determined based on shipping date and distance to the destination.
58492_17_ITEM15_P59_S3	We have no significant or unusual price protection, right of return or acceptance provisions with our customers.
58492_17_ITEM15_P60_S0	Sales allowances, discounts and rebates can be reasonably estimated throughout the period and are deducted from sales in arriving at net sales.
58492_17_ITEM15_P61_S0	SHIPPING AND HANDLING FEES AND COSTS: Shipping and handling costs are included as a component of Cost of goods sold.
58492_17_ITEM15_P62_S0	RESTRUCTURING COSTS: Restructuring costs are items such as employee termination, contract termination, plant closure and asset relocation costs related to exit activities or workforce reductions.
58492_17_ITEM15_P62_S1	Restructuring-related items are inventory writedowns and gains or losses from sales of assets recorded as the result of exit activities.
58492_17_ITEM15_P63_S0	We recognize a liability for costs associated with an exit or disposal activity when the liability is incurred.
58492_17_ITEM15_P64_S0	Certain termination benefits for which employees are required to render service are recognized ratably over the respective future service periods.
58492_17_ITEM15_P65_S0	The provision for income taxes is determined using the asset and liability approach of accounting for income taxes.
58492_17_ITEM15_P65_S1	Under this approach, deferred taxes represent the future tax consequences expected to occur when the reported amounts of assets and liabilities are recovered or paid.
58492_17_ITEM15_P66_S0	The provision for income taxes represents income taxes paid or payable for the current year plus the change in deferred taxes during the year.
58492_17_ITEM15_P66_S1	Deferred taxes result from differences between the financial and tax basis of our assets and liabilities and are adjusted for changes in tax rates and laws, as appropriate.
58492_17_ITEM15_P66_S2	A valuation allowance is provided to reduce deferred tax assets when management cannot conclude that it is more likely than not that a tax benefit will be realized.
58492_17_ITEM15_P67_S0	A provision is also made for incremental taxes on undistributed earnings of foreign subsidiaries and related companies to the extent that such earnings are not deemed to be indefinitely invested.
58492_17_ITEM15_P68_S0	The calculation of our U.S., state, and foreign tax liabilities involves dealing with uncertainties in the application of complex global tax laws.
58492_17_ITEM15_P68_S1	We recognize potential liabilities for anticipated tax issues which might arise in the U.S. and other tax jurisdictions based on management s estimate of whether, and the extent to which, additional taxes will be due.
58492_17_ITEM15_P68_S2	If payment of these amounts ultimately proves to be unnecessary, the reversal of the liabilities would result in tax benefits being recognized in the period when we determine the liabilities are no longer necessary.
58492_17_ITEM15_P68_S3	Conversely, if the estimate of tax liabilities proves to be less than the ultimate tax assessment, a further charge to tax expense would result.
58492_17_ITEM15_P69_S0	CONCENTRATION OF CREDIT RISKS, EXPOSURES AND FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS: We manufacture, market, and distribute products for the various end markets described in Note E.
58492_17_ITEM15_P69_S1	Our operations are principally located in the United States, although we also have operations in Europe, China, Canada, Mexico and other various countries.
58492_17_ITEM15_P70_S0	We maintain allowances for potential credit losses.
58492_17_ITEM15_P70_S1	We perform ongoing credit evaluations of our customers financial conditions and generally require no collateral from our customers, some of which are highly leveraged.
58492_17_ITEM15_P70_S2	Management also monitors the financial condition and status of other notes receivable.
58492_17_ITEM15_P71_S0	Other notes receivable have historically primarily consisted of notes accepted as partial payment for the divestiture of a business or to support other business opportunities.
58492_17_ITEM15_P71_S1	Some of these companies are highly leveraged and the notes are not fully collateralized.
58492_17_ITEM15_P72_S0	We have no material guarantees or liabilities for product warranties which require disclosure.
58492_17_ITEM15_P73_S0	From time to time, we will enter into contracts to hedge foreign currency denominated transactions, and interest rates related to our debt.
58492_17_ITEM15_P74_S0	To minimize the risk of counterparty default, only highly-rated financial institutions that meet certain requirements are used.
58492_17_ITEM15_P74_S1	We do not anticipate that any of the financial institution counterparties will default on their obligations.
58492_17_ITEM15_P75_S0	The carrying value of cash and short-term financial instruments approximates fair value due to the short maturity of those instruments.
58492_17_ITEM15_P76_S0	Although we obtain insurance for workers compensation, automobile, product and general liability, property loss and medical claims, we have elected to retain a significant portion of expected losses through the use of deductibles.
58492_17_ITEM15_P76_S1	Accrued liabilities include estimates for unpaid reported claims and for claims incurred but not yet reported.
58492_17_ITEM15_P76_S2	Provisions for losses are recorded based upon reasonable estimates of the aggregate liability for claims incurred utilizing our prior experience and information provided by our third-party administrators and insurance carriers.
58492_17_ITEM15_P77_S0	DERIVATIVE FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS: We utilize derivative financial instruments to manage market and financial risks related to foreign currency and interest rates.
58492_17_ITEM15_P77_S1	We seek to use derivative contracts that qualify for hedge accounting treatment; however some instruments that economically manage currency risk may not qualify for hedge accounting treatment.
58492_17_ITEM15_P77_S2	It is our policy not to speculate using derivative instruments.
58492_17_ITEM15_P78_S0	Under hedge accounting, we formally document our hedge relationships, including identification of the hedging instruments and the hedged items, as well as our risk management objectives and strategies for entering into the hedge transaction.
58492_17_ITEM15_P78_S1	The process includes designating derivative instruments as hedges of specific assets, liabilities, firm commitments or forecasted transactions.
58492_17_ITEM15_P78_S2	We also formally assess both at inception and on a quarterly basis thereafter, whether the derivatives used in hedging transactions are highly effective in offsetting changes in either the fair value or cash flows of the hedged item.
58492_17_ITEM15_P78_S3	If it is determined that a derivative ceases to be highly effective, deferred gains or losses are recorded in the Consolidated Statements of Operations.
58492_17_ITEM15_P79_S0	On the date the contract is entered into, we designate the derivative as one of the following types of hedging instruments and account for it as follows:
58492_17_ITEM15_P80_S0	The hedge of a forecasted transaction or of the variability of cash flows to be received or paid related to a recognized asset or liability or anticipated transaction is designated as a cash flow hedge.
58492_17_ITEM15_P81_S0	The effective portion of the change in fair value is recorded in accumulated other comprehensive income.
58492_17_ITEM15_P81_S1	When the hedged item impacts the income statement, the gain or loss included in other comprehensive income is reported on the same line of the Consolidated Statements of Operations as the hedged item to match the gain or loss on the derivative to the gain or loss on the hedged item.
58492_17_ITEM15_P81_S2	Any ineffective portion of the changes in the fair value is immediately reported in the Consolidated Statements of Operations on the same line as the hedged item.
58492_17_ITEM15_P82_S0	Settlements associated with the sale or production of product are presented in operating cash flows and settlements associated with debt issuance are presented in financing cash flows.
58492_17_ITEM15_P83_S0	The hedge of a recognized asset or liability or an unrecognized firm commitment is designated as a fair value hedge.
58492_17_ITEM15_P83_S1	For fair value hedges, both the effective and ineffective portions of the changes in fair value of the derivative, along with the gain or loss on the hedged item that is attributable to the hedged risk, are recorded in earnings and reported in the Consolidated Statements of Operations on the same line as the hedged item.
58492_17_ITEM15_P84_S0	Cash flows from settled contracts are presented in the category consistent with the nature of the item being hedged.
58492_17_ITEM15_P85_S0	The functional currency for most foreign operations is the local currency.
58492_17_ITEM15_P85_S1	The translation of foreign currencies into U.S. dollars is performed for balance sheet accounts using current exchange rates in effect at the balance sheet date and for income and expense accounts using monthly average exchange rates.
58492_17_ITEM15_P85_S2	The cumulative effects of translating the functional currencies into the U.S. dollar are included in comprehensive income.
58492_17_ITEM15_P86_S0	Certain reclassifications have been made to the prior years information in the Consolidated Financial Statements and related notes to conform to the 2016 presentation.
58492_17_ITEM15_P86_S1	These were primarily associated with a balance sheet reclassification for new accounting guidance related to the presentation of debt issuance costs as discussed below.
58492_17_ITEM15_P87_S0	The Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) regularly issues updates to the FASB Accounting Standards Codification that are communicated through issuance of an Accounting Standards Update (ASU).
58492_17_ITEM15_P87_S1	Below is a summary of the ASUs, effective for current or future periods, most relevant to our financial statements:
58492_17_ITEM15_P88_S0	ASU 2016-09 Improvements to Employee Share-Based Payment Accounting : Simplifies the financial reporting for share-based compensation.
58492_17_ITEM15_P88_S1	We adopted this guidance in the first quarter of 2016:
58492_17_ITEM15_P89_S0	All income tax effects of stock-based compensation are now classified within income tax expense, rather than recognizing some of the effects in additional contributed capital.
58492_17_ITEM15_P89_S1	To the extent tax deductions from stock-based compensation payments differ from the compensation cost recognized for financial reporting purposes, the tax effects are recorded as discrete items in that quarter.
58492_17_ITEM15_P90_S0	Prospective application was required, and the impact of adopting this new guidance resulted in an additional tax benefit of $18.2 for 2016.
58492_17_ITEM15_P91_S0	This ASU impacted the calculation of the dilutive effect of stock-based compensation on earnings per share, which resulted in an increase in our average diluted shares outstanding of approximately .5 shares.
58492_17_ITEM15_P92_S0	The income tax effects are now classified as cash flow from operations, rather than cash flow from financing activities.
58492_17_ITEM15_P92_S1	We have elected to apply this cash flow classification guidance prospectively.
58492_17_ITEM15_P93_S0	Consistent with our past practice, when shares are withheld from the issuance of stock to fund the payment of the employee s taxes, the payment is classified as a financing activity.
58492_17_ITEM15_P94_S0	We have elected to continue to estimate the number of stock-based awards expected to vest, rather than electing to account for forfeitures as they occur.
58492_17_ITEM15_P95_S0	ASU 2015-03 Simplifying the Presentation of Debt Issuance Costs : Changes the presentation of long-term debt issuance costs in the financial statements to a reduction of the related liability rather than as a separate asset.
58492_17_ITEM15_P95_S1	We adopted this ASU in the first quarter of 2016 and retrospectively reclassified net deferred loan costs associated with each of our long-term debt issuances from assets to long-term debt on the balance sheet.
58492_17_ITEM15_P95_S2	The adoption of this ASU did not have a material impact on our financial statements.
58492_17_ITEM15_P96_S0	To be adopted in future years:
58492_17_ITEM15_P97_S0	ASU 2016-02 Leases : Requires that a lessee recognize a right-of-use asset and a lease liability on the balance sheet for most lease arrangements.
58492_17_ITEM15_P97_S1	This ASU will be effective January 1, 2019, and we are assessing all potential impacts of the standard.
58492_17_ITEM15_P97_S2	Currently, we anticipate adopting this standard January 1, 2019.
58492_17_ITEM15_P97_S3	We believe it will increase our assets and liabilities for the addition of right-of-use assets and the corresponding lease liabilities on the balance sheet.
58492_17_ITEM15_P97_S4	We are also evaluating its impact on our statements of operations and cash flows.
58492_17_ITEM15_P98_S0	ASUs 2016-13 Financial Instruments - Credit Losses , 2016-15 Statement of Cash Flows (Topic 230): Classification of Certain Cash Receipts and Cash Payments (a consensus of the Emerging Issues Task Force) , and 2016-16 Income Taxes (Topic 740): Intra-Entity Transfers of Assets Other Than Inventory are currently being evaluated, however, we do not expect these updates to materially impact our future financial statements.
58492_17_ITEM15_P99_S0	ASU 2014-09 Revenue from Contracts with Customers : Supersedes most of the existing authoritative literature for revenue recognition and prescribes a five-step model for recognizing revenue from contracts with customers.
58492_17_ITEM15_P99_S1	In July 2015, the FASB deferred the effective date of this ASU by one year, which results in the new standard being effective January 1, 2018.
58492_17_ITEM15_P99_S2	In addition, the FASB has issued several amendments to the standard during 2016.
58492_17_ITEM15_P100_S0	This standard permits two transition methods, the full retrospective method or the modified retrospective method.
58492_17_ITEM15_P100_S1	The new standard will also require expanded disclosures pertaining to revenues from contracts with customers in the notes to the financial statements.
58492_17_ITEM15_P101_S0	We established a cross-functional implementation team in 2014 to assess all potential impacts of this standard We continue to make progress in implementing the new revenue standard and in evaluating its impact on our future financial statements.
58492_17_ITEM15_P101_S1	We have not yet selected a transition method.
58492_17_ITEM15_P101_S2	We will apply the guidance at the new revenue standard s effective date of January 1, 2018.
58492_17_ITEM15_P102_S0	The FASB has issued accounting guidance, in addition to the issuance discussed above, effective for current and future periods.
58492_17_ITEM15_P102_S1	This guidance did not have a material impact on our current financial statements, and we do not believe it will have a material impact on our future financial statements.

58492_17_ITEM15_P223_S0	Our investment policy and strategies are established with a long-term view in mind.
58492_17_ITEM15_P223_S1	We strive for a sufficiently diversified asset mix to minimize the risk of a material loss to the portfolio value due to the devaluation of any single investment.
58492_17_ITEM15_P223_S2	In determining the appropriate asset mix, our financial strength and ability to fund potential shortfalls that might result from poor investment performance are considered.
58492_17_ITEM15_P223_S3	Approximately 55% of our significant plans (the "frozen plans") are employing a Liability Driven Investment strategy and have a target allocation of 60% fixed income and 40% equities.
58492_17_ITEM15_P223_S4	The remaining significant plans (the "active" plans) have a target allocation of 75% equities and 25% fixed income, as historical equity returns have tended to exceed bond returns over the long term.

58492_17_ITEM15_P231_S0	Extended Duration Treasury Index: Diversified exposure to U.S. treasuries with maturities of 20-30 years.

58492_17_ITEM15_P265_S0	We utilize fair value measures for both financial and non-financial assets and liabilities.
58492_17_ITEM15_P266_S0	The areas in which we utilize fair value measures of financial assets and liabilities are presented in the table below.
58492_17_ITEM15_P267_S0	Fair value measurements are established using a three level valuation hierarchy that prioritizes the inputs to valuation techniques used to measure fair value into the following categories:
58492_17_ITEM15_P268_S0	Level 1: Quoted prices for identical assets or liabilities in active markets.
58492_17_ITEM15_P269_S0	Level 2: Inputs other than quoted prices included in Level 1 that are observable for the asset or liability either directly or indirectly.
58492_17_ITEM15_P269_S1	Short-term investments in this category are valued using discounted cash flow techniques with all significant inputs derived from or corroborated by observable market data.
58492_17_ITEM15_P269_S2	Derivative assets and liabilities in this category are valued using models that consider various assumptions and information from market-corroborated sources.
58492_17_ITEM15_P269_S3	The models used are primarily industry-standard models that consider items such as quoted prices, market interest rate curves applicable to the instruments being valued as of the end of each period, discounted cash flows, volatility factors, current market and contractual prices for the underlying instruments, as well as other relevant economic measures.
58492_17_ITEM15_P269_S4	Substantially all of these assumptions are observable in the marketplace, can be derived from observable data or are supported by observable levels at which transactions are executed in the marketplace.
58492_17_ITEM15_P270_S0	Level 3: Unobservable inputs that are not corroborated by market data.
58492_17_ITEM15_P271_S0	* Includes both current and long-term amounts combined.
58492_17_ITEM15_P272_S0	The fair value for fixed rate debt (Level 2) was greater than its carrying value by approximately $25 and $13 at December 31, 2016 and 2015, respectively.
58492_17_ITEM15_P272_S1	The carrying value was $750.0 for both years.
58492_17_ITEM15_P273_S0	The primary areas in which we utilize fair value measures of non-financial assets and liabilities are allocating purchase price to the assets and liabilities of acquired companies as discussed in Note Q and evaluating long-term assets (including goodwill) for potential impairment as discussed in Note C. Determining fair values for these items requires significant judgment and includes a variety of methods and models that utilize significant Level 3 inputs.
58492_17_ITEM15_P274_S0	Long-lived assets, acquisitions and the second step of a goodwill impairment test utilize the following methodologies in determining fair value: (i) Buildings and machinery are valued at an estimated replacement cost for an asset of comparable age and condition.
58492_17_ITEM15_P274_S1	Market pricing of comparable assets are used to estimate replacement cost where available.
58492_17_ITEM15_P275_S0	The most common identified intangible assets are customer relationships and tradenames.
58492_17_ITEM15_P275_S1	Customer relationships are valued using an excess earnings method, using various inputs such as the estimated customer attrition rate, future earnings forecast, the amount of contributory asset charges, and a discount rate.
58492_17_ITEM15_P275_S2	Tradenames are valued using a relief from royalty method, which is based upon comparable market royalty rates for tradenames of similar value.
58492_17_ITEM15_P276_S0	(iii) Inventory is valued at current replacement cost for raw materials, with a step-up for work in process and finished goods items that reflects the amount of ultimate profit earned as of the valuation date.
58492_17_ITEM15_P276_S1	(iv) Other working capital items are generally recorded at face value, unless there are known conditions that would impact the ultimate settlement amount of the particular item.

58492_17_ITEM15_P302_S0	Foam Antitrust Lawsuits Beginning in August 2010, a series of civil lawsuits was initiated in several U.S. federal courts and in Canada against several defendants alleging that Leggett and Platt and certain other manufacturers of polyurethane foam products had engaged in price fixing in violation of U.S. and Canadian antitrust laws.
58492_17_ITEM15_P302_S1	We were party to several antitrust proceedings regarding polyurethane foam products.
58492_17_ITEM15_P302_S2	The majority of these proceedings were fully resolved in 2015.
58492_17_ITEM15_P303_S0	The ultimate amount of settlement payments in these cases was not materially different than the amounts originally accrued.
58492_17_ITEM15_P303_S1	The remaining antitrust proceeding, along with the resolution of other proceedings, is disclosed below.
58492_17_ITEM15_P304_S0	We deny all allegations in the pending antitrust proceeding.
58492_17_ITEM15_P304_S1	We will vigorously defend ourselves in this proceeding and believe that we have valid bases to contest all claims.
58492_17_ITEM15_P304_S2	However, we have established an accrual for the estimated amount that we believe is necessary to resolve the pending antitrust matter.
58492_17_ITEM15_P304_S3	We also believe, based on current facts, it is reasonably possible that we may incur a loss in excess of the recorded accrual associated with the pending antitrust proceeding.

58492_17_ITEM15_P305_S0	U.S. Indirect Purchaser Class Action Cases.
58492_17_ITEM15_P305_S1	We were named as a defendant in an indirect purchaser class consolidated amended complaint filed on March 21, 2011 and were subsequently sued in an indirect purchaser class action case filed on May 23, 2011, in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio under the name In re: Polyurethane Foam Antitrust Litigation , Case No. 1:10-MD-2196.
58492_17_ITEM15_P305_S2	The plaintiffs, on behalf of themselves and/or a class of indirect purchasers, brought damages claims under various states' antitrust and consumer protection statutes, and were seeking three times an amount of damages allegedly suffered as a result of alleged overcharges in the price of polyurethane foam products from at least 1999 to the present.
58492_17_ITEM15_P305_S3	Each plaintiff also sought attorney fees, prejudgment interest, court costs, and injunctive relief against future violations.
58492_17_ITEM15_P305_S4	The Ohio Court ordered all parties to attend non-binding mediation with a mediator of their choosing.
58492_17_ITEM15_P306_S0	Settlement of U.S. Indirect Purchaser Class Action Cases.
58492_17_ITEM15_P306_S1	We reached a tentative settlement in the U.S. Indirect Class Action cases on May 18, 2015, by agreeing to pay an amount not materially different from the amount previously accrued for this claim.
58492_17_ITEM15_P306_S2	We continue to deny all allegations in the cases, but settled the indirect purchaser class cases to avoid the risk, uncertainty, expense and distraction of litigation.
58492_17_ITEM15_P306_S3	The Court preliminarily approved the class settlement on July 31, 2015.
58492_17_ITEM15_P306_S4	The full settlement amount was paid in escrow in the third quarter of 2015.
58492_17_ITEM15_P306_S5	The final settlement approval hearing was held on December 15, 2015 and the Court granted final approval of the settlement.
58492_17_ITEM15_P307_S0	Several objectors filed notices of appeal of the order approving the class settlement to the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals.
58492_17_ITEM15_P307_S1	On April 14, 2016, the Court ordered the objectors to post an appeal bond by May 13, 2016.
58492_17_ITEM15_P307_S2	Certain of the objectors filed a motion to reconsider or stay the bond order, which the Court denied on May 12, 2016.
58492_17_ITEM15_P307_S3	Subsequently, three of the five objectors voluntarily dismissed their appeals.
58492_17_ITEM15_P307_S4	On June 20, 2016, the Sixth Circuit dismissed the remaining two appeals, one for failure to post an appeal bond, and the other because it was untimely filed.
58492_17_ITEM15_P307_S5	One of the two objectors filed a petition for rehearing en banc (requesting that all judges rather than the normal 3 rule on the appeal) on June 29, 2016.
58492_17_ITEM15_P307_S6	That petition was denied on September 27, 2016.
58492_17_ITEM15_P307_S7	On December 22, 2016, the objector filed a petition for a writ of certiori to the U.S. Supreme Court.
58492_17_ITEM15_P307_S8	The petition was denied on January 23, 2017.
58492_17_ITEM15_P307_S9	As such, these cases have been fully resolved.

58492_18_ITEM1_P0_S0	Leggett Platt, Incorporated was founded as a partnership in Carthage, Missouri in 1883 and was incorporated in 1901.
58492_18_ITEM1_P0_S1	The Company, a pioneer of the steel coil bedspring, has become an international diversified manufacturer that conceives, designs and produces a wide range of engineered components and products found in many homes, offices, automobiles and aircraft.
58492_18_ITEM1_P0_S2	As discussed below, our operations are organized into 14 business units, which are divided into ten groups under our four segments: Residential Products; Industrial Products; Furniture Products; and Specialized Products.
58492_18_ITEM1_P1_S0	Our Residential Products segment began in 1883 with the manufacture of steel coil bedsprings.
58492_18_ITEM1_P1_S1	Today, we supply a variety of components and machinery used by bedding manufacturers in the production and assembly of their finished products.
58492_18_ITEM1_P1_S2	Our range of products offers our customers a single source for many of their component needs.
58492_18_ITEM1_P1_S3	We also produce or distribute carpet cushion, fabric, and geo components.
58492_18_ITEM1_P1_S4	Innovative proprietary products and low cost have made us the largest U.S. manufacturer in many of these businesses.
58492_18_ITEM1_P1_S5	We strive to understand what drives consumer purchases in our markets and focus our product development activities on meeting end-consumer needs.
58492_18_ITEM1_P1_S6	We attain a cost advantage from efficient manufacturing methods, internal production of key raw materials, purchasing leverage, and large-scale production.
58492_18_ITEM1_P1_S7	Sourcing components from us allows our customers to focus on designing, merchandising and marketing their products.
58492_18_ITEM1_P2_S0	1 Drawn Wire includes our former Wire Products business unit effective January 1, 2018.
58492_18_ITEM1_P3_S0	The quality of our products and service, together with low cost, have made Leggett Platt the leading U.S. supplier of high-carbon drawn steel wire.
58492_18_ITEM1_P3_S1	Our Wire Group operates a steel rod mill with an annual output of approximately 500,000 tons, of which a substantial majority is used by our own wire mills.
58492_18_ITEM1_P3_S2	We have three wire mills that supply virtually all the wire consumed by our other domestic businesses.
58492_18_ITEM1_P3_S3	We also supply steel wire to trade customers that operate in a broad range of markets.

58492_18_ITEM1_P5_S0	The Industrial Products segment also has a diverse group of trade customers that include:
58492_18_ITEM1_P6_S0	1 Home Furniture includes our former Furniture Hardware and Seating Distribution business units effective January 1, 2018.
58492_18_ITEM1_P6_S1	2 Consumer Products includes our former Adjustable Bed and Fashion Bed business units effective January 1, 2018.
58492_18_ITEM1_P7_S0	In our Furniture Products segment, we design, manufacture, and distribute a wide range of components and finished products for the residential furniture, office and commercial furniture, and specialty bedding markets.
58492_18_ITEM1_P7_S1	We supply components used by home and work furniture manufacturers to provide comfort, motion and style in their finished products, as well as select lines of private-label finished furniture.
58492_18_ITEM1_P7_S2	We are also a major supplier of adjustable beds and fashion beds, with domestic manufacturing, distribution, e-commerce fulfillment and global sourcing capabilities.
58492_18_ITEM1_P8_S0	1 Formed January 31, 2018, with the acquisition of a manufacturer of hydraulic cylinders.
58492_18_ITEM1_P9_S0	Our Specialized Products segment designs, manufactures and sells products including automotive seating components, tubing and fabricated assemblies for the aerospace industry, and hydraulic cylinders for the material handling, construction and transportation industries.
58492_18_ITEM1_P9_S1	Our technical capability and deep customer engagement allows us to compete on critical functionality, such as comfort, size, weight and noise.
58492_18_ITEM1_P9_S2	Our reliable product development and launch capability, coupled with our global footprint, makes us a trusted partner for our Tier 1 and OEM customers.
58492_18_ITEM1_P10_S0	For information about sales to trade customers, sales by product line, EBIT, and total assets of each of our segments, refer to Note E on page 82 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
58492_18_ITEM1_P11_S0	Our reportable segments are the same as our operating segments, which also correspond with our management organizational structure.
58492_18_ITEM1_P11_S1	In conjunction with the change in executive officers, our management organizational structure and all related internal reporting changed effective January 1, 2017.
58492_18_ITEM1_P11_S2	As a result, the composition of our four segments also changed to reflect the new structure.
58492_18_ITEM1_P11_S3	The new segment structure is largely the same as prior years except the Home Furniture Group moved from Residential Products to Furniture Products (formerly Commercial Products) and the Machinery Group moved from Specialized Products to Residential Products.
58492_18_ITEM1_P12_S0	In addition, the changes in LIFO reserve are now recognized within the segments to which they relate (primarily Industrial Products).
58492_18_ITEM1_P12_S1	Previously segment EBIT (Earnings Before Interest and Taxes) reflected the FIFO basis of accounting for certain inventories and an adjustment to the LIFO basis for these inventories was made at the consolidated financial statement level.
58492_18_ITEM1_P12_S2	These changes were retrospectively applied to all periods presented.
58492_18_ITEM1_P12_S3	The methods and assumptions that we use in estimating our LIFO reserve did not change.
58492_18_ITEM1_P13_S0	Total Shareholder Return (TSR), relative to peer companies, is the key financial measure that we use to assess long-term performance.
58492_18_ITEM1_P13_S1	TSR = (Change in Stock Price + Dividends)/Beginning Stock Price.
58492_18_ITEM1_P13_S2	Our goal is to achieve TSR in the top third of the S P 500 companies over rolling three-year periods through an approach that employs four TSR sources: revenue growth, margin expansion, dividends, and share repurchases.
58492_18_ITEM1_P14_S0	Our incentive programs reward return generation and profitable growth.
58492_18_ITEM1_P15_S0	Senior executives participate in a TSR-based incentive program (based on our performance compared to a group of approximately 320 peers).
58492_18_ITEM1_P16_S0	For information about our TSR targets and performance see the discussion under " Total Shareholder Return " in Item 7, Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations on page 28 .
58492_18_ITEM1_P17_S0	During the past three years, we generated $1.36 billion of operating cash, and we returned much of this cash to shareholders in the form of dividends and share repurchases.
58492_18_ITEM1_P17_S1	Our top priorities for use of cash are organic growth (capital expenditures), dividends, and strategic acquisitions.
58492_18_ITEM1_P17_S2	After funding those priorities, if there is still cash available, we generally intend to repurchase stock.
58492_18_ITEM1_P18_S0	For information about dividends and share repurchases see the discussion under "Pay Dividends" and "Repurchase Stock" in Item 7, Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations beginning on page 44 .
58492_18_ITEM1_P19_S0	We utilize a rigorous strategic planning process to help guide decisions regarding business unit roles, capital allocation priorities, and new areas in which to grow.
58492_18_ITEM1_P19_S1	We review the portfolio classification of each unit on an annual basis to determine its appropriate role (Grow, Core, Fix or Divest).
58492_18_ITEM1_P19_S2	This review includes criteria such as competitive position, market attractiveness, business unit size, and fit within our overall objectives, as well as financial indicators such as business unit return, growth of EBIT (earnings before interest and taxes), EBIT margin, EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization), and operating cash flows.
58492_18_ITEM1_P20_S0	Business units in the Grow category should provide avenues for profitable growth from competitively advantaged positions in attractive markets.
58492_18_ITEM1_P21_S0	Core business units are expected to enhance productivity, improve market share, and generate cash flow from operations while using minimal capital.
58492_18_ITEM1_P21_S1	To remain in the portfolio, business units are expected to consistently generate after-tax returns in excess of our cost of capital.
58492_18_ITEM1_P21_S2	Business units that fail to consistently attain minimum return goals will be moved to the Fix or Divest categories.
58492_18_ITEM1_P22_S0	We revised our TSR framework in 2016 to moderately increase the expected long-term contribution from revenue growth to 6-9% (from 4-5% previously).
58492_18_ITEM1_P22_S1	Over the last three years, the Company has generated combined unit volume and acquisition growth of 5% per year on average, but this growth was partially offset by divestitures, commodity deflation and currency impact.
58492_18_ITEM1_P23_S0	Our long-term 6-9% annual revenue growth objective envisions periodic acquisitions.
58492_18_ITEM1_P23_S1	We primarily seek acquisitions within our Grow businesses, and look for opportunities to enter new, higher growth markets (carefully screened for sustainable competitive advantage).
58492_18_ITEM1_P23_S2	We expect all acquisitions to (a) have a clear strategic rationale, a sustainable competitive advantage, a strong fit with the Company, and be in an attractive and growing market; (b) create value by enhancing TSR; (c) for stand-alone businesses: generally possess annual revenue in excess of $50 million, strong management and future growth opportunity with a strong market position in a market growing faster than GDP; and (d) for bolt-on businesses: generally possess annual revenue in excess of $15 million, significant synergies, and a strategic fit with an existing business unit.

58492_18_ITEM1A_P0_S0	Investing in our securities involves risk.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P0_S1	Set forth below and elsewhere in this report are risk factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from the results contemplated by the forward-looking statements contained in this report.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P0_S2	We may amend or supplement these risk factors from time to time by other reports we file with the SEC.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Costs of raw materials could negatively affect our profit margins and earnings.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P2_S0	Raw material cost increases (and our ability to respond to cost increases through selling price increases) can significantly impact our earnings.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P2_S1	We typically have short-term commitments from our suppliers; therefore, our raw material costs generally move with the market.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P2_S2	When we experience significant increases in raw material costs, we typically implement price increases to recover the higher costs.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P2_S3	Inability to recover cost increases (or a delay in the recovery time) can negatively impact our earnings.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P3_S0	through reduced selling prices to our customers.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P3_S1	Reduced selling prices combined with higher cost inventory can reduce our segment margins and earnings.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P4_S0	Steel is our principal raw material.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P4_S1	The global steel markets are cyclical in nature and have been volatile in recent years.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P4_S2	This volatility can result in large swings in pricing and margins from year to year.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P4_S3	Our operations can also be impacted by changes in the cost of fabrics and foam scrap.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P4_S4	We experienced significant fluctuations in the cost of these commodities in past years.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P5_S0	As a producer of steel rod, we are also impacted by volatility in metal margins (the difference between the cost of steel scrap and the market price for steel rod).
58492_18_ITEM1A_P5_S1	If market conditions cause scrap costs and rod pricing to change at different rates (both in terms of timing and amount), metal margins could be compressed and this would negatively impact our results of operations.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P6_S0	Higher raw material costs in past years led some of our customers to modify their product designs, changing the quantity and mix of our components in their finished goods.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P6_S1	In some cases, higher cost components were replaced with lower cost components.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P6_S2	This primarily impacted our Residential Products product mix and decreased profit margins.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P6_S3	If this were to occur again it could negatively impact our results of operations.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P7_S0	Competition could adversely affect our market share, sales, profit margins and earnings.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P8_S0	We operate in markets that are highly competitive.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P8_S1	We believe that most companies in our lines of business compete primarily on price, but, depending upon the particular product, we experience competition based on quality and performance.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P8_S2	We face ongoing pressure from foreign competitors as some of our customers source a portion of their components and finished products from Asia and Europe.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P8_S3	In addition to lower labor rates, foreign competitors benefit (at times) from lower raw material costs.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P8_S4	They may also benefit from currency factors and more lenient regulatory climates.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P9_S0	If we are unable to purchase key raw materials, such as steel, at prices competitive with those of foreign suppliers, our ability to maintain market share and profit margins could be harmed by foreign competitors.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P10_S0	We are exposed to litigation contingencies that, if realized, could have a material negative impact on our financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P10_S1	Although we deny liability in all currently threatened or pending litigation proceedings and believe that we have valid bases to contest all claims made against us, we have, at December 31, 2017, an aggregate litigation contingency accrual of $.4 million.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P10_S2	Based on current facts and circumstances, aggregate reasonably possible (but not probable) losses in excess of the recorded accruals for litigation contingencies (which include Brazilian VAT and other matters) are estimated to be $22 million.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P10_S3	If our assumptions or analysis regarding these contingencies is incorrect, or if facts and circumstances change, we could realize loss in excess of the recorded accruals (and in excess of the $22 million referenced above) which could have a material negative impact on our financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P10_S4	For more information regarding our legal contingencies, please see Note S on page 115 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P11_S0	We are exposed to foreign currency risk which may negatively impact our competitiveness, profit margins and earnings.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P12_S0	We expect that international sales will continue to represent a significant percentage of our total sales, which exposes us to currency exchange rate fluctuations.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P12_S1	In 2017, 37% of our sales were generated by international operations.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P12_S2	The revenues and expenses of our foreign operations are generally denominated in local currencies; however, certain of our operations experience currency-related gains and losses where sales or purchases are denominated in currencies other than their local currency.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P12_S3	Further, our competitive position may be affected by the relative strength of the currencies in countries where our products are sold.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P12_S4	Foreign currency exchange risks inherent in doing business in foreign countries may have a material adverse effect on our future operations and financial results.

58492_18_ITEM1A_P14_S2	In addition, net property, plant and equipment and sundry assets totaled $793 million, or 22% of total assets.
