58492_18_ITEM1A_P16_S0	We review our reporting units for potential goodwill impairment in June as part of our annual goodwill impairment testing, and more often if an event or circumstance occurs making it likely that impairment exists.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P16_S1	In addition, we test for the recoverability of long-lived assets at year end, and more often if an event or circumstance indicates the carrying value may not be recoverable.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P16_S2	We conduct impairment testing based on our current business strategy in light of present industry and economic conditions, as well as future expectations.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P16_S3	If we are not able to achieve projected performance levels, future impairments could be possible, which would negatively impact our earnings.

58492_18_ITEM1A_P24_S3	To a lesser extent, market demand is impacted by other broad economic factors, including disposable income levels, employment levels, housing turnover and interest rates.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P25_S0	drive demand for our components and products.

58492_18_ITEM1A_P33_S0	On December 22, 2017, the U.S. government enacted comprehensive tax legislation commonly referred to as the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (TCJA), resulting in significant changes to U.S. federal income tax law, including the reduction of the statutory federal income tax rate for corporations and the transition from a worldwide tax system to a territorial system.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P33_S1	We are continuing to assess the extensive changes under this legislation and its overall impact on the Company.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P33_S2	Based on our current understanding, we expect TCJA to reduce our tax rate in future periods.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P33_S3	However, this expectation is based on our current knowledge of the legislation and assumptions we have made.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P33_S4	Recognized impacts could differ materially from current estimates based on additional analysis, changes in our interpretation of certain aspects of the legislation, actual financial results for 2018, additional regulatory guidance that might be issued, and other factors, including actions the Company may take as a result of TCJA.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P34_S0	Business disruptions to our steel rod mill, if coupled with an inability to purchase an adequate and/or timely supply of quality steel rod from alternative sources, could have a material negative impact on our Residential Products and Industrial Products segments and Company results of operations.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P35_S0	We purchase steel scrap from third party suppliers.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P35_S1	This scrap is converted into steel rod in our mill in Sterling, Illinois.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P35_S2	Our steel rod mill has annual output of approximately 500,000 tons, a substantial majority of which is used by our three wire mills.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P36_S0	Our wire mills convert the steel rod into drawn steel wire.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P36_S1	This wire is used in the production of many of our products, including mattress innersprings.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P37_S0	A disruption to the operation of, or supply of steel scrap to, our steel rod mill could require us to purchase steel rod from alternative supply sources, subject to market availability.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P37_S1	Ongoing trade action by domestic rod producers against several foreign suppliers could result in the imposition of additional duties on steel rod imports which could result in reduced market availability and/or higher cost of steel rod.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P38_S0	If we experience a disruption to our ability to produce steel rod in our mill, coupled with a reduction of adequate and/or timely supply from alternative market sources of quality steel rod, we could experience a material negative impact on our Residential Products and Industrial Products segments and Company results of operations.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P39_S0	Inability to identify and consummate acquisitions at a sufficient rate and at appropriate prices could negatively impact our annual revenue growth rate.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P39_S1	Our long-term 6-9% annual revenue growth objective envisions periodic acquisitions.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P39_S2	We expect to continue our strategy of seeking acquisitions that have a clear strategic rationale, a sustainable competitive advantage, a strong fit with the Company, are in a growing market, and create value by enhancing total shareholder return.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P39_S3	Our ability to grow revenues at 6-9% depends, in part, upon our ability to identify and successfully acquire these businesses at appropriate prices.
58492_18_ITEM1A_P39_S4	Because of competition among prospective buyers which often leads to higher valuations, the need to satisfy applicable closing conditions or obtain antitrust and other regulatory approvals on acceptable terms, and accounting, regulatory and tax requirements, we may not be able to identify or consummate these acquisitions at a sufficient rate, which could adversely impact our annual revenue growth rate.

58492_18_ITEM7_P6_S0	We assess our overall performance by comparing our Total Shareholder Return (TSR) to that of peer companies on a rolling three-year basis.
58492_18_ITEM7_P6_S1	We target TSR in the top third of the S P 500 over the long term.
58492_18_ITEM7_P6_S2	For the three years ended December 31, 2017, we generated TSR of 7% per year on average, placing us just below the midpoint of the S P 500.
58492_18_ITEM7_P7_S0	These topics are discussed in more detail in the sections that follow.
58492_18_ITEM7_P8_S0	Total Shareholder Return (TSR), relative to peer companies, is the key financial measure that we use to assess long-term performance.
58492_18_ITEM7_P8_S1	TSR is driven by the change in our share price and the dividends we pay: TSR = (Change in Stock Price + Dividends) / Beginning Stock Price.
58492_18_ITEM7_P8_S2	We seek to achieve TSR in the top third of the S P 500 over the long term through an approach that employs four TSR drivers: revenue growth, margin expansion, dividends, and share repurchases.
58492_18_ITEM7_P9_S0	We monitor our TSR performance relative to the S P 500 on a rolling three-year basis.
58492_18_ITEM7_P9_S1	For the three-year measurement period that ended December 31, 2017, we generated TSR of 7% per year on average, just below the midpoint of the S P 500.
58492_18_ITEM7_P10_S0	The table below shows the components of our TSR targets.
58492_18_ITEM7_P10_S1	Accomplishing this level of performance over rolling three-year periods should enable us to consistently attain our top-third TSR goal.
58492_18_ITEM7_P11_S0	We serve a broad suite of customers, with our largest customer representing approximately 5% of our sales.
58492_18_ITEM7_P11_S1	Many are companies whose names are widely recognized.
58492_18_ITEM7_P11_S2	They include producers of residential furniture and bedding, automotive and office seating manufacturers, and a variety of other companies.
58492_18_ITEM7_P12_S0	Many factors impact our business, but those that generally have the greatest impact are market demand, raw material cost trends, and competition.
58492_18_ITEM7_P13_S0	Market demand (including product mix) is impacted by several economic factors, with consumer confidence being most significant.
58492_18_ITEM7_P13_S1	Other important factors include disposable income levels, employment levels, housing turnover, and interest rates.
58492_18_ITEM7_P13_S2	All of these factors influence consumer spending on durable goods, and therefore affect demand for our components and products.
58492_18_ITEM7_P13_S3	Some of these factors also influence business spending on facilities and equipment, which impacts approximately one quarter of our sales.
58492_18_ITEM7_P14_S0	In many of our businesses, we enjoy a cost advantage from being vertically integrated into steel wire and rod.
58492_18_ITEM7_P14_S1	This is a benefit that our competitors do not have.
58492_18_ITEM7_P14_S2	We also experience favorable purchasing leverage from buying large quantities of raw materials.
58492_18_ITEM7_P14_S3	Still, our costs can vary significantly as market prices for raw materials (many of which are commodities) fluctuate.
58492_18_ITEM7_P15_S0	We typically have short-term commitments from our suppliers; accordingly, our raw material costs generally move with the market.
58492_18_ITEM7_P15_S1	Our ability to recover higher costs (through selling price increases) is crucial.
58492_18_ITEM7_P15_S2	When we experience significant increases in raw material costs, we typically implement price increases to recover the higher costs.
58492_18_ITEM7_P15_S3	Conversely, when costs decrease significantly, we generally pass those lower costs through to our customers.
58492_18_ITEM7_P15_S4	The timing of our price increases or decreases is important; we typically experience a lag in recovering higher costs, and we also realize a lag as costs decline.
58492_18_ITEM7_P16_S0	Steel is our principal raw material.
58492_18_ITEM7_P16_S1	At various times in past years we have experienced significant cost fluctuations in this commodity.
58492_18_ITEM7_P16_S2	In most cases, the major changes (both increases and decreases) were passed through to customers with selling price adjustments.
58492_18_ITEM7_P17_S0	Throughout 2015, market prices for steel decreased significantly, leading to downward pressure on selling prices.
58492_18_ITEM7_P17_S1	We realized a beneficial pricing lag during 2015, as costs generally decreased at a faster rate than selling prices.
58492_18_ITEM7_P17_S2	In 2016, steel costs once again became volatile.
58492_18_ITEM7_P17_S3	Steel inflation during the first half of 2016 was followed by deflation in the third quarter, and significant inflation late in the year.
58492_18_ITEM7_P17_S4	This steel inflation continued throughout 2017.
58492_18_ITEM7_P17_S5	We implemented price increases to recover most of the higher costs, but with the normal lag in realizing selling price increases, the cost inflation led to margin pressure throughout 2017.
58492_18_ITEM7_P18_S0	As a producer of steel rod, we are also impacted by changes in metal margins (the difference between the cost of steel scrap and the market price for steel rod).
58492_18_ITEM7_P18_S1	Metal margins within the steel industry have been volatile in past years, were moderately compressed in late 2016, and began to increase modestly in the second half of 2017.
58492_18_ITEM7_P19_S0	Our other raw materials include woven and non-woven fabrics, foam scrap, and chemicals.
58492_18_ITEM7_P19_S1	We have experienced changes in the cost of these materials in past years and generally have been able to pass them through to our customers.
58492_18_ITEM7_P20_S0	When we raise our prices to recover higher raw material costs, this sometimes causes customers to modify their product designs and replace higher cost components with lower cost components.
58492_18_ITEM7_P20_S1	We must continue providing product options to our customers that enable them to improve the functionality of their products and manage their costs, while providing higher profits for our operations.
58492_18_ITEM7_P21_S0	Many of our markets are highly competitive, with the number of competitors varying by product line.
58492_18_ITEM7_P21_S1	In general, our competitors tend to be smaller, private companies.
58492_18_ITEM7_P21_S2	Many of our competitors, both domestic and foreign, compete primarily on the basis of price.
58492_18_ITEM7_P21_S3	Our success has stemmed from the ability to remain price competitive, while delivering innovation, better product quality, and customer service.
58492_18_ITEM7_P22_S0	We continue to face pressure from foreign competitors as some of our customers source a portion of their components and finished products offshore.
58492_18_ITEM7_P22_S1	In addition to lower labor rates, foreign competitors benefit (at times) from lower raw material costs.
58492_18_ITEM7_P22_S2	They may also benefit from currency factors and more lenient regulatory climates.
58492_18_ITEM7_P23_S0	We typically remain price competitive in most of our business units, even versus many foreign manufacturers, as a result of our highly efficient operations, low labor content, vertical integration in steel and wire, logistics and distribution efficiencies, and large scale purchasing of raw materials and commodities.
58492_18_ITEM7_P23_S1	However, we have also reacted to foreign competition in certain cases by selectively adjusting prices, and by developing new proprietary products that help our customers reduce total costs.
58492_18_ITEM7_P24_S0	Since 2009, there have been antidumping duty orders on innerspring imports from China, South Africa and Vietnam, ranging from 116% to 234%.
58492_18_ITEM7_P24_S1	In March 2014, the Department of Commerce (DOC) and the International Trade Commission (ITC) determined that the duties should be continued.
58492_18_ITEM7_P24_S2	In April 2014, the DOC published its final order continuing the duties through February 2019 (for China) and December 2018 (for South Africa and Vietnam).
58492_18_ITEM7_P25_S0	An antidumping and countervailing duty case filed in January 2014 by major U.S. steel wire rod producers was concluded in December 2014, resulting in the imposition of duties on imports of Chinese steel wire rod.
58492_18_ITEM7_P26_S0	antidumping duties range from 106% to 110% and the countervailing duties range from 178% to 193%.
58492_18_ITEM7_P26_S1	Both remain in effect through December 2019.
58492_18_ITEM7_P26_S2	Also, in March 2017 certain U.S. steel wire rod producers filed antidumping and countervailing duty petitions on imports of steel wire rod from Belarus, Italy, Korea, Russia, South Africa, Spain, Turkey, Ukraine, United Arab Emirates, and the United Kingdom.
58492_18_ITEM7_P26_S3	The ITC and the DOC have made final affirmative determinations and imposed antidumping duties on imports from Belarus (280%), Russia (437% to 757%), South Africa (135% to 142%), Ukraine (35% to 44%), and United Arab Emirates (84%).
58492_18_ITEM7_P26_S4	Final antidumping and countervailing duty determinations on the remaining countries are expected in March and April 2018.
58492_18_ITEM7_P27_S0	Because of the documented evasion of antidumping orders by certain importers, typically shipping goods through third countries and falsely identifying the countries of origin, Leggett and several other U.S. manufacturers formed a coalition to seek stronger enforcement of existing antidumping and/or countervailing duty orders.
58492_18_ITEM7_P27_S1	As a result of these efforts, the U.S. Congress passed the Enforcing Orders and Reducing Customs Evasion (ENFORCE) Act.
58492_18_ITEM7_P27_S2	The ENFORCE Act requires U.S. Customs and Border Protection to implement a transparent, time-limited process to investigate allegations of duty evasion and to assess duties where appropriate.
58492_18_ITEM7_P28_S0	Our reportable segments are the same as our operating segments, which also correspond with our management organizational structure.
58492_18_ITEM7_P28_S1	In conjunction with a change in executive officers, our management organizational structure and all related internal reporting changed as of January 1, 2017.
58492_18_ITEM7_P28_S2	Effective January 1, 2017, Perry E. Davis became President of the Residential Products and Industrial Products segments, and J. Mitchell Dolloff became President of the Specialized Products and Furniture Products segments.
58492_18_ITEM7_P29_S0	The composition of our four segments also changed effective January 1, 2017.

58492_18_ITEM7_P30_S1	The Industrial Products segment (formerly Industrial Materials) had no changes.

58492_18_ITEM7_P31_S0	Prior to January 1, 2017, all of our segments used the first-in, first-out (FIFO) method for valuing inventory.
58492_18_ITEM7_P31_S1	In our consolidated financials, we converted approximately 50% of these inventories (primarily our domestic, steel-related inventories) to the last-in, first-out (LIFO) method, and reported the related LIFO benefit or expense outside of the segments.
58492_18_ITEM7_P31_S2	Effective January 1, 2017, the LIFO benefit or expense was recognized within the segment to which it relates.
58492_18_ITEM7_P31_S3	This change has been retrospectively applied to all prior periods presented.

58492_18_ITEM7_P41_S0	Our tax rate is determined by a combination of items, some recurring and some discrete.
58492_18_ITEM7_P41_S1	Recurring items include income earned in various tax jurisdictions and differences in tax rates in those jurisdictions.
58492_18_ITEM7_P41_S2	These items tend to be relatively stable from year to year.
58492_18_ITEM7_P41_S3	Conversely, discrete items may not be as consistent from year to year.
58492_18_ITEM7_P42_S0	On December 22, 2017, President Trump signed into law TCJA, enacting significant changes to the U.S. Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended, including a reduction in the maximum U.S. federal corporate income tax rate from 35% to 21%, the transition of U.S. taxation from a worldwide tax system to a territorial system, and the imposition of a one-time tax associated with the mandatory deemed repatriation of untaxed foreign earnings.
58492_18_ITEM7_P42_S1	Although these provisions are generally applicable for years after December 31, 2017, several impacted our 2017 earnings, including the one-time deemed repatriation tax, additional taxes for expected foreign cash repatriations, and the revaluation of our U.S. deferred taxes.
58492_18_ITEM7_P42_S2	As a result, we recorded a net tax expense of $50 million in the fourth quarter of 2017 related to these items, which negatively impacted our full year tax rate by 12%.
58492_18_ITEM7_P42_S3	Of this total amount, $67 million is related to the one-time deemed repatriation tax that will be paid on a graduated scale over the next eight years.
58492_18_ITEM7_P43_S0	The amount recorded is our best estimate and based on our current understanding of TCJA and the guidance currently available, but should be considered provisional.
58492_18_ITEM7_P43_S1	The ultimate impact may differ from the provisional amount and the accounting will be finalized no later than the fourth quarter of 2018.
58492_18_ITEM7_P44_S0	While the U.S. statutory federal income tax rate was 35% in both years, our worldwide effective income tax rate on continuing operations was 32% in 2017, compared to 25% for 2016.
58492_18_ITEM7_P44_S1	As discussed above, our rate was negatively impacted by 12% in 2017 due to the effect of TCJA (16% associated with the deemed repatriation tax and 2% from tax on expected future foreign cash repatriations, partially offset by a 6% benefit from the revaluation of our U.S. net deferred tax liabilities).
58492_18_ITEM7_P44_S2	In both years our tax rate benefited from earnings in non-U.S. jurisdictions, which reduced our effective tax rate by 8% in 2017 and 6% in 2016.
58492_18_ITEM7_P44_S3	In addition, the 2017 tax rate benefited by 2% related to tax attributes from a divested business, 2% related to the tax effects of stock-based compensation deductions in the year, and 3% from other permanent tax differences.
58492_18_ITEM7_P45_S0	The 2016 tax rate benefited by 3% related to the tax effects of stock-based compensation deductions in the year and 1% (net) from other items.
58492_18_ITEM7_P46_S0	We anticipate an effective tax rate for 2018 of approximately 22%, which includes the anticipated tax effects associated with TCJA and certain other expected discrete items, including stock compensation payments.
58492_18_ITEM7_P46_S1	The expected tax impact from stock compensation can fluctuate based on stock price and other factors, and any changes to our 2017 provisional and 2018 expected TCJA amounts could impact our anticipated 2018 tax rate.
58492_18_ITEM7_P46_S2	Our tax rate is also contingent upon other factors such as our overall profitability, the mix of earnings among tax jurisdictions, the type of income earned, business acquisitions and dispositions, the impact of tax audits and other discrete items, and the effect of other tax law changes and prudent tax planning strategies.

58492_18_ITEM7_P69_S0	In the first quarter of 2016 we adopted Accounting Standards Update (ASU) 2016-09, Improvements to Employee Share-Based Payment Accounting .
58492_18_ITEM7_P69_S1	This ASU provides that the tax effects of stock-based awards must be treated as discrete items affecting the tax rate in the interim reporting period in which the tax deductions occur.
58492_18_ITEM7_P69_S2	Many variables (such as timing of award settlements or expirations, changes in stock price over time, ultimate payout levels for awards with performance contingencies, shares cancelled before vesting, and the tax rules in effect at the time of settlement) will impact both the timing and the amount of the tax deductions.
58492_18_ITEM7_P69_S3	Thus, this ASU is likely to add more volatility to the effective tax rate of companies such as Leggett that use stock-based compensation plans.

58492_18_ITEM7_P135_S0	We prepare our consolidated financial statements in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
58492_18_ITEM7_P135_S1	To do so, we must make estimates and judgments that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues, expenses, and disclosures.
58492_18_ITEM7_P135_S2	If we used different estimates or judgments our financial statements would change, and some of those changes could be significant.
58492_18_ITEM7_P135_S3	Our estimates are frequently based upon historical experience and are considered by management, at the time they are made, to be reasonable and appropriate.
58492_18_ITEM7_P136_S0	Estimates are adjusted for actual events, as they occur.
58492_18_ITEM7_P137_S0	Critical accounting estimates are those that are: a) subject to uncertainty and change, and b) of material impact to our financial statements.
58492_18_ITEM7_P137_S1	Listed below are the estimates and judgments which we believe could have the most significant effect on our financial statements.
58492_18_ITEM7_P138_S0	We provide additional details regarding our significant accounting policies in Note A to the Consolidated Financial Statements on page 71 .
58492_18_ITEM7_P139_S0	Goodwill is assessed for impairment annually as of June 30 and as triggering events occur.
58492_18_ITEM7_P140_S0	Goodwill is evaluated annually for impairment as of June 30 using either a quantitative or qualitative analysis at the reporting unit level, which is one level below our operating segments.
58492_18_ITEM7_P140_S1	We begin with a qualitative assessment of whether it is more likely than not that a reporting unit's fair value is less than its carrying value before applying the two step goodwill impairment model.
58492_18_ITEM7_P140_S2	Judgment is required in the two step model to estimate fair value for the reporting unit.
58492_18_ITEM7_P141_S0	We estimate fair value using a combination of a discounted cash flow model and a market approach using price to earnings ratios for comparable publicly traded companies with characteristics similar to the reporting unit.
58492_18_ITEM7_P142_S0	The cash flow model contains uncertainties related to the forecast of future results as many outside economic and competitive factors can influence future performance.
58492_18_ITEM7_P142_S1	Margins, sales growth, and discount rates are the most critical estimates in determining enterprise values using the cash flow model.
58492_18_ITEM7_P143_S0	The market approach requires judgment to determine the appropriate price to earnings ratio.
58492_18_ITEM7_P144_S0	Ratios are derived from comparable publicly-traded companies that operate in the same or similar industry as the reporting unit.
58492_18_ITEM7_P145_S0	The June 2017 review indicated no goodwill impairments.
58492_18_ITEM7_P145_S1	However, we exited a few small businesses in each of the years presented and evaluated goodwill for impairment when they were classified as held for sale.
58492_18_ITEM7_P145_S2	We recognized goodwill impairments of less than $5 million in each of the years presented, associated with the exit of these businesses.
58492_18_ITEM7_P145_S3	Information regarding material assumptions used to determine if a goodwill impairment exists can be found in Note C to the Consolidated Financial Statements on page 79.
58492_18_ITEM7_P146_S0	At December 31, 2017, we had $822 million of goodwill.
58492_18_ITEM7_P147_S0	We conduct impairment testing based on our current business strategy in light of present industry and economic conditions, as well as future expectations.
58492_18_ITEM7_P147_S1	If we are not able to achieve projected performance levels, future impairments could be possible.
58492_18_ITEM7_P148_S0	Other long-lived assets are tested for recoverability at year-end and whenever events or circumstances indicate the carrying value may not be recoverable.
58492_18_ITEM7_P149_S0	For other long-lived assets we estimate fair value at the lowest level where cash flows can be measured (usually at a branch level).
58492_18_ITEM7_P150_S0	Impairments of other long-lived assets usually occur when major restructuring activities take place, or we decide to discontinue product lines completely.
58492_18_ITEM7_P151_S0	Our impairment assessments have uncertainties because they require estimates of future cash flows to determine if undiscounted cash flows are sufficient to recover carrying values of these assets.
58492_18_ITEM7_P152_S0	For assets where future cash flows are not expected to recover carrying value, fair value is estimated which requires an estimate of market value based upon asset appraisals for like assets.
58492_18_ITEM7_P153_S0	Impairments averaged approximately $2 million per year over the last three years.
58492_18_ITEM7_P154_S0	At December 31, 2017, net property, plant and equipment was $664 million and net intangible assets other than goodwill was $169 million.
58492_18_ITEM7_P155_S0	We reduce the carrying value of inventories to reflect an estimate of net realizable value for obsolete and slow-moving inventory.
58492_18_ITEM7_P156_S0	We value inventory at net realizable value (what we think we will recover).
58492_18_ITEM7_P156_S1	Generally a reserve is not required unless we have more than a one-year's supply of the product.
58492_18_ITEM7_P156_S2	If we have had no sales of a given product for 12 months, those items are generally deemed to have no value and are written down completely.
58492_18_ITEM7_P157_S0	Our inventory reserve contains uncertainties because the calculation requires management to make assumptions about the value of products that are obsolete or slow-moving (i.e., not selling very quickly).
58492_18_ITEM7_P158_S0	Changes in customer behavior and requirements can cause inventory to quickly become obsolete or slow-moving.
58492_18_ITEM7_P159_S0	The calculation also uses an estimate of the ultimate recoverability of items identified as slow-moving based upon historical experience (65% on average).
58492_18_ITEM7_P160_S0	At December 31, 2017, the reserve for obsolete and slow-moving inventory was $35 million (approximately 6% of FIFO inventories).
58492_18_ITEM7_P160_S1	This is consistent with the $33 million of reserves at December 31, 2016 and 2015, representing 6% of FIFO inventories.
58492_18_ITEM7_P161_S0	Additions to inventory reserves in 2017 were $5 million, which were lower than 2016 and 2015 amounts of $9 million and $10 million, respectively.
58492_18_ITEM7_P161_S1	We do not expect obsolescence to change from current levels.
58492_18_ITEM7_P162_S0	We are substantially self-insured for costs related to workers compensation, and this requires us to estimate the liability associated with this obligation.
58492_18_ITEM7_P163_S0	Our estimates of self-insured reserves contain uncertainties regarding the potential amounts we might have to pay.
58492_18_ITEM7_P163_S1	We consider a number of factors, including historical claim experience, demographic factors, and potential recoveries from third party insurance carriers.
58492_18_ITEM7_P164_S0	Over the past five years, we have incurred, on average, $8 million annually for costs associated with workers compensation.
58492_18_ITEM7_P164_S1	Average year-to-year variation over the past five years has been approximately $1 million.
58492_18_ITEM7_P164_S2	At December 31, 2017, we had accrued $34 million to cover future self-insurance liabilities.
58492_18_ITEM7_P165_S0	For accounts and notes receivable, we estimate a bad debt reserve for the amount that will ultimately be uncollectible.
58492_18_ITEM7_P166_S0	When we become aware of a specific customer s potential inability to pay, we record a bad debt reserve for the amount we believe may not be collectible.
58492_18_ITEM7_P167_S0	Our bad debt reserve contains uncertainties because it requires management to estimate the amount uncollectible based upon an evaluation of several factors such as the length of time that receivables are past due, the financial health of the customer, industry and macroeconomic considerations, and historical loss experience.
58492_18_ITEM7_P168_S0	Our customers are diverse and many are small-to-medium sized companies, with some being highly leveraged.
58492_18_ITEM7_P168_S1	Bankruptcy can occur with some of these customers relatively quickly and with little warning.
58492_18_ITEM7_P169_S0	In cases where a customer s payment performance or financial condition begins to deteriorate, we tighten our credit limits and terms and make appropriate reserves when deemed necessary.
58492_18_ITEM7_P169_S1	Certain of our customers have from time to time experienced bankruptcy, insolvency and/or an inability to pay their debts to us as they come due.
58492_18_ITEM7_P169_S2	If our customers suffer significant financial difficulty, they may be unable to pay their debts to us timely or at all, they may reject their contractual obligations to us under bankruptcy laws or otherwise, or we may have to negotiate significant discounts and/or extend financing terms with these customers.
58492_18_ITEM7_P170_S0	A significant change in the financial status of a large customer could impact our estimates.
58492_18_ITEM7_P171_S0	We believe we have established adequate reserves on our riskier customer accounts.
58492_18_ITEM7_P171_S1	We have experienced favorable trends in the number of accounts monitored for possible loss or written off in the last few years.
58492_18_ITEM7_P171_S2	The average annual amount of customer-related bad debt expense was less than $2 million (significantly less than 1% of annual net sales) over the last three years.
58492_18_ITEM7_P171_S3	At December 31, 2017, our allowances for doubtful accounts were less than $5 million (about 1% of our trade accounts and notes receivable of $528 million).
58492_18_ITEM7_P172_S0	For our pension plans, we must estimate the cost of benefits to be provided (well into the future) and the current value of those benefit obligations.
58492_18_ITEM7_P173_S0	In 2017, we completed an annuity purchase transaction for pensioners that were currently receiving a small monthly benefit, and in 2015 offered a voluntary one-time lump-sum payment option to selected participants.
58492_18_ITEM7_P173_S1	Please see Note L to our Consolidated Financial Statements on page 99.
58492_18_ITEM7_P174_S0	The pension liability calculation contains uncertainties because it requires management's judgment.
58492_18_ITEM7_P174_S1	Significant assumptions used to measure our pension liabilities and pension expense annually include: - the discount rate used to calculate the present value of future benefits - an estimate of expected return on pension assets based upon the mix of investments held (bonds and equities) - certain employee-related factors, such as turnover, retirement age and mortality.
58492_18_ITEM7_P174_S2	Mortality assumptions represent our best estimate of the duration of future benefit payments at the measurement date.
58492_18_ITEM7_P175_S0	Each 25 basis point decrease in the discount rate increases pension expense by $.5 million and increases the plans benefit obligation by $8 million.
58492_18_ITEM7_P176_S0	A 25 basis point reduction in the expected return on assets would increase pension expense by $.4 million, but have no effect on the plans funded status.
58492_18_ITEM7_P177_S0	Assuming a long-term investment horizon, we do not expect a material change to the return on asset assumption.
58492_18_ITEM7_P178_S0	We evaluate various legal, environmental, and other potential claims against us to determine if an accrual or disclosure of the contingency is appropriate.
58492_18_ITEM7_P179_S0	If it is probable that an ultimate loss will be incurred and reasonably estimable, we accrue a liability for the estimate of the loss.
58492_18_ITEM7_P180_S0	Our disclosure and accrual of loss contingencies (i.e., losses that may or may not occur) contain uncertainties because they are based on our assessment of the probability that the expenses will actually occur, and our reasonable estimate of the likely cost.
58492_18_ITEM7_P180_S1	Our estimates and judgments are subjective and can involve matters in litigation, the results of which are generally unpredictable.
58492_18_ITEM7_P181_S0	Legal contingencies are related to numerous lawsuits and claims described in Note S to the Consolidated Financial Statements on page 115.
58492_18_ITEM7_P182_S0	During the three-year period ended December 31, 2017, we recorded expense of $18 million ($13 million for continuing operations and $5 million in discontinued operations).
58492_18_ITEM7_P183_S0	There were no material uninsured individual claims during the three-year period ending December 31, 2017.
58492_18_ITEM7_P184_S0	In the ordinary course of business, we must make estimates of the tax treatment of many transactions, even though the ultimate tax outcome may remain uncertain for some time.
58492_18_ITEM7_P184_S1	These estimates become part of the annual income tax expense reported in our financial statements.
58492_18_ITEM7_P184_S2	Subsequent to year end, we finalize our tax analysis and file income tax returns.
58492_18_ITEM7_P184_S3	Tax authorities periodically audit these income tax returns and examine our tax filing positions, including (among other things) the timing and amounts of deductions, and the allocation of income among tax jurisdictions.
58492_18_ITEM7_P184_S4	If necessary, we adjust income tax expense in our financial statements in the periods in which the actual outcome becomes more certain.
58492_18_ITEM7_P185_S0	Our tax liability for unrecognized tax benefits contains uncertainties because management is required to make assumptions and to apply judgment to estimate the exposures related to our various filing positions.
58492_18_ITEM7_P186_S0	Our effective tax rate is also impacted by changes in tax laws, the current mix of earnings by taxing jurisdiction, and the results of current tax audits and assessments.
58492_18_ITEM7_P187_S0	On December 22, 2017, the U.S. enacted comprehensive tax legislation commonly referred to as the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (TCJA), which resulted in significant changes to U.S. federal income tax law affecting the Company.
58492_18_ITEM7_P188_S0	Current and expected impacts are based on our current knowledge of the legislation and certain assumptions we have made.
58492_18_ITEM7_P188_S1	Please see Note M-Income Taxes on page 103 for more information.
58492_18_ITEM7_P188_S2	At December 31, 2017 and 2016, we had $12 million and $26 million, respectively, of net deferred tax assets on our balance sheet related to net operating losses and other tax carryforwards.
58492_18_ITEM7_P188_S3	The ultimate realization of these deferred tax assets is dependent upon the amount, source, and timing of future taxable income.
58492_18_ITEM7_P188_S4	In cases where we believe it is more likely than not that we may not realize the future potential tax benefits, we establish a valuation allowance against them.
58492_18_ITEM7_P189_S0	In addition, assumptions have been made regarding the non-repatriation of earnings from certain subsidiaries.
58492_18_ITEM7_P189_S1	Those assumptions may change in the future, thereby affecting future period results for the tax impact of possible repatriation.
58492_18_ITEM7_P190_S0	Changes in tax laws could impact assumptions related to the repatriation of certain foreign earnings.
58492_18_ITEM7_P191_S0	Audits by various taxing authorities continue as governments look for ways to raise additional revenue.
58492_18_ITEM7_P191_S1	Based upon past audit experience, we do not expect any material changes to our tax liability as a result of this audit activity; however, we could incur additional tax expense if we have audit adjustments higher than recent historical experience.
58492_18_ITEM7_P192_S0	The likelihood of recovery of net operating losses and other tax carryforwards has been closely evaluated and is based upon such factors as the time remaining before expiration, viable tax planning strategies, and future taxable earnings expectations.
58492_18_ITEM7_P192_S1	We believe that appropriate valuation allowances have been recorded as necessary.
58492_18_ITEM7_P192_S2	However, if earnings expectations or other assumptions change such that additional valuation allowances are required, we could incur additional tax expense.
58492_18_ITEM7_P192_S3	Likewise, if fewer valuation allowances are needed, we could incur reduced tax expense.

58492_18_ITEM7_P194_S0	A large percentage of the accruals and cash payments in 2015 and 2016 were related to antitrust proceedings.
58492_18_ITEM7_P195_S0	The above litigation contingency accruals do not include accrued expenses related to workers' compensation, vehicle-related personal injury, product and general liability claims, taxation issues and environmental matters, some of which may contain a portion of litigation expense.
58492_18_ITEM7_P195_S1	However, any litigation expense associated with these categories is not anticipated to have a material effect on our financial condition, results of operations, or cash flows.
58492_18_ITEM7_P195_S2	For more information regarding accrued expenses, see Note H - Supplemental Balance Sheet Information to the Consolidated Financial Statements under "Accrued expenses" on page 90 .
58492_18_ITEM7_P196_S0	We have relied on several facts and circumstances to conclude that some loss is probable with respect to certain proceedings and matters, and to arrive at a reasonable estimate of loss or range of loss and record the accruals, including: the maturation of the pending proceedings and matters; our experience in settlement negotiations and mediation; comparative settlements of other companies in similar proceedings; discovery becoming or being substantially complete in certain proceedings; certain quantitative metrics used to value probable loss contingencies; and our willingness to settle certain proceedings to forgo the cost and risk of litigation and distraction to our senior executives.
58492_18_ITEM7_P196_S1	Although there are a number of uncertainties and potential outcomes associated with all of our pending or threatened litigation proceedings, we believe, based on current known facts, that additional losses, if any, are not expected to materially affect our consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash flows.
58492_18_ITEM7_P196_S2	However, based upon current known facts, as of December 31, 2017, aggregate reasonably possible (but not probable, and therefore not accrued) losses in excess of the accruals noted above are estimated to be approximately $22 million, including approximately $21 million for Brazilian VAT matters and $1 million for other matters.
58492_18_ITEM7_P196_S3	If our assumptions or analyses regarding these contingencies are incorrect, or if facts change, we could realize loss in excess of the recorded accruals, and even greater than our estimate of reasonably possible losses in excess of recorded accruals.
58492_18_ITEM7_P196_S4	For more information regarding litigation contingencies, please refer to Note S on page 115 of the Consolidated Financial Statements, which are incorporated herein by reference.

58492_18_ITEM9A_P0_S1	Based upon this evaluation, the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer have concluded the Company s disclosure controls and procedures were effective, as of December 31, 2017, to provide assurance that information required to be disclosed by the Company in the reports that it files or submits under the Exchange Act is recorded, processed, summarized, and reported, within the time periods specified by the Securities and Exchange Commission s rules and forms.
58492_18_ITEM9A_P0_S2	Disclosure controls and procedures, include without limitation, controls and procedures designed to ensure that information required to be disclosed by the Company in the reports that it files or submits under the Exchange Act is accumulated and communicated to the Company s management, including its Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, or persons performing similar functions, as appropriate to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure.

58492_18_ITEM10_P0_S0	The subsections entitled Proposal 1 Election of Directors, Board Committee Composition and Meetings, Consideration of Director Nominees and Diversity, Section 16(a) Beneficial Ownership Reporting Compliance and Director Independence as well as the introductory paragraph under the "Corporate Governance Board Matters" section in the Company s definitive Proxy Statement for the Company s Annual Meeting of Shareholders to be held on May 15, 2018, are incorporated by reference.
58492_18_ITEM10_P1_S0	Directors are normally elected annually at the Annual Meeting of Shareholders and hold office until the next annual meeting of shareholders or until their successors are elected and qualified.
58492_18_ITEM10_P1_S1	All current directors have been nominated for re-election at the Company s Annual Meeting of Shareholders to be held May 15, 2018.
58492_18_ITEM10_P1_S2	In order to be nominated for election as a director, a nominee must submit a contingent resignation to the Nominating Corporate Governance Committee (N CG Committee).
58492_18_ITEM10_P1_S3	The resignation will become effective only if (i) the director nominee fails to receive an affirmative majority of the votes cast in the director election; and (ii) the Board accepts the resignation.
58492_18_ITEM10_P1_S4	If a nominee fails to receive an affirmative majority of the votes cast in the director election, the N CG Committee will make a recommendation to the Board of Directors whether to accept or reject the director s resignation and whether any other action should be taken.
58492_18_ITEM10_P1_S5	If a director s resignation is not accepted, that director will continue to serve until the Company s next annual meeting or until his or her successor is duly elected and qualified.
58492_18_ITEM10_P1_S6	If the Board accepts the director s resignation, it may, in its sole discretion, either fill the resulting vacancy or decrease the size of the Board to eliminate the vacancy.

58492_18_ITEM15_P16_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (i) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (ii) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (iii) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
58492_18_ITEM15_P17_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
58492_18_ITEM15_P17_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.

58492_18_ITEM15_P26_S0	ESTIMATES: The preparation of financial statements in conformity with generally accepted accounting principles in the United States of America ("GAAP") requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses and the accrual and disclosure of loss contingencies.
58492_18_ITEM15_P27_S0	CASH EQUIVALENTS: Cash equivalents include cash in excess of daily requirements which is invested in various financial instruments with original maturities of three months or less.
58492_18_ITEM15_P28_S0	TRADE AND OTHER RECEIVABLES AND ALLOWANCE FOR DOUBTFUL ACCOUNTS: Trade receivables are recorded at the invoiced amount and generally do not bear interest.
58492_18_ITEM15_P28_S1	Credit is also occasionally extended in the form of a note receivable to facilitate our customers operating cycles.
58492_18_ITEM15_P28_S2	Other notes receivable are established in special circumstances, such as in partial payment for the sale of a business or to support other business opportunities.
58492_18_ITEM15_P28_S3	Other notes receivable generally bear interest at market rates commensurate with the corresponding credit risk on the date of origination.
58492_18_ITEM15_P29_S0	The allowance for doubtful accounts is an estimate of the amount of probable credit losses.
58492_18_ITEM15_P30_S0	Interest income is not recognized for nonperforming accounts that are placed on nonaccrual status.
58492_18_ITEM15_P31_S0	Allowances and nonaccrual status designations are determined by individual account reviews by management, and are based on several factors such as the length of time that receivables are past due, the financial health of the companies involved, industry and macroeconomic considerations, and historical loss experience.
58492_18_ITEM15_P32_S0	Interest income is recorded on the date of cash receipt for nonaccrual status accounts.
58492_18_ITEM15_P32_S1	Account balances are charged against the allowance when it is probable the receivable will not be recovered.
58492_18_ITEM15_P33_S0	All inventories are stated at the lower of cost or net realizable value.
58492_18_ITEM15_P33_S1	We generally use standard costs which include materials, labor and production overhead at normal production capacity.
58492_18_ITEM15_P33_S2	The cost for approximately 50% of our inventories is determined by the last-in, first-out (LIFO) method and is primarily used to value domestic inventories with raw material content consisting of steel, wire, chemicals and foam scrap.
58492_18_ITEM15_P33_S3	For the remainder of the inventories, we principally use the first-in, first-out (FIFO) method, which is representative of our standard costs.
58492_18_ITEM15_P33_S4	For these inventories, the FIFO cost for the periods presented approximated expected replacement cost.
58492_18_ITEM15_P34_S0	Inventories are reviewed at least quarterly for slow-moving and potentially obsolete items using actual inventory turnover, and if necessary, are written down to estimated net realizable value.
58492_18_ITEM15_P34_S1	We have had no material changes in inventory writedowns or slow-moving and obsolete inventory reserves in any of the years presented.

58492_18_ITEM15_P36_S0	Significant accounting policies associated with a decision to dispose of a business are discussed below:
58492_18_ITEM15_P37_S0	A business is classified as discontinued operations if the disposal represents a strategic shift that will have a major effect on operations or financial results, meets the criteria to be classified as held for sale, or is disposed of by sale or otherwise.
58492_18_ITEM15_P37_S1	Significant judgments are involved in determining whether a business meets the criteria for discontinued operations reporting and the period in which these criteria are met.
58492_18_ITEM15_P38_S0	If a business is reported as a discontinued operation, the results of operations through the date of sale, including any gain or loss recognized on the disposition, are presented on a separate line of the income statement.
58492_18_ITEM15_P38_S1	Interest on debt directly attributable to the discontinued operation is allocated to discontinued operations.
58492_18_ITEM15_P38_S2	Gains and losses related to the sale of businesses that do not meet the discontinued operation criteria are reported in continuing operations and separately disclosed if significant.
58492_18_ITEM15_P39_S0	Assets Held for Sale An asset or business is classified as held for sale when (i) management commits to a plan to sell and it is actively marketed; (ii) it is available for immediate sale and the sale is expected to be completed within one year; and (iii) it is unlikely significant changes to the plan will be made or that the plan will be withdrawn.
58492_18_ITEM15_P39_S1	In isolated instances, assets held for sale may exceed one year due to events or circumstances beyond our control.
58492_18_ITEM15_P40_S0	Upon being classified as held for sale, the recoverability of the carrying value must be assessed.
58492_18_ITEM15_P40_S1	Evaluating the recoverability of the assets of a business classified as held for sale follows a defined order in which property and intangible assets subject to amortization are considered only after the recoverability of goodwill and other assets are assessed.
58492_18_ITEM15_P40_S2	After the valuation process is completed, the assets held for sale are reported at the lower of the carrying value or fair value less cost to sell, and the assets are no longer depreciated or amortized.
58492_18_ITEM15_P40_S3	An impairment charge is recognized if the carrying value exceeds the fair value less cost to sell.
58492_18_ITEM15_P41_S0	The assets and related liabilities are aggregated and reported on separate lines of the balance sheet.
58492_18_ITEM15_P42_S0	If a decision to dispose of an asset or a business is made and the held-for-sale criteria are not met, it is considered held for use.
58492_18_ITEM15_P43_S0	Assets of the business are evaluated for recoverability in the following order: (i) assets other than goodwill, property and intangibles; (ii) property and intangibles subject to amortization; and (iii) goodwill.
58492_18_ITEM15_P44_S0	In evaluating the recoverability of property and intangible assets subject to amortization, the carrying value is first compared to the sum of the undiscounted cash flows expected to result from the use and eventual disposition.
58492_18_ITEM15_P44_S1	If the carrying value exceeds the undiscounted expected cash flows, then a fair value analysis is performed.
58492_18_ITEM15_P44_S2	An impairment charge is recognized if the carrying value exceeds the fair value.
58492_18_ITEM15_P45_S0	Loss contingencies are accrued when a loss is probable and reasonably estimable.
58492_18_ITEM15_P45_S1	If a range of outcomes are possible, the most likely outcome is used to accrue these costs.
58492_18_ITEM15_P45_S2	If no outcome is more likely, we accrue at the minimum amount of the range.
58492_18_ITEM15_P46_S0	Any insurance recovery is recorded separately if it is determined that a recovery is probable.
58492_18_ITEM15_P46_S1	Legal fees are accrued when incurred.
58492_18_ITEM15_P47_S0	PROPERTY, PLANT AND EQUIPMENT: Property, plant and equipment is stated at cost, less accumulated depreciation.
58492_18_ITEM15_P47_S1	Assets are depreciated by the straight-line method and salvage value, if any, is assumed to be minimal.
58492_18_ITEM15_P48_S0	The table below presents the depreciation periods of the estimated useful lives of our property, plant and equipment.
58492_18_ITEM15_P49_S0	Accelerated methods are used for tax purposes.
58492_18_ITEM15_P50_S0	Property is reviewed for recoverability at year end and whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that its carrying value may not be recoverable as discussed above.
58492_18_ITEM15_P51_S0	Goodwill results from the acquisition of existing businesses and is not amortized; it is assessed for impairment annually and as triggering events may occur.
58492_18_ITEM15_P51_S1	We perform our annual review in the second quarter of each year.
58492_18_ITEM15_P51_S2	Our nine reporting units are the business groups one level below the operating segment level for which discrete financial information is available.
58492_18_ITEM15_P52_S0	The Company has the option to first assess qualitative factors to determine whether events and circumstances indicate that it is more likely than not that goodwill is impaired.
58492_18_ITEM15_P53_S0	conclude that the goodwill of a reporting unit is not impaired, then no further action is required (commonly referred to as the Step Zero Analysis approach).
58492_18_ITEM15_P54_S0	For those reporting units where a significant change or event occurs, and where potential impairment indicators exist (based on the Step Zero Analysis approach), recoverability of goodwill is then evaluated using a two-step process.
58492_18_ITEM15_P55_S0	The first step involves a comparison of the fair value of a reporting unit with its carrying value.
58492_18_ITEM15_P56_S0	If the carrying value of the reporting unit exceeds its fair value, the second step of the process is necessary and involves a comparison of the implied fair value and the carrying value of the goodwill of that reporting unit.
58492_18_ITEM15_P56_S1	If the carrying value of the goodwill of a reporting unit exceeds the implied fair value of that goodwill, an impairment loss is recognized in an amount equal to the excess.
58492_18_ITEM15_P57_S0	Fair value of reporting units is determined using a combination of two valuation methods: a market approach and an income approach.
58492_18_ITEM15_P57_S1	Each method is generally given equal weight in determining the fair value assigned to each reporting unit.
58492_18_ITEM15_P57_S2	Absent an indication of fair value from a potential buyer or similar specific transaction, we believe that the use of these two methods provides a reasonable estimate of a reporting unit s fair value.
58492_18_ITEM15_P57_S3	Assumptions common to both methods are operating plans and economic projections, which are used to project future revenues, earnings, and after-tax cash flows for each reporting unit.
58492_18_ITEM15_P57_S4	These assumptions are applied consistently for both methods.
58492_18_ITEM15_P58_S0	The market approach estimates fair value by first determining price-to-earnings ratios for comparable publicly-traded companies with similar characteristics of the reporting unit.
58492_18_ITEM15_P58_S1	The price-to-earnings ratio for comparable companies is based upon current enterprise value compared to the historical earnings for the past two years.
58492_18_ITEM15_P58_S2	The enterprise value is based upon current market capitalization and includes a control premium.
58492_18_ITEM15_P58_S3	Projected earnings are based upon market analysts projections.
58492_18_ITEM15_P58_S4	The earnings ratios are applied to the projected earnings of the comparable reporting unit to estimate fair value.
58492_18_ITEM15_P58_S5	Management believes this approach is appropriate because it provides a fair value estimate using multiples from entities with operations and economic characteristics comparable to our reporting units.
58492_18_ITEM15_P59_S0	The income approach is based on projected future (debt-free) cash flow that is discounted to present value using factors that consider the timing and risk of future cash flows.
58492_18_ITEM15_P59_S1	Management believes that this approach is appropriate because it provides a fair value estimate based upon the reporting unit s expected long-term operating cash flow performance.
58492_18_ITEM15_P60_S0	Discounted cash flow projections are based on 10-year financial forecasts developed from operating plans and economic projections noted above, sales growth, estimates of future expected changes in operating margins, terminal value growth rates, future capital expenditures and changes in working capital requirements.
58492_18_ITEM15_P61_S0	There are inherent assumptions and judgments required in the analysis of goodwill impairment.
58492_18_ITEM15_P61_S1	It is possible that assumptions underlying the impairment analysis will change in such a manner that impairment in value may occur in the future.
58492_18_ITEM15_P62_S0	Substantially all other intangible assets are amortized using the straight-line method over their estimated useful lives and are evaluated for impairment using a process similar to that used in evaluating the recoverability of property, plant and equipment.
58492_18_ITEM15_P63_S0	The cost of employee services received in exchange for all equity awards granted is based on the fair market value of the award as of the grant date.
58492_18_ITEM15_P63_S1	Expense is recognized net of an estimated forfeiture rate using the straight-line method over the vesting period of the award.
58492_18_ITEM15_P64_S0	We recognize sales when title and risk of loss pass to the customer.
58492_18_ITEM15_P64_S1	The terms of our sales are split approximately evenly between FOB shipping point and FOB destination.
58492_18_ITEM15_P64_S2	The timing of our recognition of FOB destination sales is determined based on shipping date and distance to the destination.
58492_18_ITEM15_P64_S3	We have no significant or unusual price protection, right of return or acceptance provisions with our customers.
58492_18_ITEM15_P65_S0	Sales allowances, discounts and rebates can be reasonably estimated throughout the period and are deducted from sales in arriving at net sales.
58492_18_ITEM15_P66_S0	SHIPPING AND HANDLING FEES AND COSTS: Shipping and handling costs are included as a component of Cost of goods sold.
58492_18_ITEM15_P67_S0	RESTRUCTURING COSTS: Restructuring costs are items such as employee termination, contract termination, plant closure and asset relocation costs related to exit activities or workforce reductions.
58492_18_ITEM15_P67_S1	Restructuring-related items are inventory writedowns and gains or losses from sales of assets recorded as the result of exit activities.
58492_18_ITEM15_P68_S0	associated with an exit or disposal activity when the liability is incurred.
58492_18_ITEM15_P69_S0	Certain termination benefits for which employees are required to render service are recognized ratably over the respective future service periods.
58492_18_ITEM15_P70_S0	The provision for income taxes is determined using the asset and liability approach of accounting for income taxes.
58492_18_ITEM15_P70_S1	Under this approach, deferred taxes represent the future tax consequences expected to occur when the reported amounts of assets and liabilities are recovered or paid.
58492_18_ITEM15_P71_S0	The provision for income taxes represents income taxes paid or payable for the current year plus the change in deferred taxes during the year.
58492_18_ITEM15_P71_S1	Deferred taxes result from differences between the financial and tax basis of our assets and liabilities and are adjusted for changes in tax rates and laws, as appropriate.
58492_18_ITEM15_P71_S2	A valuation allowance is provided to reduce deferred tax assets when management cannot conclude that it is more likely than not that a tax benefit will be realized.
58492_18_ITEM15_P72_S0	A provision is also made for incremental taxes on undistributed earnings of foreign subsidiaries and related companies to the extent that such earnings are not deemed to be indefinitely invested.
58492_18_ITEM15_P73_S0	The calculation of our U.S., state, and foreign tax liabilities involves dealing with uncertainties in the application of complex global tax laws.
58492_18_ITEM15_P73_S1	We recognize potential liabilities for anticipated tax issues which might arise in the U.S. and other tax jurisdictions based on management s estimate of whether, and the extent to which, additional taxes will be due.
58492_18_ITEM15_P73_S2	If payment of these amounts ultimately proves to be unnecessary, the reversal of the liabilities would result in tax benefits being recognized in the period when we determine the liabilities are no longer necessary.
58492_18_ITEM15_P73_S3	Conversely, if the estimate of tax liabilities proves to be less than the ultimate tax assessment, a further charge to tax expense would result.
58492_18_ITEM15_P74_S0	CONCENTRATION OF CREDIT RISKS, EXPOSURES AND FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS: We manufacture, market, and distribute products for the various end markets described in Note E .
58492_18_ITEM15_P74_S1	Our operations are principally located in the United States, although we also have operations in Europe, China, Canada, Mexico and other various countries.
58492_18_ITEM15_P75_S0	We maintain allowances for potential credit losses.
58492_18_ITEM15_P75_S1	We perform ongoing credit evaluations of our customers financial conditions and generally require no collateral from our customers, some of which are highly leveraged.
58492_18_ITEM15_P75_S2	Management also monitors the financial condition and status of other notes receivable.
58492_18_ITEM15_P76_S0	Other notes receivable have historically primarily consisted of notes accepted as partial payment for the divestiture of a business or to support other business opportunities.
58492_18_ITEM15_P76_S1	Some of these companies are highly leveraged and the notes are not fully collateralized.
58492_18_ITEM15_P77_S0	We have no material guarantees or liabilities for product warranties which require disclosure.
58492_18_ITEM15_P78_S0	From time to time, we will enter into contracts to hedge foreign currency denominated transactions, and interest rates related to our debt.
58492_18_ITEM15_P79_S0	To minimize the risk of counterparty default, only highly-rated financial institutions that meet certain requirements are used.
58492_18_ITEM15_P79_S1	We do not anticipate that any of the financial institution counterparties will default on their obligations.
58492_18_ITEM15_P80_S0	The carrying value of cash and short-term financial instruments approximates fair value due to the short maturity of those instruments.
58492_18_ITEM15_P81_S0	Although we obtain insurance for workers compensation, automobile, product and general liability, property loss and medical claims, we have elected to retain a significant portion of expected losses through the use of deductibles.
58492_18_ITEM15_P81_S1	Accrued liabilities include estimates for unpaid reported claims and for claims incurred but not yet reported.
58492_18_ITEM15_P81_S2	Provisions for losses are recorded based upon reasonable estimates of the aggregate liability for claims incurred utilizing our prior experience and information provided by our third-party administrators and insurance carriers.
58492_18_ITEM15_P82_S0	DERIVATIVE FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS: We utilize derivative financial instruments to manage market and financial risks related to foreign currency and interest rates.
58492_18_ITEM15_P82_S1	We seek to use derivative contracts that qualify for hedge accounting treatment; however some instruments that economically manage currency risk may not qualify for hedge accounting treatment.
58492_18_ITEM15_P82_S2	It is our policy not to speculate using derivative instruments.
58492_18_ITEM15_P83_S0	Under hedge accounting, we formally document our hedge relationships, including identification of the hedging instruments and the hedged items, as well as our risk management objectives and strategies for entering into the hedge transaction.
58492_18_ITEM15_P83_S1	The process includes designating derivative instruments as hedges of specific assets, liabilities, firm commitments or forecasted transactions.
58492_18_ITEM15_P83_S2	We also formally assess both at inception and on a quarterly basis thereafter, whether the derivatives used in hedging transactions are highly effective in offsetting changes in either the fair value or cash flows of the hedged item.
58492_18_ITEM15_P83_S3	If it is determined that a derivative ceases to be highly effective, deferred gains or losses are recorded in the Consolidated Statements of Operations.
58492_18_ITEM15_P84_S0	On the date the contract is entered into, we designate the derivative as one of the following types of hedging instruments and account for it as follows:
58492_18_ITEM15_P85_S0	The hedge of a forecasted transaction or of the variability of cash flows to be received or paid related to a recognized asset or liability or anticipated transaction is designated as a cash flow hedge.
58492_18_ITEM15_P86_S0	The effective portion of the change in fair value is recorded in accumulated other comprehensive income.
58492_18_ITEM15_P86_S1	When the hedged item impacts the income statement, the gain or loss included in other comprehensive income is reported on the same line of the Consolidated Statements of Operations as the hedged item to match the gain or loss on the derivative to the gain or loss on the hedged item.
58492_18_ITEM15_P86_S2	Any ineffective portion of the changes in the fair value is immediately reported in the Consolidated Statements of Operations on the same line as the hedged item.
58492_18_ITEM15_P87_S0	Settlements associated with the sale or production of product are presented in operating cash flows and settlements associated with debt issuance are presented in financing cash flows.
58492_18_ITEM15_P88_S0	The hedge of a recognized asset or liability or an unrecognized firm commitment is designated as a fair value hedge.
58492_18_ITEM15_P88_S1	For fair value hedges, both the effective and ineffective portions of the changes in fair value of the derivative, along with the gain or loss on the hedged item that is attributable to the hedged risk, are recorded in earnings and reported in the Consolidated Statements of Operations on the same line as the hedged item.
58492_18_ITEM15_P89_S0	Cash flows from settled contracts are presented in the category consistent with the nature of the item being hedged.
58492_18_ITEM15_P90_S0	The functional currency for most foreign operations is the local currency.
58492_18_ITEM15_P90_S1	The translation of foreign currencies into U.S. dollars is performed for balance sheet accounts using current exchange rates in effect at the balance sheet date and for income and expense accounts using monthly average exchange rates.
58492_18_ITEM15_P90_S2	The cumulative effects of translating the functional currencies into the U.S. dollar are included in comprehensive income.

58492_18_ITEM15_P92_S0	The Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) regularly issues updates to the FASB Accounting Standards Codification that are communicated through issuance of an Accounting Standards Update (ASU).
58492_18_ITEM15_P92_S1	Below is a summary of the ASUs, effective for current or future periods, most relevant to our financial statements:
58492_18_ITEM15_P93_S0	ASU 2016-16 "Accounting for Income Taxes (Topic 740): Intra-Entity Asset Transfers of Assets Other than Inventory": Eliminates deferral of the tax effects of all intra-entity asset sales other than inventory, resulting in tax expense being recorded on the sale of the asset in the seller's tax jurisdiction when the sale occurs, even though the pretax effects of the transaction are eliminated in consolidation.
58492_18_ITEM15_P93_S1	Any deferred tax asset arising in the buyer's jurisdiction is also recognized at the time of sale.
58492_18_ITEM15_P93_S2	We adopted this guidance in the first quarter of 2017.
58492_18_ITEM15_P93_S3	The modified retrospective approach was required, and as a result, we recorded a $1.1 increase to beginning retained earnings on January 1, 2017.
58492_18_ITEM15_P93_S4	Adoption of this new guidance did not materially impact our 2017 Consolidated Statements of Operations.
58492_18_ITEM15_P94_S0	To be adopted in future years:
58492_18_ITEM15_P95_S0	ASU 2014-09 Revenue from Contracts with Customers (Topic 606): Supersedes most of the existing authoritative literature for revenue recognition and prescribes a five-step model for recognizing revenue from contracts with customers.
58492_18_ITEM15_P95_S1	This standard was issued in 2015 and was subsequently amended several times in 2016.
58492_18_ITEM15_P95_S2	We will adopt the standard effective January 1, 2018.
58492_18_ITEM15_P96_S0	We do not expect the adoption of this standard to materially impact our future statements of operations, total assets, or cash flows.
58492_18_ITEM15_P96_S1	We will transition to the new standard using the modified retrospective method.
58492_18_ITEM15_P97_S0	Under the modified retrospective method, there will be an adjustment to our January 1, 2018, equity for the cumulative effect of existing contracts.
58492_18_ITEM15_P97_S1	2017 and earlier years will be presented under legacy GAAP.
58492_18_ITEM15_P97_S2	2018 will be presented under the new standard for existing and new contracts.
58492_18_ITEM15_P97_S3	The footnotes will disclose existing and new contracts under both the new standard and legacy GAAP.
58492_18_ITEM15_P98_S0	We disclosed in our September 30, 2017 Form 10-Q that we identified certain contracts containing provisions that will require the recognition of revenue over time.
58492_18_ITEM15_P98_S1	These contracts were for the production of a highly customized good with no alternative use where we had a contractual right to payment (including a normal profit) for goods in a finished goods status in the event of contract termination.
58492_18_ITEM15_P98_S2	In finalizing our interpretation of Topic 606 and a deeper analysis of the termination provisions of these contracts, we have concluded that most of our contracts will not meet the criteria to recognize revenue over time.
58492_18_ITEM15_P99_S0	At the work-in-process stage, our contract provisions only provide for a reimbursement of costs.
58492_18_ITEM15_P99_S1	Based on these conclusions, we would lack the contractual right to a payment that includes a normal profit throughout the duration of the contract.
58492_18_ITEM15_P99_S2	Thus, Topic 606 would require revenue to be recognized at the point where the customer obtains control of the goods in most of our contractual arrangements.
58492_18_ITEM15_P100_S0	We have concluded that our customer obtains control of a good when it has the ability to direct the use of the good, obtain substantially all the remaining benefits of that good, or obtain the right to deploy or restrict another entity from deploying the good.
58492_18_ITEM15_P100_S1	We believe this control transfer will occur upon shipment from our facility or upon delivery to our customer s facility and will depend on the terms of the contract.
58492_18_ITEM15_P100_S2	We do not believe our control transfer conclusion will have a material impact on our income statement when compared to legacy GAAP.
58492_18_ITEM15_P101_S0	During the fourth quarter, we concluded our tooling arrangements with our customers are not part of ongoing major or central operations and therefore, do not transfer a good or service to our customers.
58492_18_ITEM15_P101_S1	In these tooling arrangements, we enter into a contract to produce or obtain tooling to be used in production of that customer s goods, and that customer agrees to reimburse us for the costs of that tooling.
58492_18_ITEM15_P102_S0	We believe that our tooling arrangements are activities to fulfill our performance obligations to our customers.
58492_18_ITEM15_P103_S0	Under prior accounting standards for the recognition of revenue, we recorded an immaterial amount of revenue related to these reimbursements.
58492_18_ITEM15_P103_S1	Upon adoption of Topic 606, we will account for these tooling costs and reimbursements on a net basis and recognize no revenue related to tooling reimbursements.
58492_18_ITEM15_P103_S2	This change will not materially impact our revenues, cost of sales, net earnings, or our total assets.
58492_18_ITEM15_P104_S0	ASU 2016-02 Leases (Topic 842): Requires that a lessee recognize a right-of-use asset and a lease liability on the balance sheet for most lease arrangements.
58492_18_ITEM15_P104_S1	This ASU will be effective January 1, 2019.
58492_18_ITEM15_P104_S2	We have assembled a cross-functional implementation team and are assessing all potential impacts of the standard.
58492_18_ITEM15_P104_S3	We believe our assets and liabilities will increase for the adoption of this ASU through the recording of these right-of-use assets and corresponding lease liabilities.
58492_18_ITEM15_P104_S4	We continue to evaluate its impact on our statements of operations and cash flows.
58492_18_ITEM15_P105_S0	ASU 2017-12 Derivatives and Hedging (Topic 815): Targeted Improvements to Accounting for Hedging Activities : This ASU is intended to simplify and clarify the accounting and disclosure requirements for hedging activities by more closely aligning the results of cash flow and fair value hedge accounting with the risk management activities of an entity.
58492_18_ITEM15_P105_S1	The amendments in this ASU are effective for annual periods, and interim periods within those annual periods, beginning after December 15, 2018, with early adoption permitted.
58492_18_ITEM15_P106_S0	We are currently evaluating the effect of the ASU on our results of operations, financial condition or cash flows.
58492_18_ITEM15_P107_S0	ASU 2017-04, "Intangibles - Goodwill and Other (Topic 350): Simplifying the Test for Goodwill Impairment": This ASU simplifies the subsequent measurement of goodwill by eliminating Step 2 from the goodwill impairment test.
58492_18_ITEM15_P107_S1	Under this ASU, the annual goodwill impairment test is performed by comparing the fair value of a reporting unit with its carrying amount.
58492_18_ITEM15_P107_S2	An impairment charge would be recognized for the amount by which the carrying amount exceeds the reporting unit's fair value up to the total amount of goodwill for the reporting unit.
58492_18_ITEM15_P107_S3	This ASU will be effective January 1, 2020, with early adoption permitted.
58492_18_ITEM15_P107_S4	We are currently evaluating this guidance, and do not expect it to materially impact our future financial statements.
58492_18_ITEM15_P108_S0	ASU 2018-02, Income Statement - Reporting Comprehensive Income (Topic 220): Reclassification of Certain Tax Effects from Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income : This ASU provides financial statement preparers with an option to reclassify stranded tax effects within accumulated other comprehensive income in each period in which the effect of the change in the U.S. federal corporate income tax rate in the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (TCJA) is recorded.
58492_18_ITEM15_P108_S1	The ASU will be effective for us January 1, 2019.
58492_18_ITEM15_P108_S2	Early adoption is permitted and the amendments should be applied in either the period of adoption or retrospectively to each period in which the effect of the change in federal corporate income tax rate in the TCJA is recognized.
58492_18_ITEM15_P108_S3	We are currently evaluating this guidance.

58492_18_ITEM15_P125_S1	We concluded that it was more likely than not that the fair value of all reporting units, except for two, exceeded their carrying values.

58492_18_ITEM15_P194_S0	We offer a Deferred Compensation Program under which key managers and outside directors may elect to receive stock options, stock units or interest-bearing cash deferrals in lieu of cash compensation:
58492_18_ITEM15_P195_S0	Stock options under this program are granted in the last month of the year prior to the year the compensation is earned.
58492_18_ITEM15_P195_S1	The number of options granted equals the deferred compensation times five , divided by the stock s market price on the date of grant.
58492_18_ITEM15_P195_S2	The option has a 10 -year term.
58492_18_ITEM15_P195_S3	It vests as the associated compensation is earned and becomes exercisable beginning 15 months after the grant date.

58492_18_ITEM15_P207_S0	We have two stock-based retirement plans: the tax-qualified Stock Bonus Plan (SBP) for non-highly compensated employees, and the non-qualified Executive Stock Unit Program (ESUP) for highly compensated employees.
58492_18_ITEM15_P207_S1	We make matching contributions to both plans.
58492_18_ITEM15_P207_S2	In addition to the automatic 50% match, we will make another matching contribution of up to 50% of the employee s contributions for the year if certain profitability levels, as defined in the SBP and the ESUP, are obtained.

58492_18_ITEM15_P209_S0	Dividends earned on Company stock held in the SBP are reinvested or paid in cash at the participant s election.
58492_18_ITEM15_P210_S0	Participants in the ESUP may contribute up to 10% (depending upon salary level) of their compensation above the same threshold applicable to the SBP.
58492_18_ITEM15_P210_S1	Participant contributions are credited to a diversified investment account established for the participant, and we make premium contributions to the diversified investment accounts equal to 17.65% of the participant s contribution.
58492_18_ITEM15_P210_S2	A participant s diversified investment account balance is adjusted to mirror the investment experience, whether positive or negative, of the diversified investments selected by the participant.
58492_18_ITEM15_P210_S3	Participants may change investment elections in the diversified investment accounts, but cannot purchase Company common stock or stock units.
58492_18_ITEM15_P210_S4	The diversified investment accounts consist of various mutual funds and retirement target funds and are unfunded, unsecured obligations of the Company that will be settled in cash.

58492_18_ITEM15_P242_S0	We use the average of the Citigroup Pension Discount Curve rate and Merrill Lynch AA-AAA 10 -year Bond Index rate to determine the discount rate used for our significant pension plans (rounded to the nearest 25 basis points).
58492_18_ITEM15_P243_S0	The Citigroup Pension Discount Curve rate is a calculated rate using yearly spot rates matched against expected future benefit payments.
58492_18_ITEM15_P243_S1	The Merrill Lynch Index rate is based on the weighted average yield of a portfolio of high grade Corporate Bonds with an average duration approximating the plans projected benefit payments, adjusted for any callable bonds included in the portfolio.
58492_18_ITEM15_P244_S0	The discount rates used for our other, primarily foreign, plans are based on rates appropriate for the respective country and the plan obligations.

58492_18_ITEM15_P253_S0	Our investment policy and strategies are established with a long-term view in mind.
58492_18_ITEM15_P253_S1	We strive for a sufficiently diversified asset mix to minimize the risk of a material loss to the portfolio value due to the devaluation of any single investment.
58492_18_ITEM15_P253_S2	In determining the appropriate asset mix, our financial strength and ability to fund potential shortfalls that might result from poor investment performance are considered.
58492_18_ITEM15_P253_S3	Approximately 50% of our significant plans (the "frozen plans") are employing a Liability Driven Investment strategy and have a target allocation of 60% fixed income and 40% equities.
58492_18_ITEM15_P253_S4	The remaining significant plans (the "active" plans) have a target allocation of 75% equities and 25% fixed income, as historical equity returns have tended to exceed bond returns over the long term.

58492_18_ITEM15_P261_S0	Extended Duration Treasury Index: Diversified exposure to U.S. treasuries with maturities of 20 - 30 years.
58492_18_ITEM15_P262_S0	The Stable value fund consists of a fixed income portfolio offering consistent return and protection against interest rate volatility.
